description:
Love this little restaurant. 

Came here for lunch for a whole week about 2 years ago before I left my internship nearby. It was a cozy place with very simply yet deliciously prepared fresh seafood. 

Came back on a Friday evening recently and waited almost 2 hours to get seated. Still amazing combination salad, still oysters that taste like the ocean, and still comforting chowder. I particularly liked the thick gigantic steamboat oysters. 

I think the closest thing (as to how the seafood is prepared) is Swan Depot but they aren't as cute/romantic as Anchor - and they don't take cards. 

Will be back again but hopefully at a less busy time ;)
author: Iris H.

description:
We ordered a dozen oysters of all three east coast. 
They were more expensive than other restaurants. 
They weren't completely fresh. 
But that was the best part of our meal. 
Then I had the open seafood face melt. 
It was way too... heavy and greasy and there was no seafood in it. Even my husband couldn't take more than one bite. 
He ordered the crab burger which was okay, but the cup of clam chowder that came with it was mysteriously missing clam or any other sign of seafood. 
We went to a restaurant in north beach that was WAY better. Message me for details.
author: Jasper A.

description:
This is not worth 4.5 stars. This is at best 3 stars. I think it's a 2-star restaurant. Here's why:

1. Boston clam chowder had NO CLAMS in it. 

2. Bread they served was not that good. The butter was a brick of ICE. 

3. Scallops were served with TONS of aioli. That's it. It didn't complement the scallops and was a poorly executed dish. Scallops do not need aioli. 

4. Waitress presented the oysters without any explanation of where they were from. This is the FIRST time I've ever been served oysters without explanation. 

5. Sake Oyster shooters were not good. I couldn't even finish it. 

One redeeming quality was the shrimp entree which was delicious. The shrimp cocktail was good too. 

Overall, this restaurant is bad. Just don't go.
author: Kunal K.

description:
Loved this quaint seafood place, oysters were perfect! I didn't see any that were appealing and the waitress went to the back and gave me some that were not listed yet, and they were super fresh and I appreciate that they cut the oyster and rinse it before serving. 

I also had the clam chowder and small shrimp Louie. Clam chowder is average, I wouldn't recommend but the salad was great. Good size for the price.

Next time I come back going for more oysters and a seafood dish -- be mindful of the long wait times!
author: Miranda M.

description:
A high 4 stars! Great seafood, one of the better restaurants in the Castro (which somehow has a dearth of quality meal options). However, they are small and always have a long wait.

THE WAIT: 30 minutes for 2 on a Saturday at 12:50pm. We sat at the bar, which accounts for about half the seating in the restaurant! 

THE COST: $98.57 for lunch for 2, before tips. Very expensive, though we had crazy leftovers. 

THE FOOD:

* Special: Seared Day Boat Scallops $16.95 - 4.5 stars
Loved the crisp, very fresh & tender, lemon aioli was excellent.

* Special: Pasta, manilla clams/cream/corn/mushrooms/cherry tomatoes $24.95 - 4.5 stars
Excellent flavor & a HUGE dish! 

* Cioppino, Smaller $38.95 - 4 stars
I don't normally like cioppino but this was great! Loved the garlic bread too.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Not as if this place needs another fabulous review, but I loved this spot on a leisurely Sunday so I had to do it for my vegetarians in the house!

I've lived up the street from Anchor Oyster Bar for the past decade +. I never even thought about stepping foot in here...Until a friend convinced me to have dinner here.

TOTALLY WORTH IT!  Especially if you're up for a carbalicious kind of dinner :) 

First off, it gets super crowded super fast.  We arrived before they opened and put our names on the list.  Within 10 minutes of the doors opening, we were in!

1.  GET THE GARLIC BREAD!  NO QUESTIONS.
2.  YOU GOTTA ORDER A BEER. 
3.  ARTICHOKE IS A WORTHWHILE VEGGIE OPTION.
4.  Side-salad is basic, but if you're a green queen like me, it's just enough to top things off.

The next thing I wanna say is that service was beyond fabulous.  It felt so homey, so personal, and just effortless.  And the character of this place is just so authentic.  I loved every little nook and cranny.

This is a San Francisco classic that cannot be missed!!
author: Angella S.

description:
It's all about the cioppino... best in SF.. freshest of seafood and an epic sauce..but I am disappointed that they only give you a ladle, as a straw would be very helpful. 

Expect a wait as they don't take a reservation
author: David B.

description:
Tourists love the gimmicky clam chowder in a bread bowl but what they should really be looking for is a great bowl of Cioppino.  As a long-time San Franciscan, I've always been on the hunt for the best bowl of Cioppino and I think I've finally found it.  

I was going to be in the area anyway and had some time to kill around lunch time.  This place is on the Michelin Bib Gourmand list so I decided to put my name on the waitlist and was promptly seated at the counter.  I ordered the "smaller" cioppino (it's enough for two) and was quickly intimidated by the massive mound of shellfish in a huge bowl. I was just blown away by the depth of flavor and all the fresh seafood in this dish (crab, shrimp, fish, mussels and clams).  I thought about eating half and taking half home but once I started eating, I couldn't stop myself. IT WAS THAT GOOD!!!  The garlic bread was great too. I will definitely be coming here again with some friends so we can try the other items on the menu. 

Quick notes - pack your patience because there's a wait to be seated and the Cioppino looks like it's made to order (about 30 minute wait). Say no to the bread and yes to the bib.  Also, bring a friend so you can enjoy the oyster plates (comes out a lot faster) while waiting for the Cioppino.  Including tax and tip, the "Smaller" Cioppino comes out to be around $50 but it's easily enough for two people.
author: Andrew S.

description:
someone at a shop told us thats the place in town to eat oysters! indeed, we have been very lucky with that recommendation. best oysters I had for a long time! also as a little place in the castro center very well located. prices are reasonable.
go there!
author: Peter H.

description:
Thank you, Anchor Oyster Bar, for restoring my faith in San Francisco fine cuisine. Our dinner Friday night was perfect.
I can say after living in SF for over 35 years Anchor Oyster Bar provides the very best cioppino to be found anywhere in The City. Simply delicious and much more than I could eat despite my best attempts to do so. The garlic bread is equally iconic.
The service was especially to point and we never felt anything less than as honored guests. Even after a minor mishap with a glass of wine you guys stepped up big time and made the meal memorable.
Thank you again - we'll be back again very soon!
author: Bill G.

description: This seafood spot is fantastic. I have been going here for 25 years and the service and the food has always been just excellent! This spot is small with only a few tables and seats- we waited one hour last night, but were happy to do so. The bucket of clams was outstanding as was my Argentine Shrimp plate. Can't wait to be back !
author: Bob H.

description: Usually with hyped up restaurants, I'm never fully impressed. But this place lives up to its hype. The clam chowder is so good, it warms your soul. And the cioppino is so good and the portion is huge! We also got some oysters, which were really fresh. It's a really small spot so you might have to wait a bit (their systems works with you writing your name on a board so don't just stand outside waiting!) but it's totally totally worth it
author: Connor W.

description:
I've been eating at Anchor since they opened because it has always been a warm, friendly place where you could get excellent raw and cooked seafood. Walking into the restaurant has always felt like I was returning home. So when I came back to San Francisco after being out of town for three months, I stepped in to say, "Hi" and check bar availability. I was a party of one and it looked like a spot might be open at the end of the bar. A new waitperson, "greeted" me by angrily shouting at me to "Go back outside and sign in! There are other people in front of you!"

I had checked the board for parties of one, and checked with each of the  four people waiting outside before I had entered the restaurant. Even so, that is not how a customer should be greeted. That was the final straw for me.

After about 40 years and recently putting up with rude tourists who crowd your table, long wait-times with no reservations, getting progressively less friendly and sometimes rude service, I'm calling "quits" on Anchor Oyster Bar.
author: Richard L M.

description:
Good atmosphere, fresh seafood. It was interesting to observe open kitchen.
But the personnel was not as polite as they should be
author: Ekaterina A.

description: Hoooooooooooly Shuck. Two words. Garlic bread. Two more words. Crab cakes. Do I dare say two more words? Caesar salad. This place was a dream reminding me of my East Hampton hometown and a vacay in southern Italy.  I miss eating here already and just left 5 mins ago.
author: Daisy K.

description:
I've been to over 41 countries and over 200 U.S. cities this is my favorite restaurant. 

What I like best is that they don't take reservations you show up and wait in anticipation.
author: Ron D.

description: Yes, it's a long wait. But, yes, it's worth it. The seafood is so fresh and full of flavor. The prices are high at first glance but the portions are pretty big. So overall this was a great experience once you get in ( just get ready to wait)
author: Ilya K.

description: This place lived up to the hype. A little over an hour wait on a Friday night but they have a bench and a nice heater outside and bring out tiny cups of clam chowder. Customer service is amazing, cool ambiance in the Castro.
author: Josh G.

description:
Lowering this to 4 stars because of the ridiculous wait time and seating system they have here. The food, however, is really delicious and impressed my boyfriend and me a lot.

So for the whole waiting thing... you're supposed to write your name, party size, and time on their whiteboard that's hanging outside by the front day, and apparently you do NOT need to be present when they call your name. Your name will not be erased, and will be called again when a table is available. However, they have a sign that says that you need to be present, so many customers would actually wait instead of running off to somewhere else and coming back later. My boyfriend and I thought that if we went off and were not there when his name was called, they would erase our names and obviously give the table to someone else. Anyway, turns out they do not erase your name and they keep calling you when a table is cleared. This is so annoying, and frankly, quite unfair. What makes it worse is that the place itself is TINY. There's only 5-6 tables maximum, with only 1 seated for 2 people. The rest are all for 4-5 people. Yes, there is bar seating too, but it only seats approximately 6 people, and they actually took away 2 seats from the bar to accommodate a larger party. Frustrating, much?

The food, however, is REALLY good. I was getting so cranky from waiting for 1.2 hours outside that I almost didn't want to eat there anymore. We had 3 kinds of oysters, the risotto cake with roasted shrimp, and the cioppino. 
Oysters: all were chucked nicely, tasted fresh, and all had great flavors and textures. (5/5)
Risotto cake with roasted shrimp special: all the ingredients complimented each other beautifully. Shrimp were plump and roasted nicely (4.8/5)
Cioppino: comes with bibs! Lots of seafood yummies-- 3 big crab legs and lots of clams and mussels! Flavorful broth too. (5/5)

Overall, this place is really good food-wise, but gosh, this place is just way too small for how busy it is, and the wait time is so annoying. I suppose they do not really have to care about that, since they're successful already as they are. I'm hesitant about coming back, but maybe once in a while.
author: Christina W.

description:
Came by on a Saturday night and this place was packed. There's a whiteboard waitlist outside and a small bench to wait at. They don't have a text/calling system but seem to be pretty accommodating if you missed your name. We were told our wait was over an hour so my friend and I went to a nearby tea shop to kill some time.

We were eventually seated at the bar right by the kitchen. It was cool seeing all the food come and go but the space was definitely very cramped and I had to move to get out of the way several times. Otherwise service was awesome!

For our meal my friend and I ordered the Anchor Special for $50 which included 12 oysters, 4 chilled prawns, & a bowl of steamed clams.
1) Oysters: We got 4 of each. Ichibans from Washington (mild, salty, and the meatiest, Chatham from Cape Cod (bright & plump), & Sweetwater  from Tomales Bay (sweet/mild brightness, less meaty)
2) Steamed clams: Tender clams in a light broth. Took the broth home and made some awesome pasta too!
3) Chilled prawns: Average prawns. Large and big but bordering on tough.

We ended our meal w/ their Cioppino and damn if it isn't the sexiest cioppino I've ever laid my eyes on. The size is definitely huge. If you're hungry this can be split between 2 people and still leave you full. This dish is just packed the brim with seafood from fish to mussels to crab. Every piece of meat was extremely tender and flavorful. The base was acidic and rich with a bit of spice and fresh seafood flavors seeping through every bite.

The garlic bread it came with was average. A bit overtoasted and tough. Looked like it would be extremely garlic-y but honestly a bit bland compared to the flavorful cioppino. In the end it's did it's job which is to get as much of the cioppino broth into my mouth as possible.

Overall, this place is definitely worth the wait if you're a cioppino fan. Since it is fresh seafood the pricetag is slightly high but it's worth the quality and even the quantity. Would definitely come again.
author: Vivian C.

description:
OMG! So good! I was introduced to this place by a friend and its definitely a gem! 

Hands down the best Cioppino that I have ever had. The oysters we also super fresh, and the crab cakes amazing. Dungeness crabs were in season, so we had the tastiest crab in both the crab cakes and Cioppino. The Caesar salad is a very good version, but what makes it special is the croutons. They are made similar to the garlic bread which is served with the Cioppino, but an extra side order of garlic bread is a must for dipping in the delicious Cioppino broth. 

This place was definitely a San Francisco treat and I can't wait to go back!

The restaurant is very small, and they don't take reservations, so be prepared to wait. But the wait is totally worth it. I still dream about this meal.
author: Corissa L.

description: This was a lucky punch as we were arriving pretty late in San Francisco and tried to find a nice spot for seafood - actually we found this place on Yelp! Very small and cozy restaurant offering excellent quality food and decent service! The place is so small and packed that you need to write down your name at a board outside and wait until you are bring called. We shared Oysters and Mussels.
author: Jan P.

description: Great food, nice service, it looks like it will never be empty. Come to lunch early...
author: Tim S.

description:
Does it even need to be rated? My favorite restaurant in SF.
The Ciampino is amazing, take extra garlic bread. 
I travel all the way from Oakland for it !
author: Victor L.

description:
Holy fucking shit. I can't believe I ignored this place for so long. I used to live in the Bay but have lived in NYC and now LA. 

Let's just say this was one of the best seafood meals of my life, and hands down, the best cioppino I've ever had. It's not even close!

Started with the combo cocktail which was fantastic. Followed that up with an amazing Caesar salad that has garlic Croutons to die for. Finally, finished with the "small" cioppino, which is clearly a crowd favorite. It's amazing and has all sorts of seafood delights including Dungeness crab .

Put your name down and grab a glass of wine across the street. They will come get you when your seat is ready! Boom.
author: Ki C.

description: This Oyster Bar is amazing! The oysters and prawns were very fresh, the clam chowder was delicious and the crab cakes were incredibly tasty!! My friends and I ordered the anchor special and also shared the crab cake appetizer, the garlic bread, and a bowl of clam chowder, it was enough for all three of us. It's a pretty popular place, but service is fast so we only waited about 15 minutes to be seated. Overall, definitely a place to check out!
author: Karla M.

description:
I loved the cioppino so much two years ago when I visited SF that I knew I had to make a visit this trip. A friend who's a local said this place has the best cioppino and she was right! She's ventured to so many places and hands down, I love their cioppino! 

It's a small restaurant with very cute nautical decor. They do not take reservations and the wait on a Monday night for the four of us was about an hour. 

I can say their seafood dishes are delicious but their cioppino is amazing with the fresh and huge pieces of seafood and tomato broth cooked and simmered with a bunch of herbs. This dish comes in two sizes - small (made for 2 people) and large (made for four people). The small size is huge and more than plenty for my hubby and I to share! The table next to us ordered the large size for five grown men. It took all five of them to finish it! 

If you plan to order the cioppino, the garlic bread that comes with it is very good. But it's not enough to scoop up all that delicious sauce, so get another order of their garlic bread side because that bread is the money. Super buttery, garlicy and holds well with anything you dip it in. That's the perfect meal to end my trip at San Francisco!
author: Judy L.

description:
Lovely, quaint, fresh seafood cafe. You can tell why they often have a wait! The restaurant is tiny, but it feels so cozy when you sit down! You can see the kitchen while you eat and the staff are super friendly.

I went on a Saturday afternoon with a group of 4.  We had put our name on be wait list which took about 50 minutes but we just walked around the neighborhood and grabbed a glass of wine across the street while we waited. 

As soon as we sat down, the waitress treated us to free glasses of champagne to celebrate the restaurants 40th anniversary of being open!

We got a sampler seafood platter of yummy, sweet and salty oysters, shrimp, and clams. We also got a side of king crab legs (I personally prefer snow or blue crabs but they were still excellent). We all got cups of clam chowder which had a wonderful aroma, texture (chunky, but not too chunky!) and instantly made me feel warm and cozy.

The bottle of rose wine we had paired wonderfully with our fresh seafood.

Would absolutely recommend if you're a seafood lover!
author: Annette K.

description: Went across town for this place to find a sign on the window that they're closed for their annual vacation. No mention of this on their web site. Who do I contact to refund my Lyft fare and pay for my lost time?
author: Lia V.

description:
LOVE this place!
I tried it for the first time on a Saturday evening before a show in the Castro Theater. Good thing, we came early enough, because the wait was 1+ hour! No wonder... the food is so good and the place so tiny. I would guess they can seat about 30 people here? We shared the dozen oyster assortment, a shrimp cocktail and the crab cakes with clam chowder. All extrodinary. No booze this time, my friend had a major hangover :-D. The oysters were perfect for her, though!
As you can imagine, the place was super busy, but service was still on point and very friendly. Will be back for sure! (my stomach did some somersaults after about two hours. I suspect the clam chowder had too much heavy cream for my sensitive system lol. The oysters were top notch and surely not the problem!)
author: Alexa W.

description: yup.  I agree, best cioppino in the city.   Got the cioppino and 24 oysters, it was awesome.  Their was a line on Thursday at 2pm, which surprised me, but it was probably just a 30 minute wait.  Surprised I haven't been here earlier, I've had the other cioppinos in the city and this one is the best for sure.
author: christopher h.

description:
Wow just finished a lunch consisting of 
Caesar salad 
Bowl of clam chowder 
Seafood salad
Mexican style shrimp
All were excellent with a multitude of different flavors. My favorite was the Mexican style shrimp served with sautéed veggies yum yum gimme some ....more please. Seating is limited so you may have to wait, but it is so worth it.
author: Craig C.

description:
Susan and whole gang provide world-class service here! It's worth the wait!

Recommendations: 
- Cioppino (small is enough for two decently hungry  people) 

- Crab Cake Appetizer 

- BEST Clam Chowder in San Francisco

- Prawn Cocktail (the prawns are huge!) 

- Mixed Seafood Salad (omg... yum!) 

- Always get the special Cod or Sole, especially if  Chef Angie is cooking 

Enjoy!!
author: Merlino T.

description:
We visited this nice little oyster bar in The City on a nice Saturday as my wife was in the mood for seafood and oysters. It's a cozy restaurant that doesn't take reservations, so be prepared for a little wait. We waited for about 45 minutes, but it was well worth it. The owner came out with some cups of clam chowder for the people who were waiting, which was a nice touch. The service is very attentive and prompt even if the place is always busy. 
The atmosphere is of an old school and no-nonsense San Francisco seafood joint, the kind that never goes out of style. We ordered a bunch of oysters; an even mix of the three kinds that had that day. The best were the oysters from Cape Cod with a clean, sweet, flavor of the sea. Followed by the oysters from New Brunswick, and last but not least, the oysters from Washington, which had a super clean but less dynamic flavor. They were all super fresh and worth visiting for. The crab cocktail was delicious as to be expected as was the clam chowder. They have a nice selection of drinks; wines, draft beer, bottled beer, and things that aren't wine or beer that I didn't pay attention to and can't remember. 
Anyway, this is a nice seafood experience. The menu is straightforward, and don't forget to check the specials board for more dishes. We'll be back for sure.
author: Kent J.

description:
On a Sunday night, we waited about an hour and a half for a table of three. Maybe it was on us for not realizing how hoppin' this place is, combined with just showing up at a bad time (6:30?), but in my opinion, there's pretty much no restaurant in the world waiting that long for in the blustery San Francisco cold. 

The way the tables worked was, in short, infuriating. You go to the whiteboard next to the front door, and write down your name, the number of people in your party, and the time at which you arrived. Bonus: there is a board of shame where they write your name if your party wasn't there when they called you. It is a teeny tiny place, like many excellent San Francisco establishments are, but the turnover was shockingly slow for a place that got food out fairly quickly. It seemed like we were the "next table of three" for about 50 minutes. Granted, this was due in part to a table that finished eating, then dawdled for about half an hour (immune to my glares from outside). I'm an asshole, I know, but it's just common courtesy not to hang around forever when you're done eating and you know people are waiting on your asses. We initially got skipped over, not because we weren't there, but due to the lightning speed with which the hostess was reading off names. I maintain that she at no point said our party's name, but that could be because my ears fell off in the cold. Luckily, one of my dining companions has the "scorned, indignant, stay-at-home mom with plenty of time to speak to your manager" aesthetic down pat. After a brief and tense stand-off, we were seated. 

Immediately upon sitting down, we were brought waters and a half-order of garlic bread as an apology for the miscommunication. I will say that after the initial tension, the service here was excellent; I'm not sure how much of that was due to the seating fiasco/the level of fear the waitstaff has for my friend. We were regularly checked on throughout our meal, our questions answered thoroughly, and our waters refilled often. Everyone was incredibly friendly, after we got into the restaurant. 

The garlic bread was stellar. Crispy on the outside, soft on the inside; topped generously with garlic and almost as importantly, mountains of Parmesan. Despite the cut I was nursing on the roof of my mouth, I barreled through the garlic bread because it was just that damn good, and well worth the pain. 

We also ordered the crab cake entree, which cake with 3 good-sized crab cakes, roasted potatoes, a small salad (kind of?), tartar sauce, and a cup of clam chowder. The clam chowder was interesting, unlike other clam chowders I've had in the past. I'll preface by saying that if it were feasible and not horrendous, I would bathe in Boudin's clam chowder; we have a sordid love affair that stretches back decades. While not quite as flavorful, this chowder was incredibly smooth, with a good amount of clams and potatoes in each spoonful. I chose not to eat the salad or potatoes, as I was preparing my belly for the cioppino to come, but heard good things from my fellow diners. The crab cakes were fine. I was expecting more complexity in the flavors, and greater chunks of that Dungeness crab deliciousness; it was a little on the mushy side, save for the well-crisped exterior. Realistically, these seem like the quality of crab cakes I could make for myself, not something I'd pay a restaurant $27 for. The saving grace of this dish, hands down, was the tartar sauce. I'm not even a huge tartar sauce gal, but I would happily eat this by the spoonful. It was flavorful, smooth, and exquisite. 

Onto the main event: the cioppino. After seeing the cauldron that is the large cioppino, we opted for the smaller, and it was definitely a good call. Still a ridiculous amount of seafood, we could barely even get our bibs on straight before diving right in. The sauce of the cioppino is excellent, truly spectacular. The creatures it contained were: crab legs, sole, mussels, clams, and a couple of shrimp. I enjoyed most of it just fine, but the crab legs were excellent. This might be because I'm a crazy person who loves to use seafood crackers. Overall though, I was let down by the cioppino, because it was talked up so much and because when it comes down to it, I don't think I'll ever love another cioppino the way I love the one at Soto Mare in North Beach. Is that unfair to Anchor? Maybe, but the heart wants what the heart wants. 

It seems unlikely that I'll return; it's not like there are no other seafood restaurants in the bay. The food was perfectly fine and the service was ultimately great, but the environment so small and crowded. Honestly, it's just not quite worth it to me for the price tag.
author: Justie L.

description: Always love the seafood here.  They don't take reservations so be prepared to wait - but it's always worth it.
author: Ashleigh P.

description:
This lovely quaint little nautical themed seafood place was my first stop when I moved to SF 4 years ago. I tried it again and I enjoyed every part of it, except the wait. The menu is pretty limited. We went with the anchor special (12 oysters, 6 shrimp and clams) and the large Cioppino. Neither were dissapointing, except I wish you got to choose the oysters instead of the spread (4 of each type they had on the menu). Had I known, I would have elected to just get a dozen oysters of my choosing and skip the clams and prawns. 1/3 of the choices were dime size oysters and quite buttery for my taste. The Cioppino was HUGE and delicious (keep in mind you have to crack your own crab). The garlic bread was honestly gross, cold and didn't have much of a flavor. The seafood was fresh and filling. It was too much food for the two of us, but we were happy to take the remainder home. The 4 stars is for service, as I explain in other reviews... if I'm going to wait an HOUR to pay over a hundred dollars for a meal I expect that our water glasses should stay filled, friendly servers and a check delivered in a timely manner. Secondly, the wait. I went expecting a wait, but the order in which they call the people was frustrating. There were people not present when their names were called, who showed up late and STILL got seated before us. They lucked out and literally came back 3 minutes before the guy walked out and jumped ahead of us even though they had missed their "chance" twice before. It was frustrating, but I can appreciate that it maybe the nature of the beast. 

Pros: the Cioppino, Oysters (make sure you choose wisely!) 
Cons: Wait, garlic bread
Overall: I'll brave the wait and a hole in my wallet; the food is really good if you know what to order.
author: Whitney B.

description:
Still one of my absolute favorites in San Francisco. Even though I don't live near the Bay anymore, I go out of my way to eat at Anchor when visiting.

It's small, so please don't show up with more than a group of three or four. We found out firsthand that it's not especially kid friendly either (with friends who requested a high chair and they were given a booster seat), but hey, the entire city isn't terribly awesome for little ones. 

I love sitting at the counter and watching the seafood/wine magic unfold before my very eyes. It's a tiny kitchen that operates at full capacity, down to the washing of the plates/glassware, then setting back in its proper place to dry.

Open face crab sandwich - go get it already! And a glass of wine!
author: Abby S.

description:
We started off our meal with the Steamed Greenlip Mussels with Saffron Cream Sauce appetizer. For only $10 bucks we were treated to some of the best mussels that I have ever eaten in my life. The sauce was easily one of the best things I have tasted in my life! It was the perfect mixture of lemon, white wine, and Saffron. The buttery and creamy elements were perfectly balanced by the acidity of the lemon and the light white wine used in the sauce. I could not help but soak up every last bit of sauce with the free bread!

I followed up the mussels with the pasta special, Clam Linguini, and was equally impressed. I quickly devoured a huge bowl, stuffed with perfectly cooked, tender clams, and al dente noodles. The dish was fresh, and the delicate shellfish flavor paired exquisitely with a light, buttery sauce.

The only qualms I had with the Anchor Oyster Bar was that our waiter could really have cared less about the service he was providing. But the manager/owner was very helpful and kind. 

If you are in San Francisco I would make a special point to swing by the Castro and try some of the best seafood in town!
author: Noah P.

description:
Got the small cioppino, steamed clams, garlic bread, clam chowder.

The chowder came out first and is very fair value. Thought it tasted like a good chowder, creamy. Wish there were more clams (I didn't taste any but maybe I got unlucky with my half of the portion).

The garlic bread that was ordered was much different than the ones that came with the cioppino. The former was softer, less burnt, smaller cuts. Think the garlic was a little more generous as well. Good supplement for more food.

The steamed clams weren't what I was expecting. Small clams and steamed in an salty olive oil base. Good flavor, but felt weird that you couldn't drink or do anything else with the "soup". Too salty.

The cioppino was my favorite (no surprise). It had a variety of seafood, fish, crab, clam, shrimp. I personally would've gotten the large for two people and cut out the steamed clams. I enjoyed the sauce. Tomato base with some chunks inside, a little salty but great with bread.

Common theme here seemed to be things will be salty, so get lots of bread.
author: Victor D.

description: GREAT SEAFOOD!! Probably one of the best ones in SF IMO. I've had the steamed clams and the broth is just so good you could drink it or just ask for extra bread to soak up the broth. Speaking of bread their garlic bread is also pretty good. My husband enjoys their cioppino and his standards for that dish is pretty high. Friendly staff and attentive being it a very small space. They have about 4-5 tables that can fit a party of 4 comfortably and 2 smaller tables that accommodates 2 and then some space at the bar. So you see it's a tiny place so prepare to wait for a table.
author: Ardielyn F.

description:
As a self proclaimed seafood fanatic, I'm always checking out new places to indulge in, and discovered this gem through word of mouth and have not stopped coming back since! 

There's literally always a line here and no matter how early I try to arrive, I always end up waiting an hour, but I would gladly wait again and again because it is so. mouthwateringly. delicious! 

Must orders every time I come: 
1) oysters, oysters, oysters 

2) crab cake entree: this is the most succulent mouthful of crab you can have. So much meat and so much flavor 

3) cioppino: this is the stuff of dreams. I can't think of Anchor and not crave this. The cioppino is generously stuffed with seafood to the brim including clams, mussels, shrimp, fish, and crab. The real winner here though is the tomato and herb broth- an incredible flavor medley. This dish really couldn't be better but they manage to make it next level with the garlic cheese bread that they put on top. You're going to devour this, but fear not! You can order extra on the side :)
author: Ashley L.

description:
Service amazing simple, yet superb. I even went as far as hugging our server. It was just perfect. I really felt like I was sitting at my mother or grandmother's table. (You know that feeling?!)
Food spectacular 
clam chowder.  Wow
Chippino -outstanding 
Clams & mussels. Just wow 
Crab cakes. I'll be dreaming of you. 
Ohh hello Garlic bread!! Our fat Asses got 2 orders!! Ha!

I even went out bro the kitchen to thank them.

They will close for the next 2 weeks too! We made it just in time.  Can't wait to go back co
author: Tanya O.

description: I've always heard great things about anchor oyster. idk why it took 8 years for me to visit. but my Wifey was in town and we came on a friday evening and waited about 30 minutes before being seated. not bad at all! the menu is pretty simple, and most people are here for the cioppino. but since it was my first time here, we tried the chowder and the clam bake, and paired the cioppino with a side of garlic bread. needless to say, the cioppino is OUT OF THIS WORLD. better than wood house, better than sutto mare. i took a quart of sauce to go - $15. it's so good im taking my parents the next time they visit!
author: Christina L.

description:
The summer of 2013, back when my husband was just an awesome boyfriend, we planned a trip to San Fran. We booked our first ever AirBNB and he planned a romantic date in the city. He took me to Anchor Oyster Bar and the following spring we were married. Oyster's are magic, ya'll. 

We recently returned to San Fran this past winter to visit some friends and made sure to carve out some time for a date night at that place we fell in love with 4.5 years earlier. I think it got even better. The food is fresh and amazing. If it's cold out, you HAVE to get the giant steaming bowl of seafood goodness. If it's hot, oyster shooters for days. The atmosphere is intimate and romantic, and the staff is simply amazing. A restaurant that can seed itself in your memory for almost 5 years and still provide an amazing experience is one worth visiting again and again. I can't wait to go back! Hopefully it's a little sooner than 2022.
author: Tiffany H.

description: An institution with great service and delicious food. Portioare large and satisfying. Avoid the long waits on the weekends, it's at least a couple of hours. Also, if you arrive after they close, they'll still let you in for oysters and clam chowder.
author: Ramon M.

description: Awesome find... small, quaint, clean.  Food was OUTSTANDING!  Super nice and welcoming staff.  So glad we found this non-touristy, local joint. Portions were perfect, prices were fair, quality was superb!
author: Michael R.

description:
My girlfriend really wanted oysters, so I did a lot of research and found this place. 

There was a bit of a wait, so we put our names on the board. 

We ended up sitting on the counter with a great view of the kitchen.

The staff was very friendly and efficient. Our water was refilled. They brought us more bread and thoughtfully asked us if we wanted out food brought in waves. There was a bit of a wait, though, between our first and second courses. When the oysters came. They described the varieties on the plate.

I got the wild prawns from Mexico. Sauteed with garlic, chili flakes, olive oil & herbs, roasted potatoes & vegetables, choice of cup or chowder or green salad. The clam chowder was good. I really enjoyed the roasted vegetables. The shrimp was large and perfectly cooked. It was a little more lemony than I would have liked. 

I would definitely come here again and try the cioppino. Many other diners were eating that, and were raving about it. My girlfriend ended up craving cioppino so bad after we went here, she ended up making her own at home!
author: Sean A.

description: I arrived just before 5:00 and didn't have any trouble getting a seat at the bar. The bartender greeted me right away and took my drink order. It was another waiter who took my food order and didn't do a great job articulating the answers to my questions. The food was good (clam chowder and crab cake appetizer), but no one checked in to see how my meal was until I was completely done.
author: Brena E.

description:
Really great little spot in the Castro with solid oysters, some great clam chowder (creamy and delicious) a lot of pretty great fish selections.

Had the green lipped mussels in a fantastic wine sauce and we also tried the whole Dungeness crab which was tender and awesome. Dipped sourdough in everything to make the meal even better. 

Put your name on the whiteboard and get ready to wait (only 5 tables and a short bar), but definitely worth it for awesome service, great food and  a really nice time.
author: Bob K.

description:
Oh we San Francisicans love our lines! 

Brought some people here from out of town and waited a total of 2 hours for a table for 4. Was it worth it? Yep. We ended up ordering, prawns, some fish (I forgot which kind), a large Cioppino, clam chowder and some garlic bread. 

Everything tasted delicious but I do wish the Cioppino wasn't as salty. 

The good thing about this place is that you can put your name down, go for a stroll and come back where as other places, you'd have to wait in line. 

Definitely would recommend this place to try in SF.
author: Mai W.

description:
Tiny restaurant so be prepared to squeeze. But first, be prepared to wait a while in a line just to be allowed to squeeze on in.

If you're going for their cioppino (and why wouldn't you--they're YUM), know their sizes so you don't get blind-sighted by their portions!
author: Yad L.

description:
We waited for about 2 hours to get a table because this place is SMALL. WARNING, DON'T COME WITH A LARGE PARTY more than 4, otherwise you probably won't get a seat in forever, and you won't sit next to each other. 

Anyways, after we finally got seated, we were so famished we could not wait to get our food. This might have been the reason why the bread and the butter was sooooo good. But I think everything there was just super delicious. I came with 3 friends and we got a large cioppino, garlic bread, caesar salad and crab cakes. We were stuffed by the end. 

Cioppino: Delicious delicious cioppino (seafood stew). I learned that cioppino was originated in San Francisco and considered Italian-American food (Kind of like kung pao chicken is Chinese-American). It was super delicious with large muscles, clams, fish, shrimp and crab. The soup was super amazing and I kind of wished we added some pasta to it (since I like noodle soups). It would have been heavenly! This is the star of the dinner and I highly recommend it! It was a tad but on the salty side for me, but it was very very very flavorful, totally satisfying my seafood craving.

Garlic bread was amazing with so much garlic and cheesy flavors. Note, the cioppino also has garlic bread on it, so don't order more carbs if you don't have to.  

Crab cakes were absolutely delicious! So much crab flavor and you can definitely tell there was so much crab in the cakes, not just batter. Paired perfectly with the dipping sauce. And also great with the cioppino.

Caesar salad was pretty delicious as well. The croutons were made from the same garlic bread bread but with dried out a little more for a great crispy crunch. Dressing was perfect, not too heavy for the romaine lettuce.

Overall, loved it. Service was excellent. Waited a long time, but it was expected since this place is super popular. Would definitely come here again!
author: Stanley C.

description:
Second time to this establishment. Waited about an hour to get seated, while outside with a large group waiting in the cold the server brings us samples of the clam chowder to keep us warm. Amazing service and such a nice staff. Small spot but they make sure your taken care of.
Order
Half oysters raw
Small blue cheese salad 
Clam chowder cup 
Cioppino small 
Half garlic bread 

Everything was fresh and amazing. 

The cioppino was amazing and just how I remember it in my the previous visit. Juicy shrimps, meaty crab, fish, mussels, and clam all in one amazing light tomato broth. Perfectly seasoned. The garlic bread was delicious and rustic all garlicky and dusted with parmesan. Just the perfect crunch and side to dip in the broth. Delicious cioppino, just try it. 

Always a great dinner at AOB.
author: Amit P.

description:
Get the cioppino! It is delicious, packs a ton of flavor. They have two different sizes, I got the smaller of the two and ended taking it to my brothers house. There was so much leftover that they had plenty for the both of their dinner. I saw bigger groups that, had a couple large ones,  on their table and they were just sharing it. Great idea! 
My brother and boyfriend got the shrimp, neither were impressed, it was boring and bland. It is all about the cioppino!
author: Kacy M.

description:
This was hands-down the best meal I've ever had in the Bay Area! Since I discovered this quaint little restaurant, I've found occasion to go five more times within the month. The waiter was incredibly friendly and brought us cups of clam chowder as we waited outside. The place is very small (~20 seats / 4 tables + bar seating), so if you get on the waitlist after 6pm, expect to wait 1.5~2 hours...But the wait is sooo worth it! I got a selection of raw oysters, a liter of house white wine, and their breathtaking ciopinno. It was an hour in heaven, and I savored every minute. I would highly recommend Anchor Oyster Bar seafood-loving small parties and couple.

Tip: Go across the street to wine taste while you are on the waitlist.
author: Richie X.

description:
Ah-mazaing.

Caesar salad (creamy and zesty) and cioppino (great fresh seafood and strong herb flavor) to die for.

Perfection.
author: Andrew K.

description: Excellent oyster bar in the Castro.  We ordered a dozen oysters.  Just a fresh mix of each different variety.  So fresh and the mignonette was great as well.  We shared half a crab, hot garlic style.  It was excellent.  Sweet mild meat, best crab I've ever eaten.  Great restaurant in the area.
author: Zen D.

description:
What can I say about this super wonderful place that hasn't already been said? In my book, this is up there with Swan Oyster Depot. Swan focuses more on the raw seafood (cherry clams and fish sashimi are my favorite) whereas Anchor has amazing cooked dishes (cioppino, seared scallops, steamed shellfish). 

Everything we had was so so good. The raw oysters were delicious but I don't remember choosing the kinds... it was just a general batch. From then on, the food just got better and better. The steamed clams was a massive dish. Unless you are a clam-fanatic, I would get the steamed shellfish combination so you get mussels and other things too.

Seared scallops usually really turn me off because of the strange smell they emit after being cooked. But this one, when paired with the housemade tartar sauce, was on another level. It's the first time I didn't mind seared scallops at all. The dish came with vegetables (squash, potatoes, broccolini) that just make you want to smother them in the sauce too. 

Last but not least, the cioppino. I've had this dish many times at pretty reputable establishments so I contemplated skipping out. But holy moly. The broth was so good; I was satisfied just guzzling that down rather than eating the actual seafood. The small is a hefty portion to share even among four people but the large is truly a centerpiece that would dazzle any out-of-towners you bring here. There were shrimp, fish, mussels, clams and crab with two pieces of garlic bread topping it. A little bit of everything. If you were to only get one dish here, the cioppino would be it.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Anytime I am ever in San Fransisco I make sure I make time to visit anchor oyster bar. This has got to be one of my favorite restaurants in Sf. Be ready to wait when it comes to dinner time. What's cool is you put your name, how many in your party, and time and you can stroll down Castro for a quick drink at the bar or coffee. You also get to see how many People are ahead of you so you can tune when you'll need to get back to check on your status. But if they call your name when your. It there they move on to the next. So don't go too far.

This is my 2nd time here and anchor still exceeds my expectations. They have one of the best steam clams dish. The broth is to die for. Trust me! Get it.
They also had a not on the menu saffron pasta. OMG! One of my favorite pasta dishes of all time. 
This place will never disappoint.
author: Crystal N.

description: THE best seafood in San Francisco, hands down!  Everything is fresh and prepared as you order.  Their daily special board includes items that are the freshest for that day.  Get there early otherwise you'll experience a wait.  It's worth it!  If it's cold outside while waiting, they often bring a little sampling of their delicious clam chowder to warm you up! I've been going here for over 20 years and I'll never stop!
author: Matt A.

description: When it comes to seafood, Anchor Oyster Bar is on top of my list. It is a quaint little restaurant that has been around since 1977. The food is very consistent. The seasonal oysters are very fresh. The steamed clams is served in a zesty and light buttery broth that makes it great for dipping the bread. The clam chowder is authentic. I always order a cup of the chowder, which is enough because you would want to save room for the entree. My favorite dish that is not on the menu, but a specialty of theirs, is the ciopinno. It comes with an abundance of seafood served in a flavorful tomato stew. The seafood includes: Dungeness crab, prawns, clams, mussels, calamari, and fish. The large ciopinno is more than enough for two people. There is always a wait and they don't take reservations. I suggest getting there early to get your name on the list.
author: Anson C.

description: This restaurant is simply the best....I love the crab and everything is so fresh and attention to detail in preparation of the food makes it absolutely delicious from start to finish.  Just show up and if you have to wait it's worth it.  Patience is a virtue.  The house salad with blue cheese dressing is a delight.  Beers and wines to choose from to go with what you're eating.  Enjoy!
author: David V.

description:
I knew this was a famous spot in SF. So it was on one of my top of the list to visit even before I came here. I read a lot of reviews on yelp and saw that it could be quite a wait before you get seated so I planned ahead and arrived right at 1130am. (It's not a huge restaurant and has maybe about 5-6 tables (4 of which can seat 4 people and the others were 2-3 max) and 6 seats by the bar.  

We got seated right away but the female waitress who initially took us seemed a bit rude at first and we thought that was just how she was but then to any other customers who came thru she was very nice and was making small talks. One word came across my head and it was racism.  We ended up getting served by a different waiter. Other people were very pleasant though but because of how she treated us in the beginning I am giving 4 stars. (I don't even know why she was rude all I asked was to seat more towards the kitchen because I was cold and they had their door open.)

Food wise, very very delicious they have special menu up on the bar area. They seem to be changed daily based on what they have that's fresh. 

They had 3 different types of oysters and when I asked questions about them, our waiter (not the rude lady) brought me and showed me how they looked and explained me the flavors. I took his recommendation and tried all 3 different kinds they had and it was the freshest and most delicious oysters I've ever had. I probably could've ordered another dozen but we wanted to try other stuff as well so we stopped. 

Since it was just two of us we ordered small cioppino. And let me tell ya it wasn't small. Enough for two people for sure and it paired very well with the wine they had. Best cioppino I had yet. Not too salty and perfectly seasoned. Tomato based broth was very very good with bread and it had a whole crab, clams, mussel, and some type of small fish meat. 

Next time I'm visiting SF, I'm defiantly coming back to try different things on their menu.
author: Jess K.

description: I've been coming to this restaurant off and on for more than 30 years and have always love it. However, I had lunch there yesterday and ordered the steamed green lipped mussels. The dish looked amazing and the broth was very good but the mussels were very large, tough (over cooked?) and had a fair amount of grit in them...frankly, for 28 dollars....I've had much tastier mussels for half the price. The staff were AMAZING and kind and I'll go back but I wouldn't order the mussels again.
author: Brent O.

description:
Top notch taste.  Only shellfish.  Huge and moist and sweet prawns. Perfect, enormous Caesar with huge hand spiced and pan browned croutons

We split the pasta special-- juicy big oysters, delicate little clams, and more prawns of wonder in a saffron sauce. Exquisite. 

$11 for excellent full to the brim glass of Gloria Ferrer champagne ( aka sparkling wine )

2 people- each with wine, splitting the salad and entree-- extremely full and happy for $90. Left $25 tip-  servers were very nice to a friend who popped by-- brought him water, were super nice when he didn't want anything else. 

We will be back!
author: paula c.

description:
This place is AMAZING! I came here a few years back for my birthday and I remember The Cioppino left a wonderful and lasting memory. And let me tell you fellow Yelpers, I am picky when it comes to Cioppino! 

PROS:
- Um, did I mention the Cioppino is AMAZING?!
- The Cioppino has lots of seafood in it!
- The sauce in the Cioppino is absolutely delicious! 
- The outer shell of the crab is not too difficult to take off.
- The Ceasar Crab Salad is YUMMO and there's a nice amount of crab meat in that bad boy!

COULD BE BETTER:
- I wish the restaurant was bigger because when you come during their busy hours, be prepared to wait a while. I came a little after 5pm on a weekday, and I got in right away! 

After coming here for my second time, I can say that I would totally come back here for the Cioppino! My sister, who is also super picky also loved their Cioppino. It truly is one of the best I've ever had!
author: Loreto D.

description:
It's pretty difficult to find decent cioppino here in SF, but they have the best cioppino ever! It's a bit pricey but makes sense considering the huge portion they serve. 
The service is always very attentive and great - I've never asked anyone to get anything. They keep checking on you quietly and bring to you whatever you would need before you even ask. 
Usually very busy with long lines to get in. But try to get there before they open. If you're lucky enough to be included in the 1st batch of people getting in, your wait is very minimal. 

Love all staff members here but especially like the gentleman with glasses (super knowledgeable and attentive) and the lady with gray hair (sorry! I forgot to ask your name, but you're super amazing!!!)

Can't wait to go back to have more oysters and cioppino!!
author: Mac K.

description: The clam chowder is simply heavenly at Anchor Oyster Bar.  Rich and silky, its unlike any other I've sampled.
author: Rafael R.

description:
2nd visit to Anchor Oyster Bar & its as good as I remembered it! There's always a long wait especially on Friday nights & weekends because the food is delicious & there's limited seating (a few tables & seating at the bar). Avoid coming with a large part because the tables accommodate up to 4 people. We lucked out on a long wait thanks to restaurant week (not offered at this restaurant) dispersing the crowds to some of the other neighboring restaurants.

Arrive before prime dinner time & write your name, party size, & arrival time on the board -- they don't take reservations nor allow you to put your name down over the phone. 

We started off with the seared scallops (perfectly cooked). Cioppino was delicious - a small is a good size to share especially if you have your heart set on trying a few other items on the menu. The last dish & my favorite of the night was this special pasta dish that had a creamy lemon butter sauce. Even though I was pretty full, I could help but grab the garlic bread & soak up all of the delicious sauce.

Service was attentive and the staff was great at recommending dishes.

Note: they're temporarily cash only
author: Ruby C.

description: This is my favorite place for cioppino and oysters. I came here at 6:30pm monday and had one team ahead of me. So I had to wait for about 20 minutes to get in. My brother and I ordered half oyster and clam, small cioppino, clam chowder and a crab cake. I have tried cioppino in 4 different restaurants and this place serves the best tasting cioppino. Crab cakes are also awesome. It tastes like japanese lobster croquet but better. I wish many people get to know this place.
author: Yeongyoob P.

description: The best cioppino in the city by far! If they have fried oysters, order them before they run out!!!
author: Ryan J.

description: I was in SF for work and was really looking to get my hands on some amazing seafood- oysters in particular. This place hit every mark with perfect precision. A little crowded (but what delicious place in SF isn't) I sat at a packed bar and put down a family of oysters, crab and some clam chowder. Nothing was left wanting for anything. Fantastic food, I will definitely be back... many times.
author: Blake P.

description:
Intimate setting and a local favorite, so if you're bringing a date, make a reservation. 

I got the prawn salad and the shrimp were huge and cooked perfectly.  I saw someone else order the ciopioni and it looked divine!!! It was a little pricey (entree starts at $25) but you get what you pay for. 

5 stars for this gem!
author: Meagan M.

description:
Anchor's ciopino totally rock - i think it's one of the best (if not the best) from our beloved city by the bay.  It is super tasty and the serving is super generous as well.    

For guilt free dining, we usually start off with the crab salad and then seal the deal with the cioppino.    

Best to visit anchor during off hours since they don't accept reservation and parking is a pain.   

Nonetheless, come give anchor a go - and you will certainly enjoy it and end your meal with a smile!
author: Gino C.

description: I have traveled all over the country and all over the world for the past 17 years and this restaurant is in my top three favorites. The cioppino is not on the menu, but if you ask the chef, they do miracles in the tiny kitchen that they work in. Definitely the top cioppino in the country.  Every menu item that I've ever eaten there has been superb. Thank you and I hope to see you soon.
author: Lynne S.

description: This place is spectacular! Ambience, great food, location, all make for a great evening of mouth-watering cuisine. Clam chowder.......AMAZING! Service.......exceptional! Worth looking for a parking spot!!!
author: Jeanne D.

description: Great place!  I had the sole special and everyone else at my table had the crab cakes.  It was all very good.  After seeing the ciopinno dish on other tables, I wished I ordered it.  It looked and smelled amazing!! The place is very small, and upon arrival, you write your name on the board at the door.  Small groups, two, get seated a bit faster.  However, if you're a larger group prepare to wait a bit.  We were a group of four and waited over an hour.  But it was so worth it.  Parking is rough so if you can Uber or Lyft, do it.
author: Bianca B.

description:
The reality is often the waiting.  I luv, luv, luv this place but you usually have to wait.  I can walk to this place with my out-of-town guests but it's nearly always a chilling out on the sidewalk wait before you can get inside.

Bundle up and you'll be fine.  The food is worth it.
author: d h.

description: I must say that this restaurant offers best Cioppino. I'm a big fan of cioppino and try almost every where city I've visited or any seafood restaurant that offer this soup but non can't match this restaurant.
author: Huey T.

description:
My wife and I stumbled upon this great little spot as we wandered around the Castro for the first time.  We sat at the bar and were immediately greeted with water and a menu.  It was during the lunch rush so we were lucky.  The place is cozy and tight, don't expect any frills.  We ordered the half anchor special (6 oysters, 2 prawns, and what we thought were going to be 4 clams...We got about 8). We are huge oyster fans so where excited to try out 3 new oysters we don't get back home on the east coast.  They were salty, refreshing, and the delicious.  The prawns were a bit too salty for my taste, but my wife liked hers and the clams were delicious.  Made us wish we had saved our bread from earlier to dip into.  

Like I said, we sat at the bar.  A gentleman was next to us and was picking at his food.  When he said he was done, he made some comment about how he doesn't like cornmeal and the woman behind the counter immediately said, why didn't tell us we would have made you something else.  He clearly has been here before, was extremely polite about it and said no worries.  He ordered another glass of wine and was content to sip that.  The next thing we see, the chef, another wonderful older woman, walks out and speaks to him, said I hear you don't like cornmeal.  I'm going to refire up your meal.  Would you like it now, or to go?  Now that is customer service.  This man clearly has been and will continue to be coming back to Anchor Oyster Bar, and with service like that who wouldn't go back?  

I know I would go back just to try the Cioppini if I didn't live on the east coast.
author: Elyse L.

description:
Anchor Oyster Bar is the home of the best Bloody Mary I've ever had. You must get it!!!!

Overall I really enjoyed my time here, and the Castro is always a fun neighborhood. I'm withholding 5 stars because I felt like the menu was pretty limited and the food was VERY expensive. I think Hog Island or Swan's Oyster Depot is cheaper for the same quality. 

This isn't a place I would return to unless I was trapped in the Castro desperate for seafood (an unlikely occasion).
author: Chelsea J.

description: Best cioppino!! Freshest oysters. And garlic bread is delicious! Love seeing the two lady chefs in the little kitchen. They were non-stop with the cioppino and fish of the day. Wonderful environment even if the place is small. Love it because it is so cozy with quality foods! Service was superb as well!!
author: Kayli T.

description: Perfect place to escape the craziness of the city. This small seafood restaurant offers quality food and pleasant service. The scallop special was amazing and cooked perfectly.
author: Leslie B.

description: Tried the chipino and raw oysters and clams. The soup of the chipino is ok which I prefer it to me more milky. The freshness of the seafood is the key,  which we felt the crab in it were not so fresh and like frozen ones, and also if they could add squid in it, it would be better. Anyway I have another Chipino restaurant in SF which's better than this, check out my review you can find it. BTW, their oysters are very fresh and good!
author: Kelvin Y.

description: Stopped here for a late lunch, ordered a dozen oysters, seared scallops, and crab cakes to start. The oysters were fresh and delicious, the scallops were my favorite of the three - they were seared perfectly and had a nice lemon aioli, the crab cakes were a nice size - full of crab and served with a nice fresh tartar sauce. We shared the small ciopino between 2 adults and 2 kids(11 & 8), it had mussels, clams, big pieces of crab, ginormous shrimp, and a big piece of fish. The broth was full of flavor, and went well with all the seafood.
author: brittany d.

description:
Great dining spot with a very good menu. I'm a huge fan but it's just so darn expensive and there are better places for me to spend my money. 

Even though I liked it once, I don't think that I can get myself to come back despite how much I liked it due to the prices. This brings it down to 3 stars from 4.
author: Joshua F.

description:
The best oysters I've ever had!  I'm a oyster lover and was amazed about the freshness of the oysters they serve! They just melt right in my mouth.

We also ordered calm chowder soup, garlic bread and Cioppino. I've never had cioppino before. I saw a lot of good reviews here so we ordered a small one. It was good, actually in a big portion with pretty much everything - fish, crab legs, clam, mussels and shrimps. Probably my expectation was way too high, it didn't really get me the same way as the oysters. I feel like it can be more favorable.

We came to the restaurant at around 5:15 pm on a Saturday and only waited for about 20 mins. The people were pretty nice, but we did spent a decent amount of time waiting for our food. I'll recommend to come to the restaurant off peak time to avoid too long of the waiting. It's indeed a $$$ restaurant - we didn't order drinks and it was about $50/ person.

In summary, nice restaurant in a nice area! I'll definitely come back for the oysters!!
author: Claire P.

description: This is my second time here and it is always impressive and worth the wait(roughly 2hrs at 7 on a Tuesday night) outside on the sidewalk. We had the clam chowder which was the right balance of creamy, salty with fresh clams. We also had 12 oysters and they were all unique, fresh and delicious.  the one major hang up I have with this place is the fact that they serve cold bread and frozen butter. If you look around the restaurant everyone is trying to literally mush frozen butter on to cold bread. Room temp butter is such and easy fix. I find it hard to believe that this late in the game no one has given them this feedback. So that leads me to believe be that they just don't care enough to listen or do anything about it. Really strange that this isn't something they are willing to accommodate.
author: Dave S.

description: What a nice place to have lunch on a Saturday afternoon. Delicious food and excellent service. Our server Susane was amazing, friendly and warm. Next time you are on Castro street, try it out. You won't be disappointed.
author: Harold F.

description: This is my favorite seafood place ever. The Cioppino is the best I've ever had! The oysters are fantastic especially with the sauce they give! Also the staff and atmosphere is fantastic!
author: Sandra J.

description: I went here for my boyfriend's birthday. We ordered a small cioppino and scallops. They were so juicy and yummy! Scallops were literally melting in my mouth..The inside decorations are nice and cozy. Can't wait to go back again!
author: Clara L.

description:
Awesome find in SF. Anchor Oyster Bar is such a cute little spot for a romantic dinner for two or a friends-night-out meal. Super tiny inside, the space only accommodates a small amount of people at a time so the wait can be an hour on average. However long the wait, though, it's worth it. 

Place your name outside on the whiteboard and wait while you sit under the heated awning at Anchor. The wait can be met with interesting people-watching and possibly a few stops in the cute shops located right down the street in the Castro District.

When you do get seated, grab a glass of wine or beer and get ready to eat!

My top picks for dinner:
Crab Caesar Salad (MUST get, loads of fresh crab on top)
Cioppino (holy wow this is good)
Anchor Special of oysters, steamed clams and prawns

Really, everything here is good. And although it's on the pricier side of things, it's worth it. Plus, you will not leave hungry. :)
author: Lori T.

description: This place sucks to say the least. Looong wait. Waited a little over 2 hours to get a seat for 2. Once we were finally inside, it took another hour to get our food. All we ordered was chiopino. For the wait i expected good chiopino. It sucked! No flavor. Inwas very disappointed. If you want the real deal chiopino take a drive down to mosslanding ca near monterey. They have the beeest chiopino for half the price. And you get a salad. Lol. Dont waste your day/night waiting.
author: Fred Z.

description:
Food: 4/5

Portions: 5/5

Venue: 4.5/5 (super small)

Table wait time: 4/5 (average wait time 1 hour)

Food wait time: 5/5

Service: 5/5
author: Briana H.

description: Amazig service and cioppini ...was absolutely DELICIOUS!!!!!!!!  can not wait to go back!!!!
author: Zolzaya G.

description: One of the best Cioppino I've ever had.. people were so friendly... the wait was minimal... caught it just right... lovely experience!
author: George A.

description: Ciopinno was superb! A small one was big enough for two to share.  We also ordered King Salmon and it was delicious.  We got there at 5:51pm on a Monday and waited for about 20 min.  Alex was our server and he was great.
author: Stella K.

description: This was our best lunch in San Francisco, and such a pleasant experience. There was a long wait, but I'm glad we stuck around. We had the crab cake sandwich (may have been a special?), clam chowder, and the shellfish combo. The shellfish was fresh - there was no "fishy" taste or stray sand. The broth was really flavorful. The staff were genuinely kind and relaxed- they never made anyone feel rushed, despite the long wait outside. Great place. Worth the wait.
author: Julia M.

description:
This nautical themed restaurant in the Castro will fulfill all your seafood craving needs! You can easily spot the anchor decorations while walking down Castro St. We were walking by around 4PM on a Sunday and locals were already lining up and recommending we wait around to sign up as soon as they opened. Luckily it wasn't too full by 5:30PM and my party 6 were able to get seated right away (all people must be present before you can have a table).

Our favorite dishes? The CIOPPINO! You can either get a large one to share (good for 2-3 ppl), or get the small one for yourself. Actually you can probably split the small one with another person along with a side dish. The tomato broth was light with a bit of spice. There were lots of prawns, mussels, clams, and crab legs in this dish. The best part was the complimentary garlic bread it came with! Dip the bread into the tomato broth and it's the best thing ever. I'm drooling as I write this review. The WILD PRAWNS plate was also tasty with juicy prawns and steamed veggies. You should also order the RAW OYSTERS and get a mix of them, they were all very sweet and fresh! Basically all the seafood tasted fresh and my boyfriend's family from the east coast enjoyed everything. 

Service was pretty quick and friendly. 

Tips:
- Come early to put your name down
- Small groups work best (max 4-6 ppl because tables are small)
author: Bonnie Z.

description: I like almost everything about this legendary dining spot. I've been here many times. Often can be a long wait because they only do the "name on the blackboard" approach. No problem there... just arrive early and go for a walk around the colorful neighborhood. The menu is limited (a good thing) food is always fresh and professionally prepared... environment is always clean. The wine list certainly lacks luster, so be smart and bring your own. Day Boat Sea Scallops over home made fettuccini, Icelandic Cod in a light creamy wine sauce with amazing roasted winter veggies. Very happy every time I dine here. Lunch too! Just do it.
author: John A.

description: I love this restaurant and have been eating here for many years. Everything is very fresh. I order the cioppino a lot, the oysters, clam chowder and the crab cocktail but this last time a really incredible sea bass. Also like the service that Alex provides.
author: Robert S.

description:
Food: 4 stars
Service: 1 star

We ordered a large cioppino and the anchor special. The bread to soup ratio is very off. The cioppino came with two slices of garlic bread but I could care less for it, given that the bread is soggy and has little to no garlic taste. 

Price: expensive.  You can get the same quality seafood elsewhere at a cheaper price and with much better serve - Hog island and phils fish market to name a few. 

Service: slow. Waitress: rude. Waited for about 30 minutes to be seated. No one comes out to update you for how much longer the wait would be.  After being seated, we waited for another 10 minutes before someone even looked our way. The lady who served us water said the waitress will be right over. We waited for another five minutes.  No waitress still.  The same lady came over again and told us that the waitress will be coming over.  We wait again. At this point, we see two more parties being seated and the waitress takes their order before even coming over to take ours. Now we're annoyed and the same lady noticed it and told the waitress. The waitress then came over to take our order. No apology or acknowledgment whatsoever. The food also came very slowly. The other parties that came after us finished their food before we even got our cioppino.
author: Stinky B.

description:
Supposedly, this place is a staple in the San Francisco Castro district. I decided to stop in for lunch and try their suppose it delicious seafood. I started with your chowder which was absolutely delicious Followed by their crab cakes which lacked quite a bit. The crabcakes were tasteless and boring and not only that very expensive.

Lastly, the staff is not that friendly and tries to jam everybody into the restaurant and even if you're in the middle of the meal I asked you to move over to fit one more person in. I know restaurants have to make money but it shouldn't be to the detriment of those are ready dining. If I was to stop by San Francisco again this will be one place I could do without.
author: Joe G.

description: Good  old school Castro seafood restaurant, great  for a mid-day meal after hanging around Castro, when the lines are shorter and it's easier to get in.
author: Laura D.

description: It was really worth the experience, the sea food was just like Anthony Bouradain said in of his episodes. Incredibly fresh and made with skill. Yes the wait is while, it is a first come first serve, so be prepared to wait for an hour for a table, but its really all worth it. The background the smell the scenery the fisherman culture, you can tell everyone around you is having a good time. I feel like they keep a tradition that keeps it classic and delicious and thats what makes people keep coming back for the experience. Im definitely looking forward to coming back, it was definitely worth it.
author: Ayaa5a S.

description:
Oh my God. We ended up waiting for over an hour but it was WORTH IT! The oysters we had were fantastic and fresh. My fiance loves oysters and says that they were very good (it was my first time and they tasted great but I had nothing to base it on so). We also shared a bottle of fantastic white wine. Of course we got the cioppinno. 

Do yourself a favor and DO NOT MISS OUT ON THE CIOPPINNO. This dish originated in SF so this is a real treat. Delicious, juicy seafood components soaked in a savory tomato broth... one word: divine. The bread they give you is crispy and wonderful to dip in the broth. We were both in awe of our meal. Worth the wait and being super cramped (it's a very small place).
author: Sarah M.

description:
A friend visiting from out of town wanted to try Anchor Oyster Bar due to the high ratings on Yelp. I've had it bookmarked for quite some time but never made an attempt to dine here, mostly because of the long waits and it being a bit out of the way for me. However, I figured a visitor in town is the perfect reason to go! 

We arrived on Sunday at 3:55pm, right before they open. We were 4th in line. Luckily, it was also the same night as the NBA Game 7, so it wasn't busy! 

Between the 3 of us, we ordered 

Boston clam chowder - thick and creamy. No complaints here!

Full order of the Anchor Special - we wanted to get a dozen oysters, but for about $10 more we decided to get the Anchor special which includes a dozen oysters, 4 prawns and a bowl of steamed clams. The oysters were amazing! There were 3 different kinds, and each were delicious. Prawns were a nice size and cooked perfectly, and the clams were tasty as well. Use either the complimentary bread or garlic bread to dunk in the broth!! 

Cioppino - this was what we were most excited about. We ordered the large and it was more than enough for me and 2 guys that have huge appetites. This is a MUST order!! There's a reason why this is their most popular dish. Shrimp, clams, mussels, crab, fish all in the most ridiculous broth. 

Garlic bread - perfect for dunking!!!!! 

Service was extremely friendly.
author: Noelle H.

description:
Cute little oyster bar in the Castro with phenomenal chowder and cioppino. Portion sizes are very generous but as with any seafood joint, prices are on the steeper side. The dungeness crab ceaser salad is loaded with crab and giant bread chunks posing as croutons (yum!). Bread and butter to start and refilled throughout dinner is a plus. Use that bread to soak up the cioppino and chowder! 

Like most places in the city, it's a tiny spot so don't show up with a group larger than 4 and expect to be seated together. The staff was accommodating but the space really can't handle large groups. 

No reservations accepted. Pro tip: go early, put your name on the list, and grab a drink or two in the neighborhood while you wait!
author: Nerri Y.

description:
I teetered between 4 and 5 stars on this because of one thing... price. This place is a little on the steep side. But ultimately, price is something you know going in. And the food was so good, the amount of the check didn't sting so bad after feasting on some great seafood.

As many people have said in their reviews, this place is tiny. I'm not real sure how we got so lucky since we went in the middle of dinner rush on a Thursday night. But after putting our name on the little white board, we were seated in less than 20 minutes. For having meals that require you to wear a bib, the inside was very clean and had a cool vibe to it. The staff was incredibly nice and accommodating.

We started with some oysters, a carafe of wine, and split some of the chowder. Had I known about the feast that was about to ensue, I probably would have held off on the chowder. But since it was so good, I will hold off any regrets. The dozen oysters came with three different types. They were all amazingly fresh and had their own unique flavors. I enjoyed being able to taste a few varieties. I highly recommend. My wife and I decided to split the small Cioppino. The only thing this dish wasn't, was small. Everything else about it was amazing. This was my first time to eat Cioppino, so I don't have anything to compare it to. But if the rest of the places that serve this San Francisco past-time are this good, you should order it wherever you see it on the menu. The broth was so hearty and flavorful, I could have eaten just that by itself. But throw in a bevy of tasty seafood options and you have nothing short of 5 stars. About halfway through eating this, we quickly realized that we needed to turn our focus on the vast amounts of seafood so it won't go to waste. Because that bowl was not dwindling as our full factor was increasing.

Because of so many options of places to eat in the bay area, I'm not sure when my next trip to AOB with be. But when that time does come, I will fully expect another great meal at a slightly steeper price.
author: Will B.

description: Susan is amazing!!!  Hands down best hostess/server on attentiveness to her customers.   Fresh Dungeness crab, exceptional clam chowder,sparkling rosè, and Phil's new favorite beer ... Trumer Pils!!.  It's worth the wait. Put your name on the list, cross the street to Swirl for a glass of wine or beer, then come back to enjoy!!!   this place!
author: Amy F.

description:
Anchor Oyster Bar has been bookmarked for way too long, especially since I live right down the street. I came here to hang out with Nina Y. who ate here before to complete her 7x7 list but was down to have it again. We put our names down and sat outside. Fortunately it was a fairly nice day, but layer-up if it's chilly since there is no space to wait inside. It was about 30 minutes before our names were called, and we were about 3rd or 4th on the list.

We were seated at the table next to the front door. We already had our eye on the cioppino, so we ordered that and also got a caesar salad to start. The salad was alright. Nothing special, though we should have gotten some seafood on top. The cioppino was not the best I've had either, but it was very filling (we split a small size) and the prawns were especially huge! Definitely good to share.

Overall I'm glad I finally got to check this off my list. It was fresh and satisfying! I know I didn't write extra stellar things about the food, but it really is a solid seafood restaurant in the Castro District. Nice for a date night or just to catch up with a friend.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
When in San Francisco, eat seafood...
