However, I got the New Mexican style mahi mahi with brussel sprouts and a salad on top and that's where they disappointed me. They were out of mahi mahi so they made it with salmon. The salmon was perfectly cooked, however I did live in New Mexico and this was a very light version of the sauces I had there. Either way perhaps this would have been better called something else... 

The hubby asked for the bay shrimp cocktail and loved it. His main course was the gulf shrimp with potatoes and broccoli on the side.

Honestly if I were going back again, I would have preferred their oysters and their cioppino...
author: Carolina S.

description:
Quintessential San Franciscan Italian seafood restaurant. Recommended by Erika C., I came here last night to celebrate Dono's birthday. At first, I was dreading the wait and really reconsidered choosing another place after reading the reviews on how long the wait is typically. However, on this Friday night around 7p, it wasn't too crowded yet. It only took around 30 mins until we were seated. A waiter kindly offered samples of clam chowder and blankets while we all waited outside for our tables. 

Once seated, we ordered garlic bread, dozen oysters, crab cake platter w/ side of clam chowder and roasted potatoes, and a small cioppino. We definitely bit off more than we could chew. Dono loved the oysters. They had three different varieties that night. Clam chowder, although not the best after visiting Seattle, is great, not too salty with clam taste. The crab cakes I could have done without. I couldn't taste the crab flavor as the breading was quite overpowering. 

I do highly suggest ordering the garlic bread with the cioppino. They are great complements! For two people, the small cioppino is more than enough! Sadly, because the cioppino came last, we were both too full to eat much of it that we had to pack two tubs of it back home! But the soup was just amazing! Great consistency and depth of flavors, the blend of seafood and tomato flavors... Yum! And don't forget to dip that garlic bread into the soup!
author: Henry P.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Simple, delicious seafood and friendly, down-to-earth staff. You can get San Francisco classics like sand dabs and Cioppino. I often order the combination Louie and the garlic bread is like no other. They don't take reservations. You sign up on the chalk board out front. I return to eat here each time I visit SF.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
The garlic bread lives up to the hype - perfectly crisp crust and a soft center with beautiful nooks full of butter and garlic. Get it. Lots of it. 

We also had oysters and the pasta of the day with mussels. Both were fantastic. Oh and the garlic bread was even better dipped in the fabulous pasta sauce. 

We went right before opening and got in line and were seated immediately. 

Also, It was fun to sit by the kitchen and watch them work their magic!
author: Macy R.

description: Hands down the best cioppino ever!! Nicest people too, did I mention the best cioppino ever?? Period, Ever Period!!
author: F G.

description:
This place is one of the best seafood restaurants in sf. Although its space is so small and always full they make sure ppl enjoy their delicious food after waiting at least  39 min. 

We enjoyed out appetizers and the main dish which was clam and muscle and shrimp fettuccini. It was so balanced and earthy yet hearty with glass of wine and gossip over stuff
author: Tai S.

description: Two times we have come to your restaurant to find it closed during regular business hours.  Wtf? Won't try again,  keep your hours or close altogether.
author: Tula C.

description:
I have only been coming here for 10 years, but I have a sense that this place has remained unchanged for the entire 35+ it's been open. And that is a good thing. I walked by it for years, thinking it was cute (only 5 tables and bar seating), but never ventured in. But once I did, I was hooked.

Again, it's cozy and only seats a few, and most always for dinner - and ALWAYS during the weekend for both lunch and dinner - there is a wait. They do not accept reservations. There is a white board outside where you leave your name on the list. And sorry if it's cold - this place is too small for you to wait inside. Often though, they'll bring out cups of chowder for its enduring patrons. 

After 10 years, I have had most everything on the fixed menu. And they have a daily changing menu, so you can always try something new. 

The fixed menu has a selection of fresh shellfish, salads, chowder, crab cakes, a cracked Dungeness crab (seasonally), and an (expensive) cioppino. You cannot lose with anything on this menu! If it's your first visit and you're with friends, I recommend the Anchor Special (12 oysters, 8 steamed clams, 4 chilled prawns) or the truly stellar (SF's own!) cioppino. Both are great for sharing. In fact, you kind of *have* to share the cioppino, it's huge!

I am also a recent convert to the salads, which never seemed that interesting 'on paper, but they really highlight the freshness and quality of the seafood. The shrimp salad (with lots of blue cheese dressing) is my go-to. 

They keep it simple on the daily changing menu - generally the day's selection of oysters and wines, a simple fish dish (usually a baked fillet), a shellfish pasta, maybe a special cioppino or stew, maybe the crab burger, maybe the crab-shrimp-cheese open faced sandwich. I won't call anything out, because I have had them all, and they're all great.

The success of this place is SIMPLICITY and FRESHNESS. The food is quality and fresh, the preparations are simple, everything is well presented. This place is probably in my TOP FIVE of SF haunts I could not do without.

If you have to use the bathroom, you're in luck (I guess) - you have to go through the tiny kitchen to get to the tiny bathroom, so you get to see the cooking in action. Really, the kitchen is small enough where you could get burnt. Be careful!
author: Corey M.

description: Wow!!!!!!! We enjoyed our dinner and wine at The Anchor Oyster Bar!!! For sure we will return in the future!!
author: Naima G.

description: Five Star Plus from me!  My server Robin & Justin couldn't have been more professional yet friendly & the food was terrific. I rushed down from Martinez to eat here, hitting more Monday night traffic than I expected, luckily finding a parking space directly across the street. Still they close at 10:00 p.m., at least according to Yelp & I walked in a few minutes before 10 thinking I may be out of luck but Robin said no problem so I sat at the counter, ordering great a cup of delicious chowder & small Cioppino that I'm capitalizing (C) it was so full of seafood, most in the shell from crab, clams, two kinds of mussels & giant prawns plus lots of fish. The broth was too good!  Also must mention the regular bread & garlic bread that later topped the Cioppino. So much fresh-tasting seafood I couldn't finish!  When I arrived home & unpacked my 'to go' I was pleasanly surprised by a couple of extras that are delicious. Guess it sometimes pays to be the last customer out, LOL.  Had a great conversation with Justin who I found to be an interesting fellow. Unsure if he is the manager. Not assuming, but he definitely knows his business. Neither he or Robin rushed me, something that's happened at other Bay Area restaurants near closing in my 40 years in the area, my first 15 in SF, the rest never more than 25 miles east. I tend to be over solicitous of restaurant personnel because I used to own Joshua's, an espresso & Bud's ice cream shop on Polk near Sutter, late 70's & early 80's that was there until around 1991. Now it's the left side of Vertigo. Plus my son Jordan is a SF  restaurant attorney. We are both attuned to what it's like working in a bar or eatery. All I can say is the Cioppino that may appear expensive is worth every penny. Mmm...
author: Joshua C.

description: I ordered their large cioppino for pickup. I love this place but not for pickup. Came home to find that they didn't put fish, it only came with 2 pieces of shrimp, 3 pieces of small scrap crab,  and full off mussels and clams!  What's going on?! I love that the broth wasn't as salty as other times. I expected the same quality and amount  of seafood items when ordering for pick up but that was not the case.
author: Tina T.

description:
Yelp can be the greatest thing!

My BF was craving clam chowder while we were in San Francisco. We had enjoyed my kind of food earlier (Asian) and now it was time for his kind of food (American). I'm not from San Francisco so I do not know where the best clam chowder is - I just know where the most famous is. 

I really wanted to make sure he got his wish fulfilled!

I'm sure you know what comes next. Yes! I checked Yelp. I looked for the best clam chowder nearest to the Castro and Anchor Oyster Bar came up. It is nothing short of amazing that such a great restaurant is in this neighborhood since the Castro is plagued with mediocre restaurants - most of them on Castro are 3.5 stars or less. Anchor truly stands out!

When we got there we saw there were people waiting outside of the restaurant. It's that good! We didn't feel like waiting regardless of what Yelp said about how good the restaurant was so we walked up and down Castro looking for restaurants that were not empty or that were not 3.5 and less according to Yelp. We found nothing else! We were about to get pizza when I decided to remind my BF he was craving clam chowder - so we walked up to the Anchor again and found out they had called our name already. No problem - one of the Anchor guys told us we would not wait much more than 15 minutes to be called again so we waited and chatted with some cool chicks from Toronto. They called our name in maybe 20 minutes.

Anchor is small. It's kind of a tight squeeze. Let's just say it's a place to get cozy with your neighbor. There's a bar and tables. The decor is not remarkable. That is, unless you find a simple real looking mackerel and that sort of thing on the wall to be a work of art.

First off, they brought us bread and butter. The bread was nothing to write home about. As an appetizer we ordered the combination cocktail which includes shrimp, prawns and crab. They are served with a side of red sauce and horseradish. The guy that took our order explained to us that the cocktail was a 40's (or 30's) style dish. It was quite fresh, tasty and not fishy at all! We both ordered the crabcakes which came with a cup of clam chowder (about $25). Both these items were fabulously delicious! Everything was so fresh! We also had some great local white wine.

Our server was really nice and attentive. She made sure we had water often. We even got a show from the dishwasher who was playing wine glasses full of water like as if they were musical instruments. He looked to see if anyone noticed and smiled when he saw we were watching.

Parking is a real problem here but we took the BART so we had no problem getting here. 

I'm glad I insisted that we come here even after my BF had given up on this place because he was so hungry and didn't want to wait! This place is a gem with a lot of character!
author: Miguel R.

description:
The next time you're on your period and craving some boring soup, come here and try the cioppino instead! The broth is similar in color to menstrual blood, but this isn't the only reason to order it - it's piled sky-high with quality seafood and accompanied by cheesy garlic bread that tastes like pizza when dipped in the tomato base. 

A smaller order of cioppino is sufficient for two people and leaves just enough stomach room for a couple of appetizers. The crab-stuffed artichoke is divine! I also recommend the oysters if you're looking to get riled up for some bloody post-meal boom boom.
author: Suany W.

description: Went because the oyster festival was way packed and we wanted oysters. The 4 stars isn't for the $36 oysters for 12 (way too pricey and nothing to write home about, not here either). The clam chowder was good, not great either. The 4 stars is for the steamed clams, they were absolutely amazing, nice and meaty and the broth was soooo tasty - make sure you ask for extra bread to soak it up., I'd go back just for the clams.
author: Perry C.

description:
Even when I'm right I'm wrong in her eyes. And when I'm wrong, well, she's right. So it's always a win-win for her.

So when she tells me that I like the crab cakes here better than Woodhouse, well, instead of arguing that I don't...I just politely nod and agree to keep the peace.

I've never had the free clam chowder for waiting in line here. Nor have I ever been right when debating a topic with her here.

The only thing we agree on is the food. We both love the food here. Oysters, crab cakes...clam chowder...well maybe not the clam chowder or crab cakes. She says Woodhouse is better. I say okay.

So we can agree on the oysters....and that the world is round....
author: Jack R.

description: Really delicious cioppino! The wait is long, but worth it! My husband and I had a fun time talking with people while we waited. Cute little ambience...very informal. We even hit up a wine bar across the street to pass the time during our 1.5 hr wait. Skip the oyster shooter...the oyster was in a really bland tomato based sauce.
author: Andrea T.

description: Great food but the restaurant is slow and inefficient by design. One server for the entire restaurant and they take forever to get to you. They should modernize in some way instead of just trying to be small and exclusive.
author: Michael E.

description: I split a steamed shellfish combo and a small cioppino with the boyfriend. The portions were huge and it was a struggle to finish it all. The sauce for both were delicious and the garlic bread that came with the cioppino was the bomb. I tried to ask for a garlic bread basket but they were running low on garlic bread so we were unfortunately not able to get more bread :( The only thing that I wasn't as fond of was the clam chowder. I was expecting a more thick consistency and more flavor and I thought it lacked taste and was a little too soupy.
author: Christina C.

description:
Come at an off hour so that you won't have to wait long! 

I usually share the garlic bread and cioppino (small) with 2-3 people. Garlic bread is toasted and flavorful, and great for dipping in the cioppino. They have great specials as well - scallops are always perfect! Only thing I was so-so on was the house wine. I thought it was a good deal but it was a little disappointing. I would upgrade to a different one next time.
author: Janelle K.

description:
Too small of a seafood spot to enjoy a nice dining experience - especially during peak hours.  The leg room was too close to the person across from me and next to me.  Every time you wanted to get out of your chair, there was hardly space to move your chair back, in order to stand up.  I didn't like it all.  It is a hole-in-the-wall seafood spot and they really need to expand.  

On top of that, the servers were bickering on and off because there was a lot of people waiting for seats outside the clear window.  It was an unpleasant sight to see.

Oysters were mediocre and just the sight of my surrounding during my dining time I was there, didn't balance off the specialty of what this place wants to be positively portrayed as. 

I waited here.  I felt crammed in this narrow place. I felt rushed here.  I'm outta here!  

Next.
author: Tiffany D.

description: I have to add that the staff was very friendly and fast. Just wasn't impressed with the quality of the oysters or the oyster shot for a specialty oyster place.
author: Hollie M.

description: Yay, not so wonderful. The cioppino, which is hyped, was bland and the crab was badly overcooked. Like so bad I couldn't finish and I LOVE crab.  The clam chowder rocks. Stick with that
author: Dina L.

description:
Everything was delicious! We split the half order of oysters, shrimp, and clams, a bowl of clam chowder, and the crab cake dinner, and we were stuffed after.

There was a bit of a wait but not too bad for a Friday night since the Warriors were playing. The prices were a bit steep too but worth it for the quality. The service was very friendly. Next time we'll come back for theCioppino.
author: Alisha K.

description: Lunch is the BEST time to check out the spot! There usually isn't much of a wait and there are always yummy specials on the menu.  Me? Well, I kinda stick with what I always do - the Combination Seafood Salad - #LovesMeSomeIt
author: Nick S.

description:
I've been here a half dozen times and was never disappointed in any way. I often order the cioppino because no other restaurant makes it better. In addition to the excellent seafood, the wine selection is great. The shellfish are always excellent.
I usually go in the mid afternoon to avoid any wait for a table. This place is worth re-arranging your schedule for.
The menu choices are very focused which might be a negative for you if you're looking for a wide variety.
author: Amelia K.

description: A small and cute restaurant with only about a dozen things on the menu. If you are looking for a great safe spot, or a place for an intimate dinner, this place is great. Fresh seafood creates a line out the door, so don't come here If you are in a hurry.
author: Ross S.

description:
It was my second time to Anchor and it was equally as amazing as it was years ago. 

Had the cup of clam chowder which was nice and creamy and full of big chunks. 

For dinner, we ordered the Cioppino and a dozen fresh oysters. Firstly, the oysters were amazing. It was a mix of 3 varieties and they tasted so fresh and good! The Cioppino is a clam and crab stew with some veggies and spices that is just amazing. The broth is a nice mix between thick and watery full of flavor and the mix of seafood is all cooked perfectly. A small order shared between two people can be a perfect portion. 

The service was great and friendly, the venue is small but very intimate and creates a nice atmosphere. Pay this place a visit, it's absolutely worth it.
author: Armando S.

description:
I would say this is the best sea food in SF I had so far. 
I'm highly recommended people to put on their name on the chalkboard as soon as they arrive. It could be cold to wait outside. They are very consideration to bring the customers clam cheddar soup! 

Go there for your sea food cravings, it won't never let you down!

Note: The dog has to wait outside.... Just not enough seating. Maybe only have five something tables and bar area. Small but delicious... Cola would understand!
author: Wen Hsia C.

description:
Pro:

The long hour wait was worthwhile! There are only 4 dinning tables that can accommodate a party of 2+ so if you are coming with a large party, avoid the peak hours!

You must get the cioppino here! It is basically a seafood party on the bowl (and in your mouth!) 

Con:
Service was slow as it was hard to get the waiter's attention but once you have his/her attention, they were nice and friendly. Because the restaurant isn't big, it got really noisy, making it hard to carry a conversation. The bathroom also was only accessible through the kitchen.
author: Linda K.

description:
This is my first review on Yelp ever and I'm only doing so because I had one of the worst dining experiences here....

Food was good but the service not so much.
The older lady who served us made me feel so uncomfortable, she was rude and unpleasant, didn't want to answer questions about the menu, overall making it hard to enjoy my food. On my way out she ran into me saying excuse me in a very harsh and impolite way. I was so shocked at how she treated a paying customer but given the number of 4 and 5 star reviews they have on Yelp, she could care less if they lost a customer to bad service.
author: Katrina C.

description:
The restaurant is small, with seating for maybe 20-24 people at full capacity. When we walked up, we placed our name and time of arrival on a white board, and the staff calls the people on a first come first serve basis. 

Once seated, the staff is very friendly and helpful. Turns out we almost ordered too much food, and the kind waitress stopped us (!), and suggested we do 1/2 order of a few of the dishes. The menu is limited, and we were hoping they prepare the dishes they offer well. It did not disappoint in the least. 

We love seafood, and we like to try whatever we can when we see a good spot. So we ordered:
- the crab cakes, (mine was a little burned, but the rest was so good, I didn't dock for it) 
- the black mussels, which were plump and fresh and quite tasty, if a bit too citrusy (which we did 1/2 order of, thankfully)
- a few oysters, I am a huge fan, and they were amazingly fresh and firm and flavorful 
- and delicious garlic bread, which we dipped into the broth from the mussels. 

And then the star of the evening arrived. Thankfully the waitress suggested we go with the small! The cioppino. The tomato broth was divine with different sized mussels (a few humongous and a good amount of the regular sized), and crab legs, and clams, and fish, along with spices and garlic and tomatoes. A few slices of garlic bread lay beautifully on top of the dish. It was a shame not to finish it or have the ability to take home as we were staying at a hotel room. 

All in all this little restaurant pleasantly surprised us. It turns out it's been around since 1977 and I hope it's still standing when we get into town next time. It's absolutely worth a trip to, even if you do not reside in the immediate vicinity or are not staying in a hotel nearby.
author: Olya A.

description:
I'm not an oyster or even a seafood expert but I know delicious and fresh food when I taste it. This was a wonderful example. A very small but quaint place, you literally walk past the chefs to get to the restrooms. It's a little odd at first but then you quickly realize it somehow works. 

Friendly staff and the owner even handed me a bib knowing the messy entree coming my way. We ordered the Cioppino- a delicious and hot Italian tomato stew with crab, clams, mussels, and cod all seasoned beautifully. We couldn't stop eating.
author: Paul K.

description:
So glad I came here instead of the tourist trap fisherman wharf's! 

*My family came around lunch on a weekday and there were actually no seats available, so we took the bar seat instead and I had a full view of the kitchen! :) 

*Staff was incredibly friendly and attentive. 

-Boston Clam Chowder (cup) - $4.25: 
If you prefer a heavier and thicker clam chowder, I don't think you would enjoy this. The clam chowder had this amazing aroma the moment it arrived to the table. It was amazingly delicious, really creamy yet not too rich and the chowder had nice chunks of clam and hearty potatoes. 

-12 oyster half shell - $34.95: 
For oysters we got half and half of Wellfleet and Quivet oysters that the restaurant offer on the special menu. I can't remember which one is which.. and I'm no oyster-expert but I believe the plump ones are wellfleet oysters. Nonetheless, they were very fresh and sweet, and the accompany sauces were delish! 

-Steamed Greenlip mussels - $20.95: 
 I'm not sure what were the broth here, but from my observation of the cooking process, it seemed to be made with a white wine and garlic broth. Mussels were cooked to perfection while slightly fall off the shells. The broth was light and complimented the mussels. 

-Cioppino (large) - $59.95: MUST ORDER. 
Holy, for $60 the portion was humongous, it can easily be shared between 5 - 6 people! The cioppino included a lot of perfectly cooked seafood, with clams, mussels, a few crab legs and large chunks of white fish. Although the broth was lacking in salt, I liked how you can truly taste the seafood base and mixture of herbs, unlike the ones I have had in Toronto where it was just bland tomato based broth. And oh god, the garlic bread was amazing, crunchy crust but soft and had a generous amount of buttery garlic spread. It was perfect to dip the leftover seafood broth.......
author: Anh T.

description:
Really all I need to say about this place is "The wait is well worth it." You will wait, yes...it's a tiny tiny place, and there's a line nearly every minute they're open. But once you taste the food, you'll agree with my statement. Literally everything on the menu is extraordinary. I've never been disappointed with the food here.

For those who complain that Anchor doesn't seat them in the order they are on the sign-in sheet, space is so limited that a party of two will get seated before a party of three if only two seats are available, etc. And if your entire party is not present, they will not seat you. I believe they're absolutely fair about seating.
author: Edna T.

description:
Food: 10/10
Atmosphere: 8.5/10 
Service: 9/10
Overall experience: 9.5/10

One of the best parts of being a tourist is being able to experience the best of what food a city has to offer. We were not (and I could not ever imagine being) disappointed with Anchor Oyster Bar.

We had heard great things and ended up waiting 1.5 hours to get into the tiny joint. It was a cooler night and they brought out fresh and piping hot clam chowder to keep us warm. Love it!

When we finally got in, we ordered:
- oysters 
- garlic shrimp (this wasn't on the menu, but they whipped it up for us on their recommendation that the shrimp in was very fresh. Brownie points for customization!)
- the small cioppino

The oysters were great. Succulunt and very, very fresh. The shrimp was good, but my mouth is watering just thinking about the cioppino. It is a seafood lover's dream - filled with so many types. They do not scrimp on portions either. I shared with one other person and we were stuffed!

The restaurant itself is very quaint and lovely. The only reason it got knocked down from a 9/10 is because we were seated at the bar and had a viewing of the dishwasher the whole time. No complaints though - I was delirious eating the food!

THE BOTTOM LINE: You like seafood? You'll LOVE this place.
author: Kristen C.

description:
We came here on a Sunday around 4ish. And it's a small momma & pop shop. There is a sign in board listed right outside the door. Name, how many people in your party, and the time you sign in. We waited around 30 minutes for a party of 5 before getting seated. It's a pretty small shop. So I wouldn't recommend coming in a super big group. But great for a date or a little get together.

As we look at the menu, there were a lot of choice. But we really came here for the Cioppino & Fresh Oyster. Our sever was very helpful in helping us choose what we wanted. We couldn't decided how many oysters we wanted to order , so he recommended that we order 15 oysters. Since there 5 of us and get to try 1 of each kind they had. We also decided to order a pasta dish. 

Fresh Oyster - $2.75 Each
The choices we had for the fresh oysters were, Washington Zen, Hog Island Sweetwaters, & Cape Cod Quivets Oysters. Out of all three, my favorite would be the cape cod. In my opinion, it was the sweetest.

Pasta choice of the day $26.95
Served with Dayboat Sea Scallops & Baby Spinach in Lemon Cream Sauce. Coincidentally there were five scallops on the plate to match the five of us at the table an easy divide. No need to add anything else as the lemon cream didn't over over the scallop which made it perfect as is. 

Cioppino - $54.95 Large/ $33.95 Small
Our server was very helpful when we couldn't decide on getting 2 small plate or 1 large. Good thing her bought out the two plate so we could compare. And we ended up getting the Large for the 5 of us. And if your a seafood lover. This dish is bombdotcom. Typically a combination of Dungeness crab, clams, shrimp, scallops, squid, mussels, and fish all sourced from the Pacific Ocean. The seafood is then combined with fresh tomatoes in a wine sauce, and served with toasted bread. But I don't remember seeing scallop nor squid in our dish. Also they ran out of crab legs. So it was replaced with just peeled ones. But overall. This dish was on point. And me and my sister are taking our parent here on there anniversary. 

But I gave this place 5/5 stars because the service, food, & atmosphere was welcoming. Would most definitely recommend this place to friends and family.
author: Tam D.

description: There is always a line and it's worth the wait. The seafood is fresh, their cioppino amazing, and service is great. Space is quite small, so I'd say it's hard to come here with large parties.
author: Francis B.

description:
This is my favorite place to eat in San Francisco. The cioppino is unbelievably good. Frankly, so is everything else, but they can wait until after you've tried the cioppino. Just get it. Now. 

Service is always friendly and attentive. The wait can be long because it's small and popular.
author: Steve P.

description:
We drive two hours every few months just to eat here. This place is amazing...tiny but the food is fantastic. My personal favorite is the chioppino. We've had it at some pretty amazing Italian restaurants in SF but I prefer it from AOB. It's brothy & flavorful & oh so delicious. There's no pasta in it to fill you up because there's so much seafood, pasta is unnecessary. They top it off with their delightful cheesy roasted garlic bread. There are two sizes now, reg $35 & large $55. I could probably eat the smaller one by myself if I were really really hungry & wore stretchy pants. Most girls would probably be better off sharing it. The larger one is definitely big enough for three people. The oyster platter is also amazing, as is the steamed clams. 


    Do not be put off by how small this place is. What they lack in space, they make up for in customer service & quality. Which means that you should expect to pay a bit more for phenomenal seafood and you may have to wait also. Do yourself a favor and wait. They often bring out samples to those waiting, so it's definitely worth your time.

    Came back to AOB with family from Chicago who had never even heard of chioppino & it blew their minds. They were amazed by the phenomenal customer service & the food. We ordered a small AND a large chioppino & the steamed shellfish platter so we had leftovers. I took them home to my parents AND they were amazed at how delicious it was the next day. Don't forget to order some garlic bread too.
author: Patricia J.

description:
Waiting in a long line for a restaurant can test your emotional fortitude. One of your friend is a hungry whiner and your other friend ALWAYS know of a good place nearby. It takes a real standup guy to hold down the fort and wait. 

Anchor Oyster will reward you handsomely for your patience. Like literally. They pass out free clam chowder for those who are waiting. It's good chowder too, and at the very least, your friends will ease the bickering. 

But the real reward is inside, for when you are finally seated. Anchor has fresh seafood that can rival the mightiness of the Chinese Steamed Fish. They really focus on the natural tastes of their dishes. Order the oysters and the clams and they'll bring your taste buds Under the Sea to meet Ariel the Little Mermaid. 

The dish that really brings it home is of course the Cioppino. Never mind pronouncing the word, just enjoy the food. It's a seafood broth with a slightly spicy tomato base. I don't enjoy cracking crab shells, so I just contented myself with the crabjuice infused broth.

Great things come to those who wait. Just ignore your buddies and don't mind the hate.    : )
author: Ringo M.

description:
Was with my friend all day on a rare 80F and sunny day in the City, and both still full from lunch.  I figure hey, oysters are pretty good and light right?  Let's come to Anchor, which I know is excellent.  Except it's on Castro Street...on the weekend after the Supreme Court decided (mostly) in favor of gay marriage.  Yeah, let's just say getting here was a pain in the ass and then some.  But after being stuck on Church Street for two hours and waiting in line for one hour, is it still worth it? HELL YES IT IS.

And yeah, so much for just oysters.  Don't get me wrong, the oysters were exquisite.  Had the Hog Island Kumamotos, Washington Tottens, and New Brunswick French Kisses (these were the best of the bunch IMO).  But if I took THAT damn long to get here, we gotta go deep.  My friend got the cioppino, small variety.  Yeah, if that's small, then I don't want to know what large is (actually I did see someone order the large size, let's just say it's about the size of a tank).  I'm a sucker for cod, and one of the specials of the day was cod with the most awesome tomato basil butter sauce.  Seriously, I could eat anything with that sauce: fish, beef, burritos, maybe even fruit.

Last note: their service is BEYOND FANTASTIC.  While we were waiting in line, I can understand why they were initially hesitant to give us some ice water.  There's like 10,000 people outside celebrating, I don't blame them at all.  But once they figured that out, they were super cool.  Plus I was talking to the chefs who made the tomato basil butter sauce, asked them what it was made of.  Not only did they tell me, they actually offered some sauce for me to take home.  And it wasn't a small cup or anything, they gave me enough to last for a good 2-3 meals.  MUCH APPRECIATION!  Seriously, you can't buy that level of service anywhere.

Love love love this place, I just wish it weren't so small so that the wait doesn't take forever.
author: Alexander Y.

description:
The best Cioppino ever! It's really good. 
I loved the Cioppino from Chez Panisse Cafe (https://www.yelp.com/biz/chez-panisse-cafe-berkeley), and I think the Cioppino from Ancho Oyster Bar might surpass Alice Walter's recipe.

This place do not take a reservation, and I usually do not prefer to wait for dine in, but I think it worth to wait for.
author: May T.

description: This is an unbeatable leader in seafood choices on Castro. Cioppino is piece or art and tastes deliciously. The only drawback is a wait list but hey this is what great food is all about! I'll be back in no time
author: Vadim O.

description:
Living in the landlocked Cleveland (no, I'm not counting Lake Erie) makes me crave seafood like you won't believe. Visiting Anchor Oyster Bar was very obviously the highlight of my trip to SF. 

The restaurant is adorable (sailor themed), and very very small. I would recommend getting there ASAP if you don't want to eat your arm in anticipation. The three of us wrote our names down about 5:20pm on a Saturday night, ran across the street for a quick cocktail and came back. We were seated by about 6:30pm - not bad! Totally worth the wait. Hell I would have easily waited two hours for this meal.

We ate like little piggies. Everything was so GD delicious: oyster shots (non-alcoholic, the best bloody mary I've ever had and I hate bloody mary's), fresh oysters (Cape Cod, Seattle, and some local ones), crab (cooked to perfection and served simply with butter and lemon), clam chowder (pretty decent but soon forgotten due to everything else being so good), and...the Cioppino. The Cioppino was simply divine. Mussels, clams, crab, fish, shrimp in a perfect garlicky-tomato-y broth. The garlic bread that came with it was sinfully delicious. I'm salivating all over my keyboard just thinking about it. And the small portion was definitely enough for 2-3 people. 

Our server was super friendly, funny, and attentive. He threw in an extra bowl of chowder when he saw my friend and I splitting one and said, "no one should share a bowl of chowder!" What a sweetie.
author: Nivedita B.

description:
Thank god we came at an "off" time. We showed up at 2-3p and were lucky enough to snag one of only a couple seats in this uber tiny joint. Come 4p I noticed the line forming outside.

Since we were in the middle of lunch and dinner we decided to split the sampler platter. Excellent choice I do say so myself. 

It came with some of the largest and freshest shrimp I've ever had, plus excellent cocktail sauce to boot. Then of course, a delicious assortment of oysters. The last was the clams that came with an amazing lemon flavored broth. 

I only wish I had known I'd be reviewing such a glorious broth, or I wouldn't have already scarfed down like three pieces of bread prior. I had I stop myself from soaking up a whole loaf in that broth. It was probably the winner out of all three of the items. Although it's hard to compare fresh oysters... Never mind, I won't. Everything was excellent and I'm happy we were able to get in!
author: Rachel C.

description:
Fine dining in the Castro, who knew?
And for all Seafood lovers, this cozy little place has always been warm and welcoming . . . and delicious.
author: Brady Y.

description:
Simple and delicious.
Their steamed shellfish mix was over the moon delicious (flavor all packed into the soup) and their clam chowder is the best I've ever had.

The place is extremely small and the wait for dinner was 45-60min for a party of 3.
Three couples were able to be seated before us since there are 8 spots open at the bar style seating, so I suppose it'll be quicker if you went with one other person. Regardless, the food was so worth it.
While we were waiting outside, a waiter was so kind and gave us small cups of their clam chowder!
author: Kathy W.

description:
I wish this place was little bit bigger so I can go there more often ! Every time I tried to go back, I just could not get a sit (usually 1hr+ wait).. With that said, I will not give up on this place and will go back soon !

Anchor oyster is worth the multiple attempts to go back. Coming from East Coast, I took pride in being a oyster snob, so I scoffed at the idea of West coast oyster. This place, not only proved me wrong, but converted me into west coast oyster lover. But that was not the highlight of the night. We order their cioppino, which after a year I still have a dream about. We had some leftover, so we had that the next day, and it still tasted wonderful. I highly recommend the cioppino and their shrimp pasta, if they have it. I will definitely return to this place, hopefully in near future ;)
author: Amy C.

description:
Pretty decent seafood at this socially inviting establishment.  I had the Cioppino which was pretty good.  I highly recommend the starter platter with clams, oysters, and jumbo prawns.

Service was mostly spot on.  The wine was excellent as were the oyster shooters.  Also enjoyed the atmosphere of Anchor Oyster Bar.  Just very relaxing with perfect temperature but lively and friendly all around.

Look forward to coming here again sometime.

Realistically, this place will set you back $60/person after all is said and done.
author: Tony U.

description: This place is spectacular! I'm almost ashamed to admit it and let others know about it. Small little restaurant with great service. Oysters are fresh and daily special pasta was to die for! Go for a late lunch and avoid the wait.
author: Diana S.

description: So I finally had the Cioppino here. It was delicious. Lots of crab, clams, mussels, shrimp and a very savory broth. I will be back again for another taste of this!
author: Kenson K.

description:
AMAZING seafood. I never leave a seafood place stuffed, and if I do it usually comes at the cost of quality. Anchor provided quality seafood, quantity, AND value - it was amazing! There was a line and we waited about 45 minutes at 6:30pm which isn't too bad. But you could get lucky, the line fluctuates and alot of times people don't show up when their name is called.

I shared one Mussels Entree ($18.24) - 5 STARS: I would recommend ordering it half Greenlip (large mussels) and half black mussels (small, sweet mussels). Both were super fresh but I recommend doing half-half because I thought I would love the smaller mussels since I like small oysters, but the larger oysters were more palatable to me. There was something that almost reminded me of liver with the smaller ones, hard to describe, but I think the larger ones are more mild in flavor. It is simmered in a deliciously fragrant broth, probably made mostly of butter and fresh Italian herbs. I believe there was also some crack laced in there. Amazing.

Clam Chowder Bowl ($6.50) - 4.5 STARS: This was delicious, fresh, and perfectly creamy. I have to give 4.5 stars just because my favorite clam chowder in SF goes to Hog Island, which is New England style but still alot lighter. I would recommend getting the bowl over the cup because it's so much better value for an extra $2 or so.

Cioppino - 4 stars: Great tomato based broth, but prefer the taste and freshness of the mussels. 

Linguini and Shrimp - 3 stars: standard. Shrimp were large but tasted a bit bleachy. 

Crab Cake Entree w/Clam Chowder Cup ($25.95) - 3 STARS: I really don't like crab cakes, but I tried some of a friends and it was good ... I guess? Really rich if you're into that kind of thing. Also, wasn't a fan of the side salad and potatoes.

Garlic Bread ($5.95) - 5 STARS: You could tell they didn't use stale bread, it was super fresh, toasted, and baked with a generous amount of butter and garlic. Delicious.
author: Jess C.

description:
Oh my god I love oysters!!!

Came to Anchor Oyster expecting to wait for a while but actually got sat down right as we entered the door. 

Got drinks rather quickly and good came out delicious with oysters, prawns, and steamed clams.

Nothing like a good Saturday lunch with some fresh oysters.
author: Jay S.

description: The lines are always long for a reason! I thought I would see if going solo would make the wait shorter last Saturday but no such luck on that particular day. After watching a party of two get seated ahead of me, I complained to the hostess.  I think her name is Susan. She is delightful! She immediately diffused my crabbiness by being empathic, responsive and kind. She brought me a complimentary cup of clam chowder and promptly seated me as soon as the next counter seat was available.  Really amazing customer service and the staff is cheerful and accommodating despite the close quarters. Oh, and the food is delicious BTW! One word: Cioppino!
author: Peggy F.

description: I can not say enough good things about this place.  It has some of the freshest seafood I have ever had.  I would rank it right up with Swans Oyster Depo.  It has a great neighborhood feel and the staff are so friendly and have been there for decades.  There are not a lot of seats, so get there early if you can, or you may have to wait.  But it is the Castro so you will have friendly people to sit and talk to while waiting.
author: Rich D.

description: FRESH. Enough said. Prices high. But you pay for great ambiance, service and quality. Coming back, again and again!
author: Elsa S.

description: Delicious! We had clam chowder in a bowl. Not fish. Very flavorful and yummy. We had half of anchor special mmmmmm~ oysters, clams, and prawns. Finished with mixed seafood deliciousness.. my goodness. It's good with their bread. :)
author: Peace Julie L.

description:
The wait is horrendous because it feels like forever this time dinning here. However, it is all worth it because everything was delicious! I was glad I had not given up on the wait and just go elsewhere to eat. 

Service was wonderful and so was the environment. Also words cannot discribe how good the food is. I will for sure come back monthly just to devour everything again. Especially the steam claims... the sauce is soo addicting!
author: Fuki D.

description: Everything about this wonderful establishment is superlative; from the freshness and preparation of the seafood to the polite and dedicated serving staff.  I do not know of another seafood restaurant in San Francisco that deserves five stars.  There are many good places, but none can come up to the standards set by the Anchor Oyster Bar!
author: David C.

description: The ciopinno is legendarily satisfying, thick with tomatoes and packed to the brim with crab, fish, freakishly large mussels and clams. One of the better restaurants in the entire city.
author: Liam S.

description: It's a nice neighborhood seafood place but I would plan on spending at least three hours to eat here. Waited an hour to get in and then another hour to get our meal after ordering. Unfortunately, by the time I got the food I was in a rush to leave so I didn't enjoy my experience. I thought maybe it was just us feeling this way but the guest to our left were also commenting how long it took just to get a waiter to take their order. It seemed like they had three bussers and one server who was taking orders and running food and checks for the whole restaurant. The couple to our right had trouble just flagging down the one waitress to make a request. They'd probably turn more tables quicker if they had one more server. Or if the bussers did more than just fill drinks and clean tables. Just a very inefficient flow, at least from what I saw. Unfortunately, I would have to have a lot of patience to return here again.
author: Renee L.

description: Absurd 2 hour wait. Old waitress with long salt and pepper hair was very rude to our party. Threw a napkin into one of my party's take out. Didn't bother to apologize. She was very talkative with other patrons she obviously knew. The young brunette waitress is nice the two times we've been there.
author: Tiffany N.

description: Birthday dinner here was amazing! Crab Cesar Salad with giant garlic bread croutons is the best thing on the menu! No wait!! The Chipiono is!!!! All so amazing! Well worth the wait! True San Francisco gem!
author: Lucas M.

description: Probably one of the best meals I have ever had. We ordered too much but it was worth it. We had clam chowder a Caesar salad and a large ciopino. The must haves are the salad and the ciopino. Best Caesar salad I disnt know they could taste this good the croutons were to die for and the dressing was so flavorful. The ciopino was layered with flavor and the seafood was excellent we actually left some because we were traveling. This will be my forst stop when I'm in the city.
author: Trina D.

description:
I love this spot! It's super tiny but worth the wait. Not for big groups... Me plus one slid right in to the bar seats! Great spot for speedy service. 


Clam chowder is New England style and to die for. Had green lip mussels which are huge in a yummy garlic broth. Hands down, best Caesar salad I've had in my life-- something about their homemade dressing & the perf amount of cheese. Just for that I'll be back for the salad and try the chiopinno.
author: Grennan K.

description: Oh my... words cannot describe the Cioppino! Me and my boyfriend came her on a Thursday night around 9PM, an hour before closing and there was only about a seven minute wait. One of the waitress saw that I looked chilly so she brought us a little sample of calm chowder to keep us warm. The service here is just amazing. My boyfriend got the New England Seafood  Stew and I got the Small Cioppino. To start off the small Cioppino is HUGE! There is no way I could finish this on my own but the flavor a were OUT OF THIS WORLD, definitely the best Cioppino ever! This really is a must order. I am completely obsessed, cannot wait to go back!!!
author: Eileen H.

description: Expect to wait about an hour an half to two hours to get a table but well worth the wait.  It's a quaint little spot in the Castro district of SF. The food is amazing! I ordered the Anchor special (1/2 order open oysters, prawns, steamed clams in a garlic butter broth to die for!) and clam chowder. Service was great too. If I'm ever in SF again, I will definitely be coming back to try more!
author: Darlene F.

description:
We got here at 4pm when the restaurant just opened. We put our name on the list and went across the street to the bar. After an hour we come back and were in the line for 45 more mins because they had no space for 3 people...
I have no idea that it's $$ place, it's very pricy and they don't have so many options in the menu. 
We were waiting for service 15 mins. It's really hard to get attention of the waiter.
The food was good but doesn't worth of long wait and that horrible service. 
Never back again.
author: Anastasia N.

description:
If you're hungry, DON'T go at a peak time! 

Because the venue is so small, the waits can be rather long, so do yourself a favor. To ensure you don't miss this gem of a restaurant with great service, great food, and an awesome, cozy atmosphere, go 45 min before peak time and ensure you'll get a seat. PS, If you like cioppino you HAVE to add this place to your list!
author: Caleb H.

description: Respectfully there is far better in our city. Crab cakes were all bread... clam chowder thin like a bowl of milk with micron pieces of clam! Salad was undressed lettuce with four olives.. not good enough for San Francisco I am sorry to say. First and last time... the second star is for the potato wedges.. those are good. Not enough to bring us back.
author: Kirk M.

description:
Came here on Saturday night at 9pm and waited until about 1030pm to be seated but that's how it goes so no big deal. My husband and I ordered the anchor tray or something of the sort which included 12 raw oysters, 4 prawn, and steamed mussels in a lemony sauce and also a small cioppino. 

The oysters were okay. Definitely better at hog island. So if you're here just for oysters you may be disappointed. The lemon broth with the clams was yummy and perfect for soaking up with bread.

The cioppino on the other hand was worth the 1.5 hour wait! It was more than enough food for my husband and I and he can eat a lot and even he was full. They did not skimp on seafood. It was full mussels, fish, crab! O the crab--delicious! Definitely get the cioppino if you are here!
author: Irene R.

description:
The wait can be insane, but it is oh so worth it. 
The cioppino is a must, and it is delicious with enough seafood to sate the hungriest pescetarian. It is inevitably likely you will end up with leftovers like we did, in which case the cioppino sauce can be the start of a wonderful shakshuka brunch the next morning. Date night done right!
I couldn't go to an oyster bar without getting the oysters, so the boyf and I got glasses of rosé and make a freakin night of it. (It's a bit of a splurge, but after working so hard in the big dirty SF city, you gotta treat yo self.) We ordered, I think, a dozen oysters, so there were six oysters for each of us. It was fun to compare the different varieties as we tasted them, all fresh. I'm getting hangry for oysters just thinking about it.
Anchor is small and intimate, and the seafood is fresh and delicious. The service is fantastic. Really, the only downer is that the word got out! ;)
author: Rae E.

description:
The cioppino is delicious, delicious, delicious, delicious. The small size was more than enough for 2 of us but I stuffed my garlic-bread crusted face. 

You'll have to wait, but it's worth it. Neph is amazing and sends you over to Swirl to have a glass or 3...and this all together is quite the beautiful evening.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
Amazing place.  Yes difficult to get into unless you are a party of one like I was and sat at the bar.  The food is worth it.  Although, I don't agree with most on the Clam Chowder.  Maybe I got the bottom of the pot but I never chewed into a clam, it was all diced potatoes.

The Cioppino made up for it.... small one for me was way more than enough.  Delicious and I will be back again... worth the visit.
author: Keith M.

description: Terrible service. Literally had a server skip over the person who "signed up" before us....skipped over them and then us to seat the person who walked up. When we inquired about the incident they began to lecture us about the importance of the "white board". I have been here many times before when it was less busy, but today was the last time. I've never had such a poor experience without even having eaten! The waitress argued about why it was okay to take people before. She even sent a second person out to talk about why it was okay (after my clear frustration). I was so worried after the interaction with the wait staff that we left without even eating.
author: Ashley K.

description:
Cioppino tomato broth is unbelievable. You must bring the leftovers home. Mussels had great flavor, especially the little ones, and Shrimp was delicious. Great amount of seafood for the price. Hit the point of "too much seafood at once" for me with the clams and crab.

Glass of the Pine Ridge Chenin Blank/Viognier 2015 was a perfect compliment. Very fun vibe overall.
author: Ojus P.

description:
I hadn't been to Anchor Oyster Bar for years and years. It's really close but every time I walk by there's a crowd outside so I never thought to return until a recent house guest wanted to try seafood while in SF. Of course this place was the first (and only) place I thought of. 

We hustled over there on Friday at 6:30pm and put our names on the list - only a few ahead of us. Our guest was like "you weren't kidding when you said this place was small". We only waited around 20 minutes and they came out with clam chowder samples (super hot but good!). Timing was perfect because after we were seated it there was a crowd outside and waits had increased to 45 minutes for tables of two.

We ended up at the table in the front corner - 3 people at a 2 person table. Cozy but not uncomfortable.

We ordered:

 * crab cakes appetizers - usually comes with 2 but they were able to accommodate us and bring out 3, really excellent crab cakes, fresh crab meat with no filler, just binder, perfect size for an appetizer, not gigantic

 * jumbo artichoke - appetizer special, really big artichoke served with a remoulade on a salad bed

 * cioppino - split the smaller size among 2 people and it was super filling, I can't imagine who can eat the large size, two large prawns, two big chunks of fish and lots of mussels/clams in a tomato garlic broth served with two big slices of garlic bread, easily easily split among 2 people who are willing to stuff themselves with seafood, this soup was so good and will set the standard for any cioppinos I have in the future

 * shrimp salad - hubby ordered this and I was too focused on the cioppino to try it but the shrimps are the smaller kind but still plump and large-ish for the type, served on a salad bed, huge plate and hubby was barely able to finish it

 * house wine - I love how they have house wine that you can order by the carafe!

It's a little spendy, as all seafood is, but very very good. I recommend getting a fish special or cioppino.
author: Jean K.

description:
O is for Oyster and Oh yea baby this place is so good!

When people call this place a gem it most definitely is. Small but serving the freshest seafood around! Establishments with small menu's impress me because that means they can focus on the freshest ingredients. Bottom line... the oysters are all you'll need! Well and that bomb garlic bread.

From local oysters to those on the other side of the country. It was all amazing. 

Service was good. We enjoyed our southern hunk of a waiter. He was from Texas!

Prices are steep but you get what you pay for - quality seafood, shucked to order!
author: Earlene C.

description:
If it wasn't a consistent 1+ hour wait, I would eat here all the time. They don't take reservations. 

The cioppino is pure seafood heaven. It's a tomato based broth with herbs and spices and loaded with seafood like mussels, clams, and crab legs. There's also large flaky pieces of white fish for all you non-shellfish eaters (seriously, you're missing out). I highly recommend a side order of the delicious garlic bread. 

I can't wait to go back! Darn you SF lines.
author: Xinxin W.

description:
After a day of hiking, bf and I were driving back to the city, looking for a place to grab a snack. Thanks to yelp, I found Anchor Oyster Bar! It was Sunday afternoon and the stars must have been aligned bc it was 3:55 when we got to AOB. They were about to open at 4pm so we just sat outside on the cushioned bench to wait. Soon after, more people started to line up. At 4 we were inside and chose seats at the bar. This place filled up fast bc half an hour later, there were a bunch of ppl outside waiting for tables. 

We started off with 2 soju oyster shooters. Yum! Then we ordered the Anchor Special: 12 oysters on the half shell, 8 steamed clams and 4 chilled prawns. The oysters were so fresh and sweet. The prawns were huge and yummy. The steamed clams were cooked in this amazing herb, butter, white wine broth. Too good! I wanted to eat more oysters but I'm slightly allergic, so I had to exercise some self control.
author: Liv A.

description:
Anchor Oyster Bar is, by far, one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. Intimate, comfortable, rich with seafood and filled with local charm. 

Anchor Oyster Bar embodies, what I like to call, San Francisco's local charm- unpretentious, casual and delicious dining, with a really long wait. If you can't tell already, San Franciscans love to wait (because almost all good restaurant have more than 30 minute wait-time with some requiring you to stay around so that you can't just leave your number and venture elsewhere).  Anchor Oyster Bar is the same way, with it sometimes taking as long as 1.5hr to get a seat (even at the bar)! Long wait aside, you'll be very happy and bubbly by the time you get seated, either at the bar or a table, probably because by then, you've already filled up on a few glasses of wine. Also take note that they do not accept call-in reservations and require you to be present when they call your name. So...don't venture too far, unless you're 15 lines down the list. 

Once you step in, you'll be welcomed by a gusto of delicious garlic seafood aroma, warming your soul, body and senses. It's a beautiful refuge from the perpetual San Francisco fog. Sit down and start looking at the menu. Know to order the cioppino (even though it is not listed on the menu), and some drinks even if you haven't had a chance to look at the menu because, trust the Yelper's, it is really THAT good. There's no room for second guessing when it comes to the cioppino. If you're a party of 2 or 3, one cioppino and a few oysters/clams/steamed bivalves should be more than enough food to share. I say this because the cioppino is big enough. My boyfriend and I made the mistake of over-ordering cioppino, shucked oysters, clam chowder, steamed mussels AND clams. In the end, we left with very happy stomachs but also very bloated stomachs, even though we are both known for being able to eat a lot. 

However, you MUST order the cioppino! It's the best in SF Bay Area and the seafood in it is phenomenal, filled with dungness crab, fish, mussels, herbs, garlic and fresh tomato sauce.  I can't rave enough about it and sometimes salivate to the thought of it. 

EXCELLENT. I can't wait to come back :)
author: Jenny Z.

description:
BEST ciopinno Ive ever ever ever had! The restaurant is super small and most of the time theres a wait. We got there alil after opening and the first wave of people were seated so we had to wait. Waited for about and hr before someone finally left. Which brings me to point out pet peeve number 1: 
      If youre eating at a oviously small establishment such as this with a large following... dont loiter. Eat your food pay your bill and get out. You dont need to spend an extra 2 hrs chit chatting and taking up space when there r a million people waiting to eat. Thats just rude. People are trying to run a business. Its not starbucks people.

Now that i got that off my chest. Once we were seated, service was polite and efficient. The kids ordered a big bowl of clams each and literally inhaled it. Husband got the seabass and gave me a bite. It was DELISH! 
Price was on par with the quality of seafood. Cant wait to come back. Just wish it wasnt so far. Try it.. u wont regret it.
author: Cynthia A.

description: This is of my favorite seafood spots! Their service is excellent and they deliver the food quickly. Also, their food is so fresh and tasty! Wait time isn't so bad but try to get there as early as possible or else you'll be waiting outside.
author: London J.

description: Don't miss this.  A gem among gems in SF. Tiny, and no reservations. Come early and get your name on the list for lunch and dinner hours.
author: Erica W.

description:
*AMAZINGLY FRESH OYSTERS AND SEAFOOD, GREAT SERVICE*

Not only is the seafood delicious- small cozy joint,  the staff is super friendly and will hook you UP! We somehow paid $70 for this meal for 2.. and we had drinks... alcoholic drinks... and food... A LOT of food... How? What? Why? Because this place is the shiz thats why.

*Bread and Butter $1.95 I'm pretty sure they didnt charge us for this.. Delicious SF sourdough w butta.. mmm.. great to dip in sauces too!

*BOSTON CLAM CHOWDER (cup) $4.25: Was looking for creamy amazing SF clam chowder and boy did this hit the spot! Filled with tons of clams and delcious flavor! http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZDvIMjJ-7I0561ckM4pAeA?select=LTriXoXcFiSWY6eWFdqGqA#crON_NDWE_cmYGkFdxYofg

*OYSTER SHOOTERS* $3.50/each: yep hit the spot also. Smooth oyster and kick of the tangy tomato juice/cocktail sauce. Squeeze of lemon. Straight up. Classic done right. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZDvIMjJ-7I0561ckM4pAeA?select=jKVkj3BsmCdq34XwsqOiyQ#jKVkj3BsmCdq34XwsqOiyQ

*GARLIC BREAD** $5.95 REALLY DELICIOUS if you dont mind some extra carbiness. SOO MUCH buttery garlic on french bread, topped with parm and parsley. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZDvIMjJ-7I0561ckM4pAeA?select=t7wSZqNPeDzwyftKTeRUiA#t7wSZqNPeDzwyftKTeRUiA

**ANCHOR SPECIAL** $38.95 (full order) HIGHLY RECCOMEND!  12 Oysters, 8 Steamed clams 4 CHILLED PRAWNS. OYSTERS! Im talking PREMO. The Kumamoto- were sweet, nutty and really fresh. They will provide hot sauce upon request. Luscious jumbo shrimp with cocktail sauce. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZDvIMjJ-7I0561ckM4pAeA?select=t7wSZqNPeDzwyftKTeRUiA#t7wSZqNPeDzwyftKTeRUiA

Wait, the platter is not over! The clams.. they weren't just steamed clams (as plainly described).. they came in this separate huge bowl in a delicious creamy buttery sauce (this is where the bread/garlic bread comes to play again). What more can I say? (p.s. you can get the half order for $20)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZDvIMjJ-7I0561ckM4pAeA?select=t7wSZqNPeDzwyftKTeRUiA#t7wSZqNPeDzwyftKTeRUiA

Boy was I stuffed and SATISFIED leaving here.. 

BE PREPARED TO WAIT
This place does not take reservations and it gets pretty packed so come early! This place only has about 5 tables in addition to a long bar top with barstools.This is not the best place for a large group. They will write your name on a board and prepare to wait! We ended up being the last seated and ended up sitting at the bar in order to get served before the kitchen closed. Wasn't the most comfy or ideal seating situation but they threw in some complimentary mussels in a yummy tomato broth and distracted by all the yummy food- so we were happy.

PARKING
Parking is not so great, like anywhere in SF. So take the train. Its not a far walk and a great way to digest! Just be sure to get back before it stops running.. or you might end up getting a ride from the seemingly harmless pot dealer at the bar across the street.. who turns out to be quite psychotic.. oh well we got to our hotel safe.
author: Nina M.

description:
After a day of exploring Noe, Castro and lounging in Dolores Park, I made one last stop at Anchor Oyster Bar for a quick meal before heading home. I was pretty excited about the sound of a hyped up crab caesar salad, a combination of two of my favorite things.

I started with the chowder based on a lot of reviews saying how good it was. That turned out to be totally misleading. It was plain old average clam chowder. Oh well, that's not why I was there.

I have to admit I was really skeptical about the idea of a $26 salad so to be on the safe side I asked for a half order. I'm glad I did because what came was a giant plate of greens and meat. I can't imagine putting down an entire full size order. I thought the dressing itself was good, but not much better than average. It got the job done. What I was really happy with were the giant delicious garlic bread croutons and the heaping pile of crab on top. Together these made this salad a definite winner.

Overall, I really enjoyed this 7x7 dish and I do think it deserves its spot on the 2015 list. I'm not quite sure that this is the best salad in the city but I will say that "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description: Simple menu with outstanding quality. Be prepared to wait at peak times.  Small place.  Be sure to check their specials.
author: Jim S.

description: Best place for lunch in the Castro.  Very small kitchen but getting a little pricey.
author: Tom P.

description: This place was small, cozy, and delicious! The clam chowder and crab legs were amazing!!!
author: Andréa B.

description:
So I came here on a whim for some dinner nearby. 

The waiter and waitress are pretty friendly when i got seated at the bar.  

I ordered:
Clam chowder
Garlic bread

Read that the clam chowder was pretty good here, but it was just okay. It was a bit watery w/not too many clams. 

The garlic bread though was real good w/a good amount of garlic and crispyness to it!

Definitely going to come back and try more things!
author: Eric T.

description: My BF and I loveeeee this place. Scallops are to die for! Clam chowder and oysters are great. Next time I want to try the Cioppino. Whoever said it's $100 a person is crazy because we are full off of two separate meals and Clam chowder and we never pay more than $70 for the both of us... Never had an issue with service like ones described below. When we can't get a seat in the restaurant we get it to go and eat it in the car. One time when we did wait for a seat they came out and gave us the BEST garlic cheese bread and apologized for the wait. Never waited more than 30 minutes (for only the two of us) and there is plenty to check out on Castro street while you wait. We love you Anchor Oyster!
author: Sarah K.

description:
From all my cioppino experience in all different kinds of restaurants, this place is the best for cioppino.. 
We have visited for dinner in autumn.  We had been waiting long line and finally seated after 40mins. and Worth to wait! 
Servers were super nice and attentive. They were very sweet to my baby daughter.   
After we got inside, sun was setting down and it seemed quite cold outside (you know the autumn in SF..) people were still waiting. The owner or manager served a cup of clam chowder to each one of them. That was really nice too. 
I wish to come here again if I can come out without my baby daughters. This place maybe a little difficult to stay with babies because it's not really spacious.
author: JS P.

description:
AMAZING!

Came here for dinner last Sunday evening with my boyfriend and we thoroughly enjoyed The Castro and the food at Anchor Oyster Bar!

came around 4:30 PM and were seated by 5:00 PM.  We ordered the half order of the Anchor Special and it came with 6 oysters, 2 prawns, and a bowl of clams in a rich butter garlic white wine broth.  Fantastic.

We also ordered the seafood shellfish combination and crabcakes and topped it off with a round of beers.  All was delicious.  We had a fantastic dinner and I am still dreaming about it 3 days later... lol

Will be back soon the next time we are in lovely San Francisco!
author: Krystle C.

description: Excellent.  Small menu but excellent execution.  Had the Dungeness crab steamed. Simple but good. Partner had crab cakes.  Avoid as they are just bready.  The oysters were good but tad expensive.  Friend had the sea bass with linguine special and that was excellent. Best part.  Went and did not have to wait.
author: Rey S.

description:
This place was awesome!  We got there around 11:30 and had to wait about 10 minutes to be seated for a party of 2.  This place is small, so expect to wait a while to be seated.  There is a whiteboard outside with a dry erase marker where you can put your name in the # in your party.  They will call your name when ready - so make sure you don't wonder away from the restaurant.  There is not much seating outside while you wait, so expect to stand until you are seated in the restaurant.

The food was amazing!  I had an oyster shooter with saki, some kind of open crab sandwich, and a half bottle of wine.  The atmosphere was nice and the patrons were pleasant.  I looked at other people's food and it all looked delicious.  All seafood is pricy so be prepared for that.  I'd say this place is a must if you are in the area.
author: Trey H.

description:
My partner and I went here early on a Sunday evening.  Because we arrived before 5 p.m., we got a table for two right in the window.
Our server was excellent and brought us lemonade very quickly.
I had a bowl of clam chowder which was excellent.  It was creamy and full of clams.  The server ground some fresh pepper over it and the oyster crackers were just the right touch.
My partner had the steamed shellfish combo which was filled with mussels, clams and shrimp.  He like it very much especially the broth which he soaked up with sourdough bread.
It was a great meal!
author: Philip C.

description: Food is so fresh and good. Sat at the bar. Friendly staff and customer. The open face crab-shrimp with melted cheese was awesome. Will definitely be coming back.
author: Bernardo C.

description:
Came here shortly before 5 (on a weekday) and there was only one other person in the restaurant. 

We were seated right away and ordered a half order of the anchor special, garlic bread and the cioppino. The oysters and prawns of the anchor special were okay...not really worth the $$ imo. The clams were definitely my favorite part of the meal. The broth is probably one of the best I have ever tried and I seriously wanted to ask if I could get a cup of the broth to-go. The cioppino was seriously huge...it's expensive but you definitely get what you pay for and the flavors were amazing! The cioppino was too big even for the two of us and we were over-stuffing ourselves by the end so that we could finish it. 

We never got our garlic bread but we were too stuffed for it anyways. Our server was really apologetic and she even gave us a card for free garlic bread on our next visit. By the time we left the place was packed and there were already about 5 different parties waiting outside.
author: Tina M.

description: Our second visit and we loved it again! Great food, service, ambience; well worth the wait. The diners were generally a jovial, mixed bunch, though one pair showed up with attitude and bitterness in their souls and then projected that onto the restaurant and then yelped about it. Attached are photos of Lia B., a major piece of work who grumbled the whole time while waiting ("No tip...they just seated that man with his stupid face and his stupid glasses...I'm going to yelp about this..." ) for 45 frickin' minutes (even as the manager was bringing everyone outside---including Lia B from Healdsburg and her date/partner in sullenness---hot chowder as we waited), who was reluctant to share the bench outside when asked (graciously, by a third party that actually smiled and seemed happy to be there, or to be alive), and who, when not yapping about how miserable she was while having to wait, was apparently whispering to her man about everyone else who was waiting or walking by. Alas, the Castro is changing along with the rest of SF (I've been visiting since the '90s). I couldn't afford Anchor OB when I first came, so perhaps difficult, demanding, antisocial, humorless types have always been around, contributing in some bizarro way to the crazy-quilt fabric of the amazing Castro, only I was kept away from them by my relatively shallow pockets. But their numbers seem to be increasing in a distressing manner. Lia B, from Healdsburg, honey, if you're out there reading this, here's my request to you and those like you: stay home until you pass that blockage and learn to contribute positively to the group. Photos attached: Lia B and partner (smiling only when yelping and taking photos of the man with the "stupid glasses" who apparently took her seat), and yours truly and John L, happy to be alive and happy to be enjoying a meal together at this wonderful place in the wonderful Castro.
author: John M.

description: Hands down one of my favorite restaurants across the states. Expect to wait, they don't take reservations and it's a pretty small place, but it's well worth it. You put your name down on a chalk board with the number of people in your party and what time you arrived. Usually if I can get the attention of a waiter I'll ask roughly how long the wait is and I'll grab a drink close by to pass the time. Everything is amazing. I always get mussels and garlic bread because they are the best I've ever had, their pasta dishes are excellent and you will never be disappointed with anything off of the daily specials board. If anyone in your party happens to be vegetarian, they are more accommodating than any other restaurant I have ever been too. I highly recommend this place. Amazing food, and great service. You won't be disappointed.
author: Amelia B.

description:
Write your name on the board. Always a wait I heard, but we got there a little afternoon and waited about 15 minutes. 

Boston Clam Chowder (Cup) $4.50
Garlic Bread $5.95

Service was alright, wasn't all that great. Speed of delivery was pretty fast considering the amount of customers. Food was good as expected. Clam chowder isn't as thick as the other places I had tried in San Francisco, but tastes healthier and creamy. A long bar and couple tables. Not a big space. All we ordered. Two of the top 100 things to try before you die.
author: Tina N.

description: So everyone talks about the food and how great the cioppino and garlic bread but can we commend the great staff of this place for stepping up and going out of their way to make your dining experience special. They make it easy for you to narrow down your choice when you have a hard time choosing. The place is small but cozy. Anyways, the cioppino is awesome the garlic bread is great and their clam chowder reminds me of splash cafe from pismo beach but this place have less clams hehe. Don't under estimate the size of their cioppino here. It's SMALLER (can feed 2-3 persons) or large (4-6 persons) do come hungry. There will be wait but it'll be worth it.
author: Ruth R.

description:
This review is long overdue.  

This oyster bar is small.  Arrive early otherwise be prepared to wait at least an hour.  Also, you will not be seated until everyone in your group is here.  

I've been here at least four times and every visit has been outstanding.  In Nov. 2012, my friend from France came to visit.  We took her and her sister to eat here and they had no complaints.  On that visit, we ordered garlic bread, Anchor Special, their specials for the night, 

Anchor Special (12 Oysters on the Half Shell, 8 Steamed Clams, 4 Chilled Prawns): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=sj_pPA_eXQbzTUvULmwBUA#sj_pPA_eXQbzTUvULmwBUA

Ahi Tuna (special): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=mvi0sRVh4sf0gf50YL_2cw#mvi0sRVh4sf0gf50YL_2cw

Penne Pasta (special): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=rRrHrpwMJnwlP_DAZoH75Q#rRrHrpwMJnwlP_DAZoH75Q

Garlic Bread - This was surprisingly good: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=5xTpcvQMlWkfKQ76P9whAA#5xTpcvQMlWkfKQ76P9whAA  

Pro: Food is delicious

Cons:  service is okay, parking sucks, long wait ( -1 star)

Can't wait to go back again!
author: Candice H.

description: We are in San Francisco one to two times a year and make sure that we visit this restaurant every single time. It is my absolute favorite place in the Bay Area. We've never had anything bad here. In fact, everything has been excellent. And in case you couldn't tell from the numerous reviews, this place is hands down, the best cioppino in San Fran!
author: Y M.

description:
Taking the crown as one of my tastiest SF seafood meals thus far, my meal at the small, locally owned Anchor Oyster Bar was one for the crab books. Our Saturday evening started out with an hour-long wait; the wait is understandably long as the tiny restaurant boasts no more than 5 tables and a few bar seats. I was particularly lucky this evening and ended up with one of the best tables in the house - I would not have been happy if I had waited as long as we did to get seated at the bar. Take caution and either plan to go with 4 people so you're guaranteed a table, or be mentally ready to sit at the bar.*
We started off our meal with a selection of oysters - they were offering 3 selections today and we tried one of each. As an oyster newbie, these were about as tasty as you can get. Our waiter was extremely friendly and helpful with good suggestions of what to get. Although the cioppino looked and smelled absolutely delicious, my hankering for crab got the best of me, and my friend and I split the whole cracked Dungeness crab (available seasonally) in the garlic, lemon sauce (although plain is offered as well). The sauce was perfection - slightly spicy, warm, lemony and garlicy, this dipping sauce was all I could ask for as a perfect complementary base for the crab. It was perfect for bread dipping in between crab bites as well. The crab itself was moist, and juicy, and knowing it was sustainably caught made it even better! The crab comes with choice of clam chowder and salad before, so we got one of both for the table. Although a little on the 'crab overload' with the chowder, the soup was one of the most delicious chowders I've tasted and the salad was a great addition to the meal to help fill that vegetable gap. All in all this meal gave the quintessential setting to a fun, seafood meal. Perhaps the best part? The price tag was very reasonable for the quality of the seafood (it's sustainably fished!), and amount of food. Point of this review? If you feel like crab, go here
author: Nicole W.

description: Fresh, tasty seafood just like that of swan oyster depot, without the long wait! Prices are reasonable for the quality.  So, why not giving this place a try if you have not done so?  Oysters on the half shell, the steamed clams and the Louie salad combination are really good!  Service is prompt and courteous.  I will return for sure :)
author: Ada L.

description:
Heaven, heaven oh crustacean heaven...

With the Michelin-starred Frances, the gastronomical Blue, the deliciously healthy Due Drop In and the sammichmania of Ike's, Castro is one of the most overlooked dining destinations in San Francisco. 

Nothing was short of amazing at Anchor Oyster Bar but come armed with your credit card or your sugar daddy if you want to leave with a belly full of top-notch seafood. With no sugar daddy in tote, I proudly brought Mr. AMEX suited up in his sexy blues. 

Be prepared to wait since Anchor Oyster Bar doesn't take reservations and is very tiny. If you don't want to wait 1+ hour, come for a late lunch or early dinner. My friend and I came on a Monday at 3 PM and there was a 15 minute wait. 

F O O D:
*SOJU OYSTER SHOOTER ($8.50)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZDvIMjJ-7I0561ckM4pAeA?select=lp90ZCvKFpAjYIdmWFVohg
