The soju oyster shooter was essentially a bloody mary with one raw oyster. A bit spendy but the bloody marry was perfectly concocted with just the right balance of tang and heat and the oyster was like silk.  

*DOZEN OYSTERS ($30)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZDvIMjJ-7I0561ckM4pAeA?select=pzt39dW0DnLICI-MC1M8RQ
Like it had been plucked from the ocean sea that morning, I savored each uber fresh oyster with a gracious *slurp* and *chug* of champagne. Keeping it classy all the time, baby! The oysters were incredibly smooth with a clean, sweet finish. I loved the cocktail sauce with the freshly grated horseradish for that nose tingle effect. 

*GARLIC BREAD ($5.95)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZDvIMjJ-7I0561ckM4pAeA?select=mQKyBg5frOaif3oVGb0f4w
In honor of the national F*ck Lo-Carb Diets Day, this carbolicious bread is not to be missed. Ok, so F*ck Lo-Carb Diets Day only exists in my delusional world. SHHHH! Nicely toasted so it was crunchy around the edges, the French bread was generously slathered with butter, minced garlic, parsley, and grated parmesan cheese which melted into every nook and cranny. Ridiculously good, it makes an extra 30 minutes on the elliptical worth it. 

*CRAB CAKES (Appetizer - $13.95)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZDvIMjJ-7I0561ckM4pAeA?select=7zS3fJXgk3W1vHrEzQlBcw
Absolutely NO fillers, the crab cakes were perfectly pan-fried creating a crunchy golden crust. The crab meat was wonderfully sweet and tender. The tartar sauce with bits of relish added that tantalizing creamy zip. A simple dish but so impeccably executed it was definitely a memorable one. 

*CIOPPINIO ($32.95)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZDvIMjJ-7I0561ckM4pAeA?select=LTriXoXcFiSWY6eWFdqGqA
Not on the menu but available every day, the cioppino is one of the BEST dishes I've ever had. PERIOD. Insanely delicious, the porcelain bowl was piled high with tiger prawns, manila mussels, clams, halibut filets, and crab swimming in a rich tomato broth. 

Forget about piecing together Saturday night, my friend and I went to town with that bowl of cioppino devouring every succulently tender crustacean and slurping EVERY last drop of the tomato broth divinely rich with deep complex flavors with a garlicky herbaceousness from the fresh garlic and thyme. 

DO NOT FORGET to save some of the garlic bread for sopping up the broth. Pure sensational bliss. Orgasms are overrated. It's all about the FOODGASMS. ;) 

S E R V I C E
Attentive but only slightly friendly; I asked for change for a dollar so I can feed the meter and one of the wait staff was very hesitant (I had to ask twice) about giving me four quarters. I'm asking for change not kingdom come. Geez. He was a bit standoffish the entire time but I'm forgiving on this aspect because the food was THAT good.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Small and kitschy with fishing memorabilia, Anchor Oyster Bar only had 5 small tables and 7 stools at the bar. Best for parties 2-4 only. 

P A R K I N G
Difficult street parking. 

Before Anchor Oyster Bar, I would have gladly taken a slab of prime rib over seafood any day but I left envisioning myself as a Lipitor-popping pescetarian.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
The wait for this small, cute, and delicious seafood bar was two hours! I think a lot of people waited over two hours for this place and that two hour wait was so worth it!

The BF and I came here on our day trip to SF.  We arrived there was a bunch of people waiting outside since the restaurant is so small and there's no wait room inside. I put my name on the board (the board is located by the door) along with the time we arrived. The worker told us it would be about an hour and a half wait for a party of two so we walked around and checked out bars/shops around the vicinity.

Two hours later we were finally seated! We sat at the bar and the seating was very tight. To my right (literally we were touching elbows) was another customer and behind me was another customer sitting at a table.  I had to make sure I didn't move otherwise I would hit all those around me, including my BF! We ordered a dozen of oysters and the cioppino bowl to share. The oysters were super fresh and melted in my mouth. Get these if you like oysters! The cioppino was so flavorful and loaded with fresh and yummy seafood. The broth and garlic bread was legit. Man, I wanted to eat more of that garlic bread. SUPER LEGIT! The bowl was larger than my head! Thank goodness we shared. Even then, we took a lot home because we were unable to finish the meal. 

The service was excellent! The workers were friendly and chatted with us freely. The restaurant is super small and crammed but that's what makes this place special. It was clean, the staff was amazing, and the food was even more amazing. I walked out and told everyone who was outside waiting outside it's worth the two hour wait. The hungry people outside looked relieved :)
author: Latda V.

description: This place is very small but produces excellent dishes.  The service is very warm and attentive.  It is a gem in this neighborhood.  Parking can be a problem but just come before the rush.  I always look forward to coming here.  You also meet the friendliest people waits outside.
author: Susan L.

description: The portion for the small cioppino was enough to feed two, I also had the garlic bread which I thought was delicious, but they should have really waited closer to when the main dishes came out To serve the garlic bread. We ate so much bread that by the time the food came out, we were nearly stuffed. I also had a cup of clam chowder and tried their steamed clams. However, I felt that both seafood dishes were lacking taste. Unfortunately, it was not a "hit" for me. Selections on the menu were limited and my cousin and I are foodies so it took us a while to decide. We parked in a 2 hour meter and drove to this place simply to try the restaurant only to rush through lunch as service was on the slow side. We were only third in line, but to get our order and the food took so much time we ended up having to pack our food to go.
author: Tina T.

description:
ok so we tried something different. we learned that the menu is in 3 places here. a paper menu, a specials menu on a white board, and written on the mirror over the kitchen. 

we had the half order of garlic bread which is not greasy and lightly buttered with a red (tomato) topping. also we shared the clam chowder - it's a thin soup , kind of atypical for chowder - it's tasty . we also had the crab burger which is on an average sized bun and romain lettuce and tartar sauce. 

Crew was more impressive in the friendliness department during my last visit. Patti wasn't there today.
author: Jeff K.

description:
Came here last September finally. Prior to coming here in September, Teammate and I tried to come here but they were closed for vacation.

Anchor Oyster Bar is the best seafood joint in San Francisco. Definitely worth the wait. The weather was a tad cold while we sat on the white bench outside so one of the cooks came out with disposable cups and a hot pot of clam chowder. The list of names were long and the dining room was small. We waited at least 45 minutes for a bar seat.

Teammate and I ordered the scallops, oysters and clams. The clams and the broth that it came in was delicious. Very smooth but not oily. Scallops and oysters were damn delicious as well.

Definitely gotta come back and try their oyster shooter!
author: Mabel Y.

description:
I stopped by this little place for lunch during a trip to San Francisco. I wanted to find a seafood place outside of the touristy mess of Fisherman's Wharf. I really enjoyed my lunch and wish I could have tried other things on the menu. 

I had the small cioppino which was fantastic. The broth, as others have noted, was delicious with lots of flavor and depth. They also included a lot of seafood, with clams, mussels, a few crab legs/claws, and large chunks of white fish. It was served with two pieces of garlic bread. I ordered half of the soup to go after stuffing myself in the restaurant. A small was way too much for one person and could easily (if messily) be shared. 

The service was friendly and fast. Others complained about the wait in reviews but I walked right in and sat down immediately at 11:30 on a Wednesday. The restaurant is quite small, so larger parties probably would have a wait even around lunch. I would definitely go back again to try other things as everything coming out of the kitchen looked fantastic.
author: Sarah M.

description: Their clam chowder is one of the best if not the best I have had. Only improvement they can make is there isn't much clam in the soup, but it is still amazingly delicious. Fresh seafood and a good selection of oysters.
author: Eve C.

description:
Consistently delicious seafood in a chill neighborhood spot. These guys do what they do well, and they've been doing it for 38 years. I really love this place.  

Yes you have to wait, but you can go across the street and do a wine tasting at Swirl. And yes it's a bit cramped, but this is part of the charm. For anyone from the northeast, this place will remind you of home.
author: Craig V.

description:
Pretty cute small store, nice interior decorations, but falls on the pricey side. The service is pretty great as well, but I had higher expectations when I walked into the restaurant. 

The oysters were good but 2 of them that I had weren't cleaned/opened properly where parts of the shells fell in. I also ordered the clam chowder, which was good, but not like OMG..to die for.. 

The crab cakes were probably my least favorite because they cost $15 for 2 but it was so dry and burnt when I got them that left me disappointed..
author: Mandy Z.

description:
I have been here more than few times. It's definitely my favorite sea food spot in the city! I love the food but I also love the staff there. 

Last time we went there, we had to wait outside to be seated ( for a very long time) it was cold and we were hungry. They came out with little cups of clam chowder and told us that they hope it'll make the wait less awful. It did! 

The space here is adorable but also very small which makes it harder to get seated right away. It's worth the wait! 
You can't go wrong with their clam chowder and Dungeness crab!!!
author: Tumay A.

description: Great fresh seafood, but the choppino is a must! The small choppino is huge, enough to feed two people! Make sure you get an order of the garlic bread too, to dip in the delicious broth (which i also packed to go after we were done with our meal, made a delicious pasta sauce for dinner the next day!). Oysters were delicious and the sampler was perfect to try a variety of shellfish. Chowder was delicious too, and they offer tons of oyster crackers on the table (you can never have too much!). Decent wine selection that pairs well with dinner. Expect a wait of 1+ hours for dinnertime.
author: Denise D.

description: My favorite place to eat in San Francisco! Always great food. Eat whatever they have on special. The wait can be long but it is always worth it. Write your name on the board and be patient.
author: Amanda G.

description:
Believe the reviews!  Anchor Oyster Bar is a gem and possibly one of the best meals I have every had.

We were visiting San Francisco and really wanted cioppino.  While there were some well-reviewed restaurants near Fisherman's Wharf, they seemed way too touristy and Anchor Oyster Bar seemed like a place where locals would eat.  Yes, the wait on a Sunday at 6:30pm was around 90 minutes, but we met some interesting people sitting outside and we were offered samples of clam chowder (so good!) to help with the chill.

We shared two entrees...cioppino along with a pasta dish with an incredible red sauce dotted with seafood.  As much as we tried there were leftovers which made for a nice breakfast treat the next day.   The only downside is that I don't know that I can ever order cioppino anywhere else it was that good.
author: Tim K.

description: The food is very good, but not worth the wait. You can wait upwards of 2 hours to be sat.. and to make it worse they will give seats to random people that haven't even put theirs name on the list.
author: Lia B.

description: crab cakes are heavenly. we got a small scioppino and it was plenty for 2 people. downside is 1 hour wait. Food was delicious!!! highly recommend it!
author: Alexis Z.

description:
While I would really love to give this place 5 stars, one person ruined the whole experience for us. We showed up at about 5:05 and my korean exchange student wrote her english name, "Genie" on their white board. We were told it would be about two hours for the wait. This was fine. We decided to take a peek in some of thr nearby shops and after about 30 minutes we came back to check our name on the list. We did this 3 times. The last time we came back, our names had been erased and moved to another board. That was fine, except they had written "gayle" instead of Genie. So we mentioned this to a waitstaff who then immediately accused us of lying. That there was NEVER a Genie on the board. We insisted that it was, in fact, us. There was no party for "Gayle" anywhere around. She reluctantly sat us and then spent the entire meal being rude, short, and unpleasant at about 7. As others were sat around us they were served immediately. We ordered a decent amount of food for the people we had, and yes it was super delicious, but served with that sour attitude spoiled it all. If i wanted to lie to get into an oyster bar in san franciso, why in the world would I pick this place? 
Eat here if youd like, but take a picture of your name on the whiteboard before you walk away or youre gonna get seafood with a heaping helping of SALT.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
It's fresh, rule number one in the seafood game.

The whole reason I went here was for the Cioppino. This place can deliver on that one dish 100%  

I find the menu to be slightly weak in terms of the variety offerings. Fair enough, do one thing and do it great. However, this would make it hard to bring certain people to eat here. 

I also feel like it might be just a bit over priced, but fresh seafood is never cheap.
One thing I love to accompany fresh seafood is a pint of Anchor Steam. I was saddened to find that Anchor Oyster Bar does not have Anchor Steam on tap. In fact the beer select was lacking. Mostly light beer.

The prawn salad looked to have only 4 large prawns.
The chowder was alright, not the best but good.

While I am glad that I tried it, I have others I favor more and many still yet to try. While I won't be going back for the reasons listed above I would still highly recommend this place to anyone who likes good seafood.
author: Ben M.

description: Small restaurant so be prepared to wait for a table - be sure to write your name on the whiteboard to hold your spot.  The seafood combo is super fresh with great cocktail and mignonette sauces for the fresh oysters.  The clam chowder is also great with good clam flavor without being overly heavy.  The star of the meal is definitely the Cioppino, lots of big pieces of seafood, perfectly cooked.  The broth is outstanding!
author: Ling T.

description:
"Without garlic I would simply not care to live". - Louis Diat

I feel you Louis.  It was really apparent as I ate at Anchor Oyster Bar today.  From the garlic bread to the steamed shellfish combination that is served in a wine garlic broth, both were loaded with garlic.  It wouldn't be the same without it.  

I'm shocked it took me so long to make my way over to Anchor Oyster Bar.  Especially being that clams, oysters, crab, and actually all seafood is one of my favorite things to eat.  It was Valentine's day so they were serving a lot of specials like Lobster Tails, Trout, Sea Bass, along with the regular menu.  But I ordered:

Steamed Shellfish Combination:  it's just a combination of Clams and Mussels in an amazing Garlic Wine Broth.  It's totally worthy of drinking.  Or at least dipping some French bread in.  I felt like the portion could be bigger.  Might have been because it was Valentines day.  Or maybe I'm just a glutton.  But 5 star worthy taste-wise.

Service was slow and kind of neglectful.  It is a real bustling little eatery and I recognize that there were a lot of people so I won't  be too hard on them.  A real casual ambience like any seafood bar.  7 stools at the counter and about 5 tables total.  

I probably give Anchor Oyster Bar 4.5 stars.  Like Louis Diat they recognize just how valuable garlic is and it shows in their food.
author: Michael L.

description:
This place is legit. Came here today on a Monday night around 5:30 and it was perfect timing.. There were 2 spots available at the bar as well as a table, but me and my mom opted for the table. The complementary bread was average nothing too special, but Jesus their garlic bread was great ! It seems like they roast the garlic first and then mash it to create a spreadable paste, it's then topped onto fresh ciabatta along with some cheese fresh herbs and oil... and then thrown in the oven for the perfect mix of melt in your mouth deliciousness with a toasty crunch ! We also ordered the cioppino (half size) but don't let that fool you ! It filled me and my mom up perfectly! The soup along with the garlic bread became a perfect marriage in my mouth! It was great mopping up that tomato soup with that bread and then shoving it into my gluttonous mouth (in the classiest way possible). The portion size was great, It had 2-3 large shrimps, 6 ish mussels, 6 ish clams, 2 meaty crab legs, a huge portion of fish, and half of a crab body along with tons of tomatoes ... And a hell of a lotta broth Hmm hmm ... Total came out to 32.50 but paid 40.00 out the door with tip. What an easy cheap delicious filling meal for two! I can't wait to go back ;)  

P.s as I was walking out I noticed a long line was forming outside even on a Monday night ! It seems like the perfect time to come is around 5:15 ish... Get seated maybe get a drink and then at 5:30 the specials board come out and you can decide exactly what you want!
author: Eleana H.

description:
Service wasn't all that great. It started with asking for the menu to look at when I was waiting outside. The guy just pointed at the large board and I was like... no, you must have a paper menu. Then he gave me one. What! When I got there, they had given my friend waiting outside in the freezing cold a sample of their clam chowder and I didn't like it much so that was helpful. Their chowder seemed to be very watery and the taste wasn't anything noteworthy. Then, when we finally got sat, we asked for a picture and the guy never came back to take our picture! Even though it was a small restaurant and our waiter walked by us so many times, he didn't look at us and didn't check up on us so we couldn't get his attention so many times! Ugh... anyway, onto the food...

The oysters were very delicious. I liked the sauces that they had with it. We shared a Cioppino, which took sooo long! I would think that would be quick since it's just a huge stew. The Cioppino was pretty good, especially because the shrimp and crab were not overcooked! The garlic bread that came with it wasn't that great, though. It had a texture of day-old bread - it was so dry and hard. There also wasn't much garlic flavor on it. Good thing we did not order another side of it! The Cioppino is definitely not worth a trip here since it's not the best I have ever had. What a disappointing visit to the Anchor Oyster Bar. I had high hopes.
author: Katherine L.

description:
My favorite place in the city for oysters and seafood.

Everything here is always impeccably prepared and it never disappoints. Their clam chowder is the tits (am I allowed to say that?) and thoroughly impressed my date. We also shared oysters and two entrees: perfectly cooked sea bass and salmon. 

Strangely enough, she was never a fan of oysters until we ate at this place, and wow: the claims that these shellfish are an aphrodisiac is absolutely no joke. 

After the dozen we shared, she gave me eyes that can only be described as... predatory. 

Her advances would have required the assistance of an adult, were I not also sufficiently plied by the spread. 

The rest is just for the two of us, but you get the idea.

Don't forget to hit up your favorite adult store afterwards for after-Anchor hijinx.
author: Byron E.

description: This place came highly recommended. The food was  on point!! Its a small place and you may have to wait a while, but its so worth it!! The cracked dungeoness crab was the best I ever had.
author: Ernest C.

description: Yummy oysters, crab cake & shrimp, and chill vibe.
author: Kim B.

description: The wait is SO worth it! It is away from the crazy of pier 39 and downtown SF. My husband had clam chowder for the first time and it didn't disappoint. It is cool because you can get the oysters a la cartel that were super fresh. You have to order the garlic bread. They have pasta not on the menu but ask. They were friendly and skilled enough to create something off the menu. Finally the crab cakes that were on the menu are worth ordering too. We hope to try it again when we visit SF
author: Whitney R.

description:
We had such a great dinner here. It's a place go to eat when we have the had time. The only negative to choosing this as a place to eat is wait time to get a table. It's a 45 minutes minimum wait time. We tried coming here three times before but couldn't wait the 45-60 minute wait time 
So, we did wait 45 minutes this time and decided to stick it out and wait for dinner. Really glad we stuck it out. We sat at the bar which was a treat because we were at the end and could see all the "happenings" in the kitchen. FUN! I've got to say that they are working in crazy tight quarters. 
They have Big Daddy on tap so MAJOR stars and points for that. BOOM! I ordered a Cold Crab Burger with a bowl of clam chowder. I  completely enjoyed both! Also got a "dry" and "wet" Oyster Shooter.. absolutely worth it! The difference between dry and wet shooter is Sake.. that's it! They add Sake! Both are great for different reason. I say try both and I'm sure you'll enjoy them. My husband had pan seared Sea scallops. ENJOY them too. All around great place to eat. 
Really the only downfall is the wait time. To me it doesn't matter, I'll be going back without a doubt.
author: Kyle G.

description: I have passed this gem daily and finally found the time to go! (be prepared, the wait can easily be an hour or more and they don't take reservations ahead of time). The restaurant is very small but perfectly decorated providing an intimate setting for family or friends. The Oysters are FANTASTIC! I had a "sampler" of sorts (Oysters from different regions) and they were some of the best I have had in Northern California. My girlfriend and I got the Large Cioppino and it was a lot of food (all perfectly prepared and delicious). This restaurant is a MUST for any Oyster fan! I do want to reiterate though that the wait times can be very long and they only seat complete parties (Tip: if you go alone there is a great chance you can quickly snag a seat at the bar).
author: David H.

description:
OK so amazing customer response. Upon reading my review of 1 Star due to being closed with no update on website, the owner sent me a personal message and offered for me and a guest to have dinner on her. So not only did we have an amazing meal food wise, but the service was great and friendly, and add to that we had a bottle of white wine, each had an appetizer and each an entree which the restaurant owner picked up the tab. Class act all the way around! 

Highly recommend anyone that can wait for bit for a quaint intimate great food in the Castro
author: Lawrence C.

description:
It was well-worth the 40 minutes wait for this scrumptious meal! We ordered 12 oysters on the half shell, a big bowl of clams to share, and a cup of clam chowder each. Yummy, it's a food delight indeed! The waiters are friendly and attentive. It has been around since 1977 (as stated on their t-shirts), so you can expect nothing but top notch food and service here.

Queue: Systematic and fair, first-come-first-serve service. I would recommend to come early, or drop your name first on the white board at the door, and go have drinks around the area while waiting for your table.
author: Wei T.

description:
Came here for their cioppino.  It's wonderfully tasty! The base wasn't too tomatoey sour compared to the famous phil's market cioppino.  With Phil's, all I can taste was tomato broth.  With Anchor, you can truly tasted the seafood base.  This is by far my favorite cioppino although I would like to see them add some crab (like crab in the shell and not just crab meat) in the cioppino.  

You can order for two or for one.  I opted with one person order and shared.  The one person order was plenty for two of us since I wanted to order some raw oysters and garlic bread.  The cioppino included some fish, green and black lip mussels, shrimps, crab meat, and clams.
author: Shirley H.

description:
I gave this place a try, even tho I'm not particularly fond of "touristy places" and Castro st. is one of them. But anyway, I'm not here to review the neighborhood, but the fantastic experience we had here.

First, there's a little bit of wait time, so be patient. Write your name, party size and hour on the white board. We didn't wait long and sat at the bar.

I asked for the Anchor special: a dozen fresh oysters, 4 large chilled prawns and steamed clams. The oysters were delicious and the prawns really big. The cocktail sauce with horseradish is very tasty, just go easy with the horseradish! *coughs*. The clams were less than stellar but still quite enjoyable. A little bit on the pricey side but seafood is something you don't want to cheap out.

Definitely a place I will go back.
author: Jose G.

description:
Clam chowder - delish, light and brothy versus heavy creamy. I like the light side of the chowder (as my favorite clam chowder is Hog Island's which is all broth and no heaviness what so ever) . This place I would have to say is my second fave. 

Cioppino - soooooo goooddddddd! Love the mix of flavors and herbs in the cioppino. I've had some at other places that were in a bland tomato based broth. Anchor Oyster bar knocks every other cioppino out of the ball park. A+ on my book. $29.99 for a half order (which probably can serve 2 people...it comes with tilapia, crab, mussels, shrimp and clams). 

Come hungry!!
author: Helen V.

description:
Looks like my brother beat me in reviewing Anchor Oyster Bar. First off, The Castro is soooooooooo friggin cool. No crime, comfy peeps who aren't afraid to express their TRUE selves, even with the TREMENDOUS BS CRAP that the rest of the world has, and still continues to OPENLY EXPRESS... 

anyhow, yea i'm just getting rid of some past residual FUMES. Again, I need to focus on this review... last, off the wall comment... if i were to live in SF, i'd choose the Castro District. HELLA safe for females to walk during the night. NO FEAR OF CRIME. Y? The rainbow loves every type of person. At the end, is a pot of GOLD.

Yea. I've got to say, aside from Perbacco, hot dog on a stick (more like cheese stick), Gary Danko, and Chef Tyler Florence's Wayfare Tavern... this place is one of my favorites of SF pickins.

LOVE RAW OYSTER. LOVE THEM. GARLIC BREAD WITH CHEEEEEEESE and HERBS?!? HOLY MOLY, I think my saliva is foaming. SALIVATE IS ON THE OVER DRIVE TYPE OF SITUATION. Where's my baby bib??? I'll wear a full suit to keep my clothes free from salivating mouth glands, runny nose snots, because ya know everything is activated now. And intense tears, because i'm so friggin happy, that raw oysters, garlic bread... AND THE BEST CLAM CHOWCHOWDER WILL BE ORDERED.

Yes, i'm in my astronaut suit... no helmet please, because my nose is flared open, to allow my nostrils to engorge the great smells of garlic and butter. Sit down, let out a good fart, so that ya know, your belly can be at ease. TOOT TOOT! It's okay Hannah, I say to myself, this place has raw garlic, and that will overcome your mini toot toots!

So yea, pretty much.... ANCHOR ME NOW A RSVP SEAT!

Oh and fyi brother of mine... next time, as you look at me disappointed, because I'm not your date... that's just fine with me... because YOU PAY! :P
author: Hannah Y.

description:
OK, picture this:

It's Pride Weekend (post-DOMA-ruling), Sunday afternoon in the Castro. Madness is an understatement. Folks are hungry; they've been shimmying, shaking, and drinking all day long at the parade, and now they're hungry. At least, we were.

We got to Anchor right as it opened: 4:03pm to be exact, and the place was already packed. Thankfully, two seats at the bar were empty and we pounced on them.

Five minutes later, we had drinks in hand (house red in mine, and a cold beer in his), and were drooling over the menu. I opted for a simple green salad, and he got a bowl of the clam chowder. Though it was sweltering hot (at least for SF standards), we had to have an order of the cioppino. At about $40, the bowl is massive, (I mean, look at the comparison to the fork on the right: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=2TkeL3gvavW5zXxzBuGoDQ#2TkeL3gvavW5zXxzBuGoDQ), so we split it. 

It was deeeelicious! (Thanks for the awesome recommendation, Cherylynn N.!) Though lacking lobster, it was PACKED with mussels, oysters, crab, two jumbo prawns, and poached seabass; the soup also came with pizza slices of garlic bread. When we finally got through the seafood, the broth was tomato-garlic-goodness, which we promptly sopped up with the garlic bread. Note: this is very dangerous because it's SO delicious, you can't stop eating. (Maybe that's just me, though.)

Loved the service, the cozy feel, and the incredibly fair prices.
author: Adena B.

description:
Its a very small restaurant. Be prepared to wait and sit very close to each other.
Not the best for large parties.

Cioppino. Yes.
Garlic Bread. Yes
Crab Cakes. Yes
Clam Chowder. Yes

All of it is delicious.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Solid seafood fare in the Castro.
Their daily specials are consistently delicious.
Clam chowder ranks in the Top 5 in the city.
They amazingly keep a very clean and organized kitchen given the compact space.

Wine/beer list could use a bit of improvement (i.e. more wide ranging)
Service is sometimes slower paced than it could be for such a small place.
Need to get there either before 6p on weeknights or by 5:30p on weekends else you'll need to wait for the next seating to turn.
author: ellelle l.

description: Half order of the Anchor Special and a small Cioppino will be enough rekk your afternoon plans. The food coma is worth it. We went here once, 3 years ago and I still get cravings for the Cioppino and garlic bread.
author: John N.

description:
Rumor has it that the owner plans to add heat lamps to the waiting area (the bench in front of the restaurant).  That'd be a great move since this place takes no reservations, has only 5 tables plus a small food bar area, and is very popular.  

Three of us enjoyed:

Crab cake entree with side of soup ($25.95)
Crab salad ( $24.95)
Artichoke w/ lemon aioli ( $10+)  
Bowl of clam chowder ($6.50)

The food was good but pricey.  Woodhouse Fish has pretty much the same menu, ambience, and flavors with a lower price point.  

The long, cold, drink-less wait for a table  with little oversight of the waiting list had me on constant high alert to the possibility that someone was going to slip their name in above mine.  A naked Santa strolled past, momentarily distracting me from my wait-list vigilance.  If I was on my toes I'd have seized that opportunity to slip my name up a notch or two.
author: Tracey A.

description:
If you like crab and happen to be there when the crab cake entree is available...get it! Lightly battered, delicious, wonderful. 

Not the right place for a quick bite. Once you get in, you'll want to relax and stay a while.
author: Mark A.

description:
Wonderful dining experience.  Ceasar salad is huge and very tasty.  And the Oysters....a-mazing.

Will definitely go here again when I am in the Bay.
author: Laura F.

description: We sat at the bar and started with a sake oyster shooter, it was my first time having an oyster, the presentation of the shooter made be brave enough to try it. It was delicious. We then moved onto Hands down the best clam chowder ever...I had the prawns & roasted veggies and it was absolutely perfect. The garlic bread was buttery delicious, I had to stop myself from continuously dipping it into my husbands cioppino sauce :) which he was delighted with...they have several local beers on tap. The service was great and I would come here over and over again if I lived in the area.
author: Ingrid G.

description: The service was excellent! Parking situation is as expected for a San Fransisco spot. I had a dozen oysters with a small serving of the cioppino. I wish that there was more variety to the oyster serving. My boyfriend and I are huge fans of oysters and we usually order 10-15 ea. We didn't ask but it seemed like a dozen oysters were the limit per party, but I could be wrong. The small size cioppino is more than enough for two people- so $35 is a decent price. Other than that I felt like the food was a bit pricey- I've had better cioppino and oysters. The gentleman who served us informed us the three different types of oysters we were being fed. The oysters were average size, not the biggest and not the smallest. This is not a place to eat for those who have claustrophobia, the restroom can be difficult for those who need a little more room. Also, it can get pretty stuffy... as expected for a small joint.
author: Julie L.

description:
Oysters were delicious. 
Chowder was delicious. 
Garlic bread was possibly best I've ever had. 
Small and intimate. 
100% returning.
author: Mike P.

description: The wait to eat here is definitely worth it! We got the Cioppino and a full order of oysters and were so happy we chose to try them out while in town. Will definitely go back! Michael our waiter was the best! All of the staff entertained and talked with our 6yo son which made the experience here even better! Best place we ate at in San Francisco in our 5 day stay.
author: D J.

description:
Sign posted out front says to write your name on the board and only full parties will be seated -- a great policy!  After waiting for about 7 or 8 minutes, a single person walked past the waiting people and sat down at his party of 6 table, alone. They were unwilling to follow their own rules (I asked) in a very small place.

The food may be good, but it is a very small place and in a space that tight, you need to adhere to your own rules. 

Won't be back. Added 1 star for the politeness of the staff even while violating their own policies.
author: Zack K.

description: Best clam chowder I have ever had in my life!! Everything we ordered was delicious. Crab cakes, salad and soup. Adorable little place with great service and food! Will definitely be back!!
author: Allison D.

description:
Attending this place before dinner was the idea. Grab a couple oyster's to start the night off and maybe a drink or two. 

Shortly after sitting down and glancing around we started to get different ideas and once our little tastes arrived it sealed the deal... We weren't going any where.

It arrived, the tasting plate. The food was fresh and clean. The oyster's were delicate and tasty. The shrimp which came out chilled had none of that moisture that normally clings to the precook variety. The clams were insane for lack of a better word. A definite must try!

Can't wait to go back for not only the food but the quaint charm and ambiance.
author: Aaron D.

description: Deeeelicious!  Oysters were fantastic, as well as everything else we had.  Cool vibe and friendly staff.  Cioppino was excellent, best broth I have ever had.
author: Mark P.

description: My go-to restaurant for Cioppino and for other seafood cravings. I've tried a few other popular restaurants in town for good SF Cioppino, and while they were good, could not beat Anchor Oyster Bar. There is almost always a wait but it is so worth it. Every dish I've tried in my numerous visits has been wonderful- clam chowder, steamed clams, oysters of course... Also the people are so nice, and the ambience is really romantic and casual/hip at the same time. Love it!
author: Yoon L.

description: I loooove seafood and this place is delicious! Cute little place with a nautical theme. It is ALWAYS packed. The clam chowder is some of the best I've had in the city. The scallops were good, but I have had better. The prawns were delicious and my boyfriend loved them too. The crab cakes are yummy too from what I remember. I plan on going back to try more (especially since I conveniently only live a block away.)
author: Nawal W.

description:
I knew this place would be a wait if I didn't get here as soon as they opened so we got here before noon on a Saturday and waited patiently in the cold for them to open.   Find parking on the street.  They have bar seats and tables and chairs.  Enough for about 30.  

For starters, we had a dozen fresh oysters.  There were 3 types that day, but kinda pricey: $2.50 a piece.  I guess I'm used to happy hour prices on oysters!  They don't have a huge selection of raw stuff like Swan Oyster Depot so if you're into fresh raw seafood, you'd probably be more interested in Swan.  But this place is good if you're in the mood for some fresh seafood and sandwiches in a calm environment.

I decided to have the Steamed Clams while husband and friends had that day's special, Crab Burger, which was a fresh cold dungeness crab sandwich with spring mix salad and a cup of clam chowder.  I had my friend's chowder and happily enjoyed it for him.  It was a very good chowder and the texture was just right for me; not too thick, not too watery.  Even recently featured in 7x7's "100 Things To Eat Before You Die."

My steamed clams was a pretty big portion with about 20 clams and had big chunks of clam meat.  I enjoyed it, but didn't care very much for the broth as all I kept tasting was the herbs since the broth was filled with various types.  I wished it was a white wine broth instead.  Then I would have loved to soak the bread in it,  The crab burger was filled with luscious fresh Dungeness crabmeat.  I love cold crab sandwiches, but I wished they used a better tasting bun.  This one was just a sesame seeded plain burger bun.

All in all, food was pretty good.  Service was great and friendly.  Enjoyed the calm environment and I liked that we didn't feel rushed as you would at Swan.
author: Erica S.

description: The food was so extraordinary that it was well worth the wait, but be careful as the restaurant is extremely small with just 6 tables and several bar seats. I was told that the seating was also directed by the limited capacity in the kitchen, so again, I caution diners to beware of the 1+ hour wait time. We went across the street to enjoy a pleasant glass of wine at the Swirl wine bar to escape the chilly wind. The extraordinarily friendly staff served piping hot, exquisite garlic sourdough bread as we waited patiently! We ordered the delicious, signature Boston clam chowder and special Petrale sole stuffed with crab. It was incredible to put it lightly!
author: William H.

description:
This is officially my favorite restaurant in SF. It is in the center of Castro and coming here during pride week is a whole other exprience. 

Now onto the food. There is not one item on the ever changing menu that I do not like. Everything is made fresh to order and it is mind blowing how complex simple ingredients can taste. 

must get item: 
Chioppino (not on the menu) - comes in a small (big enough to share, but you wouldn't want to) or a large. It is filled with all the freshest seafood from fish to clams. The broth is the star of the dish in my opinion. It was so refreshing and light! 

Tips:
Listen to all the yelp reviews and ARRIVE EARLY. They open at 4pm on most days I believe so I would get there by 3:30pm.
author: Marvel Z.

description:
I really wish Yelp had .5's to add to a review. Came here at 8 pm on a Saturday, put my name on the white board outside and waited out in the cold for about 35 mins. I was seated at the bar. I've been hearing about the Cioppino all week in SF and had to get it. For $45 (feeds 2-3) you get mussels, shrimp, clams, cod, dungeonness crab, and garlic bread in a big tomato broth. 

I'm sure this is prepared well in advance as it seemed every table had an order of this. I literally got my order within 10 mins, the guy next to me ordered a special salad and that came out 10 mins after mine and he was there before I sat down. The dish was really good, I wish they put in more shrimp and less mussels and clams. The garlic bread was phenomenal and the crab meat was pretty good; the cod itself was blah and had no taste. 

Service was really good, it was packed as hell but it didn't stop them from being attentive. I'm glad I had the Cioppino and I plan on trying the dish at other places. 

P.S Parking in Castro is a fhasfhsaofhsaofjasof!
author: Daanyaal K.

description: This place is the shit. They're not messing around with the Cioppino. Get the full garlic bread and dip it. They sell everything to go too. Next time I'm planning on getting a bunch of Cioppino broth and making a pasta dish at home.
author: Tim B.

description:
This place is AMAZING! Had dinner with my family there the Wednesday before Thanksgiving. The staff was very friendly and worked to accommodate our large party of 6 even though the restaurant was tiny. EVERYTHING we ordered was delicious. The dungeness crabs are a specialty here and are a must order. The fish special of the day, shrimp, and scallops were also scrumptious. 

Be prepared to wait for your table -- but the wait is worth it!
author: Ellen C.

description: This place is simply the best for fresh fish, oysters, cioppino, garlic bread & more! The head chef, Patricia, made us the most amazing cioppino & checked in with us during our meal which was so thoughtful! We were very happy soaking up the juice with our garlic bread & washing it all down with some vino! The restaurant is small & very much worth the wait. Cozy atmosphere, delicious seafood, friendly staff....what more could you ask for!?
author: Alison A.

description: Delicious food.  I ordered the Pasta with prawns and was blown away.  The place is small but worth the wait!
author: Dirk N.

description:
After hearing so much about this place, my husband and I decided to brave the wait and give it a go. We put our name on the board and sat outside in the freezing cold...for a long time. And watched all the people walk out the door looking happy and contented, and kept waiting. 

Then, lo and behold, a guy came out bearing a tray full of shrimp cocktail. Not a little measly bite of shrimp cocktail, but a full-on serving. We enjoyed every last bit and resumed our waiting...only to have him reappear 20 minutes later with clam chowder. Like, bowls of it. Good grief, it was delicious. Creamy and rich and ocean-y and everything one could want in clam chowder. 

Once we were finally shown to our seats at the bar, we ordered the shrimp salad, which was delicious, and the server admonished us to try the cioppino. So we did. Oh, the cioppino. I think it changed my life. It is the standard by which all other cioppinos are judged, but I've pretty much given up on ordering it anywhere else, because I'm always disappointed. The broth is just ridiculous--tomato-y, savory, unreasonably flavorful, and studded with an incredibly variety of seafood, each piece cooked to perfection. I ate until I was full, ate the same amount again, and then took the rest to my sister and demanded she eat it, even though she'd just had dinner. And she was glad.
author: Dara M.

description:
This place is the absolute best!! You want to order everything on the menu it is so good. The staff treat you like you are the only person that matters....your satisfaction is their mission. 
I would never come to San Francisco and not dine here.....as many times as possible.
Kudos kudos kudos to Mike, Neftali and Susan. They are great!!

Bonita!!
author: Bonita C.

description:
Prepare to wait if you didn't make it to the first round of the dinner crowd. Anchor Oyster Bar is far too small for the number of customers that wish to dine there. My table wrote our name down on their white board and probably weren't seated for at least half an hour. If you're lucky and are waiting out in the cold - they sometimes offer a small serving of clam chowder! Great idea.

This is the place to be if you're a shellfish lover! Their special of fried oysters was so good. I could eat 3x the order and i may still want more. Steamed black mussels and the steamed shellfish combination was just enough for my party of three.  The broth is so clean tasting and flavorful. Order the garlic bread to soak up it all up. Trust. My friend informed me of a suggestion that an employee at Anchor told her.  Take the extra sauce home and make a pasta with it!!

I only held back one star for the wait time and service. Service is friendly but it's crowded and they have lots of people to tend to.
author: Samantha L.

description:
First off, the line at 7:30pm was 90 minutes long. For me to be waiting that long, this had better be among the best oyster/seafood restaurants in Northern California.

I came with some friends and ordered 3 dishes. Each one was between $20-30:

- Steamed clams - A bowl of the tiniest clams I've ever had eaten. I felt like a baleen whale filtering for plankton. Skip this.

- 12 Oysters On The Half Shell, 8 Steamed Clams, 4 Chilled Prawns. Other than the prawns, everything was TINY and a huge letdown. I couldn't do much except swallow everything whole. However, the prawns were plump and delicious.

- Steamed shellfish combination - I enjoyed the sauce/soup in which the pieces were soaking. As with the other dishes, most of the seafood were in tiny pieces. I enjoyed the mussels very much. They were as good as steamed mussels you can at a slightly-above-average buffet, which made it one of the highlights of the meal.

In summary: The jumbo shrimp and mussels are excellent. Skip everything else in this pricey little restaurant that lacks sufficient seating and has a ridiculously-long line.
author: Nathan Y.

description: I first tried oysters in Seattle from the Walrus and the Carpenter and have been hesitant to try any others since. Currently living in Utah I don't trust any place to have them fresh enough and during a visit to San Francisco I was hesitant to try the oysters here... But I'm so glad I did. Oysters were amazing as was the clam chowder. I saw a bowl of cioppino being delivered to absorber table and it looked out of this world. It's a small space, not great for large groups, and you may experience a wait... But it's so worth it.
author: Rene R.

description: High quality sea food. Best crab spot with out a doubt. I absolutely love the garlic roasted dungeness crab, which is only available seasonally and off menu. Crab cakes ciopino, and garlic bread are phenomenal as well. Service is friendly an attentive. Beware! The restaurant is extremely small and can only fit about 25 guests, if that. Arrive early or before your hunger kicks. The smell emulating the restaurant and watching the delicious, huge bowls of ciopino being served while you await in a hunger filled misery is as close to hell as you will ever experience on Earth.
author: Kennedy F.

description: I love the food here but the service was horrible.  They only had 2 customers and didn't want to wait on us at all. Took forever to get our food, had to ask twice for refills and we just felt we were a bother. Don't think I'll be back.
author: Jackie P.

description: We waited an hour and a half for a table but it was worth it we had to Ciopinno and one of their fresh fish specials they kept serving us little appetizers outside because the wait was too long . The service was wonderful tight and cramped they need a bigger place but well it wouldn't be the same little hole in the wall but I tell you the people in that kitchen can cook fish right.
author: Patti P.

description:
I'm from southern california so I'm not very used to all the small & tiny shops, stores, and restaurants.. so I was pretty shocked when I found this tiny place with a large crowd of people waiting outside. Everyone in socal told me that I MUST eat seafood while at San Francisco. So I did.. and here are my thoughts on this restaurant.

I personally am not a huge fan of seafood. I think it's difficult to eat especially when it's still hiding in its shell and it can get messy. I also don't think it's very filling or tasty. So I wasn't really expecting a lot from this restaurant. But I must say that this place was pretty good for  being seafood. I just hope they would cook the seafood a little less because my seafood came out not so soft. Seafood was fresh though and seasonings were alright. 

I saw many many reviews on yelp demanding readers to try their garlic bread and clam chowder so I did! It. was. so. so. so. good. I loooove. clam chowder. Their clam chowder was one of THE best. I was going to wait until I tour around the bay area to try clam chowder but I'm so glad I ordered it here. It was so creamy and savory and just so so delicious!! I also LOVED the garlic bread. Before I ordered it I thought, how good can garlic bread be? BUT DAUM it was yummy. I'm getting hungrier as I write this review...

Overall, a great restaurant. Great service, waiters were all very very friendly and adjusted well to needs. I will return for a meal when I visit San Francisco again in a few months...!
author: Diana S.

description: This place has the best Boston Clam Chowder. Tonight I'm trying the cioppino which I'm told people come from all over the Bay Area to try. The service is great and all there food is delicious.
author: Carlton D.

description: Write your name on the board as you arrive. Expect to wait if not there early as they only have 5 tables and 6 bar seats. Had the killer anchor special with raw oysters, steamed clams with the best broth I've ever tasted, and large prawns. Half order perfect. Add a cup of their best Boston chowder and you have a meal you will not forget. Loved it so much that we returned 2 days for a repeat. My favorite seafood restaurant in SF.
author: G Y.

description: What a delightful experience! I love San Fran and now I love it even more because of Anchor Oyster Bar. It's in such a fun part of town and only seats 24 so it's very charming. The food was out of this world. You have to try the Cioppino, I can't even describe how amazing it is. They don't take reservations so bring a jacket and be prepared to wait outside....  I know it sounds crazy but it's worth the wait.
author: Aviana V.

description: Best cioppino around. Really good chowder. Very small place so be prepared to wait. Service was amazing too. They even brought some samples out for us to taste while we waited
author: Tim H.

description:
I've already decided that I'm coming back the next time I'm in town. Definitely come for an early dinner to avoid the line. They are open all day through dinner, with dinner service being switched a little after 5PM. There's a small white board waiting list on the side wall by the door. Make that your first stop before grabbing a seat on the bench (if there are any open). We got there at 4:45PM and there was only one couple that arrived a minute before us, and we still waited 20-30 minutes before a seat opened up for us. 

This place is SMALL. Too small. There's a counter/bar with a handful of seats, and about 6 tables total. I counted only ~23 diners with a crazy line out the door. It isn't particularly fast food or service either, so the turnaround rate for a table is slow.

I had only two things I knew I was going to order for sure: the cioppino and the garlic bread. Surprisingly, the cioppino's not on the menu. It also took a while for our waiter to tend to us and answer some questions. They were switching between lunch and dinner services, and the waiters didn't know what the dinner specials were until the chef posted them on the board.

We entertained the idea of getting the large bowl of the cioppino, and our server said it was probably doable, but we wouldn't have room for any other food. We wanted the garlic bread for sure, and couldn't decide between the shellfish selection. Good thing we held off, too, bc the small cioppino and the garlic bread were more than enough. The basket of garlic bread was massive. It's practically a whole loaf of cheesy bread. It was addicting and was like a pizza. The cioppino came with four small slices of garlic bread, too, but with less cheese. The soup was thicker than I expected, and there was so much seafood! This place is not shy with their garlic either. There was probably a whole cup of garlic slivers in the soup. Every spoonful there were at least 2-3 slices. They were awesome and not garlicky at all. But don't be surprised if you're burping up garlic hours later.
 
The small bowl of cioppino was $30 and the large was $50 I think? Next time, I'll forego the garlic bread, and maybe order some mussels instead. I'm already craving for more.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Anchor is my go-to dinner spot for SF visitors. Yes, there's a long wait (can be up to 3 hours on a weekend) but they run the list efficiently and well, and often bring snacks and sparkling water out to the folks who are waiting outside.

More importantly, the food is amazing and the service is very gracious. I lived in Boston, and Anchor's clam chowder rivals anything I've had in Beantown. Their oyster platters are delicious, filling, and really pretty. The seafood is flavorful and well-cooked, and they coax every bit of flavor out of their vegetables.

The waiters are always super kind and attentive. I've twice gotten free drinks here, once when I was asked to move to the bar to accommodate a bigger party (I didn't mind at all, and would have moved without the reffills!) and once when they took a long time to run a credit card.

Yelp lists this place as three dollar signs, but I think that's overestimating--if you order the specials and split dishes you can make it out of their for $20-$30 per person. A great deal for this wonderful place!
author: Anita J.

description: Last night was my first time and I already in loved!! All I can say is way better than SAMs chowder house!! Will come back for sure
author: Shelly H.

description:
Oysters- very fresh! (Rating: 5/5)
Cioppino- Pretty tasty. (Rating: 4/5)


Note: If you love cioppino, try it at Sotto Mare. To this date, it's the best I've had in SF.
Tip: Come early with your plus 1, since the place is small.
author: Jenny W.

description:
My first visit was just a quick oyster appetizer meet up, but this time, I've had the chance to wait for a table and sit for a full meal.  It was a Sunday and we didn't have to wait too long at 2pm if you are open to sitting at the bar.  There were folks who had to wait a lot longer for a table.  The bathroom is tucked away in the back and have to walk through the kitchen and I'm glad of that because I realize how passionate their cooks are.  You can tell they cook each dish with care and made fresh to order!

They had one dedicated wait staff who took care of drinks and busing tables and one who took orders and serving.  They were both pretty good - well deserved of a tip past the 15%.  

My friend and I ordered the half order of the Anchor special which comes with 6 oysters (2 of three types) and a pair of shrimps.  Very fresh and delicious!   They do serve sourdough bread and butter.  They have a specials menu and I ordered the Manhattan Seafood Chowder.  It has a mix of fish, mussels, clams, etc. in a nice hot tomato broth.  Very tasty!  Seasoned perfectly.    I also like that their sodas are served with a slushy type ice vs. the cubes.  

Great place and I would come back with family or friends.
author: Neville B.

description:
The Anchor Bar is a place i have gone to many many times since 2010. It's just up castro from Castro and Market street. Anchor is a very small spot with exquisite seafood, so there is frequently a wait. They have a dry erase board, you walk up, write your name, then have a seat on the couch lit by a blue light. On the few occasions i had a longer than 30 minute wait, they brought out small samples of clam chowder or shrimp cocktail, which was super nice. 
Once you get inside, you are welcomed by fantastic service and clean, sea side themed decor. I really love the way this place feels, very casual yet very refined. My favorite things to get here: Anchor has, in my opinion, the best clam chowder in SF. Of course you must get oysters, which i love getting with a glass of sparkling laurent perrier to wash them down. They also offer a changing menu of seasonal seafood dishes.
The bar seating is comfortable, and even the fact that you must walk through the kitchen (look out for flaming pans!) to get to the tiny bathroom, is rather charming. It's an opportunity to see how impeccably tidy the kitchen is.
I bring all my new friends here, and i recommend Anchor to anyone visiting SF who wants to try seafood done the way that most pleases locals like me.
author: Iliea S.

description:
Lovedddd it! Went there for dinner and ordered the anchor special, garlic bread, clam chowder, and cioppino. 

Garlic bread: crusty and crunchy, soft in the middle with lots of butter and cheese. I dipped it in EVERYTHING!  (Clam sauce, chowder, cioppino). 

Anchor special: came with 3 different oysters, we really liked 1 type, ate all of them and forgot which ones were which. Our waitresses went thru all the shells to help us figure out our fave so we could order more! It said 8 clams... We got wayyy more than that, and they came in a white wine sauce which was my #1 dipping sauce choice! I took the left over sauce home, yummy.

Clam chowder: not the best, especially compared to everything else I was eating.

Cioppino: Omggggg... Really?!? I hate tomato sauce but this shit was bombbbbbb! Fresh lump crab, white fish... Ughhh I was so stuffed by the time this came around I couldn't eat very much. Dip your bread in here, it's like a pizza! Must go back for moreeee! 

The service was great but a little slow cuz they were busy, the restaurant is quite  small and we sat by the door, but the food was good enough to forget about everything else. People came out of there looking stuffed and happy. Can't wait to go back!!!!
author: Lynne L.

description: This place re-lit my love for SF. There are good restaurants in SF but this restaurant blew service, food quality, and experience out of the water. I'm in love and can't wait to return!! Thank you thank you
author: Sophia C.

description:
Obvious 5 star rating. Consistently the best restaurant in the Castro. I had to think about writing this or not because I don't really want people competing with me for a table. There are no reservations and the line can be long.

Hint: Ask about the pasta special. It's not on the menu or on the specials board but they always have it and it's insanely good.
author: Daniel K.

description:
The dishes are simple, and delicious. I think its important to note that its very small (maybe 6 tables and a bar) and not very fancy. There is about 45-60 minute wait at dinner time, worst on Friday-Saturday. 

They have insanely fresh fish here. The menu on the website doesn't highlight the daily specials which is what most folks order when they visit.

Highly recommended.


Neighborhood Pro Tip: 
They also sell super fresh, raw fish at market prices. You've probably never had fish this fresh before. Just go to the back counter and ask them what they are selling on that day. You won't be disappointed.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Two words. Clam Chowder. OK, two more words. Crab ceaser.

You will wait in line, but it's worth it.
author: Thomas Nathan S.

description:
Small place but definitely worth the wait.

The four of us got there at 9pm on a Monday night, it was full house. We waited for an hour for a bigger table that actually fit us. The staff was super friendly, it seemed like everyone had been working there for a very long time, they know their menu and they know their shit. We ordered a clam chowder, oyster shooter (must get!) and a large Cioppino (we asked for white wine & garlic sauce)... the food was just amazing! My favourite was the prawns, the clams and the mussels. It was so nice to share such a big dish with a group. I still don't understand how one person can consume the whole portion of Cioppino.. service was super, they always put customers first and make sure we're taken care of at all times.

All in all, Anchor Oyster Bar is a great place to take anyone for any occasion if you're looking for affordable seafood with high quality in an unpretentious environment. I kinda wish they could open til later and expand the restaurant for more tables... at the same time I kind of like the coziness of it.  Hope they can open one in SOMA where my house is!
author: Shaz L.

description: Ridiculous waiting time. I came on April 23rd alone and there were only tables for 2 and the bar. So I was in line for 1 hour and they kept seating couples, woman who was a host kept saying that they have seats for 2 people. Even if people came later than me and there were seats at the bar. I think it's not fair. Discrimination of people who come alone.
author: Serafima I.

description: Wonderful food! Different kinds of fresh oysters and reasonable price! I am a fresh oyster fan! Small restaurant, so please go early or expected for long wait for a table!
author: Katherine L.

description:
This tiny little restaurant is my favorite thing about San Francisco! 

You've GOT to order the cioppino! It's the best cioppino I've ever had in my entire life. 

And the ambiance is so wonderful. I don't even know how to articulate the feeling I get when I'm here.
author: A E.

description: A local treasure.  This is truly San Francisco food at its finest.  Unpretentious, delicious and sometimes hard to get in (because it's small) not because of any phony air.  The menu has not changed in years.  But then why would you if it's perfect.
author: J B.

description:
This was my second time here. The wait was longer this time but it was expected being that it was a Saturday. There were 16 ppl total making up smaller parties waiting for their turn inside. It was fun to chit chat with each other and ppl watch the diners inside and speculate over which tables looked almost finished and which party would likely get sat next depending on how many ppl the tables sat. Some of us even offered to team up our parties of two to make a party of four if it was a table for four that came available. When we finally got inside we got the best table in the house (which I choose not to divulge), lol! 

Only two male servers run the show in the FOH. They both helped us. None of that this is my table, that ones yours. Which worked out great for us because we were very well attended to. 

Now for what we ordered:

Oyster shooters
Bowl of Clam chowder
Dozen oysters
Pellegrino
Champagne
Beer
Crab salad
Seafood combo pasta

All was delicious! Can't say enough good things about this place! Always a wonderful experience! Don't let the sometimes long wait outside discourage you. It's beyond worth it!
author: Ashley G.

description:
Let's start with 3.5 for now..and maybe eventually work our way up. 

I've had Anchor Oyster Bar bookmarked for sometime and since we were nearby..we decided to finally give it a try. 

Sunday afternoon..post Britney Spears madness..we arrived around 415..and since they open at 4pm it wasn't too packed yet. We picked a table at the middle of the restaurant and were asked for our drink orders 4 times by 3 people in a span of a couple minutes. Nothing wrong with attentive service, but our server comes back and tells us he needs to wipe down the table (to remove visible sauce spills) Strange since they had just opened; wouldn't you expect everything to be clean and in order? Quickly skimming yelp, we ordered a feast for two. 

* Garlic Bread - pizza pringles, cheesy bread and garlic all in one. This was delicious and you were given alot. 
* Oysters - The Cape Cod Oysters were a bit bland, but get the Hog Islands. $2.50 a piece for yumminess. 
* Clam Chowder - Not too creamy with just the right amount of seasoning and ingredients. I do wish there were more clam chunks but still tasty. 
* Crab Cakes - We were skeptical because you only got 2 pieces for about $13 but went for it anyways. Huge disappointment. Maybe the kitchen wasn't on par but these crab cakes were tiny and completely burnt on one side. I tasted more burnt crust than crab. Don't waste your money ordering this. 

Anchor Oyster Bar is a pretty small restaurant so if you have come with a group of 4+ you'll have to sit at the bar. Our total came out to around $50, which isn't bad; just the crab cakes really weren't worth it and we left a bit disappointed and feeling ripped off. I'll be back again for the cheesy bread and oysters once I'm over this first time.

- jenn
author: Jenn Y.

description: Came here to treat myself to an early dinner. Have loved this spot in the past. Today wasn't so great. I was supper excited to come in but left irritated and disappointed. I started with  two each of the oysters . Two of them had a decent amount of chipped shell. One in which had 1/3 of the shell missing... still ate it... wish me luck. Once the sever was finally done catching up with some regulars I ordered the board special. As the sever rang it in I could over hear kitchen staff cheer that they are 86'd Sole and they can finally can take it off the board. How long has it been in house? The sole took 20-30 mins and they were not busy. I am a patient person but that got me irritated. For a lunch I was about ready to walk out and pay the bill but I was so committed to eating there. Asked the support staff two time and said it was coming... finally a 3 burnt pieces of breaded sole. It was so thin I was like how can you mess that up. 30 seconds in the frier and it would have been perfect but left it in to long. I accepted the dish and moved on to the vegetables. The broccoli taste like it just came out of the Napa fire. It wasn't a nice smoky or charred flavor. It was unbearable! Luckily, I had a lagunitas to slam it back. Never finished the plate. Paid the bill and left. I left so disappointed living. 50 bucks later I found myself eating sushi across the way at Osaka. The sushi was platted two minutes after I order which had the same amount of covers. I'm not Writing this place off but stick to the classics and I won't be back for awhile.
author: Adam L.

description:
Clap clap, props to Chef Patty! Everything was DEEEELICIOUS!!!!!!!!!

We started off with the garlic bread http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=ON3C7f7J-KMpotRv0FkHKw#0kwD_S8u72R3QwHyf9_fwQ. I had an oyster shooter http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=ON3C7f7J-KMpotRv0FkHKw#cSAvtSNTb6wkZDZJXIOjpQ, tastes like V8. I wanted one because it was highly recommended even though I"m not a huge fan of shooters, just tastes like V8, and I do like me some V8. Friends had the raw oysters http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=35_EnuQPt0OpYHVCsN_glw#35_EnuQPt0OpYHVCsN_glw, I personally don't like them so I didn't eat them. I can't say if they were good or bad. The salad, fresh mozzarella http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=35_EnuQPt0OpYHVCsN_glw#57B_DQI6z90x1h0rt9CPkQ, assorted tomatoes, nice vinaigrette, & corn! Good good clam chowder http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=35_EnuQPt0OpYHVCsN_glw#IK_pn-qVeZKwjhuJF8a4EQ. Crab cakes with a lot of real crab http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=35_EnuQPt0OpYHVCsN_glw#x2V3STyWeu_whdAm13iNqA, can't go wrong there. One of my favorite items, the scallops http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=35_EnuQPt0OpYHVCsN_glw#6jfLd3bhVcAacMQXpN-yPA, just good scallops overall. Huge cioppino http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=35_EnuQPt0OpYHVCsN_glw#l6JCynqpBQbRrd2NM8LGnA with bread to dip http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=35_EnuQPt0OpYHVCsN_glw#ON3C7f7J-KMpotRv0FkHKw. The best cioppino I've ever had.

I'm salivating just thinking about this place.
author: Kylie L.

description: Yum. Delicious. Yum. Great spot in Castro! A teensie tinie little spot but with amazing food. We came on a Wednesday night and it was bustling. Waited about 45 minutes for our table and then got 2 spots at the bar. Cioppino was some of the best I've had!
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
I am fussy about seafood and find myself rarely impressed. This place is terrific! I had a half dozen oysters which were divine. Then moved in to an Idaho trout which was perfectly baked with a light nut crust and grilled asparagus. 

The staff is wonderful. Warm and friendly but leave you to your food. 

This is a simple seafood place. Don't expect bizarre combinations and preparations you've never heard of. It's just good honest well made food. It does not disappoint. It impresses.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I was so excited to try this place because of all the great reviews. I think this place is a bit over rated and overpriced though.. Not disappointed but not exactly a fan yet.

We ordered the half order anchor special, half order combo seafood salad, half order cioppino, and roasted prawns and potatoes. Our bill came out to about 90$.

Of everything the only thing that really stood out to me was the steamed clams that came with the anchor special. Now that was Delicious. I would definitely come back for helpings of that.. Everything else was mediocre.. 

BTW keep the bread basket slightly full because they will constantly come back asking if you would like more. I guess it's a store policy for every customer to have bread.. 

The service was EXCELLENT though. Servers were extremely helpful, knowledgeable, and friendly. I like how you could see the cooks cooking right next to you. Although the place is small and tight the ambiance and decor is amazing. It looks clean and modern, yet has a country feel to it. Absolutely such a cute restaurant.
author: Ames A.

description: Nice food nice service! Love this place,if you want to try seafood, come here but know that there no restroom, hahaha
author: Momoko S.

description: My favourite seafood joint in SF, it's intimate but yet still buzzing all the time and even though they don't take reservations and you whiteboard your name it just adds to the character of the place! The cioppino is honestly the best I've ever had and the mixed seafood platter is always a winner. Definitely recommend for a fun time.
author: Emily G.

description:
Anchor Oyster Bar is the bee's knees.  I chose it, thanks to my fellow Yelpers, and found a world of culinary delights tucked into an amazingly friendly, beautiful neighborhood.  We got out of the cab and were greeted by rainbow flags, I already knew it was a cool neighborhood from there.  

We walked a block or so to the restaurant.  And by the grace of all things culinarily awesome, we were swept inside for seats at the cozy bar, without the lengthy weight bestowed upon larger parties.  The inside is cozy, that is the only way to describe it - why is it that some of the best restaurants can only serve a small finite number of folks at a time?  I don't judge, but just wonder.  

The couple we sat next to were super nice to us, and by the time I got my bubbly and my Boston clam chowder, I was already swimming amongst good feelings.  The chowder was the perfect consistency, the right amount of sea, perfect flavor profile - and they have fresh ground pepper and a basket of oyster crackers (instead of giving me a measly bag of 5).  I had Kumamoto oysters as my entree, that was all I needed.  Sea briny deliciousness with a lovely mignette.  My husband had the shrimp cocktail dinner salad and was thoroughly satisfied.  I will come back to this neighborhood gem every time I am in San Fran.  I wish I was there tonight!
author: Cyndi J.

description:
We got there around 5:30pm on a Saturday night and had to wait more than an hour in line to get a seat. While we were in line, they brought out tastes of the shrimp cocktail and clam chowder to make sure we weren't starving to death. That was nice.

It is a very small place with 5 tables and some bar space. Why they don't expand or take reservations, I have no idea, but the wait was definitely worth it.

I stopped by because dungeness crab just got in season and I wanted some. I ended up getting that with clam chowder, and 3 oysters. The oysters were fresh and delicious, and the clam chowder one of my favourites on the west coast, but the cracked dungeness crab was straight out of heaven. It was cooked in butter, herbs and garlic, and I was sucking the sauce off the shells and my fingers, while amazed at how tender the meat was.

The mister had the crab cakes. The breading was light while the crab cakes were flavourful. The side dishes were really good as well! He pretty much cleaned the plate.

The seafood here will blow your mind. They just have the freshest catch combined with great cooking skills. Just a word of warning though -- not for groups bigger than 4. In fact, you'll have a better chance if you only have 2 or 3 people.
author: Alice C.

description: The best seafood in my town. The same beautiful place I was introduced to in 1979. Same as it ever was-perfect. I love that you can order 1/2 portions of seafood pasta, seafood stew, & garlic roasted crab. The carb is so good-/ fresh thyme, garlic, white wine & chili pepper flakes. They have new staff -- so be very careful how you order. Be specific. Cos they still need training;)))
author: Connie C.

description:
GO TO THIS PLACE!

(my friend wonders why yelpers don't just straight forward and tell him GO or DON"T GO!  I am afraid people like my friend doesn't want to read the comments.  anyways.... get to the point!)

how can i not give this place 5 stars!!!!  the oyster wow.... it's so delicious!  the clam chowder is fantastic!  the steam clam, better than everywhere else.  i love the steam clam sauce, i even drink the sauce!!!!!!!!  

My bff and i enjoyed this place a lot, but when we got the check, our face was immediately changed because of the price!  however, it's worthy!  We had entire full order of anchor special which is around 35.  we had 10ish extra oyster....etc.  i think 91bucks for our entire order is fair and we expected that already.  

anyways, i recommend this place!  if you live in san francisco and never gone to this place, GO tomorrow (remember go there early).  we went there around 12pm, and the place was almost full!  the place it's small, so make sure you go there as early as you can!

if you are a tourist, come here!  love this place so much!  i will come visit here again because i want to try crab burger and oyster (again!)  

A++++

P.S. we had oyster shooter!  the presentation is pretty, and the oyster is fresh.  I like the sauce, but it's a little spicy for me.

P.P.S  the crackers are good too!  everything is good!  the service is good too!
author: Brandy C.

description: There's always a wait, which usually means good food. That's the case here! Very nice wait staff. You do have to sign in outside for the wait list. Ask the muscles guy what to order, he helped point me and the lady next to me in right directions.
author: Adam M.

description:
Yes, this place is small, but it has that great, comfortable small diner kind of feel. If you show up here in the middle of lunch or dinner hour on a busy day, you will probably have to wait. I came here at noon on a Monday and found a table right away.

The oysters here are fantastic, although they're not all that cheap. They usually price them on the board; when we came here, they were $2.50 each. We ordered the ANCHOR SPECIAL, which came with 12 oysters (4 of each to try the different kinds), 4 large chilled prawns, and a bowl of 8 steamed clams in a buttery wine broth. Total of $38.95, and it also comes in a half order for $20.95. Sure, it's a bit pricey, but it's also delicious. It all just depends on your budget.

If you like oysters and bloody marys, don't miss out on the $3.50 Oyster Shooter, which comes in a good-sized glass and tastes great.
author: Natalia S.

description: Great food and awesome service! Seafood is super fresh and tasty. Good wine recommendations as well. The service was also very good. The restaurant is small and a little cramped. They made us wait outside until our whole party arrived but it was nice out so that was ok. Overall it was a great place for lunch.
author: Zippity D.

description: They have a really great Cioppino, so good in fact they made it official and added it to the menu. The portion size is large, so 2 people can definitely split a small cioppino. I made that mistake and ordered a small for myself.
author: Bryan M.

description: Solidly executed seafood classics. Wait is an issue but worthwhile if you are in the mood.
author: Saad H.

description: Write your name and party size on the dry erase board by the door. Be prepared to wait a while. The   Cioppino is well worth the wait and enough for two-three people. Ask for deep-fried oysters, secret menu item. Met Rob Schneider here a while back.
author: Roger E.

description: Anchor Oyster Bar has a great reputation and the quality of food/service to back it up. My party of 3 waited for about an hour and half due to the limited seating, however they served us some light appetizers for waiting patiently. I enjoyed the pacific oysters and the green lip mussels were better than I was expecting. Overall, the quality of food, service and experience were very good but would I wait 1.5 hours again? Probably not. Personally, I'd rather wait 2 hours to drive down to Monterey's cannery row to my favorite restaurant if I was really in the mood for some top quality Seafood.
author: Dane O.

description:
It was very good. I don't know if I would go so far as to say that's it's the best seafood in SF hands-down, but it was good. 
I ordered the "smaller" size cioppino- I don't know what the large looks like, but that thing was massive. It also had three full crab legs along with the slew of shellfish and cod. Very good overall. 
Keep in mind, you can't eat here if you have a party of more than 4. Seriously, there is no room.
author: Karsten B.

description: WOW! is the word that sums up our visit to this gem in SF! I am italian and I am a cioppino lover. This cioppino was hands down the best I have ever had. My bf and I shared that and the steamed clams, we were in love! I also had the amazing raw oysters on the half shell...FRESH is the word to sum that dish up! The chef even put our plastic bibs on for us.The wait is a bit long but the owner/chef comes out with fresh made garlic bread to keep you held over until youre up!
author: FC C.
