description: Have been to that place quite a few times already and the food has ALWAYS been FANTASTIC!!! You cant really go wrong with anything you order there! No wonder there is a wait every time (especially weekends) but trust me, it is sssooo worth it! Highly recommend!
author: Katerina P.

description:
Service was excellent.  While sitting at the bar, they discreetly let the three of us know that the table behind us was finishing up, and they offered to hold that table for us.  Dining at the table was more comfortable since there were three of us.

They also made us a linguine dish that was not on the menu--all we had to do was ask.
They were happy to make us a pasta dish that included arugula, fresh tomatoes, prawns, garlic, white wine, toasted and seasoned bread crumbs and hot chili flakes.

It was excellent.

We started with oysters, steamed clams, a prawn cocktail and garlic bread.  We washed things down with Stella Artois, Guinness and Goose Island on draft.

Word to the wise--get there before 6pm if you are hungry.  There wasn't much of a wait then.  However, when we left at 7:30pm, there was quite a line to get in.

Also, be sure to let them know if you like hot chili flakes as they add them to quite a few of their dishes.
author: Thomas D.

description:
We've always been curious, but was put off by the constant line outside. So one happy weekday afternoon that my husband and I both happened to have off, we went right when they opened at 11:30. It quickly packed up within the next 30min.

One of the BEST meals I've ever had. Hands down.

Do it. Worth the wait. 

The crab burger (do NOT pass on the tartar sauce!) --- amazing! The chowder ---- amazing! The Anchor appetizer --- amazing!

Really.

(BTW it must be confirmed amazing because a woman with a shellfish allergy dined with her husband next to us...)
author: jen m.

description:
I've have been going here for over 16 years and it never disappoints. 

I'm always amazed that they can produce such great food out of such a tiny kitchen. 

The crab cakes are some of the best I've ever had.  They have a great selection of raw oysters. The clam chowder is exactly how I like it, not too thick.  Great cesaer salad.  Nice variety of fish entrees.  Great bread, with butter. Even their oyster crackers are great. 

The wait can be a pain in the butt, but the food is worth it.
author: Mark W.

description:
This letter was snailed mailed to the owners of the restaurant on Monday and is now shared here.

Dear Terry and Roseann,

I tried to eat at your restaurant on Saturday, February 20, around 4 in the afternoon but because of disorganization on either the service or kitchen staff's part, I had an unpleasant experience.

The waiter took my order quickly after I sat down, and the order of the man who took a seat next to me soon after I got settled.

Two of the specials piqued my hunger: the scallops appetizer and linguine with clams.

About ten minutes later, the other patron's oysters arrived and maybe 5 minutes after that his entree was in front of him.

Sensing my anxiety and frustration that the man who can in after me was now eating his second plate and I hadn't been served my appetizer, the waiter apologized that my food was still being prepared and promised it would soon be out.

More minutes passed. The fellow next me, sipping his wine, tried to converse with me about how busy the place was and he was sorry I was still waiting for my food.

With my food nowhere in sight, I told the wait staff to cancel my order. The waiter apologized for the cioppino order ahead of mine that was being prepared and said my scallops would soon be out.

A twenty-plus minutes' wait for even the appetizer was unacceptable to my empty stomach and listening to the other diner sure ruined the good mood I had when entering your restaurant.

Yes, I understand when your place is crowded that it will take time to cook the seafood properly but watching and listening the other patron get two plates of food while I was waiting for one was unacceptable especially with the prices you charge for the fine dining.

Not sure what the issues were for such shabby treatment but I was soon off to a nearby pizza parlor to fill my empty tummy.

My disappointment with the standard of service on Saturday, fell far short of your usual high standards.

This neighbor and diner won't be back to the Anchor Oyster Bar any time soon.

Sincerely,

MPetrelis
author: Michael P.

description:
The food here is amazing- some of the best seafood I've ever had! Went with my gf and got the oysters, clam chowder, and the cioppino. The portions were very generous, and everything was made to perfection. Both the wine and atmosphere were also standouts.

If you don't get here early you will have to wait, but trust me, it's worth coming early and potentially waiting a bit.
author: David H.

description:
There was a wait for this massively popular seafood joint, but it was worth it! We took our 3 & 4 yr olds for an early dinner and were amazed not just by the food, but how much of it they ate! The garlic bread is heavenly and by far the best I have ever had. I try to stay gluten free, but had to bend the rules for this stuff! It is divine. The fish tacos were fresh and flavorful and the Anchor Special disappeared very quickly. My 4 yr old discovered a taste for clams and oysters here, and my 3 yr old devoured all the prawns on the dish. Chef Patty Blecha is a seafood genius. 
This place allows BYO, so we washed it down with locally made Azari wine. Wonderful.
author: Heather C.

description:
Anchor oyster bar is solid. Great food and price was reasonable. Got a 4.5 star review on Yelp and well deserved.

Excellent New England style clam chowder. One of the top 3 in my opinion. Legal Seafoods in Boston is still my favorite. Perfect consistency and fresh clams and potatoes.

Anchor Special: Steamed clams with butter and garlic, oysters on the 1/2 shell, and chilled shrimp. Great deal, $40 for a dozen oysters, steamed clams and 4 chilled shrimps.  $20 for the 1/2 special.

Anchor special: shrimp were fresh and were more like prawns. I really liked their oyster selection for the special. It was 3 different types and each had a different flavor profile. I couldn't understand the waiter, so don't know the name of the oysters. 1) mildly briny with a clean finish; 2) moderately briny with a cucumber finish; 3) creamy with a melon finish.
author: Joe B.

description:
The staff is friendly. The clam chowder is good.

Everything else was just ok...
The oysters are a bit small. Some of them were even sandy, which is not good for oysters.
The seafood on the cioppino was good, but the broth was kinda bland.

I don't know if i'll try it again
author: Ngan B.

description:
Cioppino, cioppino, CIOPPINO.

Well, I didn't actually have the cioppino, but the guy sitting next to me did, and I could smell it.  This was the first time in my life I have ever regretted having oysters.

Anchor Oyster Bar is located in the heart of San Francisco's famous Castro neighborhood, which is perhaps best known for its many art galleries.  I got here right before dinner started, so the super friendly guy behind the counter, who I believe was the owner (on account of his freely helping himself to a glass of wine whenever he damn well pleased), offered me any seat I wanted.  I helpfully chose the open spot at the end of the bar.

I went with the chowder, and the seafood combo, which included a dozen oysters, the steamed clams, and four prawns.  Everything was excellent, and it was more reasonably priced than the more hyped Swan Oyster Depot.

Not too long after I sat down, the throngs began amassing outside the store.  I noticed the staff feeding them shrimp cocktails to make the wait more enjoyable.  That's nice of them!

Anchor Oyster Bar was definitely worth going out of my way to eat there.  It's in a neighborhood whose main attraction is something that I'm not particularly interested in myself (art, of course).  Next time I'll order the cioppino.
author: Jeremy P.

description:
I came here with my parents on a Monday, put down "Jon 3 7 12pm" on the whiteboard, and waited for two hours... I thought after such a long wait, no restaurant can convince me to give them 5 stars, but I was wrong, this place is worth the wait.

The menu is tiny and everything is good. The chilled and raw items are very fresh, and everything else are well flavored and cooked. I love garlic and their food is very garlic-y!

We had the half order of oysters, clams and shrimps to start, shared a bowl of Cioppino. If you're on yelp, you probably know that their Cioppino is a must order and it is not on the menu. For entrees we had crab cake, dungeness crab and pasta.

Everything is just so good, the portion is decent, we actually can't finish the pasta (I had it for lunch the next day, still good!) This place is a must try if you love seafood, just get there early if you don't want to wait for too long!

Oh also, must mention that everyone waiting for a table in the cold had complementary clam chowder! They care about making their customers happy, FIVE STARS!
author: Jon C.

description:
Just amazing !!! We had the best cioppino in our life !!! The garlic bread is just simply the best. But what it made it beyond amazing was the staff , Mike, Susan and Roseann (owner) , they made my son Tommy feel so special that he said that this was his best experience ever , that the food was sooooo good  and that the people there were the nicest people ever , he wants to go back no matter how long he has to wait to be seated. Thank you Anchor bar !!! This  place is everything you can think off.
Love it !!!!!!!!
author: Katia C.

description:
I ordered Anchor special, ceaser salad, clam chowder, and white wine. 
And all of them were sooooooooooo delicious! OISHII! 
Especially I loved Oyster on a half shell. 33 
 I'm a big fan of raw oysters and I have tried other restaurants too. BUT SO FAR THIS PLACE IS THE BEST!! 
The oyster were sweet and creamy and rich. Most importantly, not fishy. I don't like it when oysters leave smelly taste. And that showed how fresh they were. When you put them in your mouth, you know they are so fresh!

Things I did not like was a LONG WAIT, lady who is a server. 
Why? The server put away my dish that I was still working on .without asking and she didn't However, I probably will come back because of delicious oysters!
author: Mii L.

description:
THE BEST. If I could, I'd give them 3 million stars. Worth the wait. It was an hour and a half wait for us when we arrived at 5:40 PM. Worth every penny. Great service. Really cute restaurant. 

Tonight we ate like queens! We'll be back!
author: Angeline S.

description:
Every city I've visited has its quintessential restaurant--one that captures the culture, flavor, and ambiance of its locale.

For me, Anchor Oyster Bar IS San Francisco.  Its intimate, bright, and features fresh local ingredients.  There is zero pretense here, and the chefs (who amble about the restaurant interacting with guests) are willing to accommodate desires/requests to help make the perfect meal for you--i.e. There's no ego.

Try a seafood pasta-yum!
author: Steven S.

description:
Wait is reaaaaaaaaaaally long! We waited a good hour to get seated, and it was COLD in SF that day (which made the meal so much more delicious and the wait so much more painful... the struggles of living in SF).

I'd give the cioppino 5/5 - it's MASSIVE. There is enough stew to feed 4 people. I ate it over a duration of 3 meals (seriously). The oysters are delicious but I don't think they can beat Hog Island. And while service is good (attentive, prompt, patient)... there's a LOT of time in between dishes and it's just a bit too stretched out to be comfortable. It seems like they're understaffed (not surprised, as the place is quite small). Our meal took 2 hours, and all we ordered were oysters and the famous cioppino.

It's a great place with great quality food, but probably wouldn't trek out here to do it again.
author: Chrystal Z.

description: great place. One of my favorite  bars on Castro, nice location, sometimes its hard to find parking. Really good food and environment.
author: Brian G.

description:
A little on the pricey side, but, being in the neighborhood I decided to give them a try. 

The place is a little smallish and cramp inside, but it is clean and inviting. I sat myself down at the counter since I was by myself. The waitress behind the counter was very friendly and greeted me right away.

I ordered the crab burger, it came with a cup of their clam chowder. I found their chowder a little lacking; lacking in clams, lacking in thickness, but at least the ingredients were not overcooked.

The crab burger on the other hand was excellent. There was a boat load of , fresh, firm, tasty chunks of crab meat. Served on a toasted sesame bun with lettuce, tomatoes and tartar sauce. 

Then, a funny thing happened when I was paying the bill. My credit card flew off the bill tray and disappeared. It took them more than five minutes to find my card. For my inconvenience, they comp'd my lunch. I told them that they didn't have to do that, but, the waitress insisted.

For the excellent customer service, nothing less than a 4 star.
author: Tony L.

description:
There was a line when we arrived around 8:30ish and the wait was about an hour. The staff was nice enough to hand out samples of their clam chowder and their shrimp roll, which was pretty delicious. Note that the restaurant is small so it might take awhile if you have a lot of people.

Oysters were fresh and savoury, had the shrimp and crab cocktail (forgot what the fancy name was) which was yummy, and my favorite--the Alaskan cod with mashed potatoes which was absolutely delicious. Was gonna try the cioppino but there wasn't enough room in my stomach. 

Next time I'm craving seafood I'm coming back. And for the cioppino!!
author: Cheri S.

description:
I just love this place so much. Food is delicious and the house wine is actually really good.

The only downside is that you have to wait a long time to get a seat. The place is actually not too big. You have to put your name outside the door and wait outside in order to get a seat.

If you are seafood lover I would definitely recommend this place to try. My fiancé is actually not a huge fan of seafood however he tried and he really enjoyed it.

Nice atmosphere. Could be a great spot for a date night. Staff is also very friendly.
author: Irem G.

description: No reservations, small venue, long wait. But worth it. If you get only one thing, get the cioppino, available in portions for 1 or for 2. Tons of seafood and a medium-spicy broth which is great for dipping bread into until you go into carb coma. Ask for a bib if you want to fully indulge without ruining your shirt. We ate at the counter, where we could see all the action. Just a tip: after you put your name on the list, go across the street to Swirl for a wine flight to kill some time.
author: Patrick F.

description: Excellent I had full seafood plate shrimp was huge love it . Waiters are attentive I live 8 yrs just cross street 9 yrs ago but I never went this place what shame!!! It was so good much better than other oyster place in ferry building . Hope they hang in there.
author: Step By Step L.

description:
This place was great!  We came for oysters for my husband, which he decided not to get!  I had a dungeon was crab sandwich. So fresh and delicious!  My husband had a seafood pasta and loved it!  The clam chowder was delicious!  We came on a weekday afternoon in July about one o'clock. This place is tiny.  We had to wait only about twenty minutes though. Service was great!  Kind of expensive but if you want fresh high quality seafood you have to
Pay for it. Way better than fisherman's wharf!
author: Keeley S.

description:
Best seafood I have ever had. We waited for almost 3 hours, but there are lots of things to do in the area (the wine bar across the street, for one). If you're a dog person, you can probably find a dog to chill with somewhere in a few block radius. 

We got the shrimp cocktail for the table, and my wife and I both ordered a custom dish--shrimp with linguine in lemon/white wine sauce. They were very accommodating and did not hesitate when we asked for something off the menu. The portion size was extremely generous and the pasta was fresh. I still dream of this meal and want to go back soon (just need to find some more friends willing to braved the long wait).

The beer selection was good, too. They had a wheat beer, which is seeming rarer each day in this city obsessed with IPAs.
author: Quinn S.

description:
I'm sorry... I don't get it.

Granted, I'm an out-of-towner so maybe I'm not as attuned to the local charm of this place, but I really don't get it... 

Don't get me wrong; the service (once we got in the restaurant) was decent, and the food was decent, but I don't understand how this place has such a high-star rating on yelp.  Based off of the really long wait for a table, and the yelp reviews I thought this was going to be the best seafood restaurant in town or at least a great dining experience, but after I was done I was perplexed by how such an average dining experience could command such a large and well-praised following.

I thought San Francisco was supposed to be a mecca of culture and dining, but if this is what you rank highly I feel like maybe I should have a go at the restaurant business ;P
author: Chad F.

description: I was already delighted with my meal when the waiter poured us another glass of wine, for free. Can't really beat that. I got to taste a few different things on their menu all extremely fresh and tasty, focus is on the quality, no fuss around presentation. The portions are generous, ideal if you like sharing.
author: Olivia M.

description:
Not being a fan of traffic jams and public transportation, I admit I didn't enjoy being a tourist in SF. Coming from sunny San Diego, SF was quite dense and gloomy.

But one ray of light that penetrated the skies was definitely Anchor Oyster Bar. Let me tell you about the wait you'll have to endure. Expect there to be several groups already waiting BEFORE they are even open, I suppose it's to be expected when you go to a joint that does it right. All I can say is that it's worth the wait.

The highlights you ask? Oysters of course! Incredible! I had to order another helping for dessert. Let them take care of you, they won't rush you EVER. This establishment just does it right in every way.

Some honor-mentions in case raw isn't something you can stomach:
*Cioppino
*Crab Cakes
author: Duc L.

description: Great food, great service, one of the best places i have eaten in SF. We had chiopino, mussels and crab cakes. All were extremely delicious. it is a small quaint place so expect a short wait. Not a problem though the waiters will kindly walk you across the street for some wine tasting and be back to pick you up when your table is ready.   Highly recommend!
author: Russell D.

description:
I can see why Yelpers go nuts about this place.

Won't take reservations - you have to write your name on the whiteboard right outside the restaurant. You may sit on the bench. Your wait might be pretty hard due to the elements (i.e. strong, chilly winds).

We waited for 15 minutes on a Saturday afternoon. We ordered some beer and wine, and shared a cup of clam chowder, a dozen oysters in the shell, and the full-size cioppino (served with garlic bread).

The entire meal was delicious. The oysters were fresh; the clam chowder was thick and rich, but the cioppino was the best. A huge bowl of light tomato sauce (with lots of garlic and thyme), and then a generous mix of white fish, crab legs, shrimp, clams, mussels...

I don't mind the wait, the wind and the cold as long as I get to eat Anchor's cioppino again.
author: Claudia G.

description: Great cioppino, steamed clams and garlic bread. The seafood in the cioppino was fresh and the broth is a bit spicy, which was nice. The clam chowder was average.
author: T L.

description:
This was an amazing meal. Can I say- I love my friends?
I never laughed so hard.
And the food was delicious.

The seafood was so fresh, it tasted as if it was hauled out of the ocean that morning. The oysters on half shell were briny, juicy; tastes of the ocean.
Thanks Yelpers for recommending the cioppino. The cioppino was filled crab, mussels, clams, squid all basking in hearty tomato broth. 

The staff was excellent: bringing our meals at the same time, anticipating our needs (more napkins? more beer?), letting us sit and laugh and feast until we practically licked the plate clean. 


Tip: I am not the only person that loves this place. I would come early to cut down on the wait time.
author: Doreen L.

description: Great place to eat with company. Ordered the Boat Day Sea Scallops appetizer and a smaller Cioppion to share - more than enough for 2 ppl. The scallops were just perfect! Fresh and tender, not over cooked, just the right crispness on the top and bottom - combine it with a light squeeze of lemon - oh heavenly! And the broth of the Cioppion was not overpowering, it was the perfect entrée following the scallops. Definitely worth  introducing to friends!
author: Mindy H.

description:
The food here is really fresh. 

We started off with the artichoke crab appetizer which was delicious.  

Then we had the clam chowder ( #28 of 100 on the Things to Try Before you Die). Good amount of clams and not so much potatoes. Just the way I like it.

Next, we ordered the Anchor Special which consisted of three kind of oysters on half shells (2 each), 2 chilled shrimps, and a bowl of clams in butter broth. These were some of the best oysters I ever had. They were all fresh and naturally sweet. The shrimps were huge. The clams were cooked to perfection in the broth which was so good I just dipped my bread into it.

Ended the dinner with some oyster shooters which had a nice kick at the end.

I will definitely be back to satisfy my seafood cravings.
author: Kien M.

description:
We came here for lunch on a Thursday and ordered the large cioppino.  I was super excited, since I LOVE seafood and was looking forward to trying what some people were calling the best cioppino in SF.

Service overall was very slow, and no one even came to take even our drink orders for a while after we were seated.  Those seated at the bar were more attended to than those of us seated at tables.  

As for the cioppino, it was good, but definitely not the best I've ever had.  I've had cioppino in New England and all over CA, so I've had my share.  The seafood was pretty good sized, though my husband ate a shrimp that he thought was very fishy and he had a stomach ache after lunch.

Most of the giant bowl was tomato sauce.  I figured for like $60, we'd get a lot more seafood and crab, but it was actually not that much.  We did get full off of the soup.  I didn't really like the tomato broth very much, since it was more like tomato sauce than soup/broth.  It had chunks of tomato (which was good), but was I think too thick (like tomato sauce for pasta).  I didn't think it was that flavorful either.  But if you like simple tomato sauce with seafood, then you'd like their cioppino.  For me, it definitely wasn't worth the $60+ for the bowl.  I thought the garlic bread that came with it was actually better than the cioppino itself.

Overall, I don't think I'd come here again for the cioppino.  Maybe to try other stuff, but not the cioppino.
author: Vez K.

description:
I, tragically, am allergic to crab, so I am probably not a worthy reviewer but there are a few places I'd recommend above Anchor if you're unfortunate like me.  The service and ambiance at Anchor were pleasant though so if you're looking to romantically share a steamy cioppino with your significant other or feel like chowing down on some fabulous looking crab cakes without being judged you should give it a try.  Once inside, I was amazed by how intimate the restaurant is - quickly explaining why there's always a crowd outside.

I found the clam chowder to be unmemorable, but I've been spoiled since my friend introduced me to the smokey chowder at Bar Crudo.  The oysters were good with a remotely fair price, same goes for the shrimp included in my sampler platter.  The platter also came with a bowl of clams in a garlicky broth which made the platter a good value compared to ordering a la carte, but after a few bites I found the broth to mask what I presumed to be great clams.

For me, it's a nice local spot, but definitely not a dining destination.
author: Krystle S.

description: The oysters were just ok. the flavors were not that great. pasta was bland. mussels were too lemony.and service was HORRIBLE. Never got my beer. Waitress was rude and never asked if we needed anything, she didn't even take our order for a really long time. I will not be returning and would way rather go wait and Hog Island Oyster Co. then to eat here again.
author: Jennie P.

description:
Tiny, but worth the squeeze for sure! 
Come hungry, but when you're not pressed for time; there's usually a wait. Write your name on the blackboard out front and salivate while you check out the menu... 
So worth the wait: my husband and I sat at the counter and shared the clam chowder, steamed clams and cioppino. All were excellent. Very tasty! The place is small, but energetically entertaining, and the fish is very fresh, flavorful, and cooked to perfection. We'll definitely be back!
author: Mish C.

description:
WOW! If you've ever wondered who has the best Cioppino in San Francisco, wonder no more! Anchor Oyster Bar will knock your socks off with how deliciously prepared their Cioppino is. Just so you know, I searched high and low for others who can compete. I've visited some of the most famous places in the city known for having "the best Cioppino". However, Anchor Oyster Bar gets a resounding 5 Stars! Perhaps it's the delicious broth that's perfectly seasoned. Or perhaps it's their amazingly fresh seafood. (The mussels are to die for!) Whatever it is, they don't need to change a thing! 

Bravo Anchor Oyster Bar! BRAVO! I'll definitely be returning for an encore performance very soon!

Note: My visit was actually on Saturday 6/28. The atmosphere is very quaint! It's tight quarters so be prepared to wait. Believe me, it's worth it!
author: H P.

description: This place is just OK. The oysters are good. We ordered pasta and muscles and it was fairly bland. The servers made us pay for bread "because they were running low" on it. No big deal, but that was kinda wierd. The service was slow, though it wasnt that busy. And the servers werent very nice. Again, the oysters were good and the location is great. I'd rather go to Hog Oyster at the Ferry Building.
author: Jon J.

description: I went there 2 nights ago. The place is really small but very well kept. Don't get afraid of a big line it won't last too long. We sat at the bar and ordered their famous garlic bread, which is scrumptious and yummy, 2 salads very well tossed and a whole crab. The Crab was amazingly sweet and crunchy. Price in line with the fair market value of the seafood. Last note the service: is fast and the people who work there are friendly and very kind. I would definitely recommend this place, in my opinion the best restaurant in Castro
author: Francesco R.

description: This is one of my favorite places to regularly visit in the city. It's a small place that doesn't takes reservations so expect a wait. The cioppino here is hands down the best I've ever had. Everywhere else where I've ordered the cioppino, I've gotten disappointed, and I think to myself why do I even bother trying it anywhere else but here. It's frankly couldn't taste any better - clams, mussels,crab,shrimp and white fish! Been here several time with my girl and never tried anything else!!!!
author: Gibran P.

description: Excellent seafood. We had a dozen Oysters from different parts of the country, scallop appetizer, filet of sole, and the crab sandwich... all excellent, but pricy. $145 lunch with tip... worth every penny.
author: Chuck D.

description: So far the best clam chowder in San Francisco. Oysters and Prawns were good, but it's kind of pricey. 1 dozen of Oysters = $35. The younger server was not 100% about customer service she passed us and took 2 other people before us. Then when she felt like it, took our order.
author: Carolyn G.

description:
It's 9am and I'm still sufficiently full from a previous night of feasting at Anchor Oyster Bar. Arrived here on a Thursday night at 7:30pm, and the place was packed. Not difficult to do, considering how tiny this place is. We settled in for the wait and after 45 minutes, the uncontrollable HANGRY-ness in me started to come out. Luckily, the attentive staff & kitchen noticed the antsyness outside, and offered all of us waiting a shrimp cocktail sample. Free food = I'LL STAY. 

Now for the fooood:
Oysters on the half shell - good variety. Boyfriend loved the Flapjacks from Washington. I don't usually like the oceany taste of oysters, but these were so fresh, I couldn't stop eating them. 
Crab cakes - that dipping/tartar sauce is straight crack. I'd eat it by itself. 
Garlic bread - good bang for your buck! One order is enough for 3-4 people. Probably didn't need to order this since the cioppino came with 2 pieces.
Cioppino - the 1 person serving was enough for two. Best part was the chunks of crab. YUMMM!  

Great staff & service. Would highly recommend!
author: Chanel F.

description: Honestly, I have to say I am not a big seafood fan, but Anchor Oyster Bar's seafood has truly convince me there is great tasting seafood. I have never enjoyed raw oysters, but the Japanese breed of oyster they recommend was really tasty. The steam clams and mussel are great to start as it fresher than anything I tasted before. The clam chowder taste way better than anything pier 39 can offer. The Cioppino is probably the best I had compared to many other places I tried. If you are willing to wait in the long line to get in, you will be delighted with a seafood treat of your life. I recommend you get there 30 min before opens or early in the afternoon to avoid the lines.
author: Mike K.

description:
So good! The cioppino and garlic bread is my favorite. I know they have you garclic bread when you order the cioppino, but do yourself a favor and order the garlic bread as well! The also do small sizes for the ciopinno, so I would recommend doing that so you can also try some oysters.

This place is tiny and tends to get really busy, so I would get there 30 minutes before they open. Even then I think there will be a wait to get on the waiting list. Don't worry, it's totally worth the wait!
author: Natalie P.

description:
WOW.. and i thought the SF Pier had the BEST clam chowder!!!

this place pleasantly surprised me.. my bf and I came here for a quick fix of drinks and soup after a long day, 
THE CLAM CHOWDER IS BY FAR THE TASTIEST I'VE HAD SO FAR IN MY LIFE....

I wish i could have it more often!! 
the ARNOLD palmer with the crushed ice is SOOO DELICious!

5 STARS!!!!!
clam chowder beats the pier.
author: S-Goddess V.

description:
If I lived in SF, I would eat here everyday! The aromas coming from the kitchen alone will get you! British Columbia Kusshis oysters are ridiculously good and fresh. Do order the Cioppino, which is not on the menu, because it's the best seafood stew you'll ever have before you die. Guaranteed or your money back!* Oh and the garlic bread that comes with it is the best I've ever had. They also have an excellent beer and wine selection to go with the food. Service was also good and not fake, which always nice in a local establisment. AOB, I will see you next time.


* Not an actual guarantee since they don't have an afterlife location.
author: Johnny A.

description: I loved every dish we had there,  great service.  You do have to wait, but it doesn't bother me and definitely was worth it. I loved atmosphere of this restaurant.
author: Elena E.

description: Came to SF and wanted to try cioppino. This tasted exactly how we imagined (actually even better). We ordered the small cioppino and it was good enough for 2 people. We also ordered the caesar salad and clam chowder. The clam chowder was very good, a little thin, but it reminded me of New England clam chowder. Garlic bread was also bomb.
author: David L.

description: Delicious and fresh oysters. Also enjoyed the clam chowder! Need to come back to try some more eats. There is always a wait though.
author: Aleyna S.

description:
This is our favorite place for many reason but before I tell you to go I will give you some advice and information to make it a better experience.
1. You will wait to be seated. The place is small and does not take reservations.
2. It is worth the wait! Your experience is about food here and it will quickly become a favorite.
3. Service can be a bit slow. Not because they aren't paying attention, again the place is small with a tiny kitchen and they can only have a few staff members working at a time so it might not be as rapid as you hope but the service is outstanding and the people are kind and working very hard.
4. Order the Cioppino! It isn't on the menu but I will say it is the best you will ever have.
5. The line out front is long....again....worth the wait!
6. Feel free to speak to the chef in back. they are all very nice and occasionally you will get to meet the owner who is warm, gracious and (of course) an amazing chef!
7. don't rush your meal. Enjoy the time you are there and your meal. it is a cozy and intimate place perfect for a date or an evening with mom and dad. My mom and dad insist on going to visit the owner and take home food.
8. the take out is just as good as the dine in. We often opt. to take a meal home.
9. Be patient and polite. Again...small place and staff is doing everything they can.
10. Last and far from least, look at the specials menu, it changes everyday and offers unique selections daily. If you don't see it....ask. They are always willing to make you something if they have it in the kitchen.
I hope these simple details will help you to enjoy one of our favorite places in San Francisco.
author: Tyler S.

description: This is the first restaurant I ate at in San Francisco. After reading so many great reviews, and hearing of this place as somewhat of an institution, I had to check it out. It did not disappoint. Excellent, informative, friendly service. Great prices. Extremely local seafood (like 45 minutes away). Also the complimentary baguette was clutch for mopping up the great sauce from my steamed clams. Would definitely recommend.
author: Nicole S.

description:
This is definitely some of the best seafood I've ever had. Fresh and delicious!

The seafood pasta special we ordered was cooked to perfection. The crab salad was a bit pricey but it had so much crab it was worth it. Not to mention the creamy garlic salad dressing, to die for! The clam chowder was so amazing we even took some to go!! The service was friendly and attentive. I cant wait to go back!
author: Melanie B.

description:
This place is the real deal. Home of the best cheesy garlic bread I've ever had in my life. I'm salivating just thinking about it. Crunch, garlickly, cheesy, greasy deliciousness.

Other yummy food: 
-Prawns - Fresh, plump, juicey, sweet amazingness.
-Oysters - This is where you go to become a certified oyster connoisseur. Try everything on the menu, you won't be disappointed.
-Crab cake - Crispy bread crumbs on the outside. Huge chunks of crab meat on the inside. Yum!
-Steamed clams - I'm a broth snob. In my opinion, it's what makes a bowl of steamed clams amazing. The broth here was not as flavorful as I would've liked but still above average.
-Clam chowder - Based on Yelp reviews, I expected this to blow my mind but it didn't as it needed a bit more flavor. It was pretty good though. Creamy, rich, salty, clammy.

Service: It's not a fancy place so the service is casual, friendly, efficient. 

Wait: Expect it. It's a pretty small cozy place. So worth it. Maybe while you're waiting, get a cookie at Hot Cookie down the street. ;) Oh and the waiting room is outside so bring extra layers, it's SF after all.

Parking: Very hard to find parking in this neighborhood esp at dinner time. Try to take public transport or bike.
author: Connie C.

description:
Would I return to pay $95(tip included) for a dozen SMALL oysters a bowl of really flavorful cioppino that was mostly clams and cod and a couple of beers? No way!

Service was killer but that only gets a place  so far.
author: J G.

description:
San Francisco, you have such good food. No matter where I am in the city, it seems you are determined to make me dead sexier. But, whatever. I roll with it. Just be careful not to be *too* dead sexy. The corners in the AOB are tight tight tight. Jack Sprat would be just fine here. His wife? Yeah, not so much.

Once you've been properly body-shamed, it's time to eat. And, you're going to want to eat a lot. Start with the chewy sourdough. You're in SF. It's only right. I know a lot of people are smitten by the garlic bread and I get it -- it's very good -- but, for me, it's all about the sourdough. After you've sated your carb lust, get in on the seafood action. Start with the clam chowder. Don't doubt me. Don't think. Get it. Eat it. Slurp it. Savor it. Ask for oyster crackers. Take a second to breathe. Get back in there and finish the soup. It's *that* good. Now, for your main, don't do what I did. I ordered the crab burger. It was on special and it made me think of SpongeBob SquarePants. So, I was in. Don't get me wrong, it was a tasty burger; simple, but tasty. Dungeness crab, lettuce, tomato, and tartar sauce (to bind) on a sesame bun. That's it. No sides. Simple. But I should have aimed higher. At my table, my friends lost their minds with the pasta, the crab cakes and the fresh fish. Stealing a bite here and there, I agreed. I was wracked with order envy but I couldn't be too too upset because, you know, Dungeness crab. Firstworldproblems. Next time I come back, I'll make sure to order a bit better and make sure that my big stomach match my big eyes.
author: Johnny T.

description: The food is good, but the place is small,  not that much available seat and you have to wait for an hour.
author: Bonnie Y.

description: Wow, I didn't know I liked steamed clams till I went here. I kept sopping up that delicious clam broth with my bread. Fresh and tasty salad. The clam chowder was very flavorful though lacking in clams. Good service in a small fun place. If I had 4 1/2 stars to give, I would.
author: Karen J.

description: Sat up at the bar top in this quaint cute spot. Mussels in a white wine broth were the best I've had- looked beautiful and it was fresh. Place is crackin' so you'll want to get there early to avoid the wait. I got there at around 4ish in the afternoon and was able to find a seat right away.
author: Aileen A.

description:
I've been wanting to eat here for some time but I don't live nearby and I hate waiting in line.  So when the opportunity arrived on a Wed. night while heading to the Castro Theatre for a movie occured I couldn't resist. 

We had beers (IPA) 1/2 dozen oysters (phenomenal), Jumbo shrimp cocktail (beware of the horseradish), Boston clam chowder and a crab ceasar salad. All super yummy and delightful. The wait was maybe 10 minutes. No big deal. My only gripe would be that the salad was dressed a little heavy. Next time I'll tell them to dress it lightly. 

What I thought might be spendy turned into about a $75 meal. I'm a fan.
author: Brad C.

description: For charm, reliable freshness of the food, and the inexplicable joy I feel whenever I eat here, it gets five stars. Eating at Anchor is like coming home.
author: Morris R.

description:
Walked in here *without consulting Yelp* because it just looked that good. We haven't experienced this quality at an oyster bar since living in Manhattan.

Hubs and I shared a half sampler platter: 6 oysters (you can choose; we went with the French Kiss, which was less briny and didn't taste like sea water); 2 truly jumbo carnation pink meaty prawns, and half dozen cooked clams in this decadent white wine butter sauce. A wonderful snack-y meal over some beer (or wine if you prefer); fresh quality seafood that makes you wanting more, but also leaves you utterly satisfied. This is good living!

We also had a cup of New England clam chowder ($4) which was one of the best clam chowders we've had in the area; the other notables to us are at Pike Market in Seattle and some places we sampled while in Boston. Bread is crusty, dusted with flour, and perfect with the food. Loved the bottomless fat oyster crackers too.

Total for the food + drinks was $35 after tip/ tax.

Service was comfortable, casual, and the small quarters made for friendly neighborhood conversation. This place is truly a gem; we happened at 530pm on a Wednesday and didn't wait, but as we were leaving around 7pm it started to fill up.
author: Debora L.

description:
I've always been in love with this place for its tiny size and laser focus on super fresh, high quality sea food. Even though it's probably not at all true, I feel like an insider for even knowing this place exists. Get there early (like before 6pm latest) to make sure you don't have to wait outside for a long time in the biting fog of the Castro.

The chowder was really excellent.
author: Brendan M.

description: We arrived at 3:30 pm on a Sunday to find a line that had already formed. It was worth the wait. WONDERFUL staff and outstanding service! Get the clam chowder. I ordered a cup and ended up ordering a second cup, as it was the best chowder I've had.
author: Teresa M.

description:
The food was amazing!! We were in town for the marathon and afterwards my GF was in the mood for oysters so we Yelped oyster bar and The Anchor came in well reviewed. Took the bus to the Castro and found it. As soon as you walk up you smell goodness. Wasn't aware of the sign in board but was quickly helped by one of the main guys. We asked where we could get a drink while we waited and he took us across the street to Swirl on Castro...a wine boutique that poured wines and craft beers. He introduced us to the staff and then said he would return to get us when out table was ready. 

Side note: Swirl was awesome...great wines and awesome staff...thanks guys, my GF left there with 3 awesome bottles!!

So now the host comes back to get us. We sat down and ordered 1/2 dozen each of the oysters on the board, can't recall the new but were dialed!! Then we had the black mussels...the broth was just fantastic, this stuff would've been just fine with a loaf of sourdough by itself!! Finally we split the dungenous crab stuffed sole...came with some mashed potatoes and veggies. Overall a great meal....great place and awesome service!!! Found the Anchor by chance....will return by choice!!!!!
author: william c.

description: One of my go to places in San Fran!  Awesome food and great service.
author: Kurt J.

description:
Cioppino.
Clam chowder.
Fresh oysters.
GARLIC BREAD. GARLIC BREAD. GARLIC BREAD.

If you were looking for what to order, now you know. 

If you want to hear a little more, read on.

First of all, this place is SMALL. So if you're going at peak dining times, don't. Unless you're willing to wait an hour or more. Go an hour before the rush if possible. Also, I noticed that the demographic of diners eating here was generally 50+. These people like to eat early so be sure to take that into account. We came around 5pm and didn't have to wait, but apparently they were short-handed or something that night because we still had to wait 30 minutes AFTER we were seated before they took our order. It then took another half hour for our food to come out. And the order in which it came out was odd...

The entrees came out first and so we ended up cancelling the clam chowders and garlic bread that we had ordered as appetizers. Luckily, the head waiter (perhaps the owner?) came to our table and apologized for the unusual wait and promptly comped our chowders and garlic bread. It was a nice gesture to be sure, one that probably bumped this review up to a 4.

Anyway, about the food. I consider myself an amateur cioppino aficionado. It's basically a medley of seafood (fresh fish, shrimp, mussels, calimari, and scallops) served in a hot tomato-y broth. It's delicious. The BEST cioppino I ever had was at delmonico's on fisherman's wharf in monterey...but this dish can definitely hold its ground. The fish was very fresh and the seafood was good. The broth was a bit too strong for my taste...more of a tomato bisque than a broth, but it was good nonetheless.

The clam chowder was good too. Not too strong and not fishy at all. Honestly, I wasn't a huge fan, but my fiancee and my other friend (both girls) LOVED it. So maybe girls should get it?

Oysters were surprisingly good as well. I don't consider myself an oysterman by any stretch of the imagination, but these were...tolerable.

And finally the garlic bread...or should I say garlic manna from heaven. It was...the bomb. Possibly the best garlic bread I've ever had. You HAVE to get it if you come here.

All in all, this place would have been borderline 5 stars had the service been timelier, but because they did their genuine best to make up for it, I'll settle for a 4.
author: Jon K.

description: Food is good.  Staff not so much. Militant about their policy of having the whole party present.  Too pricey for food quality and diner atmosphere.
author: Christian S.

description: I've been here twice and both times, I thoroughly enjoyed my meal. I love that the menu is simple with a few specials. The food is not only delicious but the portions are generous. I always get the steamed clams that come with a white wine garlic stew. I've also had the crab cakes, also delicious. If you like clams but your dining partner likes mussels, get both because the stew is different for each. The only downside to this place is that it is rather small so the wait can be long. Go early!!! I will end with saying that the staff is friendly and attentive. I will be making this a regular on my list of favorite places to dine in SF.
author: Yuxuan N.

description: The dot system is crazy. Someone can put their name in at 530 then come back at 730 and just walk in at the next available seat opening. Their name should be erased and go to the back of the line.
author: Drew S.

description:
I had a craving for some steamed clams and decided last minute that I wanted to go to Anchor Oyster Bar.  After an hour drive on a Sunday night, I scored VIP parking right in front of the restaurant!  I walked in and there was an empty table calling my name.  Scored... no wait.

I started with the soju oyster shooters.  It was delicious!  There was just enough alcohol for me to feel a little tingly.  By the way, I'm a lightweight.

The clam chowder was good, not too rich and creamy and definitely made fresh with just enough potatoes and clams.  Don't forget to add the oyster crackers for an extra crunch.

This time around, I decided to get the steamed seafood combo.  It was good, but not as good as the steamed clams by itself.  The combo consisted of clams, mussels, green lip mussels, and shrimp.   I'm not a big fan of mussels but I thought I would give it a try.  The broth was nice and light with aromatics such as thyme, basil, lemon, and garlic.  The toasted garlic bread was definitely a good way to sop up the natural sweetness of the shellfish broth.  After I finished the bread, I just got a spoon and dug right into the bowl.  

The Mexican Corvina sea bass was another hit.  After the oyster shooters, clam chowder, steamed shellfish, and garlic bread, I was concerned that I had ordered too much food.  Thankfully, the sea bass was a very light dish.  It was more like a salad.  The sea bass was lightly fried with a nice crispy edge on a bed of lightly dressed spinach.  There were roasted carrots and fingerling potatoes. What tied the whole dish together was the fried garlic bits.  I love texture in my food, so the crispy garlic was a nice bonus.

Anchor Oyster Bar is a great place for fresh seafood.  It's a small, quaint place with eight seats at the bar, three tables that seat four, and two tables that seat three.  Come here and enjoy some seafood with a glass of wine for a relaxing meal.  Too bad they don't have dessert.
author: Laina T.

description:
Brings a whole new meaning to finger licking good! 

Be prepared to wait in line, get there an hour before the hunger beast hits because it is typically an hour plus wait. Be sure to write your name on the chalkboard as soon as you get there. The place is small but tables empty out fairly quickly so stick around in case your name gets called. 

Their clam chowder and bread is delicious. They always have a great assortment of oysters which is why I love going to this place but what really makes the meal is the cioppino! They have the best cioppino I have ever had in my life! It makes you want to lick the bowl and ask for another, yup that good. In fact just writing about it makes me want to go and have some.  

The reasonable prices, great oyster selection, amazing food, and great service make Anchor worth the wait.
author: Caro S.

description:
Ladies and gents, may I present to you Tubby Tubster? She packs on five hundy into her 62.5 inched frame (vertically). Yipyep, hello everybody!

Now everybody wants to know-- what's her secret? What in the world could possible contribute to her (and soon to be America's) chronic obesity?

Anchor Oyster Bar.

Anchor's chunky clam chowder that you may souse with a dozen packets of oyster crackers. Their ample St. Louis crab salad with hidden pockets of creamy Thousand Island Dressing. Their uber-stuffed St. Louis crab burger slathered with house-made tarter sauce. Their extra cheesy open-faced sandwich that makes you moan like Sally Albright at the delicatessen. Their buttery garlic bread, hot and toasty from the oven. The friendly pair and the Arnold Palmers they deliver to your table with their infecting smiles.

Stop reading and eat already!

W and I always end up spending at least $30 a piece here with happy bellies flopping all over the place (picture Steve Jobs during his last few moments with Homer Simpson's tummy). Pricey enough to keep us from hitting one thousy, but reasonable so we may visit at least a few times a month.
author: Elaine N.

description: We ate here twice this week, and loved everything! The oysters were amazing, the steamed seafood combo was heavenly, and the Anchor special was so fresh. The ambience is delightful, with only 5 tables and I believe 8 seats at the bar. The service was impeccable and it's obvious that the staff are in sync. The chef also made the rounds of the room, which added that special touch. We highly recommend this restaurant, it's no wonder they've been open for decades! We'll be back!
author: Ronaldo B.

description: Not only is the food delicious, but it's beautiful as well.  I haven't eaten here in a couple of years, but wanted to write an updated review because we recommended the restaurant to our Dentist and his wife, and they loved it!  They both said it was the BOMB and they would most certainly come back again, and I said I 2nd that EMOTION!!!!
author: Annette D.

description: AMAZING seafood, especially their cioppino. This place has ruined me.  I can no longer have cioppino from anywhere else.  Why must you be located so far from San Jose!  Awesome food in a fun area.
author: James L.

description: Took a while to get seated but it was worth. Oysters are very juicy and tasty as well as the clam chowder . Not 5 stars because the shrimp and crab burger were underwhelming and the water was 5/10.
author: Justin N.

description:
A great little oyster bar in the Castro. Definitely come early or be prepared to wait. There's only four tables or so and then a few seats along the bar.

They had three types of oysters, so we tried all of them and also got some clams and shrimp with the combo plate. We also had the halibut (just ok), crab cakes (a must), and clam chowder (excellent and not too creamy).

It's a nice place for a simple dinner or even just oysters and beers.
author: Kenny J.

description: Ben, our Uber driver, who picked us up at the airport hippes us to the place. Big props to u Ben!.. Took Uber to restaurant. Luckily no wait. We got in and had a.great meal,. I had the walnut crusted ted meat trout with roasted potatoes, broccoli rabb,  carrots, and asparagus. Oustanding!. Wife had excellent crab cakes and roasted veggies. Daughter and.mother-inlae had shellfish with linguine in butterand lemon sauce. Wel.worth the trip. As.Arnold used to say, "I'll be back!".
author: Kevin B.

description: Best seafood restaurant in San Francisco. We go once a month because it's that incredible.
author: Michael M.

description:
Man ol' man, where do I begin. 
I waited 1 hour and 20 minutes before I was seated. I arrived at 7:40pm. 
Place your name on the white board to the right of the door. Be sure to write your name, the time you arrive, and circle the number of guest in your party. 
Please, please, PLEASE... be courteous to your fellow seafood eating friends and NOT erase their names off the white board OR lie about the time you arrive. People ARE WATCHING. 


This place is pretty small, but definitely worth the wait. 
bar seating, 3 or 4 tables of 4, 2 tables of 2-3 seats. 

One of the waitstaff came out and offered us clam chowder! WoohoOo! 

House Bread - it comes with WARM butter. YAY! No bread spread ripping that night. 
Clam Chowder (6, bowl)- SO DELICIOUS! They got the soup portion right - not too watery, but not creamy thick. 
Garlic Bread (6) - delicious! It comes with toasted cheese. mmmMmmmm 
Garlic Clams (24) - These were delicious. I only wish there was a different cooking/flavor for the clam, other than that I would highly recommend this dish. The clams are definitely fresh and you can taste it. We got 43 clams! 

You  might be wondering why I didn't get the cioppino, that's because I don't eat oysters or mussels. So yeah, I probably missed out. 

I recommend you bring your young children, especially those who think throwing rocks at their parents is okay and opening and closing the door on a cold San Francisco night because people definitely can use a big fat gush of fresh cold air during their meal.

I highly recommend you and your friends to come here (not in a large group of course).
author: Jess W.

description: This is ny second time here. We waited for almost 2hrs to get in, but it worth it 100 percent. Great meals, great service, great ambiance. It is my oster joint to go place. Thanks for your gracious hosting. I will be back.
author: Mitra M.

description: Came here after reading all the reviews. This place truly does live up to the hype! Had the garlic cracked crab and split the small Cioppino between 2 of us. It was heaven on earth for me. Garlic crab and broth was unreal! Cioppino was also amazing. Definitely try this place out! Only downside was size and seating. Super tight and expect a wait. Well worth it though
author: Chris K.

description: I was excited about this place, waited for more than half an hour to be seated, but it turned out the crab was not even hot, it was lukewarm and didn't taste as good. I was kinda worry that I might get food poison after eating that crab. And the Clam chowder was just meh. I still don't know why they have such high rating on yelp. This place is so mediocre. I definitely won't come back anymore in case I get food poison next time due to their lukewarm seafood.
author: Cory J.

description:
This is probably the best seafood restaurant in San Francisco. 

This tiny neighborhood standard sets the bar for quality, fresh food, and friendly, helpful service. I've tried many of the items on the menu and everything is always fresh, flavorful, and delicious!

Anchor Oyster Bar definitely has the best Cioppino in the bay area (and we've tried them all.) All seafood (no potato or pasta filler like some area restaurants) with a delicate yet complex tomato broth and amazing hearty garlic bread for savoring. If you don't see it on the menu, definitely ask if it's available! 

The space is very small so you may have to wait during prime dining time, but you will be glad you did!
author: J D.

description:
Lately I've been on this oyster/seafood kick. All I want are oysters and beer and or any type of seafood and beer. Needless to say, I'm a repeat offender. I repeat offend seafood restaurants that I know and have grown to love. Enter...Anchor Oyster Bar. I don't live in the neighborhood but I will gladly get out of bed, get in my car, roam around for parking, just to have a meal here. I've been here many times (no idea how I even forgot to review the place) and I've never been disappointed with my meal. 

Last weekend my coworkers and I decided to come for dinner. We were greeted and seated immediately. The waitstaff are always so friendly and personable. I'm pretty sure they think I'm this weird crazy stalker lady since I'm there all the time. I just love me some oysters. There is bar seating with ample tables. It is VERY popular so come early if you want to avoid any waiting. The decor is simple, not overdone or tacky. It has always looked clean every time I have visited. 

Anyway, we enjoyed the clam chowder (so good on a chilly day), shrimp salad and the half order of the Anchor special (oysters, steamed clams, and chilled prawns). Yum. It is by far my favorite plate on the menu. We also shared some of the crab, which was surprisingly very tasty. I hardly ever get crab outside of Asian restaurants (its just the Asian in me) but I really liked Anchor's crab. My coworker has the crab cakes as an entree and she mentioned that she loved it. It was cooked to perfection, not soggy or mealy. She described it as "just like how they make them on the Food Network." Whatever that means. 

I'm always here. So there is no point in telling you that I will come back. But I highly suggest checking them out. Great food, awesome service, clean and inviting atmosphere. Highly recommend!
author: Katie Anne N.

description: You have to come and write your name on the white at the front door. There is no advance booking. The restaurant is pretty small and can accommodate not more than 30 peoples. The oyster is fresh and the signature dishes can well feed two men. The famous Castro street for LGBT community can supplement your visit while you are...
author: Michael W.

description:
We arrived about 3:30 pm which we were told was perfect time to come to ensure getting a table. It's  very warm in here and that was uncomfortable and we liked it every time someone arrived and opened front door so fresh air came in.

I'd say the service was worst part.  We had to ask for  water refills.  And even then she only filled one glass and no one else's empty glass at the table. So odd!!!!

We ordered the cioppino, fish tacos, oysters in the half shell.  We didn't realize until the check that she brought us the cioppino for TWO when we wanted the smaller size.  

So be super clear when you order. Because they don't ask!  

Very long wait for the food.  It was so hot, and they dint refill water and we were dying waiting.....

I would not say it's the best cioppino in town but it was pretty good!  The fresh fish was really good,  the fish tacos were tasty but average and forgettable. Served with some boring rice,  the oysters were great appetizer.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Had my first cioppino here, and it was really, really good. 
Really fresh seafood, very well seasoned, buttery garlic bread and great atmosphere. 
Expensive, but not more so than seafood normally is. 
Will definitely be back.
author: Maroka K.

description:
This is my favorite place in the city to get oysters.
The service is always great and the staff is so friendly.

Do get the garlic bread
Do dip in the clams steamer broth

HEAVEN
author: Anne-Mary P.

description:
There are numerous recounts of how good the cioppino is already so I won't get into that nor do I need to talk about the freshness of the seafood or the sublime garlic bread.

All I want to say is that this establishment helps me weed out Yelp reviewers. From now on, any yelper that gave Anchor Oyster Bar any rating less than 4 stars no longer has reviews that interest me for our tastes obviously differ. Fortunately, that leaves a lot of reviewers that were blown away by the seafood here.
author: Chris C.

description: The cioppino was really amazing.. And big!  Order it with an extra side of garlic bread!  This review is really just based on the cioppino, and the fact that you can see the chef prepare the cioppino in front of you is really cool as well.
author: Austin N.

description: Its not very often in this life, that food, reaches art, and art, is attained by grace, and grace does not come easily. My wife and I experienced this culinary GEM tonight for the first, but definitely not the last time! Ordered the garlic bread, glass of merlot, half order of Oysters from Washington state..believe they were called flapjacks? Then for the main course, Ciapotto..hopefully I spelled that correctly. This dish just sparkled, and was a seafood delight. Service was amazing, very friendly atmosphere. A must!
author: Michael W.

description:
What an amazing experience!  Nestled into a row of businesses and other restaurants on Castro Street/Ave(?) is this 30 person max seafood restaurant in the heart of San Francisco!  The smell of morning picked fresh sea-foods is intoxicating.  The decor is quaint, but quite honestly it could have had flat walls with no color and the food alone would have made this place a must visit! However a nautical theme is evident and eye catching.

Tip!  Pay attention when the waiter specifies that a dish is a "large portion!"  I had the Cioppino special which probably weighed 15 pounds and was intended for two or more people.  It was my entree and it took me almost 45 minutes to finish it.  There was such a generous amount of fish and shelled deliciousness!  Fresh squeezed lemonade washed it down perfectly!
author: Alex T.

description: Long wait, but the freshest oysters in SF
author: Phillip C.

description: The check in process is ridiculous. The wait was 2 hours and we waited. Others who's name was called were able to get ahead of us even tho they weren't there at the time they were called but was able to get ahead of us. Never again!
author: Kiko C.

description: Today after shopping for our new years party I went to Anchor Oyster Bar to pick my order that I phoned in 3 days ago. All I ordered was 18 jumbo prawns. I've always ordered the same thing and always yummy. Not so much, today, entered AOB went to the back told the girl  I'm here for my order, some older woman came out from behind the glass and threw a bag of prawns on the counter. I asked if they were going to be put in the box that they are always in, not really any response from anyone. Then the lady again came out and put the stuff in a bag. Not looking until I got home and upset since I spent 53.10 for an order I that I have to prep, I got half a container of cocktail sauce and about a tablespoon of horse radish, the best...2 whole lemons. Wth, I called and complained to I guess the owner, she asked if I want to come back and they'll box it up...no I'm not going back to repack my prawns. Owner stated she will talk to the staff, really? What would have been nice to get our business back would have offered a discount on our next order. Oh well, lost us. Joy
author: Joy E.

description:
Ok.  Let me preface this by saying I work in hospitality - I've been a manager in the  fine dining world of NYC, won stars with James Beard Chefs, executed private events for celebrity clients, and won bids with high end, high budget event producers.  

Everything I thought I knew, or was better than, or tried - is so woefully under performing when put up against the simple, humble, perfectly prepared meal I shared with my wife on the first night of our honeymoon.  Fresh, well presented dishes, that were thoughtful, true to their local, and served by some of the most genuine staff members I've ever encountered.  No show, no egos, nothing but the best food you will put in your mouth, paired with some of North Cali's small wine producers.  We went on to spend a week in Napa, and the entire time... all I could do was talk about our the oysters, and fresh pasta with linguisa, the Markham sauv blanc.

Make this a mandatory stop on your travels, expect to wait, don't be a jerk, don't ask a million questions, don't instagram your whole meal - just go, enjoy, and spend the rest of your life knowing you may never have a meal as humble, or as tasty in your life.
author: S C.

description:
Tiny place. Huge portions. 

This was actually our second trip to Anchor, as I had visited here previously a few years ago. Imagine the wife and I's surprise when friends recommended we all go to this place! As the name of the restaurant suggests, it was mostly the thought of fresh pacific oysters that drew us back. Of the various places that have very good oysters we know of in SF, this was the one that was open in the evening.

And indeed, the oysters were beautiful, local fresh and paired with great delicate mignonette sauce as well as the traditional horseradish (both of which we used sparingly so as not to cover the taste of the mollusk). We ordered two varieties from different areas, and they were indeed distinct from one another in taste and brine and the waiter had represented each perfectly when we asked prior to ordering.

Did I mention that the service is very friendly and attentive -- despite the fact that the restaurant was packed with customers. This brings me to a word of warning: Anchor is TINY, so get here right as they open (about 5:30) if you don't want a crazy wait.

Inside, the decor is intimate and charming, and features an open kitchen which inspires confidence in the cooks handling your fish. On our prior visit, the chef owner was there and quite friendly.

I had a seafood pasta in a garlic cream sauce and it was great; I was asked if I wanted a variety of seafood or prawns, and I chose the prawns. When it arrived it was generous within the dish, and the portion was monstrously large. My wife had the river trout special, and the fish was fresh and perfectly prepared. It was also a generous helping.

Thus, while the prices aren't exactly inexpensive, the portions offset it quite a bit.
author: Ian T.

description: So fresh. Some of the best most cleanly shucked oysters I've ever had. Plus their home potatoes which are just a side dish are actually insanely delicious and perfect sopping up lemon sauce. One of the only classic sf joints still standing and never wavering on quality. The service is simple but you can tell they truly care and put their heart into it.
author: Lera D.

description: The food was so amazing that it's prompting me to post my first review! The cioppino was one of the best dishes I've ever had in my entire life. The broth was so flavorful and the garlic bread was divine! I recommend going there before it opens about 15 minutes to get a seat!
author: Michelle B.

description:
Soooooo good. The place is small but very cozy. Very well lit and there's jazz in the background which definitely is the way to set me in a good mood. We came around 6:30 and only waited for about half an hour. 
We started with the Anchor Special (half order) which includes half a dozen of oysters, two shrimps and some steamed clams. All of them were just amazing. Whatever they used in the steamed clams sauce was working super well. The clam chowder was very delicious and creamy. Then we had the Cesar salad with crabmeat. I thought It was pretty pricy for salad but then I changed my mind when the waitress brought us two big plates of the salad and told me she split it. The salad was very good and there was a good amount of crabmeat in it. Then we had the cioppino (smaller order) and it was splendid. There were fish, mussels, cracked crab, clams, and two piece of bread in the big bowl. By the time we got the check, I was beyond full and fulfilled :) 
Wooooo and the service was great too.
author: Sabrina L.

description:
Went there on a Saturday night at around 6:45pm. The wait was approximately 1 hour and 45 minutes. I think they have less than 10 bar stools and about 4 tables available for seating. Don't even think about going in there with a party of 20 because you'll have to book the entire restaurant. haha.

Heres a helpful tip:
The host tends to come outside and do a "check" on who is waiting. Don't let this deter you from leaving. We literally stood outside for the full 1.75hrs waiting for our table...and others who left and came back before they were called got to get seated before us because they "checked-in" before us.
THEREFORE......go ahead and write your name...walk across the street to the wine bar...and have a good time there for an hour or so, then come back. What you can also do is tell the host that you'll be going across the street for some wine and desert. I literally watched him run across the street to the other bar to tell someone that their table is read (Maybe they're regulars? not sure...)

Anyway...the food was amazing. Don't know if i'll ever be down to wait for 2 hours again....

We got the cippino (sp?). It seems to be the most highly recommended dish. It comes packed with fish, crab, huge mussels, clam, prawns, and the soup that its cooked in is  mouth watering.

We also got the "anchor special", which is a dozen raw oysters, fat prawns, and some garlic butter clams. This is definitely worth it too. 

WARNING: DONT FILL YOURSELF UP WITH THE FREE BREAD!!! ORDER THE GARLIC BREAD. *droooools*

Anyhoo....the service was outstanding. I love that you can see into the kitchen. Its amazing to see what a small kitchen and small staff they have while producing such amazing food. The food was great.
The wait is crap.

So if you're a patient person that wants great food and service...I highly recommend this place.


*****another tip******
Oh yeah, the waiter gave us a tip...go on Sunday at around 4pm. Thats when they open. He says the restaurant is near empty whenever they just open.... That will solve your waiting issue.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Food is delicious! Oysters and ciopinno are my favorite! The ciopinno is even better as a left over with some pasta. Yes, the wait is always at least an hour for dinner, 2 hours on weekends. So just go at 4:30pm when they open and just have a REALLY early dinner. Or just come here for lunch. There's usually only a few table for lunch during the weekday. There's heat lamps outside, so you won't wait in the cold. They give you free clam chowder while you wait too.

My husband and I had our first date here and it was the perfect start of our relationship =)
author: Kimberly L.

description: The half order of the Anchor special was the perfect afternoon snack for the BF and me. The oysters were super fresh, the prawns were perfectly cooked, and the clams were swimming in a lemony, garlic broth. YUM! I've had my fair share of steamed clams and the sauce in this one was fantastic-- it was really light and the splash of chili flakes was a nice touch that really brought the dish together. The service was great and they were also so gracious in letting me charge my phone by the counter! Thanks!
author: Allison S.

description:
I've been here 3 times and I always leave feeling satisfied. Yes the wait is long, but luckily there are local bars for you to go get drinks. Come back to check on the list often, they don't give you a call when it's your turn. 

Oysters are fresh but they are limited. 
The cioppino comes in full and half size, the half size was good enough. 
The cod was cooked perfectly and was just melting in your mouth.
The clam chowders are to die for and they offer it to those who are waiting outside. 
The service is great and so is the food. Hope they can expand their restaurant in the future so the wait isn't too brutal.
author: Lisa n.

description: This is by far the best meal I've ever had. I'm a huge seafood fanatic and after the 1.5 hour wait I was ready to dig in with two of my best buds. We started with the oysters which were beyond fresh and tasted amazing, and moved to the crab-cakes crusted to perfection. We ordered two entrees, the sandabs and the shellfish combo, and I have to say nothing I've had in years has compared to this meal.
author: BigNik R.

description:
While I can't add much that hasn't already been said about it being small and having yummy food (ciopino was amazing), there are a few details that made this place a fun experience.  We arrived early at five with a baby in tow so had a tight schedule and saw there was a table ready, but by the time we parked the 4top was taken with 2. They were very accommodating and switched the two people to a two top so that we could sit. 

I love the decorations and ambiance. I felt like I went back in time to another era. Clean modern yet rustic sea.  

Going to the bathroom was even an experience as we had to walk through the kitchen do it felt like I got a tour of masters at work. Seafood was fresh. 

I would say don't go off you are in as hurry but do go.
author: Sonya L.

description: A friend was visiting from out of town and our first choice was Swan Oyster Depot (which is phenomenal), but the line was too long so we went here. I've wanted to try this place given the average of 4.5 stars among over 1,000 reviews on Yelp but it did not live up to the hype. We had the clam chowder, combo shellfish, garlic bread and cracked crab...eh, it was all ok (not terrible) but nothing special. Seafood tasted frozen, definitely didn't taste live and fresh.
author: B T.

description:
I ordered take out because we had a party of 8 and didn't want to wait in line.  There are only a few tables and some bar seating.  This place is small like most places here in SF. I basically ordered based on recommendations and yelp reviews. 

Cioppino was amazing! I ordered the half order because my friends were already full.  We just wanted to have a taste and see how good this dish was. There was a great portion and selection of seafood in this dish. There was about half a crab, fish, clams, shrimp, and mussels with a delicious sauce. The seafood tasted fresh and was cooked perfectly. I found myself dipping the bread in the sauce alone when the seafood was gone. I'm salivating as I'm writing this review hours later.

Garlic bread was perfectly cooked with visible garlic pieces cooked into the bread. I believe it's butter that's soaked throughout into each piece. 

Clam chowder was extremely creamy and buttery. This was definitely one of the better clam chowders I've tasted. I wish there were more clams.

I did not have a chance to try the oysters. Maybe next time!
author: Theresa D.

description: This place was awesome!  Great service!  We got in as soon as they opened at 11:30.   The garlic bread was the best I've had anywhere.  The clam chowder was light but flavorful.  Alex, who served us, made sure our table was always clear for food, constantly picking up napkins and oyster cracker wrappers - great service.
author: Vernon A.

description:
I've been to Anchor twice, and each time they did not disappoint.  Food was on point!

Hands down, the best (1) crab cakes, (2) clam chowder (even better than in Boston), and (3) garlic bread I've ever put in my mouth!  That's all ya gotta know.

Ok, ok...here are a few more thoughts:
-This place gets busy and the dining room only has a half dozen or so tables and a long bar.  So be prepared to wait or come super early.  Or put your name down on the list and grab a few drinks at a bar nearby in the Castro.  Just don't drink too much because you'll definitely want to enjoy your meal here.

-Be sure to check out the specials white board above the bar.  There is a rotating menu featuring some of the freshest catches from the sea!

That's about it.  Get #1-3 I mentioned above and I promise you'll be a happy camper.
author: Matt S.

description:
Absolutely the best! Anchor is one of those places where no matter how often you go, you are always assured of a consistently fabulous experience. It's tiny, so unless you get there before it opens, hit it just right, or are just really lucky, you will probably have to wait a bit to get in. But is it ever worth the wait!! 

The menu is limited -- all seafood, natch! -- but you may be sure that no matter what you order, you will be served the freshest, tastiest seafood and shellfish ever! Don't get me going on the fisherman's stew -- loaded with succulent shellfish in a spicy broth!!! Drool-worthy!

And if you go more than a few times, Alex will remember what you like to drink and will ask if you want to order the same dishes you had last time. Now that's nice. 

There's always an interesting assortment of clientele, lots of regulars, and often tourists and foreigners here on holiday who presumably read the raves online or in a guidebook. 

Anchor is a true San Francisco treasure!
author: E. G.

description:
I've had one too many fishy tasting oysters so I'm always a little weary when eating raw oysters..but this place has some delicious, succulent and fresh oysters! I've never loved raw oysters so much! I'm so happy we found this place after we found out the other restaurant we wanted to try (Swan Oyster Depot) was closed. We arrived a little after 5 on the Monday the day after Christmas and this place was already packed. We were asked to write our names on the board just outside of the restaurant and to take a seat outside. As we were waiting, a waiter handed us a cup of their clam chowder. It was not thick and more soupy than what I'm usually used to, but was very tasty and wholesome. Also, there are many shops in the area to check out while you wait..

And for people that gave low reviews who didn't even try their oysters..Hello!! Read the name of the place - Anchor Oyster Bar. Don't knock it if you only tried their garlic bread and clam chowder.
author: April Rose D.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place!! (Did I mention that I absolutely LOVE this place?) My friend from LA wanted to eat oysters for dinner and I didn't want to take her to the overly crowded and over priced places in SF, so we decided to try Anchor Oyster Bar. We're so glad we did! 

When we got there, we were worried that we wouldn't find parking on a Friday night, but we ended up finding one 2 blocks down. When we got to the restaurant there was a couple tables before us, but we were seated in about 45 mins (which is an amazing time compared to the 10 groups of people who came in after us). 

When the manager/server took our order, he was so considerate in closing the door since we sat right next to the open door. (You don't really see that these days). We decided to order a bowl of clam chowder for my friend, half order of the seafood combination, and a full order of the Cioppino. When the clam chowder came out, instead of giving us 1 bowl, the server/manager decided to give us 3 small bowls, one for each of us! SO SWEET! The clam chowder was a great way to start our meal bc it was soo warm and filled with yummy clams and potatoes. It was one of the best clam chowders I've had in the city.
