When the seafood combination came out (6 oysters, 2 prawns and a bowl of clams in a garlic/wine/rosemary/butter broth) the server/manager gave us an extra prawn so that each one of us had one to ourselves. HOW SWEET IS THAT?? I've never experienced such great and considerate service as I have with the staff at Anchor Oyster Bar. The clams in the garlic/wine/rosemary/butter broth was AMAZING!!!! I've never tasted a broth SO DELICIOUS! My friends and I kept using the clam shells and bread to drink more of that heavenly broth. 

We had to force ourselves to not finish the broth because the CIOPPINO came! The full order is HUGE!!!! we were amazed by how much we got for the price we paid for it. The garlic bread was a great pairing with the tomato base of the Cioppino soup/broth. The soup/broth of the Cioppino is amazingly DELICIOUS! We had plenty of clam, oysters, mussels, shrimp, cod, and lobsters to share with each other and plenty of broth/soup. After about 3 bowls each, we were done with our meal. (I regretted eating so much bread bc I could've saved more room to finish the Cioppino soup/broth)

In the end, the wait and the price we paid for our meal was DEFINITELY WORTH IT! This is definitely my go-to place to splurge on when I want to eat out.
author: Jenn C.

description: Very delicious Ciopinno! Seafood was top notch, bread was the best... Sauce, good but not mind blowing... I think I also prefer some pasta in my Ciopinno. All in all 4 stars, would be 5 stars if it wasn't in SF competing against other seafood restaurants... Oysters were good, but that doesn't require anything other than buying them from the right place and getting them to the table so I can't include that in my review. 5stars to the guys in Washington who harvested them I guess.
author: r k.

description: My friend and I decided to give their Clam Chowder a try but the restaurant was pretty busy so we ended up getting a bowl to go.  I am a fan of their chowder.  It's not too thick or thin...pretty good consistency.  It was nice and creamy...the way I like it.  The potatoes were tender; always a plus.  The only negative thing I could say is I wish there were more clams in it.  I don't like to have to "fish" for clams in my chowder.  But other than that, it was a really tasty chowder.  I'd like to go back and try their other dishes.
author: Rose A.

description: I was lucky I came alone. I was able to jump in front of a lot of folks on the list. Small, cozy place. High prices, but high quality. Got chowder, salad and my first raw oyster ever. All great. They need to find a new bread provider though - I'd recommend Acme or another local one with some punch.
author: Khalid N.

description:
This place is OK, but not that amazing. I'd give it a 3.5 stars, and bump up cause there was no glaring bad stuff. 

Came here on a weekday, and waited a mere hour to get in. We failed because we were the 4th large group to wait - there's only 3 tables for groups of 4. We were a group of 5 and there's really only one table for that size. Umm..I'd suggest coming as a group of 2. The waiters were nice and tried to serve as quickly as possible. It was a little strange though, that we were waiting and the guy came out to tell a group of 4 white chicks that if we weren't here waiting they were next. Umm...if you look around, you can clearly see we were a group of 5 people who were waiting. Oh, well. At least we were seated before them.

What we ordered:
Pasta of the day (Panchetta seafood penne): It was good! The panchetta wasn't very evenly spaced, but you had light hints of it. There was probably a slab of panchetta in each of the dishes. There was a crispy garlic thing on it which was yummy.

Clams in sauce: Either we were hungry, or this is delicious. The sauce was decent (not the BEST, but it's yummy).

Clam Chowder: I have learned a cup of clam chowder is never enough. Always go for a bowl. The chowder was decent, but there was nothing very unique about it. There was a fair amount of clam chunks in there, which I appreciated.

Green Mussels: Also yummy - similar sauce to the clams, but with some tomatoes. Yummy...

Garlic Prawns with roasted veg: This was probably my least favorite dish. I like my veg, and speared a broccoli for myself...which was kind of burnt. I tasted a carrot later, which was still burnt. We probably should have requested a change in it, but the shrimp was fine...so I guess when they roasted the veg, they over roasted?

Service was pretty good. They had about 3-4 servers for a restaurant fit for about 30 people max, so the servers were really attentive. Pretty nice, actually!
author: Lily W.

description:
I've been prowling around this place for years, always thinking that there wasn't room for me in there. I wondered what it was like to be inside rather than on the outside peering in, rubbing my empty stomach and hoping someone would throw a half-eaten crab leg my way. Oh who am I kidding? I just don't like crowds. But last Monday, I saw my opening. I was in a good mood because I bought a nice Briggs & Riley bag at Michael Bruno and entered the place with my head held high.

Man, it's small in there. Tables are not an option for singularly-minded diners. I went straight for the counter where I saw three stools empty. I naturally sat in the middle hoping another couple would not come in. I don't mind voluntarily sliding to the next stool if I see it would accommodate a happy couple. I just hate it when they automatically say - "Well, if Fatso would move, we could all be happy." That's a true story that happened in a New York luncheonette. But no such invectives came my way this evening, and the serving staff was nice as can be in accommodating my first-time visit there.

I took a quick look at the menu and a much longer one at the handwritten menu overhead. It took me a while to read not because I am dyslexic but because the penmanship was marginal. They need Mr. Chalkboard Guy or whoever does the perfectly lined Squat & Gobble-Crepevine-SoMa Inn chalkboard menus. I went for a $4.25 cup of Clam Chowder, a house specialty (see my photo). Probably because I'm the type who would think nothing of putting heavy cream into a saucepan of Progresso's New England-Style Clam Chowder, I just thought it was on the watery side. True, the clams were fresh, but the consistency brought out my tendency to splash the soup onto my shirt.

Better was the $22.95 San Pedro California Striped Bass - pan-seared and served with a risotto mixed with some toasted pinenuts and thyme (see my photo). They served grilled asparagus, a perfect complement to a well-done, hearty slab of fish - though I still think there was a tad too much cornstarch in the risotto (you could almost stand a fork in it). The meal was quite satisfying, just not quite the wowee-wow I was led to believe it would be. And I never did have to move my seat. I'd come back since the mystery is gone, as I really want to try the cioppino next time. Maybe I can even sit at a table, too.

FOOD - 4 stars...good fish, watery chowder, all fresh
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...very white and very compact...kinda like Dakota Fanning
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...yes, stellar...both the young guy with the nice smile and the guy who's been there for centuries
TOTAL - 4 stars...neither up to the hype or down with the bottom-feeders...even if the Castro is the land of the bottom-feeders (ba-bump-bump)
author: Ed U.

description: Would never ever go to this sh&thole again. We were next on the list for a table for two, fu&king "host" decides NOPE the table for two that opened up is going to the party of 3 that arrived 10 minutes after us. We could sit at the bar or F off. Went elsewhere screw them. Never ever again.
author: Bob I.

description:
Was an accidental find years ago for the bf and me, but evidently a not so secret gem judging by the yelp reviews!  

Fantastic cioppino - rich savory broth with layers of flavor, and chock full of seafood,  perfectly cooked.  Was so good we stuffed ourselves silly! 

Still dreaming of the cioppino all the way out in NYC - SF, you evidently still have my heart. ;)
author: Kim N.

description: 非常新鲜，好吃！Yummy and reasonable price! First time in San Francisco, We came here two days in a row...
author: Zu X.

description: My family was visiting from New England, and since they are rather picky about their seafood, we took them here Monday night.  High quality, delicious oysters. Excellent preparations (chilled with salted butter and hot drenched in garlic and butter) for their dungeness crab. Very good crab cakes and chowder as well. Even their salads were well-made and fresh, as fresh as their seafood. My parents were very pleased, and my boyfriend and I were over-the-moon. We'll be back soon!
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Amazing cioppino. Nothing more I can say other than eat there now.  Best meal in San Francisco.  Be prepared to wait but the neighborhood is interesting and they brought out samples during the wait.
author: Alison M.

description: My fiancé and I absolutely love the ciopino dish here! The oysters are fresh and pulped. The service was good. The waiter warned us that we might over order :X We will most certainly be back; Till next time San Francisco!
author: Thuy C.

description:
I hope the owner is seeing this because something must change. Under regular circumstances I would give this place a 3*, but if I do just that, I won't be able to make a statement. 

I rate restaurants based on the entire experience from food, ambiance all the way to its service quality. 

If we're talking about just food, like all other reviewers, I agree they have probably one of the best and most addicting seafood soup I ever had in my life. Everyone gets it who go there. Just ask for their signature seafood soup. 

So you're probably asking why the 1 star?

Their service quality is simply awful to the 1 millionth power. If it wasn't for chef patty, who was probably the only nice person there, it would be awful to the 2 millionth power. 

They probably have one of THE SLOWEST service speed I have ever experienced in my life. To set up one table with 5 sets of service plates and utensils, it took them 20 minutes. That is ridiculous considering they only have 10 tables total in the entire restaurant. Once we sat down, we were hoping things would be better. The next thing we knew, we were greeted poorly by a grumpy server. The entire meal probably took 1.5 hour, when we only ordered 2 or 3 dishes. I won't lie, we enjoyed the food. But when we were done, we wanted to get out of there ASAP. But guess what!, they wouldn't even let us do that.... We called for the check...30 minutes later, we were still staring at each other twiddling our thumbs. I mean seriously, does it take 30 minutes for us to get a simple check????

On top of that, when we asked for to-go on our seafood SOUP, they packed everything EXCEPT the SOUP. Are you kidding me? I asked you to get my soup togo, but you didn't give me any soup...Seriously???

This restaurant seriously needs some help with staffing and service training.  When you have such a great product, it's really a shame to have such a simple problem hold you back.

If you are willing to wait till your hair starts falling off, you're definitely coming to the right place.
author: Alan T.

description: THE BEST CIOPPINO I HAVE EVER HAD!!! All the ingredients are FRESH! The flavor has so much depth and all the seafood flavor literally just bursts in ur mouth. Great portions with great prices. Also their garlic bread is to die for! We waited for an hour and twenty minutes and they were serving us garlic bread and a small cup of clam chowder. Small gestures like this really shows how much they care about their customers. 2nd time this week and I gotta say, money well spent! Thank u for such great hospitality! Definitely will be back cuz this is my new favorite restaurant.
author: Ella A.

description:
This has become one of our mainstays when we're too lazy to cook at home and want to treat ourselves. During our most recent visit, we shared an order of garlic bread (possibly the best garlic bread on the planet) and clam chowder, crab cake entree for him, one of the daily specials for me (steamed Alaskan cod with lemon & thyme, mashed potatoes, and asparagus), with iced tea & white wine to drink...our bill was just under $60. A tremendous value compared to most meals we've enjoyed at this caliber in SF.

As this establishment is small, and gets busy, I recommend dining early. We love having early dinners here around 5-6pm during the weekdays, and right when they open at 4pm on Sundays. We're able to take our time and don't feel the pressure of having to rush through our meal to make room for waiting customers. Also, make sure to check out the daily specials written by the door and up above the bar's dry-erase board. They're always a treat, and almost never repeated twice.
author: Elaine W.

description: Best seafood ever have in my life!!!!I'm from LA and that's my second time here. We got steam shellfish combination and Cioppino, both very delicious and the broth is just killing. Had a great night with my baby for our first anniversary.
author: Mengxiao Amy L.

description:
Hubby and I came here on a Thursday afternoon around 1:30 and all the tables were full but there were still a few chairs at the bar so we were able to grab those and sit immediately.

While we were up in SF I tried oysters at several different places and this one is by far the best I had.  They were decent sized and tasted very fresh.  I wish I had a dozen in front of me now...*sigh. 

We also ordered the pasta which was REALLY good and the cioppino (not on the menu so make sure to ask for it!) was awesome as well.  The half order was enough for me and hubby to share. I saw a table next to us order the Manhattan Seafood Stew and oh dear that looked good too.  I would without a doubt come back here. 

By the time we were finished, which was about 3pm the place had pretty much emptied out, so that's a good time to come, I suppose!
author: Patti O.

description:
A change of plans and the need for a fabulous dinner found us once again at Anchor Oyster Bar!!!  We never mind the 45 minute wait because we always find ourselves happy and so very satisfied.  Greeted by the same wonderful guy trip after trip who always remembers us and greets us with a great smile--you are FABU!!!
A little chilly out as almost always,  we were provided with a little paper cup of amazing clam chowder--really delish!!!  A cute couple waiting outside and chilled to the bone was given a special AOB blanket to wrap themselves in while they wait--A pleasant surprise indeed!!!

Once in, we ordered 6 oysters, 2 of each.  Fresh, fresh, fresh and wonderful on the palate!!!  More please!!!!  Followed by the jumbo artichoke - cooked to perfection with a wonderful dipping sauce!!!  Really lovely!!!

And of course, our frequent entree (even when not on the menu) cioppino!!!  OMG!!  The perfect garlic bread, clams, mussels, shrimp, fish and the sauce--give me some extra to go!!!!  And a wonderful cabernet to top it all off.

This is our 5 star favorite--always amazingly delicious!!!!

More than a pleasant surprise!!!
author: Jeff P.

description:
AMAZING FOOD.

-FRIED OYSTERS
-GARLIC BREAD
-DUNGEONNESS CRAB stuffed with sole fish and mashed potatoes
-house special Pancho (or panko?? its not listed on the menu)

I was playing tourguide in the city, and my boyfriend wanted to eat SF seafood for dinner. I asked my brother to look up a place (since i still do not own a smart phone) and he redirected us here. 

For starters we had the house special FRIED OYSTERS which is what everybody raves about. They. Were. Amazing. I recently became a fan of charboiled oysters (I HATE the texture and taste of regular raw oysters), and these fried oysters were GREAT!! Then for entrees we ordered the special for the day which is a DUNGEONNESS CRAB stuffed with SOLE FISH and mashed potatoes. I've been wanting to try the dungeonness crab for forever, as it is not an east coast delicacy so I was incredibly excited to try it!! and just let me tell you, it lived up to my expectations and more! The sole was also amazing and delicious.  My man ordered the house special PANCHO (or panko? i forget what it's actually called) which came with GARLIC BREAD. It's a soupy seafood extravanganza. 

Ok. To be honest, the first bite of the garlic bread is very par. However, after you get past the first bite, omg. the Garlic bread is delish just like everyone raves about! 

Overall, it was one of the better seafood meals i've had in my life. It's so amazing.  OMG definitely a MUST GO!!

Etc - This place is super CUTE! You put your name, party quantity, and time of arrival at this white board outside, and you can wait in the seats for them to come get you when there's a space available. The area is super COZY and quaint with cute decorations. The bathroom is super cute, organized, and pretty! It's tucked back into a little corner behind the kitchen.
The kitchen is kind of in an open space behind  a circular open window thing in the back, but you can definitely see them preparing your food. At the end ,I gave the chef and sous-chef my regards and I think they really appreciated it! The food was so amazing I love this place. Can't wait to go back out and try other restaurants in the castro district. I wish the east coast had a Castro district / Anchor oyster bar as well. 

Note - while i was sitting outside waiting for my name to be called, a naked pair of old wrinkly men walked past me in the chilly sf weather. hahaha. oh man. only in castro....
author: Christine L.

description: I wish we could be able to rate this place 100,000,000,000 stars!  My hubby and I have been here for the third time tonight and we always order the anchor special.  It comes with 12 oysters, 4 jumbo prawns and steamed clams plus two cups of the most fantastic Boston clam chowder.   This place is the best oyster bar ever. The staff and chefs are friendly and make sure you're taken care of.   Do not hesitate to stop here.   It is worth your time waiting and the price.
author: Joshua G.

description:
This place is the quintessential San Francisco establishment.Everything about it is awesome: the food, the ambiance, the service. I no longer look at the menu when I go--it's all about the cioppino. I even ordered it to go for Valentine's Day, and they were so thoughtful in the way they packaged it for us to finish cooking at home. 

A word of advice: I would recommend avoiding peak times if you don't have time to wait, because it's quite small with very few tables.
author: Lisa F.

description:
Walking up on a wet evening last night, we put our name on the  list.  Tip - stick near the door because if you are not there when your name is called, your seat can be given away.  As luck would have it, that happened just after we put our names on, and we were sat at the bar after about a 5 minute wait.  Tip two - sit at the bar if offered. The table seating is very cramped and the wait for a table is much longer than the bar.

The food was awesome.  I had the sandabs.  My date had the sea bass.  Both dishes were fantastic.  The beat/grapefruit salad was sublime.  The oysters before that delicious.  And, we had a view of the cooking area and were able to  talk with the Chef.  She was super friendly and fantastic.  I can't believe they turn out such great food in such a small space. 

Anchor has been there for about 35 years, and I'm guessing in this tradition, another 35 because they are that good.  Oh, and if you order the chiopino, one order is enough for two, and the double order is enough for four.  We didn't have it but saw another table that did, with the mental note to order that next go around.
author: Aaron A.

description:
A friend had suggested this place when we mentioned we were going to dine at a similar place in town.  We are so glad that we took that suggestion.  This overall was the best meal we had all week start to finish while in town.  We were very lucky that we came early and had to only wait a few minutes.  At 7PM when we left some people were waiting almost 2 hours.  The food is worth the wait though!
For starters we got the oyster sampler and the Dungeness crab cocktail.  Both were delicious.  We also ordered an order of garlic bread later on.  Best garlic bread I have ever tasted.  Even with as busy as they were they did not rush us to place our dinner order.  When we did order we both ordered the cracked crab.  I got the garlic version and my husband got it simply steamed.  With the entrees comes a soup or salad.  I got the caesar while my husband got the chowder.  The caesar was delish and his chowder was the best we have ever tasted.  We did not finish them though as we wanted to save room for the crab.  It was decadent.  Either version is delicious.  
We are already planning on visiting San Francisco again and Anchor is definitely on the top of the dining list.
author: Shannon B.

description:
This review is for oysters, i love oysters hehe. MMmmmm, I'm an oyster fanatic so I know and have tried majority of the oysters. Comming from OC, whenever I think of the bay area, I think of seafood! So we got the sampler, it was mmmm good! I'm a year behind on this review so I can't recall the five oysters included in our sampler but, I do rememeber the Kushi! That one is the best one : ) It's small and slightly sweet. The garlic bread was also reallly goood.

I took off a star because they don't have the bombay Gold Band oysters from the Gulf of Mexico. It's probably a seasonal reason but anyways, OMG, I hope they supply them so you guys can try and enjoy it too! They are round, plumpy, sweet and a little chewy....sooo bombbb! When it comes to oysters, usually the small ones are the good ones but, that sucks because that's a terrible teaser but, with the Gold Band, you're in luck! They're not the biggest but, bigger than average. They're called Gold Band and are unique because they remain fresh throughout the patented High Pressure Processing (HPP) system which shucks the oysters (non-hand) without removing the nutrients. So look out for them! They are super special little guys. 

For reference: I'm from way out of town so my perspective might be different than yours, if you're a local. Shop is extremely small but, cozy restaurant. It's perfect for a little date. It's a popular little place so the line was pretty long. But, other than that, the service was great. I had a good time, I enjoyed it though it was cold and we waited an hour in line and half was outside, in the cold so you might want to bring a jacket. Also, I noticed SF people prefer to spend another extra hour hogging the seat and extending their time though they stopped ordering an hour ago; in OC, we leave within 30 mins when we're done or even earlier if there's a long line waiting.
author: Cece Z.

description: I came to this restaurant because I heard it was a neighborhood hot spot. Also, I always see a huge line outside of the place and needed to try it for myself. TBD not as good as I thought it'd be. Don't get me wrong, the crab cakes were super fresh, the atmosphere was great, as were the people serving us. But their cioppino simply can't compare to that of Sotto Mare in North Beach. Loved that they gave garlic bread served with the cioppino, the seafood wasn't overcooked, and there was a fair amount of seafood in it, but the flavor was just not fully developed in my opinion. Also, I wish they had calamari in it. Now that I'm writing this whole review, I am tempted to downgrade my rating to a three, but overall I will say this place is pretty delicious. I will definitely need to go back and try other items on the menu, but as for now I can't stop comparing it to the cioppino at Sotto Mare.
author: Samantha C.

description:
This was the awesome seafood I was craving. My party of 3 ordered the anchor special (a dozen oysters, steamed clams, and shrimp) and the cioppino. One of us also got a cup of clam chowder. 

The good:
- The chowder was very flavorful but not as thick as I would like. 
- The raw oysters were very tasty and were served with cocktail sauce, horseradish dip and this light sauce with shallots in it. All very good. Our server told us that he threw in some extra oysters for the wait. 
- The shrimp were so delicious! The were very large and go great with the cocktail sauce. They come deveined, but each of our shrimp had a small bit of intestine still attached, so watch out for that.
- The steamed clams were incredibly flavorful. The bowl comes with probably 30-40 clams swimming is the most amazing, garlicky broth. Out server was nice enough to give us some more bread to sop of that juicy goodness.
- The cioppino was abundant and plenty for 3 people. The broth was rich, and the garlic bread that it comes with is just amazing.

Now the bad:
- The wait was lengthy. The place is pretty small so that's part of the issue. The other part is that the service could use a little work. They're really nice but slow.
- At the end of our meal, our waiter told us that their credit card system is down so we would have to pay in cash. That kind of information would've been good to know during the 30 minutes we were waiting before we even sat down.
author: Gina J.

description:
This restaurant is VERY popular and doesn't take reservations. Not difficult to get a bar stool, but there can be a long wait for a table. Food here is very good--I hadn't been to Anchor Oyster Bar for a few years, so was eager to try it again. 

I started with a half Caesar Salad which was quite generously sized and more than enough. Order the half salad if you're also having a main course--you won't go hungry.

Two of us each had Ahi Tuna which was prepared perfectly--about as good a tuna gets and served on a bed of fresh veggies. But there was one flaw: it was flavored with an off-tasting oil that I did NOT like at all. My dinner companion didn't have the same reaction, so it might be just the way I taste things.

I like the flavor of extra-virgin olive oil when it tastes like olives; "earthy" tasting or infused olive oils with some herbs can ruin a good thing. I asked what the oil on the main course was and was told it was lemon, but it tasted more like cilantro (which I dislike) or some other herb. In any case, I think my dinner would have been nearly perfect if the oil drizzled thereon had been good olive oil without any cloying infusions that nearly wrecked the excellent fresh veggies under the tuna.

Service was very friendly and efficient, and aside from being jammed into a small space, it was generally comfortable. I'd go back, but would insist that the chef use extra-virgin olive oil that tasted like olives and nothing else.
author: IQuack D.

description: I don't normally write reviews, but tonight Anchor completely earned it. Small restaurant, fresh seafood, kinda pricey but its SF, and everything's fresh and delicious. Near the end of the meal it was about time I needed to leave to the airport and our last dish hadn't come out yet. As quickly as they could, they boxed it up for us and put it on the house. Customer service at its finest. I'll be back!
author: Vivian N.

description:
Had lunch earlier today - a Crab burger from the specials board, with a cup of chowder and crab cakes. The crab cake was tasty enough and the chowder was fairly decent, but the crab burger just lacked flavor. The two people I was with agreed with me on the crab cakes and each had the Caesar crab salad, which, looking at the price you would expect to be way more interesting. 

I don't understand how this place is ranked #1?
author: Owen M.

description:
4.5 stars? 3 stars for me. Ok place, but kind of overrated.

Why?

1. we waited for almost an hour and a half for 5 people
2. small place
3. no bathrooms
4. food wasn't anything special

More detail:

1. Do not, I repeat, DO NOT come here with more than a party of 2 if you don't want to wait. There's literally 3 tables, 2 tiny tables for couples, and then a bar for maybe about 6-8 more people, allowing about 25 customers max to feed for a place this popular. We waited for an hour and a half. AN HOUR AND A HALF. It can take me 10 minutes to finish a meal if I'm super hungry! But, they were very nice and reciprocated to this by giving us a lot of free samples for being so patient.  They gave people standing/sitting outside cups of clam chowder. When we finally got our table, we got free bread and butter as well as garlic bread! And they were chowed down in no more than a minute because we were starving. So yeah, come when it first opens or with no more than 2 people. 

2. Look at number 1

3. Yeahh... self explanatory haha

4. People talked about the clam chowder being "perfect" but it wasn't really. Too thin, being creamy and thicker would've made it perfect. The garlic bread was good though, nice and crunchy. We ordered a seafood pasta the server recommended that wasn't in the menu or board.  He said he had calamari, clams, white wine, some tomato sauce, basil, etc (he talked really fast I couldn't catch everything). It was really good, but not too special for the wait we had. 

Overall: Ok place, nothing special, good service, but would try something different rather than coming back here.
author: Raquel Y.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said? This place is our favorite neighborhood restaurant, and never fails to please. The menu hasn't changed much in 30 years... and it doesn't need to.

Come over, sign your name on the board, and go to one of several Castro neighborhood bars for a drink (there is usually a line during normal dinner hours).

Small, excellent, and worth the wait. Order the Cioppino (not on the menu), grab a half-carafe of house white, and get your hands dirty.
author: Nate R.

description:
This was my third time here! I got the same waiter, the taller guy with the salt and pepper hair. He was very nice. I was here with my parents and we got an assortment of fish dishes, scallops and the large cioppino. So good! 

We ended up having to wait almost an hour, but we got clam chowder while we waited, which was great. All in all still my favorite seafood (not counting sushi!) place in San Francisco.
author: Emily H.

description:
Hit all the spots. Full, savory, tasty seafood, served in enormous, delicious portions. 

Frustrating, because this spot is TINY, doesn't take reservations, and is usually backed up by one full seating by 6PM. COME ON!

We kill our wait time with a preprandial flight at lovely Swirl, across the street.
author: Liz C.

description: Cioppino. Is. The. Best. Seriously that's all I get when I come here. Between two people, you can share a dozen oysters and the smaller order of cioppino and it's the perfect serving. Pair it with a $5 beer on tap and you got yourself an amazing meal. Get there on an off time after the lunch rush so you don't have to wait to the long. The line can get crazy
author: Sara P.

description: It is hard to imagine that their Cioppino is sooo good because the place is so packed. Usually quality is sacrificed for quantity (no. of customers). The Garlic Bread , out of this world !!!!~ Considered this my first 5 Stars on a restaurant . Woohoo !
author: Wai C.

description:
Warning: it's small, so be prepared to wait outside in the chilly air of San Francisco. Also it's first come first serve (which IMO is very fair.) the parking was a nightmare. 

Despite all that, they made it up with their food and service.  If you like seafood, go there. If you want the San Francisco experience, go there. Worth it.
author: Lisa L.

description: Incredible experience! Great scallop and mussel! Patty gave awesome rec on the scallop. We enjoyed it as always. Love this place.
author: Fanny Z.

description:
Ahhh, how can one go wrong with fresh seafood and spectacular customer service?! 

My friends and I came here with a party of five, shortly after five o'clock and lucky us...we were seated immediately. We pretty much beat the rush, because when we looked outside during our meal, there was a huge line outside! Score!

We went with the off-the-menu ciopinno, a dozen oysters, a bowl of clam chowder, a combo seafood cocktail, a garlic roasted crab, and a crab caesar salad. Everything is prepared fresh and they have a pretty teenie-tiny kitchen, so the food takes some time to come out. Be patient though, because it's all worth it!

The ciopinno (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=lLfbLtUo6anjlZA0T3-LBg#lLfbLtUo6anjlZA0T3-LBg) was a tomato-based soup/stew that was pretty good and hearty. It came with a variety of seafood, that included fish, mussels, clams, and crab. It also came with some mighty cheesy garlic bread. I'm typically not a fan of tomato-based dishes, but this one was not too bad. Dipping the garlic bread into the soup/stew was the best part! The raw oysters (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=NDrVOKHe7AQR-YCQ603oIw#NDrVOKHe7AQR-YCQ603oIw) for the day included Washington Chelseas and Pacifics. Both were very fresh and came with a cocktail sauce and a vinegar based wash. They even gave us an extra oyster so that each of us would be able to have five! The clam chowder was delicious--not too chunky, not too watery, and had good flavor. Our waiter was aware that we were sharing everything, so without us even having to ask, he split up the bowl into five smaller bowls for us to share! That's what you call diligent customer service! 

The combo seafood cocktail (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=60hxPakGzuwCvAUffzondw#60hxPakGzuwCvAUffzondw) included tons of crab meat and shrimp. It was a simple cocktail, but great since it was so fresh. My favorites from our meal were the garlic roasted crab (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=0J6aG8CJDkAIKs7KxxhbGQ#0J6aG8CJDkAIKs7KxxhbGQ) and the crab caesar salad (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/anchor-oyster-bar-san-francisco?select=kerBcpAuJuTFguvYUU2_dw#kerBcpAuJuTFguvYUU2_dw). The garlic roasted crab was prepared in a delicious buttery garlicky sauce that didn't overwhelm the natural sweetness of the crab. The crab caesar salad was absolutely delicious. I've never had seafood with a caesar salad before, and surprisingly the crab meat went perfectly with the peppery caesar dressing. I enjoyed the caesar salad a lot; so much that I was pretty sad that I had to share with my friends. Ha!
author: Lien T.

description:
GET THERE EARLY! They lose 1 star for their seating process. However the food is amazing.
So, seating, there really isn't a system besides writing your name on a board. However, doesn't mean you will get seated in the order it was written.If they see a friend, they will get seated ahead of you JUST cuz.
Now. 4 stars is for food since that is how good it was. We had the cioppino, which had very generous portions. I like that the menu is tiny. Once seated, you are cared for by the lovely servers. I'll come back, but will have to figure out what times are the best to head there.
author: Nadia N K.

description: This is one of the best spots. Just be prepared to wait and to sit very close to others.
author: James G.

description:
Went here for our 5 year anniversary to have dinner. The place is really small but definitely worth the wait. I ordered an off the menu seafood soup cioppino.  It was the best ever. My gf doesn't even like cioppino but when  she tried it.. it totally changed her mind. If you ever have any left over broth from your meal... take it home. It's that good. We used the broth to cook something else at home.. so for all you people that can do a little something in the kitchen I recommend taking it home don't waste good food. 

The lady that was working there and serving us was awesome. . I forgot her name but she was glad we took the leftovers home haha. Worth the wait just try it of you love seafood or are curious what good seafood is.
author: Bobbie V.

description:
To be honest, I love this place but not the service. 

Took my cousin and boyfriend here yesterday. We were waiting for 1 hour for seats, thought customers were taking too long eating and chatting. Almost the second we got seated, I realized it was the waiters. They were very inefficient. Our waiter could ran away for serving other tables when we were ordering food. It was a really small place, but ordering food took us a good 10-15 minutes. Dislike. 

Food was very fresh. We ordered shooters, oysters, cioppino and pasta of the day. We really liked the food. However, the time of waiting for food was really looooooooong. We waited for about half an hour for the last dish. Dislike. 

Overall, food was good, service and waiting were really bad given that this place was really small.
author: Cait Y.

description:
Oven baked oysters excellent.
Tried the Cioppino, man it was the best!
Expect to wait about an hour, but its worth it.
author: Mike R.

description:
If you don't mind the wait (1st-come 1st-serve, wait on average 1h, max 2h), it's IMHO the best fish restaurant in the city. The new chef Shawn does a super job (it's almost better than before!) and the BYOB option (no corkage fee) only makes me want to thank them by visiting often, making it my once-a-month restaurant.
Hands-down the best Cioppino I've had (1 portion is usually enough for 2 people), amazing garlic bread, and I've never been disappointed by their daily selection (fresh fish) written on their whiteboard.
author: Pierre R.

description: Wow I would wait all day for this food!!! Me and my husband cant stop thinking about how good it was. He got the Cioppinno (not on menu, please ask) it is incredible, it was never ending seafood in this dish and he only got the half order! It had the largest chunks of crab, everything was so fresh and that suace in there was perfection. Wow. Agian. I got the open face crab sandwich and i am just as amazed with how much I got. His dish was $25 (which should have been more becuase it was amazing) and mine was maybe $15, I forgot, but worth every single penny. My husbands food took alittle bit longer to come out so out waiter brought a free plate of huge fresh shrimp. He was on top of it, such a great waiter, wish I had his name. Everyone that works there actually wants to be there. Total 5 star experience.
author: L L.

description:
Came here for a late lunch on a Wednesday at 2ish. The joint was pretty empty except for two people at the bar and another two at a table. Off hours on a weekday means no wait, w00t w00t!

My sis and I were told that we could sit anywhere we liked. The establishment is very clean with attractive, nautical decor. Service was fast and friendly. One of the girls offered me a bib to keep my white blouse spotless and even put it on for me. :)

We ordered Kumamoto oysters to start. They were fresh and creamy with a clean aftertaste. Next was a HUGE bowl of cioppino, brimming with fresh mussels, clams, fish, shrimp, and crab...more than enough for two, complete with large slices of garlic cheese bread. The cioppino flavor was excellent, though I felt it needed a little more salt and the garlic bread was quite charred on the sides, but still good.

Add 2 glasses of Gloria Ferrer bubbles and a Coke and our bill came out to roughly $50 p/p, including tax and tip.

Things to consider:
- Metered street parking is plentiful during this time on a weekday.
- There are 3 tables for up to 4 ppl and I think 2 more that seat up to 3. Less than a dozen seats at the bar.
author: Catherine P.

description:
Very solid seafood restaurant and perhaps a solid 4.5 if half star ratings were allowed. 

Oysters - they were all fresh and excellent

Chilled shrimp - colossal sized shrimp...may have been a little overcooked 

Clams - tender, sweet and a really flavorful broth

Crabs - served in garlic and herb broth...delicious
author: Mai C.

description:
From one seafood lover to another...This place ROCKS!

I stumbled upon this place while visiting the castro area.  I planned on just stopping by to get some oysters, and I ended up eating an enitre meal. I highly recommend this place.  Everything from the oyster shooters, to the chowder, to the "Anchor Special" is amazingly done.  Super tiny place, filled with character and a great wait staff.  I highly recommend this place for anyone who LOVES seafood.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Best. Restaurant. Experience. Ever!!!  

Everything was so absolutely delicious, and we had such amazing service from the chef / cooks!  Everyone was so sweet, and when we were standing outside in the cold (the line is crazy) they came out and served us all clam chowder in little bowls to keep us warm and hold us over.

My boyfriend and I were both so pleased with everything there it completed our night,  I have been to restaurants that have a more fancy setting, or more spacious dining area.. but I have NOT been to restaurants with better food or service than this one.  A great night!!  I can't wait to go back :)
author: Stephanie S.

description:
seafood glore!!!! They have everything and anything seafood :) 

We ordered half of the menu (hahahaa seems like it) and we finished everything! Ok ok maybe had two things to take home with us but mostly everything was devoured. 

Try the muscles in a garlic butter sauce ... that hit the spot! Very flavorful and made you wanting more. A good amount for one order. Make sure to dip the bread into the sauce too. 

Ohhhhh the garlic bread was sooooo good too! 

One thing I thought was unique was the oyster shooter! It's a bloody mary with Soju and an oyster at the bottom. It's not a shot glass size, it's like a regular wine cup size ... it was pretty tasty and I guess i got the one with more Soju in it but of course anyone who knows me, I wouldn't complain. Overall not bad, I added a few drops of tabasco sauce into the oyster shooter. 

The only downfall, the place is super small. We we're sitting elbow to elbow with just a party of five :( They don't take reservation so make sure you either call to check if there's a wait or just go at a not so busy time.
author: Jenny M.

description:
I came here for my friend's birthday and the wait was about 40-50 minutes long, even for a late week night so you might want to prepare yourself. The waiter was very nice though and came to update us every so often on how long the wait was going to be. We were probably the second to last table being seated.

We finally get seated and we order garlic bread and I get the crab cake entree (I love crab cakes) while my friend orders something off the special menu and I can't recall what it was. The garlic bread was pretty damn amazing; a generous coating of garlic butter and cheese. The only downside was that some of the pieces were overly charred, almost burnt but there were so many, I just ate around it and it's just worth it LOL.

The clam chowder that came as an option with my crab cake entree was pretty darn good. Throughout the eating it, I was expecting to bite into sand but that didn't happen which was very surprising to me. I know, it's not supposed to be there but it's kind of one of those things that I just come to expect when it comes to clam chowder. The crab cake, unfortunately, was a tad underwhelming after eating both the chowder and garlic bread (but they were pretty hard to beat). I felt like that the crab cakes had a bit too much filler and not enough crab and just texturally, felt very one dimensional. It wasn't bad by any means, I was just expecting them to really nail it on the head and make it better than anywhere else but I suppose my expectations were also a tad high. Regardless though, the crab cakes were still delicious.

Over all, I definitely see myself coming back. The service was great, the food was great, the only complain that I have was the wait time but it's not their fault that they're in high demand so I don't really mind and it's well worth the wait.
author: Richard C.

description: Cioppino is the most amazing in all the world!  Must try.  Plan to wait for a table, place is old-school and small but worth it.  Great staff!
author: John F.

description: Everything here is amazing. Cioppino is a must try. We always take the leftover soup home and mix pasta with the sauce.
author: Shuang J.

description: Believe the hype!  The ciopinno was ridiculously good. Got the large for fam of 4 with side of garlic bread and was full. Everything was fresh.  The restaurant is small. 5 tables and counter seating. To avoid the crowd go during off peak times. We went on a Friday at 2pm and immediately got a table.
author: Joseph C.

description:
Loveeee Anchor Oyster Bar. I have been too many times especially with friends from out of town, and my favorite time to go is when they open at 4pm on Sundays. MUST ORDER: SEAFOOD CIOPPINO (they have it for 2 or 4 people)

-- Review on my 1st visit: 

4 REASONS why I had one fo the best Sundays ever in this little gem*

1) Got here 15 mins before opening time, was freezing our pants off until the Amazing Todd came out and served us some piping hot Manhattan clam chowder on the house! :D

2) Ambiance &* food: We sat at the end the bar (close to the kitchen) and loved every single moment of it. The restaurant was thoughtfully decorated and even the small bathroom was super cute!!! (note the light switch with the little fish on the side... )

- Mini bottles of Laurent Perrier champagne comes in their own little ice buckets ($14).. sooo cute and such at such a good deal*

- Oysters are highly recommended. Really some of the BEST in the Bay.

- Bay Shrimp Louis salad. YUM!

- Seasonal Dungeness crab: Both chilled (with butter sauce) &* roasted garlic were amazing.

- Cioppino * .. Trust me. this is the BEST I've had so far in the city.. must dip the freshly baked garlic bread in it and pair it with a glass of Malbec or Cabernet savignon.. (A meal on its own!)


3) Super friendly and efficient service: 5 star*s to Chef Patty and our server Mike - Both AMAZING people!

4) Good crowd: Love how Anchor Oyster doesn't over pack the restaurant like a sardine can. Although the place is small, you can actually have your own space to enjoy your food and everyone is relaxed. ** One funny person came up to us and said..." I mean this in the NICEST way but how do you Skinny bitches stay so skinny when you've ordered EVERYTHING on the menu?" HAHAHAHA made our day!! Thank you whoever you are!

*** REMEMBER TO GO EARLY!!
author: Amber S.

description:
I went here on the recommendation of a life long SF resident as her favorite restaurant in the city. Anchor lived up to her praise with super nice staff and exceptional seafood.
The place is small and can fit about 25 customers. Don't come here for dinner if your blood sugar is crankily low. The wait was an hour, but was made better by having a delightful drink at Eureka lounge around the corner. Our food came out fast and it was amazing. My favorite was the anchor special, a platter of shellfish. Bravissimo!
author: Carrie H.

description: The food was fantastic!  The kitchen operation was amazing with only two burners. The restaurant was very small and we had to wait for a bit but it was certainly worth it. They even brought out some chowder while we waited. Highly recommended!
author: Jing H.

description:
This night didn't start out all too rosy, but this place was quite a find.

We got there about 7:15pm and the place was already packed.  Granted there are only about 6 tables and about 8 bar seats, so it doesn't take much for that place to get packed.  It was raining and cold, and our return on our time invested waiting in line there wasn't looking good even though there were only four groups before us.  Some mysterious people showed up and got to skip the sign in and the line and everything, which upset a lot of us--so much so that one of the guys actually went in there and confronted the people to let them know everyone was displeased.  I'm not sure if that's just the policy of the owner to do that, but we weren't too excited about the other people's preferential treatment...hence the minus one star.

Once we finally got into the place about 8:30pm (the people eating there didn't seem to want to leave even when they had no food in front of them after their meal), we ordered the half appetizer platter (6 oysters, 2 jumbo shrimp, and half order of clams), the artichoke appetizer, the pumpkin ravioli with dungeness crab, and the alaskan true cod.

Appetizer Platter:  The oysters (two of each type of oyster they had) were fabulous...not too big, but bursting with flavor and very fresh.  The shrimp were huge and fresh.  The clams were delicious and we needed to ask for more bread to soak up the incredible chili garlic "soup" they were prepared in.

Artichoke:  It was well prepared and very tasty, but was really overshadowed by all the rest of the food.  If i had to choose, i'd probably have skimped on this appetizer to enjoy the rest of the stuff more.

Alaskan True Cod:  Lightly breaded, perfectly cooked and just slightly on the meaty side as far as texture...yum!  The only downside was that i felt there was a little too much rosemary on the fish that kind of made it a little too herbally for me.  The potatoes were delicious as  well and it came with some grilled veggies to compliment the dish.

Pumpkin Ravioli with Dungeness Crab:  Truly the highlight of the evening.  I was a little skeptical at first when we ordered it, but the ravioli was so fresh (hand made that day), the pumpkin was incredibly flavorful, and the huge mound of dungeness crab didn't hamper the dish either!

In the end, we left very satisfied and stuffed to the brim with one of the best seafood meals i've had in a LONG time...don't take my word for it...try it out =)

Happy Eating!
author: Bradley H.

description: Amazing Cioppino, garlic bread and friendly service makes the two hour wait completely worth it. This is now a permanent must have every time I visit the bay area.
author: Anthony M.

description:
Definitely a fan of this place! Small and intimate but the portions are big and a great value. The FRESHEST seafood I have ever tasted. 

Recommend going with parties of 2-4. Be sure to have some nice wine with your food!
author: Ernest L.

description: Get here early; the wait is no joke.  After more than one foiled attempts to try this place (came once to find the entire joint closed for a week for cleaning), a couple weeks ago I finally made it into the promised land, but not after waiting over an hour in the freezing cold.  No really.  We arrived at about 4:45, figuring the wait couldn't be that bad, given the place opens at 4:00, and who eats dinner at 4:00 aside from really old people?  We were wrong.  I guess you have to get here before opening and then rush to get a spot.  There was a group that got here at 4:00 and must have missed the first cattle/seating call.  And they were pissed and getting testy (see most recent one star review) and swearing at the hostess and in general disbelief that they could be waiting for more than an hour and a half and still not be entitled to a table (as though the restaurant was being totally unreasonable for having a first come first seated policy, which is how most restaurants work).  Anyway.  The wait was made somewhat more tolerable by the free chowder cups they brought out (saw them bringing out garlic bread later in the night when we were already seated).  When we were finally let in the pearly gates, we were shown to a neatly set table with a plate of bread ready and waiting (which we promptly devoured).  When inside, I could see how truly tiny this place is.  I counted 26 seats.  8 stools at the bar, three 4 tops, and 2 two tops that had an extra chair added for a third person.  But who cares?  Let's eat.  The menu is pretty simple.  They had some specials on the white board behind the counter.  They looked good, but I already knew what I wanted, considering I had been scrutinizing the menu the whole time I had been outside.  We ordered a salad with shrimp, clam chowder, mixed shellfish, and black mussels.  FYI, portions here are pretty big.  I really enjoyed the shrimp salad, which was quite generous with the shrimp.  The chowder was good, not the best I've had, but very inviting after a long wait in the cold.  Finally, both shellfish platters seemed to have enough seafood to feed an army.  They had different broths, which was nice, or we would have had two plates of mostly the same thing.  Of the two, I preferred the mixed shellfish, which had both black and green mussels, clams, and shrimp.  I preferred the taste of the broth also, which was like a classic meuniere while the other broth had more tomato flavor.  They were also very generous in bringing out extra bread for soaking up the broth.  Also, the nice lady gave us some free garlic bread to try.  Gotta say, it was melt in your mouth delicious and I wish I'd gotten a whole order. Overall, the food was highly satisfying, the service was warm and friendly, and the place had a great cozy vibe.  Definitely worth the wait (but even better if you can get here before the line forms).
author: Ash T.

description:
I genuinely wanted to give this place 5 stars, but I couldn't bring myself to it. There are definitely 5 star traits.... but having this experience only warrants 3 stars.

You can't deny the freshness of this place. The oysters were on point! We ordered a half dozen and our server described where each oyster was from. I wish we were given the choice, because I think we all preferred the oysters from Canada, as opposed to the locally grown (the locally grown were large, but we preferred the sweetness of the other oysters). 

Buckets of oyster crackers lined the side of the restaurant, and there was another heaping basket of crackers on each table. This is a hint to order the clam chowder. Clam chowder was delicious, and was hearty, but could have used more clams.

We ordered clams and mussels for the table. The clams were delicious! And the broth was heavenly. We must have asked for extra bread 4 or 5 times to dip into the garlic/wine broth that the clams were bathing in. However, the mussels.... ick. I love mussels, but these tasted weird, and I had a sick feeling in my stomach after eating a couple. 

I ordered the pasta special. YUM!!!! The tomatoes and pasta absorbed the seafood flavors beautifully. Though it was a very large portion, I did not feel overstuffed after eating a majority of it. Such a satisfying feeling :)

Others at the table had the Petrole (YUM!), crabcakes (flaky and not dry), and mussels. The portions were large for all of the servings.

Overall a good meal, and great service. However, the mussels really soured the experience for me. We spent about $200 on the meal for four of us, and to leave not feeling well was just not a good thing.
author: Mar A.

description: As a vegetarian, the five stars for a seafood restaurant should carry even more weight. My three omnivore dining companions thoroughly enjoyed the anchor platter to start, clam chowder, and cioppino.  The chef went out of her way to make me a delicious entree salad for me which had really tasteful touches of fresh herbs, well cooked and seasoned veggies and a nice vinaigrette. She also provided the table with a little platter of complimentary scallops and garlic bread for the wait, which was only about 30 minutes. Overall we had a wonderful experience. Anchor will be our go-to restaurant to take our visiting family and friends.
author: Kelly G.

description:
What's the saying? Happy as a clam? 

Yes, that was me, except I was as happy as an OYSTER. Was visiting SF and meeting up with friends for dinner. I let them have the pick of restaurant since they know the lay of the land. 

via text
Jeff: Do you like spicy foods?
Me: Spicy good in my book!

(couple of hours later)

Me: Not to make things difficult but I'm sorta in the mood for oysters?
Jeff: lol, don't worry. I have the perfect place. Anchor Oyster bar on Castro. No reservations taken and may be a line but well worth the wait. Will try getting there early and put our name on the wait list.

And that my friends, is how the start of a great dining experience was born.
author: Polly S.

description: The cioppino was excellent. The small was big enough to share with someone. Huge portions of shellfish and broth was delicious! It was about $35 which is standard for this SF native dish! The 30 Minute wait on a Tuesday night was worth it!
author: R I.

description:
Arrive early for a table. If you have a large group (6+) I would not recommend this place due to the limited seating. Oysters are SOOOOO good, very fresh and perfectly shucked!!
Staff is very warm and attentive.
author: Derek F.

description:
Attention: Tourists! Do not go to the tourist traps by Fisherman's Wharf for fresh oyster! GO HERE!

Word on the street is there's a long wait if you dare to try the lunch or dinner hours. So my Mom and I went at 3:30pm on a Thursday, and there was NO LINE! Woo hoo!

She had the Full Anchor Special. Her steamed clams were waving at me from the buttery pool of garlicky deliciousness they were swimming in. I had to snag one! YUMMM! I had an open-faced crab and shrimp melt. That also was very good, and very filling!

My Mom definitely wants to go back the next time she's in town. As for me, I'm going back next week! This time, I have my eye on that cioppino!
author: Kara L.

description:
Wow was that damn good cioppino. Like, request for your last meal on earth good. It's not on the menu so luckily we saw someone at the next table eating it and asked about it. Apparently Anchor doesn't always have crab and only serves the cioppino when they do. The serving is ginormous, but it's really difficult to convince yourself to stop eating. 

The restaurant is small and cute. Simple wine list, friendly waiters, lots of seafood and not much else. What more do they need? I would definitely go back.
author: Vanessa N.

description:
My friend and I were grabbing lunch and we decided we wanted to try something different. It felt like clam chowder weather and lo and behold, Anchor Oyster Bar was closeby!

The place itself is easy to get to if you take muni. It's pretty small so you might pass by it without noticing, but it's a pretty cool place. Very lovely inside. 

We ordered the sauteed garlic prawns entree (with roasted potatoes, veggies, and a cup of clam chowder) with a side of garlic bread. 

The garlic bread came in a huge basket. It was toasted nicely with a good amount of cheese and garlic flavor. Definitely worth getting.
author: Sofia R.

description: Best food in San Fran, I live in Phoenix Arizona, and I traveled for this restaurant. The food is amazing, the people who work there take pride in their jobs. When you go there you will understand how amazing the whole experience is to be with those amazing people. Many trips to come just for this place. Remember this when you read this review, I fly from Phoenix t San Fran just to eat here.
author: Hani E.

description:
Went here on a Saturday night, we had to wait, but they have comfy benches and heat lamps.  The waiting list is outside, but if you leave the area they will seat the next on the list who is sitting there.  Makes me feel bad for the guy acting as host, some pushy guys came back after not waiting and pushed in front of us but the host handled it with grace.

The food was amazing, the staff was delightful.  So glad we went!
author: Kristin G.

description:
Really expensive for mediocre quality of food.

Sorry I don't get it.
author: Erica D.

description:
I've never had a bad meal here. 

Crab season? Ask for the Cioppino, not on the menu but it is the best I have ever had. Oysters are always fresh and amazing selection. Definitely try their garlic bread and clam chowder. 

Warm day in SF? Get the gazpacho. Full of seafood. Seasoned perfectly. 

Crab Melt....so good I can't stand it. 

One of my top 3 for seafood in sf
author: Sabrina M.

description: All the stars! Small and quaint with the best cioppino I have eaten! Definitely worth the wait!
author: Bren Y.

description: Officially my favorite seafood place in SF. The wait list was 2 hours long, but I slid in at the bar after 30 minutes - perks of dining solo! Discovered it was well worth the wait. Friendly service was the first thing I noticed. The oysters were the freshest I have tasted in recent memory. I especially loved their shallot-vinegar sauce that complimented the flavor of the wellfleets. I read such great things in the yelp reviews that I took the liberty of ordering everything that looked interesting. Clam chowder = phenomenal. Steamed shellfish combo = delicious, savory broth and a huge portion of fish!  I was craving garlic crab ( which was the reason for going) and it was also great, but I liked all the other "appetizer-entrees" more.  I also liked seeing one of my fav beers, Ninkasi oatmeal stout, on tap.  Can't wait to go back and take my boo!
author: Jaimee M.

description:
You've got to be patient and wait cos this place is tiny but the food is good! Unless you go for an early lunch on weekdays...

Best clam chowder in SF. Not too salty unlike most other places. Yum.

They know how to cook fish too and it was a special order cos we're allergic to crustaceans so the cook substituted fish instead and it was great. Too bad it's not on the regular menu. Had another fish special the 2nd time I went. It was baked fish and pretty good but I preferred the plain fried in butter one I had the 1st time.

My mom enjoyed the oysters. We had steamed mussels which were good too. Good place for seafood if you don't mind the wait. Also good place to bring out of towners.
author: pj n.

description:
Some friends and I headed off to spend the evening in SF, with the intention of finally trying out Ike's Place.  Unfortunately due to traffic and some not-so-thorough planning, by the time we actually arrived in SF it was past closing time and a back up had to be found!

So I jumped on my handy dandy smart phone and immediately turned to Yelp for an answer.  Anchor Oyster Bar popped up as being one of the most highly rated restaurants in Castro.  We reprogrammed Suzy (my most beloved GPS) and headed off.  

The restaurant is very small and cozy.  My group actually walked right past it while we were looking for it because it was so small, and had to ask for directions from a shop owner.  There were probably about 8 tables or so, with only 3 tables being devoted to larger groups.  The smaller tables seated 2 or 3 people, and my party of 4 had to wait for one of the large tables.   We put our names down at 8:30, and didn't get seated till nearly an hour later. 

 It was a chilly, rainy night, and we were all very pleasantly surprised when one of the servers brought out a tray of individual clam chowder bowls, complete with bags of oyster crackers and "silver" plastic forks.  He topped it off by grating fresh pepper into our bowls for us too. These were definitely NOT little itty bitty sample portions either...after I finished mine I probably didn't need to eat anymore.  The chowder was  delicious.  I usually like my chowder to be very hearty and thick, and even though this was a thinner version, it was most definitely not lacking in flavor.  

After the chowder, we knew we were staying for the long haul, however long they were going to make us wait.  While sitting outside occasionally patrons would finish and come out, giving us thumbs up and telling us the food was definitely worth the wait.  

At long last, we were seated.  A plate with a small loaf of  sliced bread and butter was brought out for us to nibble on.  We ordered garlic bread and crab cakes for our appetizers, and then sea bass and steamed mussels in broth for our entrees. The garlic bread was $5 but easily fed all 4 of us.  The portion was huge, and generously sprinkled with cheese, garlic, and herbs. The crab cakes came out and were perfection.  Slightly crisp on the outside, moist on the inside, and served with a tangy tartar sauce that my friend couldn't stop eating (no seriously...after the crab cakes were gone he proceeded to scoop out the sauce and eat it alone).

Entrees were no less spectacular.  The sea bass was mildly seasoned, and cooked just right.  It was served with fingerling potatoes and a vegetable medley.  I think where Anchor Oyster Bar really got this dish right was just in the way they cooked everything.  The flavors were so simple, but they were done just right.  The bass also came with a garlic aioli sauce that again, my friend could not stop eating.  The steamed mussels came with a white wine and garlic broth that was great just to dip the bread into.  

The service was excellent.  Again, since the restaurant is small, our server was very attentive.  My glass was never more than half empty, and our bread was refilled the second we finished it.  I asked for my sea bass to-go, and he boxed it up, asking if I cared to have some of the sauce on the side (he'd noticed with some amusement how mesmerized we were by the addicting sauces).  When I opened my take-out box the next day, I found two FULL containers of both the sauces, the garlic aioli AND the tartar (that hadn't even accompanied my dish). Between that and the free chowder in the rain, Anchor has some of the best service I've ever gotten.

This IS seafood in San Francisco, so I feel the pricing is very reasonable.  Garlic bread $5, crab cakes $12, sea bass $23, and steamed mussels $29.  Well worth it, and I can't wait for my next visit!
author: Vi N.

description: Walking around the Castro tonight; I came across this cool tiny neighborhood oyster bar. It's been there 38 years. Popular place with folks waiting out front for a table. They were able to seat me immediately due to I'm alone and there was 1 seat available at the bar.  I had a couple IPAs, an oyster shooter, oysters on the half shell, huge prawns, sautéed clams in the most amazing clam liquor and sourdough French bread.  Wow is the only word I can think of at the moment. Only $40 including a 20% tip. I'll be back.
author: Jim L.

description:
What a quaint, warm, delicious dinner at Anchor Oyster Bar! First, there are only about 6 tables inside so go early. Their wait system is a little hilarious, you write your name on a dry erase board and wait outside. Luckily we were there on the early side and were sat after about 10 minutes. I could see a huge wait building up here as the seating inside was limited. 

Once seated, we all had a difficult time deciding what to order. So many items looked delicious, particularly the specials. Our waiter was incredibly helpful in ordering the oysters. We had a sample of all their offerings and they were all fantastic. I ended up ordering the cioppino, which is always an option at Anchor Oyster Bar, but not listed on the menu. This was a large bowl containing a plethora of seafood in a flavorful tomato broth, delicious. It also came with a very tasty garlic bread meant for dipping. I highly recommend this dish to anyone stopping by! My colleagues had tuna tartar and mussels, they were all pleased with their choices. Great find, recommend to anyone who will be in the area.
author: Leslie B.

description:
This is such a cozy spot on a cold night to get some seafood. I came here midweek around 7pm and the wait was about 20 mins. Not bad at all. They have a list out front you just write your own name on. You can belly up to the bar or grab a table. 

The place was very lively when we were there. I loved the steamed clams. The broth was so good - we dipped tons of bread in it. Clams plus a salad and you have the perfect meal.
author: Natalie N.

description: My go to spot for cioppino. So not mess around, go to this local spot, put your name on board and wait to put seafood ecstasy in you mouth. Personally I think its the best one in the city. Wash down with Trumer Pils. Mmmmm Greeeeeat!
author: Brian S.

description: Ordered the prawn entree, clam chowder and combo cocktail for take out on Father's Day. Everything was so good. So, so good. The entree was perfect, all of the veggies were seasoned and beautiful, the prawns huge and flavorful. The chowder is amazing. The cocktail so so so so good. Everything was fresh and just so good. I want to go back and try the cioppino-- it looked amazing when I went in to grab my dinner.
author: Summer S.

description:
One of the best seafood places in town. 
Highly recommend the crab cakes and the garlic crabs.
They add a little bit of chili pepper to most of their dishes. If you don't like the spice, please be specific when order.
author: Olivia N.

description:
Anchor Oyster is a hidden gem waiting to be discovered by you if you haven't already been seduced by its deliciousness. From the quaint and sparkling interior to its friendly staff-- your entire dining experience is top-notch. This is my go-to spot with out of town guests wanting fantastic seafood, especially since the entire dining experience has a wonderful neighborhood feel in a adorable space.

Go for the daily specials and oysters. They never disappoint. Chef Taylor knows how to create magic in your mouth. The things he can do with seafood has diners turning heads as plates parade out from the kitchen. The garlic bread is to die for too.

Pricing is on the higher end but you pay for quality and innovation.
author: CTP p.

description: Cioppino was really good. Lots of fresh fennel, but it was a bit sweet for me. I guess I like the more savory broths, but that's just personal preference. Wait was long, but worth it. You can go to the wine bar across the street and drink while you wait, but the waiters will sometimes just skip you if you're not in front of the restaurant.
author: Jefferey L.

description:
Thanks Yelp. We ordered the clam chowder, garlic bread, cioppino (small) and anchor special (half) - all on your advice. Everything was delicious and generously proportioned. 

The staff was friendly and attentive - our waiter knew my friend and I were sharing everything and even split our little cup of chowder for us. 

We arrived around 7 pm on Wednesday night and were seated right away. Our tab came out to be about $70, which I thought was very reasonable given how much we ate.
author: Angella A.

description: This  is one of the best hidden gems in the City and certainly in this area for a delicious seafood dinner. It is easy to see why they have stayed there so long, and I hope they keep it the same charming little place forever. Dinners are even better than lunches, but also more expensive. The service is experienced and friendly.
author: John H.

description:
My party came at 7:30pm for a table of 6... WORST IDEA EVER! The restaurant is super small - has a bar that can accommodate 8 -10 people and 5 smaller tables that can accommodate 5 max per table. We ended up waiting for about 1.5 hours for 6 seats at the bar cause otherwise, we would have to be split up into two separate tables. However, it was very nice of them to bring us clam chowder while we were waiting in the cold! 

The food was pretty awesome, but after a while, everything will start to taste the same as it's all shellfish, with the only difference in the broth it's in. Overall, I really enjoyed my time there since I love seafood. Everything was super flavorful and cooked to perfection!

1. Garlic Bread
Cheesy, not too garlicky, and just enough crunch! I mean, the garlic bread was good, but I don't think it's out-of-the-world good as some reviews have described them to be. 

2. Kumamoto Oysters
Some of the best oysters my bf has had.

3. Clam Chowder
Loaded with potatoes, just the way I like it! It's creamy and flavorful. Not overpoweringly rich. I wish the bread it's served with was more hearty and dense so that it can really soak up the chowder. The bread kind of just shrivels up and dissolves when it's dipped in the chowder. But I wouldn't mind having this chowder everyday :)

3.Steamed Clams 
Ooops.. my party ate all the clams they had! Clams were fresh, and I really enjoyed the sweetness and freshness of the broth. 

4. Combination Steamed Shellfish 
Loaded with seafood - prawns, clams, and mussels! This broth was more tangy, not as good as the steamed clams broth, but I still enjoyed it! 

5. Cioppino
Noms! Again, loaded with seafood in a tomato based soup. Seafood was very fresh and the soup was very flavorful. Generous portions! 

Would definitely come again, but either at 6pm or after 9pm, and with a party of 4 or less! You have been warned.
author: Michelle L.

description:
So I am really torn about this place. I have friends and family that rave about this place, it's food, it's great service. 

This would get 5 stars if it weren't or our last horrible experience. The wait (at 8 pm) took about an hour and we were the next people up for about 40 minutes of that hour. We were up for the bar, but was told it would only be a few more minutes for a more comfortable table, so we waited. It turned out to be 30 more minutes in the freezing cold. 

The only saving grace that night was the free chowder they gave us while we were waiting. We had the Cioppino. That was quite good and their Clam Chowder was quite delicious. 

i'll need to come back for another review, because my experience was definitely tampered. 

I would recommend coming to this place if you come at 10 pm.
author: Winny F.

description:
Summary: Anchor isn't bad, but I'd rather go to Tadich. Same type of food, similar prices, same ridiculous wait, but Tadich just executes better. 

Anchor is a very cute, if tiny, space. The first time I tried to go was a Tuesday night at 9:15pm, and after waiting 20 minutes, I gave up. So be prepared to wait. The restaurant's interior is charming, very New England. 

My friend and I shared a bowl of clam chowder and garlic bread. The clam chowder was lighter and less creamy than other versions I've had, but quite good. The garlic bread is BOMB. Crunchy, garlic-y, faintly cheesy. Usually I dislike garlic bread with cheese on it, but Anchor pulled it off. I could have eaten a whole basket myself. 

I really didn't like my entree, though. I had some sort of caper sole, and it was just...absurdly caper-y. The thin, small filets were totally overpowered by the caper.  Even if I'd liked the fish, there wasn't that much of it. The mashed potatoes were rich and delicious but I felt like I was paying $27 for mashed potatoes. 

My friend had a pasta with scallops and andouille sausage that was much, much better. Huge portion, great flavor.
author: Ada T.

description:
I've had dinner here twice in the last since months and both times have been absolutely outstanding.  Both times we've waited an hour+ but it's always worth it.  The service starts before you're even seated as they bring folks cups of clam chowder while they wait outside.  Once inside they repeatedly thank you for your patronage and patience.

The cioppino is out of this world good.  They were out of clams by the time we ordered - bummer.  How about scallops instead?  And then upon arrival, "he made it a bit bigger than usual."  It was HUGE - like could've fed a small village huge.  

Great service, cozy atmosphere, insanely delicious food.  Can't wait to go back again.
author: Rich L.

description:
Defiantly one of my favorite restaurants. Even though they always run out of Kumamoto oysters, but other oysters and pastas are fantastic!!
Their white wine pairs really good with the sea food and pasta!!
It's a small place with only less than 7 tables, but is very enjoyable! 
Good service and great ppl. 
Love it, Love it, Love it!!!!
author: Tiger L.

description:
This place might be small but the wait is worth it! 

My boyfriend and I came here to celebrate our  7 year anniversary. We decided not to wait for a table and just to sit at the bar. The staff was very friendly and greeted us right when we walked in. 

Even though they had a small menu, you could ask what specials they had available that night. I was in luck, they had Cioppino!! Until this day I keep thinking about the cioppino I had that night. The broth was perfect, there was lots of prawns, mussels, scallops, fish and two crab legs! Most places I go to don't give you that much seafood. 

My boyfriend got the halibut and clam chowder, they were both awesome. I can't wait to come back to this place!
author: Kim L.

description: Went to have lunch around noon on a Tuesday and plenty of seating (even though only like 5 or 6 tables plus counter). Quick service and the food...to die for!!!!! Started with garlic bread...amazing and then the Green Mussels...get the half order which still I think gave me 12 and they are huge!!! The wine broth, herbs made the dish...and then we had the crab cake appetizer which was lightly breaded and fried up...sooooo fresh. Top it off with a glass if wine and we were all set to visit some of the local shops. We also were able to park on street with no problem. However, when we left around 1ish, restaurant was hopping and car was waitin to snag our spot on street. Worth the trip and then some!
author: Laurie W.

description:
Went here for dinner. Weather was just getting cold and we wanted something warm and savory. This was probably couple of hours before closing and we waited about 30 ~ 45minutes until we were seated. We did sit on the nice cushy bench right outside and enjoyed the view. I just love the neighborhood here: little shops merchandised nicely, peeking into the Anchor Bar window to see who is eating what.
 
We didn't budge though, we had to get the Cioppino and Garlic Bread.

The taste is a lot more lighter than cioppinos around North Beach, which I love! I felt like I was tasting the seafood instead of salty, overly condensed seafood broth. Plus putting it on the garlic bread that comes with the cioppino will keep it savory enough. Fluffy crab meat was already pulled out from it's shell so no need to get messy too. 

Definitely going back there for more.
author: Yuki A.

description:
I've had dinner here twice in the past year.  It really is as delicious as all the reviews say.  Just be forewarned that you will have to wait for a seat (put your name on the whiteboard next to the door) if you arrive past 7pm - they only have a few tables which means you may end up waiting hours for one.  Our first visit we waited for two hours.  Our second visit we arrived on a weekday shortly after 6pm and were seated within 10 minutes.

Ambiance:  Warm, comfortable and relaxed.

Service: Excellent and very accommodating for food allergies.

Food (gluten-free dairy-free perspective): This is some of the best seafood in San Francisco.   I highly recommend the cioppino.
author: G B.

description: I split an order of mussels and clams prepared in their amazing white wine sauce. The sourdough bread was fresh and was a perfect accompaniment to the meal.
author: Lauren P.

description:
This place is delicious! 
1. The garlic bread is soft and garlicky :)
2. Clam chowder is creamy,yum!
3. Oysters : very fresh ! (Recommend)
4. Open faced sandwich.. Makes my mouth watery just thinking about it.. I believe it had shrimp and crab With melted cheese.. Ugh. so good!
5 ciapino : very flavorful 

 It is small so I would suggest going with a party of 5  or less. Definitely recommend!
author: Debbie D D.

description:
Speechless...the best Seafood Restaurant I have been so far  Definitely coming back to this restaurant! 

Oh and by the way...the CIOPPINO was INCREDIBILE - mamma mia
author: Manuel B.
