description: The food is amazing- world class. The service is horrible. Come here with lots of time to spare.
author: Julian C.

description:
Anchor Oyster Bar was one of the best seafood experiences I've ever had. If not THEEE best. We came in around 4pm so there was no wait. We sat down and started to order some foods. We got the anchor special (comes with clams, oysters, and shrimp), a cup of clam chowder, and a soju oyster shooter for myself :D.  The soju oyster shooter was awesome. Downed it like butter. My cousin had the clam chowder and said it was good... but not 'Boudin's' good. Then the anchor special came out.

Holy smoke. Everything tasted awesome. The clams came out with a white wine sauce that was to die for. The special came out with three different oysters. I guess they change it frequently. The shrimp was also nice and plumpy. After eating all of that food, my cousin wanted more! So he ordered another steamed mussels. The mussels came out drenched with another white wine sauce. I didn't want to eat any more seafood... but I proceeded to drink the sauce with the big spoon like it was soup. So awesome. 

A definite MUST VISIT place if you're visiting San Francisco. We drove around 30 minutes to look for parking and it was definitely worth the wait :)
author: Charles T.

description: I mean really. THE BEST, FRESHEST OYSTERS I'VE EVER HAD IN SF. Even though it's super small (maybe sits 15 to 20 people), usually a long wait and expensive, it's totally worth it, and I'm not one to spend frivolously. Staff is attentive and wonderful and everything I have ever eaten there (anything raw, steamed clams, chowder, mussels, ciopino, even the bread!) is spot on incredible. Very intimate setting and great for date night! Plus it's in my favorite neighborhood of SF. Can't hate on the Castro! (unless you're a homophobe - what are you doing in SF? We don't want your kind here!)
author: J C.

description: Excellent quality. Fresh and delicious seafood dishes. Cozy ambient with vintage naval items as decorations.
author: Raffaele F.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in this city.

They have amazingly fresh seafood. I've been here 5 times and each time it blows me away. Whatever pasta they have on the specials board, get it. Their pasta is delicious. 

To top it off, they have some of the best service in the city too. Last time I went the wait was about 45 minutes and it was pretty cold out so one of the waiters brought everyone a small cup of their delicious clam chowder. They go above and beyond to make their customers happy. Love this place!
author: Desa F.

description: We drove over three hours to experience this greatness.  Alas, we were disappointed.  We ordered the clam chowder, the half dish appetizer that included oysters, prawns, and mussels. And to top it off, the cioppino. I must say the oysters and cioppino were amazing. The cioppino was so different than anything I've ever tasted before.  Clam chowder was just average, prawns were overcooked.  And we went at 300pm so the restaurant wasn't overly crowded but the service was just not that good.  So yes if you're looking for oysters and cioppino definitely go but be prepared.
author: Michelle T.

description: Best place ever. My husband and I live down the street and this is the one place we come to over and over again. We love it--- we bring our own bottle of wine (use to be no corkage but now only $12) and order a few oysters and a large ciopinno. Prepare to wait... put your name on the list and go grab wine from the wine shop up the street and have a glass there while you wait. If they call your name and your not there your name just stays at the top of the list. Genius, makes for a nice little date night.
author: Kelly H.

description:
We came here arond 5:15 on a Sunday evening and ended up waiting for about 45 minutes for our seat at the bar table. 

I had a taste of the garlic bread, clam chowder, and the crab cake entree. 

Overall thoughts: The food was pretty tasty and satisfactory. However, it doesn't have quite the spark that would entice me to crave what I had tasted and return again. The service was bright and friendly and the portions were plentiful (the vegetarian pasta bowl was HUGE and seemed to be never-ending). Perhaps I need to try other things on the menu next time.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Best dining experience ever! (:

I've gone here before on the way back from vacation, and loved it then as well, so I had to go back. My boyfriend and I just finished watching Cirque du Soeil at the Cow Palace so it was the perfect opportunity. 

We got there and found a pretty good parking spot on a cross street, and signed our name in. Immediately after doing so, a waiter came out to tell us it'd take 15 minutes. Soon after, we were asked if we were hungry by who seemed to be the head waiter, and he came out with a tray full of clam chowder! It made the wait soo worth it, and so much warmer (:

Anchor Special is a MUST! We were able to pick which oysters we wanted, four of everything. French Kiss and Sweet Waters were my favorite. And the clams were delicious! Perfect combination with the complimentary bread too. After the whole meal was devoured by us, my boyfriend left for the rest room, and I was approached by the super nice waiter who offered the clam chowder and he did another super nice gesture and gave me one of their anchor oyster t-shirts! My boyfriend even made a comment right when we entered the restaurant that customer service is definitely their number one priority here & I totally agree. The customer service was the best I've ever had, I will definitely come again. The experience left my tummy and spirits in a good mood. (:
author: Cindy C.

description:
I'm mortified that I'm typing this, but I have no better words to express my delight in this place:

ERMAHGERD.

Seriously. 

On a whim, I decided to drag my poor friends here for my birthday. Which falls on a holiday. Which also happens to be on the weekend. Don't get me wrong. I'm not calling them "my poor friends" because they had an awful experience. Quite the opposite.

If you haven't been here before, you will be greeted by a grumpy waiter monitoring a whiteboard filled with names of parties waiting to be seated. People, there is a reason a huge line has congregated in front of this tiny place. The food is to DIE for.

We waited a cool 2 hours to seat my party of 5 (haha), but it was soo worth it. The restaurant was nice enough to serve us small cups of chowder while we shivered in the cold outdoors and glared at the patrons taking their sweet ass time to finish eating and free up a table. When we were finally seated, we had the most amazing meal.

Must try before you die:
-FULL order of the Anchor Special
-CIOPPINO (not on the menu)
-Garlic cheese bread (oh my god, the garlic cheese bread)

Basically, I'm going to stop raving and let you try this place out. But please please do it. Unless I happen to be in line and you're making my wait longer :)
author: Nicole S.

description:
really delicious, everything is fantastic.  the clam chowder is more milky than creamy, so good.  oyster, prawn, clam platter, also fantastic.  the best was a special which was steamed clams with chorizo, omgeeee that was good.   they also have kim crawford sauvignon blanc which is a great wine match. 

it doesn't look obvious kid friendly but they are very friendly.  they have a kid booster seat and they gift you a crayon box and a coloring book.
author: Wakako U.

description:
It's a wonderful day in the gay-borhood! Especially when seafood is on the menu!

Anchor Oyster Bar lives on Castro (between 18th & 19th) but the inside screams East Coast. I love the nautical decor, simple white walls & a basket of oyster crackers sitting on aluminum tables. Bar seating & a handful of tables is all you get in this crowded establishment, which explains the hungry masses always huddled outside in the cold.

We ordered:
* [half order of Anchor Special, $20]: 4 different types of raw oyster (I don't eat raw anything, but my friend said they were good), large prawns with a wonderful cocktail sauce & horseradish (my fave) & clams in a butter wine sauce. (I am not a fan of clams--no dirty jokes--but they were good here especially with the sauce. I could not stop dipping my bread into it.)
* [appetizer order of crab cakes for me, $13]: dungeness crab, perfectly brown on the outside, mild tasting & accompanied by a chunky dill tarter sauce. Not the best crab cakes I've had but easily one of the better ones out there. 
* [Italian Fishstew special for my friend, $25]: basically cioppino minus the crab, which isn't in season. Light tomato broth, huge portion. My friend walked away feeling "full & insulated," as he put it! 
* I had the house chardonnay ($5) & my friend also had a glass of white.

Service was pretty much perfection. Our waitress & the guy helping her (wasn't sure if he was a busser or another server) were SO nice. No attitude, none of the snarkiness I've experienced at other restaurants in the area; Their inviting, *5 star* service with a smile attitude ensured them repeat customers (as if the amazing food wasn't reason enough.)
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Thank you my fellow yelpers!!!  Because of the reviews I read before going here, I knew to order cioppino (although not seen on the menu).  It was so delicious!   It was full of seafood and the broth was very flavorful  (tomato sauce). We came here, ordered the half sampler, a bowl of clam chowder, and cioppino.  We thought about ordering the garlic bread, but luckily I remembered seeing a picture of cioppino on yelp with garlic bread, so we didn't order it.  This is a lot of food for two people, and we were not able to finish the food.   I would say if you want to try a dish here, cioppino is the dish to order.  They give you endless bread for dipping in the soup or sauce. The service is also very great especially for a busy restaurant. 


Definitely would want to come back again soon!!!
author: Tiffany H.

description: Dropping by for a late lunch on a Thursday, we got a table quickly. For an oyster bar, we would have expected more oysters on the menu, but the ones we had were delicious and the clams was served in a fantastic soup / sauce. The waiters were polite and quick, but did neither add to nor reduced the experience.
author: Hildegunn N.

description:
Had a number of things there over lunch -- everything was great to awesome!  

Crab sandwich - really really fresh crab meat!  I thought it would be similar to a crab melt, but not so much.  Not melty, just fresh and good.

Crab cakes - best crab cakes in SF...very similar in terms of texture and seasoning to crab cakes I've had on the east coast.  Not too much breading, chunks of crab

Clam chowder - not as thick as most in terms of consistency, but really really good

Seafood stew for 2 - not on the menu, but they always have it, just ask.  This thing was the winner!  The broth was awesome!  Huge shrimps, mussels, clams, fish, squid, etc.
 I will get this every time I got back!
author: j k.

description:
CRAB CAKE ENTREE. OYSTERS OF THE DAY.

Great clam chowder and potatoes. Crab cakes were good. Wifey really like them, I thought there were a little too creamy/buttery but still good. Liked the 3 varieties of their oysters of the day.

Service was great as well. Wait staff explained in detail all the oysters of the day as well as the menu items. Were great at accommodating our 2 1/2 year old (they don't appear to have high chairs). Good bread & butter and immediate refills on our waters. 

Only have a few tables along with bar seating so if you have little ones, plan on parking your stroller outside. We came on a workday at ~2:30 pm and were immediately seated. I love great food & service even more when I don't have to wait for it ;-).
author: Atif Q.

description: Some of the best seafood I have ever had in my life for a great price and great service. We started with the half anchor sampler and clam chowder, then had the crab Caesar salad, followed by the small cioppino. Everything was fresh, delicious, and perfectly seasoned. We would come back in a heartbeat!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
2.5 stars. 
I went here last night and agree with the rest of the reviews that this place is super tiny! That said, there was a line outside to get in the whole time I was there. The service is ok - since the place is so busy, the wait staff doesn't give you much time of day. The food was good, not great. My date loved the cioppino, however I've had better elsewhere. The portion was right on for the price tho. The fried oysters were a miss for me too. The batter was very generic and bland. I probably won't come back unless I am with someone who suggests this place.
author: Nikki F.

description:
Found this spot on Yelp before hopping on plane to San Fran for a weekend getaway.  Our hotel was far from here so we cabbed it on a cold 40 degree nite.  The place is small, had to get on a waiting list.  I hate being cold but had to stand outside and wait for 10 mins...20 mins...30 mins...40 mins.  I don't have on enuf layers for this shit, my wife is bitching about her freezing feet, I'm also staring thru the restaurant window at other people's food like a homeless man wanting to be who they are.  Then FINALLY they call my name.

Got inside and was damn happy.  Staff was friendly as hell, bread was served immediately which made me want to shake folks' hands, I was grateful to be with the "in" crowd meaning INSIDE.  Wine was really good, not overpriced.  Caesar salad was so-so, but the oysters were great and the cioppino was excellent!!  It really was a great meal.  Highly recommend but dress in layers in case u have to wait the fuck outside for 3 days.  Good luck.
author: Don S.

description:
Overall a very disappointing experience.
We waited inline for about one hour and a half. When finally we got inside we were seated at a table on the side of the entrance. Immediately we noticed that one of the glasses with the water had a very bad smell, something chemical. We complained and the waiter immediately replaced the glass without providing any explanation on how a dirty glass managed to reach a customer's table. 

On one plate the roasted potatoes were not really roasted, they were just steamed, while the steamed broccoli and carrots were simply raw. On the other plate the roasted potatoes were extremely hot, the typical high temperature of food straight out of the microwave. 

While we were trying to enjoy our dinner, a group of 4 or 5 customers came inside trying to avoid the cold wind outside. While they were waiting for their table they started to lean on our table shaking it in a very annoying way. Two girls were actually sitting on our small table making us very uncomfortable. Nobody asked them to wait outside or to be more considerate toward the seated customers (us).

Overall a very bad experience when considering the average price for this restaurant. This is the kind of place were you don't want to go back. Ever.
author: Frank F.

description: So delicious it's stupid.  If you have bothered reading my review among the 1200+ other 4 and 5 star reviews you've likely spent too much time debating to go here or not.  Just go.  You won't be disappointed.  The wait can be long but you've got the Castro to explore and people watch.  Just go when you're not hungry and by the time you are seated... you'll be hungry.  Otherwise, you'll get hangry.  No one likes a hangry dinner guest.   I wish I had leftovers from here right now...
author: C. K.

description:
Oh the wait, the wait, the wait. It was worth it though! The food was delicious and fresh, and the waitstaff were attentive and friendly. We waited outside in the bitter cold for about an hour and a half, but they brought us warm clam chowder (how thoughtful!)

The kumamoto oysters were delicious, so sweet and refreshing. The steamed clams and mussels were also top rate as well, the broth serves as a nice accompaniment for the bread.

Overall, great experience. Sitting at the bar is probably the best since you can always grab someone's attention.
author: Andy S.

description: I used to go there with my partners a lot during the weekends for brunch when We lived near Castro. Very delicious. Oysters are fresh(my favourite!) I feel like the food offered is comparable to the oyster restaurants in the ferry building. Up to the bar.
author: Alanda B.

description:
By far the best restaurant in the neighborhood, Anchor is also one of the best Seafood and Oyster Bars in the city. They always deliver high-quality food and I have yet to have a bad meal or experience here.  

Last night I watched the Kumamoto Oysters convert a non-raw seafood eater into an rabid oyster fan. The steamed clams were incredible, and it's hard to find better clam chowder on the West Coast. Also, the wine selection is simple and excellent... this place his a great!
author: Adam T.

description: Though we did not get to try the oyster or the cioppino and waited quite long time to get seated, I would still give AOB a 4 stars. Firstly, the garlic bread itself was well worth the wait. It was fresh, crispy and de-lish! Secondly, the clam chowder was creamy, not too fish and seasoned to perfection. Thirdly, the crab cake was moist and tasty. The whole meal did not disappoint only our appetite. In addition, the service here was outstanding although I wish they would expand so they can serve more client.
author: Riza R.

description:
Price & Quality- The food here is absolutely delicious and worth the price. Prices here tend to be a bit....up there but definitely not expensive per say, especially for seafood. Bottom line here though is that their food definitely tastes good.

Service- The waiters here are very nice and attentive.

Vibe- Always a vibrant atmosphere in the castro haha. Nice vibe here to enjoy some delicious foo.

Will I come back? Yes. This place has only a few flaws one being its small size and the other being the prices which I feel could be lower. Regardless, I am a fan.
author: Moises L.

description: Best meal I've had in the city. Ordering anything off the specials menu is the way to go.
author: Lisette P.

description:
My favorite seafood joint in the city.  We go here at least once a month, usually twice.  Small, cozy, with consistently excellent food, inventive specials, and top-notch, friendly service.  The only downside is that if you go at peak hours, you're likely to wait at least 20 minutes.  Peak hours on a weekend, and you're likely waiting an hour-- at least.  Our favorite menu items: 

- Caesar salad (about as decadent as a salad can be)
- Garlic bread (again...decadent)
- Clam chowder
- Crab cake

But forget about that.  You want to eat one of the specials.  Especially if they have the Idaho red meat trout with roasted vegetables and mashed potatoes.  Also their pasta dishes are pretty amazing.  And most of their tuna specials.  So so so good!
author: Ritik C.

description:
I heard they had the best clam chowder, and it's good but that's not what keeps me coming back. 

What keeps me coming back are the specials. Consistantly creative and delicious. Always paired with the perfect wine. That and the service make anchor oyster bar one of the few places I know I can go and eat fine food in a comfortable setting.

I love this place!
author: Gettye G.

description: Amazing. The only seafood restaurant I'll go to. The Cioppino is delicious, big portions, full of seafood and broth and the garlic bread that comes along with the dish is the best (get extra). And the staff is so sweet and attentive. Simply the best.
author: Diana S.

description: So we were in the city and I googled "best Caesar salad in San Francisco".  Up pops this restaurant so we made our way to the Castro and were delighted that we did.  The salad was really the best that I have ever eaten. My husband had the seafood salad I could not believe how much seafood they served him!  It looked like over a pound of fresh beautiful crab shrimp.  We will go here at every opportunity.  I highly recommend the Anchor Oster Bar!
author: Mary B.

description: Came here for lunch on a Wednesday with some out-of-town guests. We had to wait about 15 minutes to get a table and passed the time by visiting Philz Coffee just down the street. They have a whiteboard outside the restaurant where you can put your name down to be seated. In anticipation of a day full of eating, we only ordered a dozen oysters (3 of each kind they had) and a caesar salad. I'm not the best person to judge oysters as I can only tell a bad one from a good one, but one of my friends knows oysters really well and said that the oysters were good. We were a little disappointed because they didn't have that many types to choose from; only four total, I think. The caesar salad was excellent and comes with huge chunks of garlic bread mixed in. Value-wise, I think Anchor is a good deal and a far better value compared to Hog Island. The restaurant is tiny but service is fairly attentive and they try to really effectively make use of the small space. I will definitely be returning to try other things on their menu in the future!
author: Jasmine H.

description:
This is easily some of the best seafood in the entire city.

The first time I came back in October, I was in a bit of an altered state after slumming around the Mission all day long. Every morsel of food I put into my mouth that night was simply divine, and until last night, I was unsure if my meal was really that delicious, or because of my mental capacity at the time, would I have found a roof shingle to be just as appealing? Well, without a doubt, I can strike the latter from the list of options, as last night's meal was just as good, if not better, than the inaugural visit.

I'm not breaking ground with my assessment of Anchor Oyster Depot or anything, but they deserve all the props they can get. They've been slinging amazing grit from their tiny kitchen for over 30 years (or, as their shirts say, 30 "shucking" years!), and I have no reason to believe they won't be around for another 30. 

Everything on their menu I've tried has been outstanding, but an immediate favorite of mine is the shrimp cocktail. Yeah, you can buy it by the ton at Costco and it's relatively tasteless... but whatever they do to the bay shrimp and cocktail sauce here will make you forget all of the other times you ate crappy shrimp cocktail at some lame after-work employee mixer in the break room of your office.

Also, the serve up a mean bowl of Cioppino. I thought that nobody could touch Sotto Mare in that department, but they just might be right up there. It's a bit on the pricey side ($28), but what you get for it simply cannot be beat. Savory tomato broth, upwards of 5 or 6 different sea creatures with toasted bread to dip into the sauce. A nice treat if you're giving yourself an excuse to celebrate.

It can get pretty busy, so your best bet is to swoop in on an off night (Monday) or early in the evening.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
Slurpity slurp slurp!  Mmm now that's a good oyster.  I've never been to an oyster bar so this was my first time experiencing one in the Bay Area.   

We were originally going to Swan Oyster Depot that was on the San Francisco 7x7 100 things to try list, but it was open only until 5pm.  No bueno. So I yelped oyster bar that was currently open and Anchor popped up.  

Matt T. and I headed to Castro and parking may be a bit more difficult to find but I found a PRIME free parking spot right outside of the restaurant.  Sweet.  The place was a bit small and cozy so there was a bit of a wait.  We put our name on the board outside and the waiter came outside to serve little clam chowder samples to keep people warm waiting in the cold!  He was heading towards us but gave it to the other customers and ran out.  I'm sure I slipped an evil eye look somewhere in there that said I want me some CHOWDA!  Soon enough, he quickly said he will come back with more clam chowder soon. Brownie points! 

After waiting about 20 minutes, we sat at the oyster bar and could see everything that was going on in the kitchen.  I felt like I was watching a mini iron chef show as they prepped the different dishes and cracked fresh oysters open.

We ordered
- Shrimp cocktail - $8.95
- Bowl of Chowder - $6.25
- Half order of the Anchor Special - $19.95 (comes with six oysters three types, steamed clams and two chilled prawns).
- Crabcake Appetizer (comes in two) - $11.95

The waiter was very nice and suggested he will serve the food from cold to hot.  The shrimp cocktail and Anchor Special came out together and I was a bit hesitant at first with the oysters.  Soon enough, we squeezed some lemon onto the oysters and slurpity slurp!  Those are some fresh oysters full of love...yummy. 

The steamed clams were served in a bowl with this delicious and tasty soup that I couldn't get enough of.  The waiter would leave that bowl there so we could dip our bread into it.  Double yum. 

The shrimp cocktail totally beats Costco or Vegas buffet cocktails I've had in the past.  They were little pieces of shrimp and tasted very fresh with the red sauce.  Tip: Don't be shy in squeezing lemon into your sauce and oysters, it adds a zesty oomph!

The crab cakes and the bowl of clam chowder came next.  The crab cakes, were by far the best crab cakes I ever had.  You could see and taste real crab pieces inside the cakes and it was crunchy on the outside. Yum. Squeeze some lemon on it and dip it into the sauce and you are in crab cake heaven.

The Clam chowder was served right in front of us so it came steaming hot which is what I like with my food...(and men)  It was thick, creamy, and had the right amount of potatoes inside although it could use more clams in the soup.

Afterwards, I may have had some reaction to eating oysters since my face was feeling hot.  It's a mystery, but it was well worth it.  Overall, it was a great first time experience at an oyster bar and can't wait to go back to slurp some more.

"Eat oysters, love longer."
author: Cam C.

description:
I've dined here several times here, and while I never thought I needed to write a review, I do have some tidbits.

Do you see fried oysters on their white board? Order it.  I hate over cooked rubbery oysters and shy away from anything baked/grilled/fried.  I don't find it very rewarding to shell out some serious money for overcooked oysters.  I had a pleasure of trying fried oysters this weekend here, and wow. Its lightly coated with panko just to add texture, and its literally thrown into the fryer just to add color to the panko and heat to the oyster.  The result is something so luscious and tasty.  Its cooked enough that it cant be called raw, but its tender & flavorful without the overcooked iron-y, mineral-y, grimy taste.  Ok I'm salivating now.   Six pieces, complimented with their homemade tar tar sauce. Which I ate till my cioppino arrived.   

Although its not on the menu, everyone that checks yelp know that they have cioppino.  Its good. Check others for their reviews.  This weekend, I sat on the edge of the bar next to the kitchen.  I watched intently and noticed the chef throwing a bounty of crab meat, topped with a heaping amount of butter, and into the broiler.  I furiously looked for a baked crab appetizer on the menu but was dumbfounded.  Minutes later it landed on my half order (its for people who wait in line for over an hour in the cold, and want to try as many dishes as you can...even if you are only a party of two) of cioppino.

If, you order the cioppino, locate the buttery crab and place it on your garlic cheesy bread FIRST.  Don't lose out on that opportunity.  After you touch the plump mussels those suckers will sink to the bottom and you'll never find yourself eating a mouthful of buttery crab.  That buttery crab meat is pure gold.  Trust me.  

Also, if you are not a big fan of garlic, they tend to be very, very, generous with their garlic so make you sure you ask them to be easy on the garlic...if you are one of those people.
author: Nat Y.

description:
My first impression of Anchor Oyster bar was negative. We couldn't make a reservation. When we got there, we had to wait in the cold outside for 45 minutes to get in. Then things started getting better, one of the servers brought us complimentary clam chowder and bread as we waited in the cold, then he gave us a discount on drinks at the bar since we were still waiting, and then we finally got a table and spent several hours devouring dozens and dozens of oysters and other oyster cousins. We ended up closing the restaurant and they would give us extra little things here and there because of how long we waited and probably because they could tell we really appreciated the food... And also maybe because it was the servers birthday-- I felt like we were all celebrating together! 

Now, I am in LOVE with this place. I think my favorite oysters were the French Kiss Oysters.

My night at Anchor Oyster Bar was one of the highlights of this past year for me. I loved the people who worked there, and enjoyed lots of great wine with their delicious seafood. Oh, and at the end of the night, we even got free Anchor Oyster Bar shirts-- 33 shucking years! :) 

WILL DEFINITELY BE GOING BACK! :)
author: Nana R.

description:
I was in an oyster kinda mood all weekend. Went to Wayfare Saturday night and they were out of oysters. Was down on the wharf on the 4th and reservations only. I finally ended up at Anchor Monday night and I should have just gone here to start with.

18 oysters gone in roughly 15 minutes. They have the freshest oysters in the city and they are so crisp, clean and ice cold. 

We saw a couple seated across from us with the steams seafood combo. They were either A) having a fight and going through the mutual silent treatment or B) loving the food! We found out it was the latter and decided to try it out for ourselves. Wow, mussels, clams, cockles and a giants succulent prawn in a white wine, garlic and tomato broth.  We finished that half order in about 25 minutes and I must say, it was AMAZING!!!! We also ripped trough a giant loaf of sourdough bread, dunking it in the broth and that was just perfection. 
They had a few specials on the menu that were ordered while we were eating and everything looked delicious. 

All the above, 2 bottles of Pelligrino just $76 plus we tipped about 20%.

Once again, this is the best place in the entire city for oysters and seafood.
author: Hector G.

description:
It's a diner for seafood.  Good food, good service, good beer selection, so who can complain?  I saw people waiting at other times, but when you get in you won't be disappointed.  

I had some of the first Dungeness crab of the season in their specialty preparation - quick pan fried with garlic and herbs, which made for a messy crab cracking experience, but with good flavor.  They give you the tools and bib so you don't ruin your shirt.  The clam chowder was a little thinner than I like, but tasted good.  

The folks behind the counter were very attentive and helpful.  the only issue would be waiting, but I got lucky and didn't have to.  It's a little hole in the wall, but worth searching out.
author: Dave N.

description: We arrived 15 mins before they opened on a Sunday (4pm) and there was a line of about 6 people ahead of us. We tried their combination of oysters, clams and shrimp and everything was DELICIOUS!! All the oysters we had were fresh and very yummy! The place is small, so I was able to see other orders from people close by and everything looked really good. Definitely going back to try more items on the menu.
author: Niki L.

description: Allthough small this is a characteristic spot in castro borough in san francisco. It offers delicious seafood. The wine is good too.
author: Margot M.

description: My favorite seafood place! Everything is delish. Go during an "off" time so there isn't a wait. I've since moved away to a beach town with great seafood but still miss this place. Brought up the boyfriend this past weekend and he was very impressed.
author: Felicia L.

description: We waited and waited! for almost 2 hours!  We are happy to say it was worth the wait! My husband and I got a small Coppino and Cesar salad both of us felt it was the best we had ever had.  The customer service was amazing, while we were waiting outside the waitstaff brought out warm slices of the most amazing garlic bread we had ever had. That was a nice touch and since the bread was so  good it kept us motivated to wait around for a main dish. Tips.. this isn't a restaurant for children!  or large groups! there are tables for 1 (bar) 2 and up to 4 people. it's really,really small and more than likely you are going to be waiting a while to eat. Tip number 2. Get there an hour before you think you want to eat put you name on the list and walk around the Castro. We love this place and go about three times a year. It takes some planning but its  worth it.
author: Susan S.

description:
Coming to anchor oyster bar is similar to a religious experience for me. Not only am I constantly blown away by Chef Taylor's new and amazing dishes, but I constantly feel welcomed and truly loved. Let me give you the breakdown of this awesomeness.

1) Since there is always a rather extensive wait, Phil, the Texan sweet-heart host/drink server/busser always suggest we hop across the street for some wine. Like a true gent, he will come get the group when our table is about to be ready. Love.

2) Once inside, make sure you check out the oyster selection. There are new selections on a daily basis and it's always nice to get a mix of each kind.

3) ORDER THE GARLIC BREAD. This stuff will change. your. life. If you're into clam chowder, theirs is definitely worth a look as well.

4) The dinner specials are constantly changing as well, but I can say I've tried the scallops, cioppino, halibut, sole, pasta dishes, and the crab caesar salad (can you tell I love everything about this place yet?). You really cannot go wrong, so just mix it up and make sure everyone at your table has a different plate.

5) As I mentioned above, the service here is unmatched. Most of the servers have been with this place 15+ years, so they know what they are doing and you can absolutely trust their recommendations. 

Overall, Anchor is a place that you just cannot miss. Look past the long wait time and really prepare yourself for an amazing meal.

Cheers!
author: Sean R.

description: Very small place but great food. Clam chowder was excellent very flavorful not as much "filling stuff" which is a personal preference I think. But the base/broth must be homemade stock. Really great deep flavor. Oyster shooter excellent. I don't like tomato juice at all but theirs is more like a sauce you can taste the spices it's rich and delicious. Oysters were fresh my fave of the night was the island creek.  Hubby had fettuccine with clams and loved it. I tried the fettuccine and it was very good. The sauce had a depth of flavor. This is the kind of food that takes time. Can't wait to come back and try the cioppino and crab cakes. The food and service is 5 stars but it's so small it's a little claustrophobic.
author: Vicki U.

description: Great food worth the wait!!!! Clams are great the sauce is great use the cheese toast to dip it in too!!!!
author: Erik B.

description:
Anchor Oyster Bar continues to be my favorite restaurant of all time. True to form, in the week that I have been here, I have eaten at Anchor 3 times. My boyfriend and I celebrated our anniversary there on Friday night (his first time to visit SF & eat at  my favorite place), then we came again on Sunday night before he left for the airport to go back home...and then I brought my bosses here Monday night. 

I love the ambiance of the place. The clam chowder & crab cakes are a must have...but so are the oysters. But save room for one of the daily selected chef specials listed on the board above the counter.

Kudos to this wonderful little establishment. Here's to many years to come that I can make it out to SF several times a year and always put Anchor Oyster Bar on my "must do" list while here.
author: Rex H.

description:
We were here a couple weeks ago with our family for a day in the City.

We wanted to find another oyster place other than Hog Island, since it gets so crowded on the weekend.  We heard this place was good and worth a try.  They open by 11:30 on Saturdays and there's a bench that you can sit on in front to wait.  

The staff actually saw us sitting outside and invited us to come in before they opened.  The service was very attentive and friendly.  We ordered a few rounds of oyster shoots, garlic break (yummy and hot right out of the oven) and a few dozen oysters.  The oyster selection is good, not as much as Hog Island, but still very good.  The place was clean, but a little cramp for space.  do get their early as they fill out pretty quick once they officially open for business.

We will come back to enjoy the food and the neighborhood.
author: Jacki C.

description: Food was so Great!!! Definitely recommend the Cipinno and the garlic bread!!!
author: KC S.

description:
The clam chowder was amazing. Oyster were fresh and the cioppino was excellent. We ordered the half order for cioppino which turned out to be a pretty good size for two. Service was also great! definitely worth the wait
.
author: Tuan V.

description: We just popped in here to grab a late lunch. Super cozy, great ambience. Oysters and clam chowder were amazing. We both ordered daily specials... so amazing.
author: Graham F.

description:
It's worth the money, calories and time :) love the chowder, clams and the crabs. Fresh, yummy, and oh-so-good. 

Service was pleasant and wait time for dishes were reasonable.

We didn't have to wait for a seat because we came in around 4pm.

Will definitely recommend to friends visiting SF. 

Cheers - Singapore
author: Tristen N.

description: consistently excellent. The best Cioppino thus far, and I've tried many.
author: Tien L.

description:
I love this place.

I came here with my co-workers after thinking back to the rare oyster-noshing days I spent in NYC and wanting to find a place in SF to do the same.  This place seats no more than 25 people at a time, you have to get here early and put your name down on a white board.  The wait is so bad that, by the time we were actually eating, the people waiting outside would start cheering whenever a party was vacating their table or bar stools.  But then again, the food here is so good...

We started with the clam chowder, which is creamy and seasoned maybe a little light compared to true New England clam chowder (maybe not enough celery and onions in the base), I couldn't really complain.  From the raw bar, we had the full size sampler with a bonus dozen oysters.  I've discovered that I love rich creamy Kusshi oysters as much as Kumamotos, while the Miyagi and Wellfleet were salty/minerally and very fresh.  Their garlic bread could've been more garlicky, but otherwise offered great buttery crisp on the top of a fluffy base.  The steamed mussels come in a delicious garlic lemon tomato broth that screamed for more bread.  The pasta of the day was a delicious conchella cooked al dente in a tomato garlic base with huge prawns.

Next time, I'm definitely ordering the cioppino and whatever amazing pasta they are serving that day, and I look forward to expanding my knowledge and taste for oysters one cold dozen at a time.
author: Gene C.

description: The time to go is late lunch. We got in easily and were very happy we did. Outstanding oysters, great salads and soups. Good service. Can't wait to go back!
author: Bob F.

description:
Best Cioppino I have ever had, ever!!!!!! And I've had it in Rome before! 

Amazing service- the kind that makes you want to move to the area. I raced over here after flying in from LA it was the one place I really wanted to eat at and they were just closing when I got there- They were so kind to let us sit even thought they were about to close. Amazing friendly service.
author: Jazmine G.

description:
Nice little spot nestled along Castro St...on the same block as the 'Sausage Factory" and "Hand Job" to be exact...

The food is delicious..super fresh oysters..hearty Cioppino...and the grilled prawns were plated with the most amazing mash..

The only downside is that the wait can be hellacious..especially on a cold night..the place is pretty tiny so there isn't really room to wait inside or at the bar..
author: Mimi T.

description: First time here.. Very small space, kind of like a hole in the wall, But the staff was great! Very friendly. The food was fresh & the oyster shooters are a must! plus the crab cakes on the side.
author: Nancy T.

description:
One of the most popular seafood places/ oyster bars in the city but honestly I was disappointed.... I had oysters and the open face seafood sandwich for lunch and it was a sad meal.... I know small oysters are small.... but for $2.50 they aren't supposed to be tiny! The sandwich was just mediocre.... completely forgettable (I can't even remember the exact name). 

I would say Swan Oyster Depot is still far a better option as an oyster bar and seafood place. Or the Waterfront Grill for $1 oysters during happy hour
author: Gordon O.

description: Um, YUM!!! If you love fresh seafood go here!! The only downfall is its super small and you will most likely have to wait for a table... But that adds to the charm, right? ;)
author: Maria B.

description:
Small Oyster Bar on the highly populated and colorful Castro Street. This oyster bar is small, but feel very warm. I first saw this restaurant on EYE on the BAY and been wanting to go ever since.

Ordered:
* New Bruinswick French Kiss $2.50 Each-The name is cute, but you can probably pass on this oyster selection. 
* Long Island Blue Points $2.50 Each-This oyster is bigger than the Kumomotos, but taste pretty good. You can definitely try this.
* Hog Island Kumomotos $2.50 Each-This is the smaller oyster that packs a strong sweet taste. 
* Clam $1.95 Each-I am fan of clams, so I really like this. And not all places serve clams, so if you love clams, you can bookmark this place.
* Cup chowder $4.25 (3.5 of 5) Creamy and robust. Pretty taste, but not a must get.
* Oyster shooter $7.00 Each with Soju (3 of 5) - It is a really big shot of soju with a fat raw oyster. Reminds me of bloody mary with an oyster. It was ok, but I really liked that they used soju, instead of vodka. Soju seems to contain the alcohol, but smoothier to drink when trying to gulp the oyster at the bottom of the shot. 
* Caesar with Prawn $21.95 (3.5 of 5) Refreshing. I really like their thick cut buttered croutons. That was my favorite piece. And their prawns were super big and gave a nice fresh crunch when you bit into the cold prawn.
author: Janice T.

description:
Delicious and fresh seafood!

We started with a cup of clam chowder each and shared the Cioppino - definitely filling enough for the both of us. There was a loooong wait (15-20 min) between the arrival of the chowder and the cioppino, but the waiter was nice enough to take the chowders off of the bill. 

The chowder is rich and creamy with a good amount of clam. The Cioppino is LOADED with seafood in a delicious tomato broth. It came with delicious toasted garlic bread as well. 

Expect a long wait to get in and to get your food. but the fresh seafood is def worth the wait.
author: Jenny L.

description:
After yelping a million places, we finally decided on Anchor Oyster Bar and I am so glad we did. When we got there, there was only two other parties before us. Within 15 minutes, the place was packed with lots of people waiting. The wait was pretty long and it was freezing cold waiting outside so they brought everyone outside a free cup of clam chowder! SO GOOD FOR A COLD COLD NIGHT! This was by far the BEST hundred dollar meal.. actually I think it was the first time I had a hundred dollar meal for two.. BUT it was well worth it.. if you're reading this peter, THANK YOU :)

This is what we ordered : 

-» Oysters : we got all four different types of oysters to try .. I didn't really taste the difference between them and I really expected more from them since we were in the bay area lol maybe i'm just not an oyster expert haha

-» crab cakes : THE BEST CRAB CAKES EVER! They were on the pricey side for such a small portion, but it was so yummy .. It was creamy and was actual crab :) TO DIE FOR.

-» Cioppino : this was not on the menu and we didn't know how to say it so we showed them a yelp picture. Definitely worth a try. It came in a HUGE bowl that had us stuffed, but I could have eaten more of it cause it was so good.. (;

Next time I'm visiting the bay area, I will be back! :)
author: Nancy C.

description:
I was not going to write a review for this place as yet, because this is my first time here today.  Thought it could be a fluke as I was really hungry when I arrived.  Since it's highly recommended by my colleague, and the food was amazing, I have no choice, but to share...

My colleague was nice enough to sacrifice his time to come here early for a table!
I am so grateful that he pushed for a meeting here so I could try this place for the first time!  I was completely seduced when I first walked in; the ambience, the setting, the coziness, the smell and the staff...OMG!! This place is a gem!

We were so busy diving into our dishes, discussing the flavors and looking at other people's dishes, we forgot about our meeting, lol.
We ordered the crab cake, crab louis salad, clam chowder, half anchor special, a cioppino and garlic bread to share...plus a few more which I didn't care for.  We were like vultures, devoured our food so fast before I could remember to take any pictures.  
I think we wanted to order every dish if we could, but our table was not big enough. The quality of the food was excellent and the not to mention the service, they were on point! Staff was attentive and did not rush us.
The oyster was sweet and clean, the clam chowder has the right consistency and balance of flavors, I prefer this over Sam's Chowder, and the CIOPPINO!  I've been going to Phil's Fish Market & Eatery for cioppino for years and I will be coming here from now on...  The ingredients in the cioppino are better in my opinion, rich flavor but not over powering of tomatoes base and plenty of seafood.
I cannot finish the review without mentioning their garlic bread, that thing is deadly!  I love garlic and butter combination so this is my weakness.  I simply could not stop eating them.  If you are on a diet, leave it home if you decided to come here. Nothing is 
off limit here.  Now that we are back at the office, feeling stuff and in a food coma.  We are still talking about Anchor Oyster Bar and spreading the words to other co-workers.  What an awesome day! I cannot wait to come back!
author: Trinity H.

description: I went here for the first time on a recommendation when I was in SF for work in April and have not been able to stop thinking about it since! I enjoyed my meal there so much I went back twice on that short trip and plan to dine again when I am in SF in November. It is a cute little place in the Castro and you arrive and write your name and party # on a white board and then wait eagerly for them to call you in for the goodness. The food was AH-MAZING - the cioppino was probably the best meal I have ever had. No frills, very fresh, open kitchen where the chefs watch you take a bite and then ask you how it is - you can only give an emphatic thumbs up because it is so good you are stuffing your mouth and can't speak!
author: Kristen H.

description: Staff is friendly.  Cute place in Castro.  I think the chowder is okay.  The oyster shooter was really good!
author: Lai T.

description:
Even though they're called an oyster bar, Anchor is my favorite seafood joint in SF. They've got the freshiest fresh fish you could want, and it's always cooked perfectly. They've nailed the side dishes and rotate the fish with whatever's fresh off the boat.

I always order an Anchor Steam and one of the mains and nibble on the amazing garlic bread. It's a cozy place, perfect for 2 - 4 people. Cozy also translates to long waits sometimes, so write down your name and grab a drink nearby, but don't let the wait stop you... it's worth it.
author: Ross A.

description:
I loved my pasta special (tagliatelle with a mix of mussels, shrimp, clams) but the boston clam chowda was only ok.  2 of my companions had the same pasta special and weren't quite as thrilled with it - their servings were lacking a lot of the juice/sauce that mine had (great for dipping all of that shellfish in and slurping up).   

We were thrilled to get sat within 5 minutes of arriving (I had called ahead and they had warned the wait could be as much as 30 minutes) - guess we hit the sweet spot with timing.  The lighting in here is perfect - super cozy and flattering and warm.
author: Monica R.

description: This place has some of the best off menu offerings of any restaurant I've ever eaten at.  Their pasta and cioppino are perfect.  Also, they don't charge a corkage fee. Yup, you heard that right.  This place is just kind of magical in about a million ways.
author: Darin E.

description:
Group of six.of us came to celebrate birthday of a friend. Unfortunately, it would take.forever to wait for a table that accommodates all of us. We ended up splitting seats with about an hour wait.This place is not a great idea for group of more than 4. 
We ordered the osyter plate, seafood.pasta and the cioppino for.two. I love the clams that comes with the osyter.. its delicious and the osyter too. Excellent seafood.
author: Susanna H.

description: This really is the only good restaurant in the Castro and one of my favorites in the entire city--incredible seafood--awesome service--amazing oysters. Just come early as the place is super small and be sure to follow the rules (put your name on the board when you arrive, and be present when they call your name).
author: Nathan P.

description:
Excellent Cioppino (crab, clams, mussels, shrimp in tomato broth).

Small venue. Don't mind the dishwasher at the bar.

Pleasant service.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Wanted to take my lady to a nice dinner of tasty seafood. Restaurant was cool, more of a bar space. Pretty small so be prepared to wait. We went specifically for two things.

- CIOPPINO
The cioppino was the main thing we went for. Because I LOOOOVE cioppino. Supposedly the best cioppino around. In my opinion it was very hearty, but a little overly flavored. It might sound wierd but I like my cioppino a little more soupy and not as thick. They definitely give you a HUGH portion which I appreciated alot. But as far as happiness in taste, I wouldn't go back for it. Not bad, but not greatly pleasing. Taste buds are different so definitely give it a try yourself.

-OYSTERS
I literally am a oyster fein. If I could inject this stuff into my veins I probably would. Anchor Oyster Bar DEFINITELY did not disappoint. Very derrricious, and the set up was right. As simple as it should be, not all oyster places give you all the right sauces. This place was perfect. Only problem is, since I wasn't a hugh fan of the cioppino, we probably could have went somewhere for $1 oysters. 

-SERVICE
Great service. Friendly staff, very helpful, and they truly care about the customer.
author: Michael S.

description: Best Cioppino in Cali  we got the large serving and the crab burger was delicious! This place have not disappoint me yet.
author: CJ P.

description:
Accessibility (Parking / Wait Time)

0/1 Star: It's street parking so we circled a couple times and ended finding parking in the neighborhood. They also don't take reservations so we tried to get there around 5:30pm. Got our names on the list and waited half an hour.
_____

Taste (0=Not Edible / 1=Edible / 2=Good (average) / 3=Must Try!)

2/3 Stars: We got the garlic bread and clam chowder. I loved the garlic bread! Warm, crunchy, and golden. The clam chowder was ok, but not mind-blowing, which surprised me given the 7x7 list and yelp reviews.

_____

Service (Waiter / Cleanness / Ambiance)

0/1 Star: I was very excited to come here to try the clam chowder since it was on the 7x7 list, but the service definitely affected the whole experience. I understand it can be crowded and people try their best to get to everyone, but we waited patiently for the waiter to take our order. Since no one came after 10 minutes, we had to ask for someone to take our order.  At the end of the meal, no one came by even though we raised our hands, tried to get the attention, and stacked our dishes to indicate we were done. 
_____

Overall Experience
2/5 Stars
author: Tiffany C.

description:
A San Franciscan friend of my wife took us here while we were on our West coast road trip. I believe it's in the super-chic gayborhood - The Castro. I was taking a picture of my wife and her friend in front of the restaurant, and when we looked at the picture later, two men in the restaurant (by the window) were exchanging a romantic smooch at that very moment. Awesome.

Okay, on to the food... it was ridiculously good. The best lobster I have ever had. Oysters were great. All of the details (bread, side of veggies) were great. There will be a wait, as the restaurant is tiny, but it's well worth it. Also, it's expensive, but you're paying for quality.
author: Tim V.

description:
This is a small place and I would not recommend going here with a large party. There are 3 large tables that can feasibly fit 6 people, but it is a squishy fit for the people that sit back to back. There were also 2 small tables that could fit about 2 people and of course there was the bar seating. 

As for wait time, if you get there early, it isn't too bad. They have a dry erase board on the outside and you write your name, the number of people in your party, and the time that you arrived there. My friend and I didn't know that and we were standing inside for like two minutes before one of the patrons was nice enough to inform us (after seeing at least my confusion) that the board was on the side wall outside. We got there a little after 6 and we were seated in under 30 minutes. 

Luckily for me and my friend, we got the large table so it was nice and spacious. The server we had was really nice and I didn't feel rushed to order, eat, and leave. We ordered the full order Anchor Special which came with 12 oysters on a half shell, 8 steamed clams, and 4 chilled prawns for $35.95 (it struck me funny that the half order was $20.95, which is not half the full price). The oysters that day were the Cap Cod Wellingtons, Marin Miyagis, and the Oregon Hoods, all really fresh and delicious. The clams were cooked in this delicious white wine, butter, and thyme broth and the waiter gave us extra bread to sop up all that delicious "broth." 

The other dish we ordered was the New Zealand Bluenose sea bass baked with lemon and thyme, served over frugula sarda with tomato basil sauce. I was a tad bit disappointed with this dish because, i guess unlike Chilean sea bass, this sea bass was lean and not buttery/flakey. Texture wise it was really similar to that of cod fish. The tomato sauce was really strong and over powered the frugula sarda, which reminded me of HUGE Israeli cous cous but a bit more texture. Other than that, I thought the meal was pretty enjoyable. 

Definitely not a place for people who do not like seafood.
author: vanessa t.

description:
My extended family were adamant about a good seafood place...9 of us were in our party including kids.  When we got to the place, it was really tiny and not geared to large parties like ours...but being the seafood junkies we are, we didn't care to be split up in the name of good seafood...we didn't mind waiting.

All of us agreed that this was the best seafood we have had on our trip.  Jesus, Lord, hallelujah!  The crab cakes were great...the best my husband tasted...not lump crab cakes, but everything, including the encasing breadcrumbs, the tartar sauce on the side, tasted nice and fresh. 

The clam chowder nice and "comforting" as my hubby commented (although I thought it needed a hint more salt).  I had the shellfish combo and it was great, however, I felt the clams were a bit small as well as some of the mussels, but I didn't care since everything tasted super fresh.  There were jumbo-sized fresh shrimp that even my midwestern husband helped me chow down.

The specials of the day...my mom got a sole dish with spicy avocado sauce and loved it.  My dad got a seafood pasta which was the best thing to all of us as we were picking at his dish as well.  He was concerned of large portions, however he polished off most of the dish as the cavatappi pasta was cooked a perfectly al dente and the scallops were sooooooo super fresh tasting and had a nice char on them and the sauce amazingly fresh with fresh basil and tomatoes.

The other half of our party (they were seated at tables rather than the 4 of us at the bar) LOVED everything as well.  My sister's daughter, a very picky eater who never eats all her food, ate all her kids pasta, as my sister commented it was unusually amazingly good for something so simple as she, her hubby, and my bro were picking at it as well.

I'm thinking this place is PACKED on the weekend as we came on late Monday night and there were still people behind us.

I hated to write this review as I'm not happy to let people know about this place...I'm selfish like that!   But I have to let the establishment know how happy all of us in the party were to eat here.   Keep up the good work!
author: S F.

description:
WOW!  All I can say.  Everything in the reviews is spot on.  This place is TINY... Three 4-tops, One 3-top, and One 2-top, plus the bar that seats about 6.  So get there when it opens (learned that trick last night) or be prepared to wait.

Our first visit we arrived there was about 3 names ahead of us it took about an hour to seat us, which was fine.  While waiting the manager greeted all of us waiting with small cups of the Clam Chowder.  Now, I normally don't like Clam Chowder, but OMFGG, this stuff was amazing.  So creamy, hot, delicious.  Filled with good veggies, clams, and seafood wonderfulness. I had already made up my mind on what I was going to have, so I knew next time I would order it.

Our first visit we shared the steamed artichoke appetizer.  Well cooked, great house made aioli, perfect for two to share.  My only complaint is that is was a special and not always available.  We also shared a half carafe of the house chardonnay.  Now normally I don't like box wine, but this was really nice, and well priced.   We also got the house garlic bread.  Its awesome (not my husbands fav, but I liked it)

I got the dayboat scallops special for my entree... WOW! My husband got the 1/2 seafood platter.  His was awesome, 6 oysters, 2 chilled prawns, and about 8 steamed clams.  The white wine sauce that the clams were steamed in was the best part.  Well the clams were good, but that sauce.  I could just drink it!! YUMMMM-O!  Great to use the bread and garlic bread to mop up the sauce. 

Our second visit we got 8 oysters to start.  We ordered Kumamotos, but we got the last 6, so the other 2 sweet waters that were served were on the house.  The oysters are so fresh, awesome cocktail sauce, and the best mignonette.  We each got a cup of the amazing Clam Chowder as well.  Just as good as I remembered from that sample the manager passed out.

For entrees I got the Caesar with crab, my husband got the crab cake entree.  The Caesar was awesome, great dressing, crunchy Romaine, and MOUNDS of fresh crab meat that was so perfect with the Caesar dressing.  The croutons were made from their house garlic bread and really a great match.  The crab cake are awesome.  I don't even know what was holding these together, there was minimal breadcrumbs or other filler. Perfectly cooked and paired with a great house tartar sauce.  My husband said the tartar sauce almost upstaged the crab cakes.

But overall, awesome food, great service and perfect location.
author: David P.

description: def one of the best seafood resturant i've ever been to !! the seafood was fresh and cooked pretty fast. severs was very very nice and polite. but be prepared to wait in line for more then a hr at dinner hrs. and ask for their daily specials!!
author: Helen Z.

description:
BYOB (with no corkage fee), varietal oysters, impressive seafood entrees, and an atmosphere that makes you feel like you're in a bustling LES locale without the NYC wait time -- who wouldn't want to eat here? 

We went with a group of 4 and our night was fabulous. The excellent service and awesome vibe made us quickly fall in love this place, and if we were locals we would surely be regulars!
author: Stephanie L.

description: Best cioppano I have ever had in my life. In fact,  I loved it so much that I went to the kitchen and thanked the itty bitty lady chef in the back. She is simply marvelous. I also had a wonderful oyster shot. Great place to dine. Just hope you don't have to wait!
author: Lydia E.

description:
Ok, AOB has always been one of our favorite places to eat seafood in SF and it did not disappoint.

Try the cioppino (it may not be on the menu so ask for it, and get the AQ price as it is not posted).  We got ours in a family style bowl for two and it was more than we could finish. Amazing!

They also have super-fresh oysters, crab dishes, and clam chowder.  Try the garlic bread with the cioppino.

The only change we noticed is that the lines are even more horrid at dinner time than before.  Not only was AOB on Check Please Bay Area but also won an award from SF Weekly so I assume many newcomers are trying out the place.  They really stick out like sort thumbs in the Castro. /wink

Do not come with groups of more than 4 expecting quick seating.  Your party must be there when your table is ready or they will skip you.  Be ready for waits of 1hour+ during the dinner crush.

It is not a great place for hyper children so please be considerate (kids bouncing off the walls in the small place made for an uncomfortable evening, at least until they left.)

I'll go earlier next time and hope to cut down on my wait time.
author: Rick G.

description: A small unique and delicious restaurant. This place was amazing, the oysters were the best I have ever had.  I will be back soon!
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
Tiny. A little overpriced. Delicious.

The Caesar salad is awesome. 

Tell the waiter and you can get a glass of wine (or two) across the road at Swirl while you wait for your table...
author: Mark P.

description:
Been coming here for  years and it never disappoints.  The service is great- warm and friendly, and you don't even have to pay a corkage.  But, on to the food.

It is sublime.  I highly recommend everything, but the dungeness crab is the tastiest freshest crab I have ever had.  Always tender and sweet.  Ditto the oysters. And so on :). Oh and the Caesar salad is divine and can easily be shared.

Be prepared for a wait.  It's worth it.
author: Jorah N.

description:
Cioppino. Cioppino. Cioppino.

It's hard to say what hasn't already been said. We waited nearly an hour for a table and I am giving an happy, happy 5 stars. That should say more than any words I can possibly write. 

The space is small, but in an intimate-not-super-cramped way. The decor is borderline kitschy nautical, but the black and white tile is a smart touch that keeps it cool. But honestly, I didn't spend a lot of time looking at the walls because the food took all my attention.

Our party of 3 started with oyster shooters, a bottle of Napa Sauvignon Blanc, and a full order of the Anchor special, a delicious combo of oysters, prawns and steamed clams. They really got something going on here with the stock they're using, because the clam broth was amazing. First you wonder why the server keeps bringing you more and more bread. Then you understand. You need to dip the bread in the broth. And dip. And dip. Till the bread is gone. More on broth later.

For entrees, I ordered the combination salad, topped with a heap of fresh crab meat, prawns and shrimp. It was a $24 salad, but they were generous with the seafood.

Husband ordered the Ciopinno. The CIOPINNO. The server will explain that it comes in two sizes, small and large. But the small is actually quite, quite large and the large is...really large. Yummy seafood dunked in a tasty, buttery broth, topped with two pieces of the best garlic bread you've ever eaten. I realize the words "garlic bread" conjure up the stale grocery store bread that you bake in foil in the oven and the butter never quite melts and tastes like chemicals - but this is not that bread. The bread was legit. 

I nearly cried when I realized that I couldn't take the Cioppino broth home because we were staying in a hotel and flying the next morning. 

So, in brief, you should eat here. Don't be swayed by the wait time or the fact that visiting the restroom means ever so carefully walking past the flaming gas stove. It will be worth it.
author: Lauren V.

description: Had the oyster sampler platter and chowder--definitely a fan of this place and I love walking through Castro. Will have to try the cioppino next time.
author: Heather R.

description:
This place is great. Great seafood, very fresh, nice variety, but a few problems force me to dock one star. We got a nice seafood feast of crab cakes ($12ish for two-appetizer), the anchor platter ($36 for 12 oysters, 4 shrimp, and a bowl of clams), and the Cioppino ($28ish I think?). 

The crab cakes were really amazing! They were cooked perfectly, my fork cut through them like warm butter. They melted in my mouth, mmmm. The sauce that they brought out was amazing too. It was not tartar, but similar. Maybe with more mayo? IDK, but it was fantastic. 

The oysters were also very good. We had three different types. I think one was local, one was from Cape Cod (one of my fave places on Earth!), and I'm not sure of the other. 2/3 of us preferred the Cape Cod ones (no bias, I swear), while the other 1/3 preferred the local as they were a little saltier. My only problem with these is that 3 or 4/12 of them were very small in comparison to the others. I mean like thumbnail size. That was pretty disappointing considering the prices. The shrimp were good, but not amazing. Just steamed, chilled prawns. 

The clams were anything but ordinary. They were in a delicious garlicky, buttery, wine-based? sauce. There were lots of them, more than I expected. Our waiter intuitively offered more bread to sop up more of the sauce; genius suggestion. 

Similarly, the Cioppino was very good. the "broth" was a little less brothy than I am used to and more thick and chunky like a tomato sauce. Otherwise though, great flavor. I would order it as the Fisherman's stew (only difference is with or without crab) because, as much as I love crab, trying to get into one of those things after it has soaked in tomato sauce is imminent disaster for your wardrobe. There was some fish in there that was delish, the mussels were amazing, and the garlic bread that came with it was fantastic. I will definitely be ordering the mussels if I am able to return. 

So here are my beefs. First, the wait was about 45 minutes on a Sunday night after they told us it would not be long. Then, once the three of us were seated at a 2-person table, the service was pretty slow. don't get me wrong, our waiter was great, but it just took a really long time to get our food and things. Also, it was a bit pricey. I know fresh seafood is costly, but I just wish that I could afford to come back more regularly. The food was excellent though for the most part, so I highly recommend.
author: Miguel V.

description:
Three words: GET THERE EARLY

 This place is surely worth the wait! 
Oysters are so good, the crab patties were Delicious! I cant wait to come back
author: Natasha I.

description:
Four of us went here for the first time on Saturday and had the best time. We ordered the cioppino (for two), Dungeness crab, steamed clams, crab cakes, clam chowder, and garlic bread.  We actually had two orders of garlic bread because it was THAT delicious. The cioppino was lovely, just enough tomatoey goodness that didn't overpower the seafood. The steamed clams were cooked in a broth that tasted as if it had a little wine, thyme, oregano, garlic and red pepper flakes.  The clam chowder was thick and creamy. The crab cakes were good, but we'd probably pass the next time. The star of the meal was the Dungeness crab. It was cooked perfectly and rolled around in butter and garlic that we sopped up with our garlic bread. 

We got served by the tall, thin, gentleman with the salt and pepper hair.  He couldn't have been nicer.  Very sweet and very attentive.  Even though only one of us ordered a cup of clam chowder, he brought out a small cup for the rest of us so we wouldn't be left out.

After reading the Yelp reviews, we got there at 5:20pm on a Saturday and was seated within 10 minutes.  While eating, we saw the crowd grow bigger and bigger so either come early or be prepared to wait.
author: C L.

description:
Update after being written to from the owner-Based on our contact not the food:

Owner Roseann Grimm left me a Yelp message apologizing for my experience the other night at the Oyster Anchor Bar. Ms. Grimm was very kind, and refunded my receipt due to my displeasure with the food we ordered. I have worked in customer service almost half of my life, and for her to make contact with me and try to rectify the situation really is going above and beyond. Her making that effort has not changed my view of staff, because (like I said before) they were great! But it has made me want to go back and try once more...maybe a different menu choice. So, thank you Ms. Grimm, and I appreciate you connecting with me in such a speedy manner.  :)
author: Natalie J.

description:
Throwing my 2 cents in....
  The Bad :   2 hour plus wait for a table......it's a small place maybe 30-35 tops....
   The Good: this was one of the top two seafood dinners I have ever experienced.  The staff, food and drink were damn near perfect.
 Oysters on shell prepared with great care and excellent quality. Huge Crab Salad was ok and then came the " fish stew"....  It was absolutely amazing...we finished off this extremely large order and wiped the bowl clean.....it was stunning.
Was the wait worth the experience........with out a doubt..and you can go across the street to Swirl for drinks and a bottle to go.
This is only the second 5 star review for me.....please go and experience this place.
author: John W.

description:
This place is money.  Very fresh seafood, simply prepared, great flavors.  
Really enjoyed the Cioppino, garlic bread, and steamers. 
In the future, I'll probably do the green lips steamers and split the Cioppino.  
Might throw in a few oysters...though they do charge a pretty penny for those!

Wish they took reservations and/or had a bigger space, but otherwise I really have no complaints.
author: Elad C.

description: I really love their cioppino.  The flavor is wonderful and the seafood is very fresh.  The steamed mussel was very fresh as well, but a bit too much lemon in there for me though.
author: Pepper P.

description:
The wait is absolutely unbearable during dinner time. That probably killed the experience from the start (you can't live up the expectations of a 2 hour wait). 

The food's solid, but I think I'll stick with my local guns (Swan Oyster and Hog Island). 

Oh yeah, finding parking as always is a blast out here.
author: Abel L.

description: Best garlic bread in town and best Italian seafood in town. The mussel and crab in the cioppino are soft and fresh.
author: Sunny J.

description: This place was amazing!!! The oysters are sweet and fresh, yum! We also had the ciopinno which wasn't on the menu, but was so worth it. My roommate said the line is typically out the door, but when we went there during the week there were seats at the bar so we were able to sit right away. It was still crowded which is always a good sign. I'll definitely come back again.
author: Maeling D.

description:
I've been dying to try this place forever, but it didn't live up to the hype I was expecting.  
Ordered and shared the anchor oyster platter (oysters, clams and shrimp), garlic bread, cioppino and the special seafood pasta that night.   

Maybe since we ordered so much seafood, the dishes all came out to have the same kinds of shellfishes, although they hold back on them.  

My favorite was probably the pasta.  I was a bit hesitant to order it since the bowl looked enormous.  After halfway through the dish, we realized it only looked big since it had so much shellfishes, but the pasta ratio was perfect!

Out the door in a happy tummy!
author: Nancy S.

description: This turned out to be a huge pearl in the seafood oyster of the world! We have dined in many 4 and 5 star restaurants in North America but never, not one time, have we had the excellent level of service and quality of food that were received at the Anchor Oyster Bar. Everything from the house garlic bread to the clam chowder to the sauteed scallops to the cioppino was just off the scale terrific. One could tell that the food had been prepared by people who were intensely proud of the offering they put in front of you. Chef Todd put his heart and soul into every dish, and it showed. The staff was coureous, attentive, friendly and efficient and were spot-on with everything they did. This little gem should not be overlooked at all. Sure, there is a bit of a wait time, most things that are worth anything require you wait a bit, anyway. This is no different. If you are looking for the best, here it is. The Anchor Oyster Bar. None better, anywhere. Wish I could give them more than 5 stars, they deserve 10.
author: Bill H.

description: Really cute seafood bar restaurant. Small so seats around 30-40  people only so go during off times. I like the decor, would be very cute spot for a date. Oysters were fresh. Clam chowder was one of the best. Very creamy and smooth. I didn't have the crab sandwich but it looked amazing and that's what most ppl got so def will go back and try that.
author: Carrie T.

description:
this place is hard to find due to the construction outside. The parking in Castro is super crowded. I went there the first time with my friend last May, we tried the Ciopponio seafood and it was huge and so delicious. It probably the best one in SF so far that I have tried. The bar was so small, make sure you get there early, so you will get a seat. 
The 2nd time i came back with another friend, and it closed for renovation....:-(
will be back soon...love their food and great service
author: T P.

description: This one also is my favorite spot, all fresh seafood, I love the oyster and clam, with white wine is the best. place is small, need to sign name line up, one time i had wait for an hr,but it's worth.
author: DontHurtMe T.

description: Food tastes great - too bad I didn't see other reviews before trying this place. I would to have tried the cioppino! We came late at around 8:45 so the wait was not and. The garlic breads are plentiful as is the Caesar salad.
author: William L.

description:
Anchor Oyster Bar has been shucking it for 33 years...  They must be doing something right.  Plus they keep the small place immaculate.  I was at first surprised, and then not so surprised by this... :)

We headed there on a Sunday afternoon, sat down at the bar and quickly selected our orders. Our waiter recommended the mixed bowl of mussels.  My dining partner went with his suggestion, and after scarfing the bowl down, she decided she preferred the taste of the green shelled mussels. Regardless, she said it was the best bowl of mussels she's ever had.  It was large enough to share, and the garlic broth was perfect for dipping the sourdough bread.

I still prefer the black mussels over green.  The guy serving us behind the counter said that typically Thai restaurants serve the green shell mussels.  I thought that was an interesting tid bit.

I ordered a bowl of clam chowder and it had just the right amount of flavor and richness..  Next, my combo seafood cocktail order was served with the cocktail sauce and horseradish just how I like it; on the side for my dipping pleasure.

This place is one very strong reason to spend an evening in the Castro.  Although, I am sure you can think of some others.
author: Georgio N.

description:
Definitely a 5/5 and worth the 45 minute wait in line (which is pretty short considering more and more people showed up after we were seated). 

My party of four came around 6:45 pm on a beautiful sunday night and there were only a couple of parties before us. It was not too bad of a wait BUT remember to bring a jacket as SF does get cold at night! (This is a note for those who are not familiar with the area). 

AMBIANCE (4/5): This small,5-6 tables restaurant is situated near the heart of Castro district between 18th and 18th street. This restaurant is so small that the washing dishes was done right in front of the customers. The tables and chairs were silver and weren't fancy, and some may know for sure that they serve seafood from the quality of the tables and chairs. Despite the lack of space and the furniture, this place left me speechless with their awesome service and their unforgettable Cioppino and fresh $2.50 oysters. 

SERVICE (5/5): At first some may think that the service is very slow and the employees will ignore their customers Even though the service is slow, they are very patient and careful with their customers. There are only a couple of waiters and they are always moving so it may be hard to flag them down BUT they do notice you and they will ask you if you are doing okay and if you need anything. They work slowly but carefully and precisely. I was particularly impressed on how attentive they are and how professional about their service. I want to mention about the chefs in the kitchen, they are very passionate in what they do and will make sure that they bring the best quality of food out to their customers.

QUALITY OF FOOD (5/5): This place is definitely going to land in one of the best restaurants to go eat in the bay area. Their Cioppino, or a big bowl of seafood covered in a nice homemade marina sauce, is the fresh, flavorful and has the perfect amount of spice to make a person wanting for more. I was in love with their mussels; they were so fresh and sweet. I've never had such fresh mussels. Aside from the Cioppino, their oysters were definitely a must-try. The oysters were $2.50 and came from three different regions so you could decide which type of oysters you wanted. We tried all three and we enjoyed all of them. The oysters were so fresh and slimy that made us order more and more. We also ordered clam chowder and garlic bread; they were decent but I could get better ones in other places. The clam chowder wasn't as creamy as i expected and i couldn't get the clam flavor from the chowder. The garlic bread was definitely homemade with nice cheese but the bread as a whole didn't really stand out to me.
