PRICE (5/5): We ordered so much food and we finished all of them with ease because it was that delicious. We ordered two orders of Cioppino and clam chowder and the bill came out to be 159 including tax and tip. The price is definitely reasonable for the quality of the food and service. 

This restaurant definitely gave us a memorable experience and we will definitely return for more Cioppino.
author: Jacky C.

description: Our hotel concierge recommended this place - best oysters I've ever had ... it was life changing.  Ask for the Cioppino - it's not on the menu but it was delish.
author: Emily S.

description: I love this place. The food, the people and just the vibe. I remember sitting outside the place waiting in line and in cold... There comes the benevolent Anchor staff member giving us a small lobster bisque soup. Who does that? Things like these reaffirm my faith on humanity
author: Sharika S.

description:
Cioppino. Not bad. 

Nice flavorful tomato/fish broth. Clams, mussels, cod, prawns, crab.
They don't officially have cioppino on their menu, but there is a item called welsh fish stew. I think its the same, except they add crab in the cioppino.  It was interesting that when I asked about the cioppino, they said they had crab today, so they can serve cioppino.  I guess if they don't always have crab, the Welsh Fish stew will provide the same dish just without the crab.

This place is tiny. I think it only seats around 20. I can see how lines form outside. I didn't see a bathroom.  Dishes are washed in front of the counter.

Went around 12:30 on a Saturday. no wait. I sat at the counter. You're shoulder-to-shoulder with the diner to the left and right of you. I couldn't spread out my elbows to either side. It was challenging to eat, just sitting still inplace. I didn't even try to crack the crab legs. Just didn't have enough room to try it. What a waste. Wish they would fully crack the legs or deshell it compeletely and just put in the crab meat.

Its the Castro. street parking only. Had to park 4 blocks away.

It's good, but if there was a line, I wouldn't have waited.

I prefer the cioppino at Taddich Grill. They deshell the crab and just put in the whole crab meat. They also add scallops. Broth is very similar. Herb tomato fish broth.
author: Marshall C.

description: LOVED the cioppino that I was looking forward to the whole trip to SF. Am glad I came early for lunch as the place is smallish and fills up quickly! I sat close to the kitchen and Alex, upon realizing that I am from Boston, was quick to make me try the chowder on the house!! it was fantastic and does the Bawston chowdah justice.   I was torn what to order next as there are a number of good, and tasty options on the menu, but consulting with Alex ...cioppino made sense.  The half portion was gorgeous and huge!! It was a meal that took me every bit of an hour to break down with all the shellfish, including manila clams, mussels, large shrimp, dungenous crab legs and fillets of what i think was halibut.  The soup was hearty and had real depth of flavor and fresh herbs that really made a difference. The chef is a sweetheart and personally came to check whether I liked my order and whether I wanted anymore garlic bread. I couldnt possibly order more bread as it would leave some of that seafood goodness behind! Very glad i made the trip and would definitely come back again !
author: Alex R.

description: Awesome spot for great seafood.  In the very cool Castro neighborhood.  Started with the mussels (a must have - the best item on the menu in my opinion), along with a few oysters (which were equally good).  Sea bass for dinner, which I enjoyed, although the brussel sprout, potato gratin was just ok.  Would definitely recommend.
author: Todd L.

description: Excellent service, delicious fresh seafood and a kitschy nautical atmosphere. The cioppino is out of this world: fish, crab, clams, mussels. It comes with garlic parmesan bread for dipping in the tomato sauce which is seasoned with big thick discs of garlic. Heaven. You might feel like a dork, but when the server offers a bib, take it. The crab cakes are perfect and oh the New England clam chowder. Not too thick, not too thin, clams perfectly cooked. Great wine selection. It's no wonder this place has been operating since 1977.
author: Audra S.

description: A big favorite! I've been there so many times. I love it. Oysters, fish, salads, special of the day. I've tried it all. Top seafood in the city. One of the rare restaurants taking the time to close to clean up the place and add a fresh coat of paint so it always looks clean and fresh.
author: Frances G.

description:
The place is very very (very) small. The wait is quite long. 

My bf and I were on a mission to try all the places in  the "Big Eat 100 Things to Eat Before You Die. " We got the clam chowder togo, and just ate on the bench outside. IT WAS ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS! The soup was perfectly cream, not too chunky and not too watery. They included bread with it also! Definitely great for cold weathers.
author: Mo W.

description: I used to love to eat their seafood combination pasta and last night I went back . A different chef served 80% of water with pasta didn't taste good at all then I asked waiter if she can cook again? And I ask him if she going recook used same sea food and he said "no." Then I went To restroom and I saw her use same food for my new dish. Worst taste of all , I'm very disappointed With the food, but I keep it to my self and leave very unhappy however the waiter were very nice to me.
author: Tony T.

description: Incredible food. I usually reserve five stars for uber fine dining, but the food here is excellent. The clam chowder is the best I've had. Excellent oysters, unlimited oyster crackers :-) and Hoegaarden and Big Daddy on tap. If I lived closer, I fear I would be broke and squishy from too much chowder! Also, the service was excellent. We sat at the bar on a Friday about 1:00.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I've been going to this place since 1991-  it's been a Castro fixture for decades. 

No fancy California cuisine menu or Asian Fusion menu here, just simple, classic prepared seafood that is always consistent in preparation, freshness and ingredients. 

My favorite dish is the Anchor Special- 12 raw oysters on the half shell (as with most seafood places types vary), 8 steamed clams and 4 chilled jumbo prawns for $34.95. The sourdough bread dipped in the remaining huge bowl of garlic butter sauce the clams came in is a great way to top off the meal. And, I always must have my Anchor Steam as a chaser. 

The service is polite, friendly, and as efficient as they can be considering they are always packed. If you're coming here for dinner hour (6pm or later), be prepared to wait outside, because there is no room in the restaurant. (So, choose a night it's not too cold). Otherwise- I strongly recommend this as a weekday lunch place- because on the evenings and weekends you can easily wait 20 minutes to a half hour. 

The decor is really casual- metal tables are packed in tight along with an eating bar- so no need to dress fancy for this quality seafood.
author: Nick M.

description:
Being from Sydney I love my seafood, so when we came on holidays to the US and were staying 50m up the road in Castro i HAD to visit Anchor Oyster Bar. I walked past every day on the way to the station. 

The queues are epic, but even as tourists we figured out the best thing to do is jot your phone number on the white board and duck across the street to drink wine in the cute little bottle shop/bar across the road. Brilliant way to kill time. 

Once inside the service is quick and snappy. Food is amazing, beer is cold. Between 3 of us we tried the oysters (not the usual selection available as it was Labour Day Holiday weekend), the mussels, the crab cakes, the bread (OMG even the bread was amazing), and the scallops. 

Check this place out!!! You won't be disappointed!
author: Beth J.

description: Fantastic.  Absolutely loved it.  I had the full order of oysters which came with steamed clams & shrimp.  Had the clam chowder which was amazing and the garlic bread.  The crab cakes were DELICIOUS.  I will be going back soon.
author: Rebekah C.

description:
OK, I don't like the fact that you can't make a reservation here.  But, if you put your name on the list, sometimes they'll let you escape to the wine bar across the street.  Once you actually get into Anchor Oyster Bar, the oysters are obviously fab. Also try the oyster shooters if you can. Those are nomtastic. 

It's a very small intimate spot and I've never had a bad time here. It comes fully recommended in my book!
author: Taylor L.

description:
This place rocks!! The service is always top notch, the people are super nice, and the place is small enough to feel homey.

Must try: Crab cakes, Crab Salad, and Claim Chowder. Oddly enough, the oysters are kind of expensive for what you get. They are good too, but the first three are my favorite!
author: John H.

description: Trully enjoyed the experience. Oysters were fresh and smoked trout salad was  Excellent, will be back!
author: Charles A.

description: The service and food was beyond excellent!   When I return to San Francisco I will definitely be coming back here to eat!
author: April W.

description: This rather petite restaurant has one of the best cioppinos in SF .   The "small" bowl is just about big enough for two. And is plenty if you get a small plate or a cup of clam chowder. The cioppino is tomatoey, olive oily, and buttery. The dipping bread superb. Again don't be afraid of the price of the small bowl--it serves two.
author: David M.

description: A SF must!  By far the best oyster place in all of the city.  Varying fresh oysters daily...always shucked perfectly. The clam chowder is fantastic.  The cioppino is delicous and comes as a huge serving certainly enough for two.  Try the garlic bread....melts in your mouth.  The only down side is the slower than expected service...which seems to lack organization.  They could be so much more effecient in service and quicken the table turn around time....you frequently are waiting for your check.  However don't misinterpret....the server staff is incredibly friendly and I appreciate their geniune warmness.
author: Jason F.

description: I have to update my review. After living here nearly six years, Anchor Oyster bar is my favorite restaurant in the Castro. The food is always fresh and delicious. I prefer to come here on weekday nights when it's less crowded because the place is small.
author: Meredith G.

description:
While tucked away from the bustling side of Castro Street, Anchor Oyster Bar is definitely no hidden gem. I immediately made that observation on that cold windy evening as I glanced at the menacing wait list. Despite the coveted four and a half stars... regardless of the woman in waiting reassuring us that "it's worth the wait"... I was still a bit skeptical. Primarily because none of the Yelp highlights were personally compelling. "They rave about the clam chowder, garlic bread, and crab cakes," I told my sister in dismay. "Nothing I'd go out of my way for..." or so I thought...

Once seated, I get down to business -- peruse the drink menu. A decent variety of four (mostly local microbrews) on tap along with the usual suspects in bottle form. I always appreciate a place with a good offering of quality brew, so kudos to Anchor for striving to provide some sort of offering given it's tiny space. 

While the space is tiny, only probably being able to accommodate twenty something patrons, it never felt cramped. Despite the fake swordfish and other swashbuckler paraphernalia adorning the walls, the ambiance was romantic -- in a cute, "I'm not trying that hard to impress you, but after you're done, I will have" kind of way. "Good place to bring a date," I mentally noted as I looked disappointedly at my sister (I'm just kidding. I love my sis! *duck*). I assume the other parties around us were in agreement. The couple across from us were deep in conversation as the man caressed his girlfriend's arm. The couple whose table we were waiting for seemed to be lingering for an eternity even after their check arrived. I only know because I was intently staring at them, sending them telepathic messages, "Pay your damn bill and get the hell out!! I'm freezing my ass off out here!!" 

The food was excellent. We ordered two bowls of clam chowder, the Anchor Special (dozen oysters, steamed mussels, four jumbo shrimp), garlic bread, and crab cakes. My only tiny issue about the clam chowder was that I wished it was hotter. The oysters were fresh -- however, our server didn't tell us which oysters were what until I asked (I'm just nitpicking here -- service was, in fact, very attentive and friendly, so I only have the silliest things to gripe about.) The broth for the steamed mussels was fantastic -- on the menu, it's just listed as "steamed mussels" -- but believe me, it's MUCH more exciting than just "steamed mussels". 

The garlic bread was the highlight of the night. I'm far from being some sort of die hard carbivore -- in fact, the only reason why I ordered it was because it was a yelp highlight -- but oh god... this was something else. In fact, the garlic bread alone made the wait worthwhile. I loved it so much, it gets its own dedicated paragraph in this review. 

And so I have a feeling that I'll be waiting out in the cold once again. However, this time, I'll be the one telling the naive skeptic, "It's worth the wait."
author: Edward Y.

description:
How the heck have I not reviewed this place until now?! This place is a memorably great spot for seafood, and my dad insists on coming here every time he's visiting. We are a family of oyster lovers who've made a point to sample oysters around the country, so a return visit is a big deal for us!

 Be warned that the space is very small and you will be waiting outside, in the freezing cold, rain, and sleet if need be... but it will be worth it. We also love their artichokes (to share as you wait for your oysters to come out). They've got a great selection of quality seafood. It won't be cheap, but you won't regret it. Their staff is always lovely.
author: Rachel A.

description: Came in for clam chowder and ended up getting the ciopinno which is NOT on the menu. My gf and I share meals and a half order was sufficient for both of us plus a cup of chowder to share. Great place, great food, nice area.
author: Mike H.

description: We did a search of "best seafood restaurants" on our first night in San Francisco and liked the sound of Anchor Oyster Bar. We called and was told that at that moment the wait for a table of four would be about 40 minutes, so we headed over to get on the list. We put our name on the board and headed across the street to buy some wine to bring with us for our meal (a great little wine store, btw). We ended up waiting 1.5 hours and then only managed to sit in 4 seats at the bar, my seat on the end and arguably  the worst seat in the place. But none of this mattered because this place is magic. Our servers made great suggestions and we ordered exactly as they suggested and ate family style; the Anchor Special starter (oysters, prawns and the best steamed clams I've ever had), the Caesar salad with crab, and their incredible  Cioppono. Everything about our meal was perfect; the service, the amazing tiny room and the incredible food! I will never come to San Francisco again without trying to come back to this wonderful place.
author: Don F.

description: We ordered 3 items on menu. Cioppino, Clam chowder, and Wild Prawns from Mexico. The cioppino was very salty and not tasty. The garlic breads comes with cioppino was even more saltier. Clam chowder was not bad but not good either. We waited more than 30 minutes and I could have gone somewhere else. I was very disappointed and definitely won't be back.
author: Yoonji K.

description:
The fish stew, not quite Cioppino without the crab, is amazingly, deliciously phenomenal.  Beware of the orgasmic response after you dip the garlic bread in the sauce and touch it to your tongue.  It will be hard to make another selection next time I go there.  

The wine list is small but decent, and they have a nice variety of beers. 

The dining room is small, but the ambiance is warm and cozy.  I loved hearing the soft voice of Ella Fitzgerald while we ate. 

Definitely going back.
author: Kurt L.

description:
Place was good, and moderately priced considering the seafood menu and the location.

I wouldn't think that 5.95 for garlic bread is a smart buy, but it was probably one of the more outstanding dishes that we had that night. Whatever kind of cheese was on it was very creamy, and very tasty.

Oyster shooters for 2.50 were also a nice find. Crab cakes weren't exceptional, but the clam chowder was quite pleasent.

Seating is very limited, we arrived around 9 pm and still had about a 20-25 minute wait, which went by fast as the area has a lot of life in it.
author: Denny P.

description:
Came here several months ago and the only thing we remember was the poor service. When they seated us and gave us our menu, nobody came to take our orders. We had to flag down a staff member to tell them we were ready, at which point our waiter actually came by. After our meal, they never brought us our check. I went up to the bar counter to ask for it and I saw our waiter in the back roll his eyes. The food itself was average but our experience was tainted by the lack of service.

My tummy gives Anchor Oyster Bar...2 Stars!
author: Allan L.

description:
The best garlic bread in San Francisco, and a bigger, better seafood menu than Swan's Oyster Depot, love this place.  This is a special place to me, kind of a neighborhood Taddich Grill or Sam's Grill, both 100 plus year old downtown legends.  It's small, intimate I guess without any implied romance or hanky panky.  I tell friends Anchor is who would cater my last meal before the executioner had his way with me.  Several very close friends, thank you Jamison, Jimmy and Matt, took me here for a birthday dinner that still ranks among my favorites dinners.  I can enjoy a perfect lunch here with a bowl of their yummy to my tummy clam chowder, a shrimp, crab and/or prawn salad and some of their GREAT garlic bread.  They also prepare several versions of a variety of truly fresh fish fresh from the sea.

It's a rainy day counter and half a dozen or so tables and it is crowded and waiting diner's can stare at you through the plate glass window to guilt you into not savoring a 6th cup of coffee.  Actually people who dally too long at a super crowded restaurant should face a meal with Osama and the recently deposed maniac leader of Libya with dirty weapons and a price on the too long at the party bastards heads.  I've had some really good crab cakes, grilled salmon, fish fried platters, oysters and just about everything else that lives in water.  The staff appear to either own or live at The Anchor because they're not young, scrubbed writer's or actors waiting for their big break.  I really love this place and hope you do too, especially if you don't get to the Castro often.
author: Stu S.

description: There's a reason why there's always a wait and they don't take reservations. I loove their cioppino.  Order whatever you want here but just be sure a cioppino is on your table.  Expect to wait 45+ min during their peak hours. Well worth it if you have the time.
author: Samson F.

description: Best cioppino I've ever had.  Very generous portions of seafood, its a hearty cioppino.  Lots of Mussels, clams, crabmeat, fish and shrimp. The garlic bread that comes with it is delicious, order extra! I took the order to-go and they packed it in a carton to-go box, and wrapped that up in saran wrap extra tight so that nothing spilled out to potentially make a mess.  The servers I encountered over the phone and when I picked up the order were super friendly.  It is $29.95 for cioppino for 1 and $49.95.  Such a deal for all that seafood!
author: Kay N.

description:
The Anchor Oyster Bar has been doin' it for "30 Shucking Years" (and my new snazzy t-shirt likes to tell you so!).

My bf's parents saw this restaurant on "Check Please" and wanted to give it a try. The wait was about 30 minutes but we checked out the wine store across the street and chatted while we waited. 

The super-nice waiters were very apologetic about the wait but the wait was worth it. The menu was short and the white board showed five specials, two of which were sold out when we got in at 8 PM. The food we had was 4-stars. The clam chowder was very flavorful and not too creamy. The salads were good but not amazing. The two fish specials we ordered were very good and the crab cake meal was yummy too. Even the table bread and table oyster crackers were yummy!

Best of all though, the service was amazing (5 stars for sure!), the house red wine was very drinkable, and the restaurant was nautical and cute.

Until I dine here again, I will be sporting my shucking shirt!
author: Meghan P.

description: I love this place! Been here several times and I'm never disappointed by this place. Long wait every time, but food is well worth the wait. Also, the staff is very friendly; makes it feel homey. The oysters are always fresh. Specials of the evening are always yummy.
author: steven h.

description:
Clam chowder was creamy and full of clams. Hit the spot on a cold day in San Fran! This tiny spot is one of my favorites located on the Castro District. I usually get the oysters on the half shell, shrimp, and sautéed clam platter. We tried an assortment of the fresh oysters... they were good... not great as it could be (how does a place make half shell oysters better than another? ) the kushhi oysters did not have much flavor (but i'm sure that is batch to batch) I have been here before and those oysters were great! 
  the shrimp was very meaty and had a nice horseradish/ cocktail sauce with it. The clam were the best dish  sauteed in butter and garlic.....really what can you not make  taste good with that?  I should have tried the Cioppino, and maybe the fresh cod or the stew??. I only seem to come here for a snack.....  it feels like a lunch/raw bar place to me. I must come back for an entree for sure !
author: Shane S.

description: Hands down the best seafood I have ever had. Super busy and small, but the service was great.  You will end up having to wait at the very least an hour,  no reservations. But just put your name on the board and go have a drink while you wait.  It will be totally worth it.....
author: Amy R.

description: My daughter was home from college and wanted some "bayarea" home food. She wanted crab and sour dough bread. We waited a few minutes and were seated.  The service was excellent and so was the food. She had the cioppino and I had the prawns.  Oh how I enjoyed those succulent prawns.  My daughter is looking forward to going back.  We certainly will.
author: sumaya g.

description: Initially, I was looking for a Vietnamese restaurant in Castro since it's near my work.  Well, it was a good thing the restaurant on the corner was still closed and saw the Anchor Oyster Bar.  I ordered the small Cioppino and I thought it was huge for me, but was able to eat it all.  The Cioppino was exceptional.  I highly recommend this place and if you love Cioppino, it's a must try.  Customer service is great!  I went in during lunch and was able to find a seat with limited seating since the place is very tiny.
author: Alicia S.

description: We had one of the specials of the day - a crab sandwich, salad, and cup of their world famous clam chowder. The prices were reasonable given the trendy-ish neighborhood, freshness of the seafood, and service. Everybody in the restaurant was so darn friendly - from the staff to the owner/manager, to the other customers.
author: John Z.

description: The food here is amazing!!!  Great Steel Head Salmon and grilled vegetables!!!  Straight forward small with not a lot of seating, but worth the wait.
author: J B.

description: Anchor Oyster Bar is fantastic and totally deserves the highest possible review. The freshest seafood is expertly prepared in the traditional way. If you want trendy, look elsewhere. Yes prices may appear a bit high, but if one understands the high costs of the best seafood no further explanation is required. As expected, the oysters were delightful. The cioppino seafood stew, piled high with fish, crab, mussels and prawns, was an inspiration. The best of the best on a compact menu, all five stars.
author: Jim T.

description: Anchor Oyster Bar is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  Their oysters are fresh and absolutely fabulous.  I've never had a bad meal here, but I always eat the same thing -- their Cioppino!  This is the cioppino that sets the bar for me for every other cioppino that I've tried and will try.  Friends have had other dishes here too and they are also equally delicious.  The place is pretty small though so be prepared to wait, but trust me, it's worth the wait!
author: Super F.

description: Really amazing crab and chowder! Wine selection wasn't quite my thing, but the food was amazing!
author: Alexander H.

description: Love this place!!!!! Clam chowder is so good  and they have the best sea food in SF! The atmosphere is adorable! A little hole in the wall ish (super tiny) but also very clean and beautiful! I love this restaurant!!!
author: Charlotte S.

description: Short and simple.   The Anchor served me the BEST muscles I have ever eaten.  I've had muscles countless times in cities around the world. These were tops! The rest of my party were equally pleased with their choices.  The staff was great, and even brought a couple of appetizers outside to share with the folks who were waiting for a table.   The wait was long, but names are on the chalk board so you can gauge your progress. I am not a big fan of waiting for more than an hour for a table, but I would do it again in a heartbeat.  (PS-right across the street is a wine shop that is licensed to serve in-store.  We went there after we put our names on the Anchor wait list, and shared a bottle of wine to fill the time.  This was a great strategy  to pass the time.)
author: Tom E.

description: I had the red snapper lunch special and it was very fresh and tasty. The clam chowder was delicious as well. Small place but the service was phenomenal. My friend and I shared all our food and they even offered to split the clam chowder soup for us.
author: Tita T.

description: This place has the best seafood dishes I've ever tasted!! We went on a Thursday night after 8, so we didnt have to wait that long. Ordered clam chowder, half anchor oyster special, and shared a cioppino. The clam chowder was pretty good. But I'm not a fan of clam chowder so I can't really judge. The oysters though, they were delicious. They were so juicy and just melted in your mouth. The shrimps were super fat!! The clams came in a sweet and sour broth, the broth was seriously the best. Just dip your bread in it and eat it. The best part was the cioppino!! It had crab meat, clams, oysters, shrimp, and fish. Came with two garlic bread on the side. The tomato broth surprisingly melts all the flavors in your mouth! Seriously the best meal I ever had.
author: Winne L.

description: The cioppino is not on the menu, but is amazing.  Extremely cheap considering it could be shared easily by two maybe even three people.  We go out of our way to eat here every time we're in town.  Possibly my favorite seafood restaurant of all time.  Im a bit of a chowder head too and they have one of my favorite clam chowders also.  If your considering eating here, don't pass it up.
author: Ross D.

description: Came here on a Saturday night by mistake and waited two hours outside in the cold. It's crazy how hot and cold the city gets all in one day. Anyways while I was freezing my a$$ off in the cold one of the servers appeared outside with a plate of clam chowder samples. Omg the clam chowder was soo good! It wasn't too creamy or too salty it was just perfect! When we finally got seated we ordered raw oysters, garlic bread, crab cakes, and cioppino. The garlic bread was just alright. It was good at first but then as I had more I felt it was a bit too salty for me. Their crab cake and cioppino however are one of the bests I ever had. All of the ingredients in the cioppino were super fresh and tasty. The only thing I didn't like was that when I had to use the bathroom I had to pass by their entire kitchen I felt very awkward. Overall I love their food quality and taste I will definitely be coming back for more :)
author: J K.

description:
Since they don't take reservations, I was a bit worried about getting a table but 9pm on a Tuesday night was perfect timing to grab a table for 5.

Staff was delightful and even offered eye glasses to someone at our table who couldn't read the menu.

The food was amazing. For starters we had a sampling of oysters, an artichoke & dungeness crab salad, and a plate of bread kept on coming out of the kitchen.

Meals that were ordered were clam chowder, mussel stew, trout, and the pasta dinner.

I got a dinner salad with shrimp that was simply okay but I have to kick myself for getting that because the trout (and everything else) was far superior.

Definitely heading back to Anchor Oyster Bar next time I'm in town.
author: Pearl C.

description: Good food, so slowwwwww everything is so slowwwwww waited until I was not hungry anymore
author: Sydney L.

description: Came here last night with three friends. We had incredible oysters and garlic bread to start, and then I had pasta with lemon, garlic, arugala, and italian sausage and clams. It was over-the-top delicious; a wonderful example of simple, fresh ingredients combined to make a fantastic dish. The portion was so huge that even I, a burrito-for-lunch-plus dessert kind of lady, couldn't eat all of it. A truly wonderful meal! The ambiance is very charming (don't bring a party of more than 4!) and appropiate for the food. If you'd like to sit down and enjoy a wonderful seafood dinner in unprententious yet comfortable surroundings, this is the spot for you!
author: Eliza L.

description:
When traveling- I follow yelp (well, at home I follow yelp as well). Yelp did not steer me wrong. There are so many choices in SF- so it was a daunting task.

First of all- the place is small. You need to write your name on a white board as soon as you arrive. I promise- if there isn't a line- a line will happen while you are waiting. 

A local started chatting with us- so our 45 minute wait or so didn't seem too bad. She even asked us how we found this gem. Awww- yelp.

EVERYTHING THEY SAY IS TRUE. We got the half order of this delicious assortment of all things seafood- shrimp, oysters, clams. It was delightful! 

We ordered the garlic bread. This is especially amazing dipped in the clam sauce.

We also shared a full order of the house pasta special. OMG OMG OMG. amazing. Best seafood pasta that I have ever had.

The pasta itself was incredible- not just the seafood. So impressive! The service was also a delight. The server did not guide us wrong and insisted that we order pasta because the particular chef that day makes the best pasta. So true!

Do yourself a favor- eat here.
author: Katherine C.

description: I love this place. Best Cioppino you will ever have in your life!!! Get there early to put your name on the wait list!!!'
author: Jeff C.

description:
Heard about this place through a friend and decided to try it out yesterday after Fleet Week air show with my boyfriend. This place is really small with just about 5 tables and a bar seating area. We got there at 615 on a Saturday and waited no more than 20 minutes, which isn't bad. 

We ordered the steamed shellfish combo and a bowl of clam chowder. The chowder is really good, it isn't thick like chowder from other places and it's sweet with load of clam taste. For $6.50, it's a bit on the pricy side, but I think it's worth every penny of it. The steam shellfish is super bomb!! I'm not a mussels kinda girl, but I loved the mussels here. All the clams and mussels soaked up the soup they were cooked in so it marinated them and is very sweet and tasty. You can truly taste the freshness of the seafood. I will most definitely order the combo again! 

The service here is good, but we were waiting to have our order taken for at least 10 minutes. They only have 1 guy who takes orders.. Other than that, the ambulance is great. You see the open kitchen where food is being cooked, and i loved cute boats decoration around the restaurant. They're restroom is a bit awkward to get to--you need to walk through the kitchen...

I'll be back to dine again. Just wish parking isn't so hard.
author: Jenny G.

description:
clam chowder is tasty but missing some clams... on the thin side

ceasar salad was ok

anchor special - shrimp, raw oysters, and steamed clams
shrimp was nice and firm
oysters- YUMMY fresh
clams should be skipped, I didn't care for it at all

garlic cheese bread, I didn't like
author: X B.

description:
Nice place to go too. I would really recommend it to anybody.

The food is something to behold for yourself. Freshness is the key.
author: Jacen W.

description:
Holy crap!  The seafood is bomb.com here.  Everything was SUPER delicious.  

Garlic roasted crab was full of garlic and butter flavor.  The crab was full of meat.  Something about that sauce just completely put this dish on another level.

Their calamari penne pasta was super yummy.  It had a little kick to the marinara but that only enhanced the flavors of the calamari and pasta.

The cioppino was nice and full of CHUNKS of delicious, fresh seafood.  Nice and tangy.

Definitely gotta add this to your "To Eat List".  I guarantee that you won't be disappointed.  It's kind of pricey but the portions are huge and enough for 2-3 people to share.  And shout out to their waitstaff.  Real helpful and on top of their game.
author: Chai S.

description:
This place is seafood lovers' heaven!
Their oysters are so fresh. It is sweet! Only super fresh seafoods have a taste of sweetness.

I am a poor college student, so this place is expensive for me. But I guess seafoods are just expensive in general.

I will definitely go back to this place again for some crab sandwich/burger.

P.S do go early and in small groups.
author: Amy Y.

description:
We came here for clam chowder, and it was great (as were the crab cakes and garlic bread)!  

Everyone was nice and helpful; and the atmosphere is cozy so the whole outing was perfect for a cloudy summer evening!
author: Rosanna R.

description:
DEFINITELY GET THE CLAMS with the ANCHO SPECIAL!

Delightful meal really - but not what I was expecting exactly. 
We ordered the ancho special with 12 mixed oysters, 4 shrimp, and the clams in some garlic broth. The oysters were fresh, but filled with sand - like they weren't cleaned very well. I understand I'm here to eat RAW oysters...but I can't slurp like usual when I see the sand around my oyster :(. The clams, on the other hand, were my absolute favorite! I seriously dipped some starter bread in the sauce b/c it was THAT good. We also got some clam chowder which were filling but nothing spectacular. 

This is a definite TRY if you're around the Castro area craving seafood with a $30 budget per person in a small group of 4 or less. 

TIP: try the oyster shooter cocktail. It was a pleasant surprise!
author: Tory L.

description: Best food ever. Caesar salad is amazing....seafood is fresh and delicious. Small place, doesn't look amazing from outside but don't let that fool you. Great service, food comes out quickly. Prices are average for seafood, worth every penny. Clam chowder is in the top 5 list of chowders I have ever had.
author: Jaime F.

description:
Dear all Oyster lovers:

DELICIOUS!  Oysters were so good that I came back the next week.

Service was unbelievable.  Seated immediately, checked on regularly, and pleasant staff.  The staff really puts their hearts into this establishment and it is easy to tell.

The price is very reasonable for the qulity.  Bust out your wallet and let loose - you won't regret it.

Go now.
author: Steven P.

description:
The place is tiny, so prepare for a wait or visit at off hours.  However, if you can snag a seat, you're in for a treat!

We three ended up at the bar, and between the service and the food, I've rarely enjoyed a culinary experience so much.  Soju oyster shooters gave us a start - a tasty twist on the vodka norm.  We then split the Anchor Standard - oysters from all over, and shrimp and clams in a broth that had us fighting over the bowl.  There was clam chowder, and crab cakes with a seriously impressive crab to breading ratio, as well as an artichoke that almost looked too pretty to eat.  Almost.  I glance at the cioppino served down the bar made me wish that I had that hollow leg I was accused of possessing as a child.

The service was wonderful - our waiter was friendly, patient, and made some excellent suggestions.  It's possible we changed our order three times, and he not only put up with us, but ensured we were well cared for throughout our meal.  A regular on the barstool next to me swore that it was always this much tasty fun at Anchor - I'm converted!

I'm already inventing reasons to drive into the city and visit this place again...  as long as there's no one who doesn't love the sea in my party - non-seafood options are lacking here, so don't plan on ordering the chicken.
author: Alexis J.

description: Waited 2 hours. Poor management of waiting list. I understand the place is small, but when our table finally came up the host told us that a party that was already seated wanted to move to a nice table OUR table so we would have to wait longer. WHAT!!! unbelievable. By the way the clam chowder is disgusting. I would not recommend this restaurant to my worst enemy. Do yourself a favor and go somewhere else.
author: Beverly L.

description:
We arrived at the restaurant at 8:15pm on a Thu night. 30 minutes later, we were feeling pretty lucky, because we were already the next one on the whiteboard. Then, out of nowhere, 3 catty women walked up and put their name down for 6pm. When the owner came out to call us in, he recognized the women as regulars and instead seated them first. We had to wait another 30 minutes before a table finally opened up. That is not the way to run an honest business. 

Otherwise, the garlic bread and cioppino were quite excellent. But not good enough for us to get over our bad initial feeling of being screwed over
author: Ken C.

description:
Awesome place. I had no idea I had a seafood restaurant so close to where I live. It's a definite must in the Castro.

I had their Garlic Roasted Crab, I really liked it! The Rosemary was a good kick.

I can't really compare it to PPQ since it's more American, but it's pretty damn good.
author: Eric A.

description: Delicious food. Went for lunch and got the open faced seafood sandwich. However, the 3 stars is due to the poor service. We sat at the bar and had to wave down our server down constantly to: order, get water, and pay. Even then, it took a long time - what would have been an hour long meal was 2.
author: Joe S.

description:
O.M.G!!!!!!!!!!

IN CRE DIB LE!!!

5 STARS Very much deserved.

We waited one hour for a table and it was well worth every minute!!!

Green salad, bowl of clam chowder and a full order of the Ciopinno!!!

THE BEST EVER!!
author: Lupe. M.

description:
I came here for date night on a Tuesday night and Anchor was fantastic. If you love seafood then you have to make your way here. The restaurant is a little cozy and seats less than approximately 30 but that's all part of that warm family feel you get when you dine here. The seating area is split between tables and a bar area where you can belly up and talk to the servers during your meal. 

We started with a couple oysters on the half shell for appetizers. Then we ordered the Welsh Fish Stew (not always on the menu) and the Cioppino (a staple at Anchor). The Welsh Fish Stew is cream-based and the Cioppino is tomato-based but besides that they're pretty similar. I'd say the Cioppino is hands down the better of the two and I'd recommend that to anyone that's trying Anchor for the first time. It's got cod, muscles, clams, dungenous crab and a couple pieces of grilled bread. It's amazing and very filling. Apparently there's a regular and a large size. I got the regular size and barely finished it. I had a lot of the broth left so I asked to have it to go. I'd imagine a lot of cooks out there could make use of that broth in a different dish but I'm not as saavy so I'll finish it off with some delicious bread. 

I thought our meal was reasonable priced at approximately $30/entree given the quantity and quality of the dinner. You'll find plenty of street parking a block or two south of the restaurant. I guarantee if you like seafood, in a casual setting, that you will love this place.
author: Ken C.

description:
I am not a raw oyster fan, but since my friend was craving oysters, I was down to go.  Its a seafood place so I was sure there would be something other than oysters for me...

When we first came in, I was a little sad because it was such a small restaurant.  We also sat right next to the door so I had a gust of cold wind everytime the door was open... 

My friend ordered the oyster combination and she said it was awesome and it tasted great.

We also ordered the crab cakes and it was made to perfection!  It had just the right amount of flavor and crispy to it.

CAN I SAY OMG???????? Screw little italy!!  
I JUST HAD THE BEST PASTA IN MY LIFE!!!  

It's not on the menu so I'm not even sure the name of the plate, but it was the special of the day.  There were clams, shrimp, and other seafood items over penne pasta and an orange-y sauce that tasted heavenly.  I asked for it to be spicey and that took it over the top!!!  

This is my new spot in SF, Everytime I get into the city, I will def come here.
author: Tyffani N.

description:
This place has the best cioppino ever!  I love SF and use to come up often to eat at the Crab House, until they were sold.  They've never been the same so we would go up to Seattle for great seafood instead.  

Recently, we were in SF for a meeting, so I Yelped around and came on this place.  Wow!  Its such a cool little place where the diners have been eating here for decades.  I chatted with people outside waiting for our table and with folks sitting next to me at the bar.  Clearly - they all said we have to try the cioppino. So, we ordered a dozen oysters, half of the garlic roasted crab, and, of course, the cioppino.  Well, the oysters were superb.  Fresh, crisp, briny, sweet, paired with a wonderful chardonnay.  The roast crab was amazing.  It was not smothered in olive oil and was perfectly roasted with just a enough garlic for garlic lovers.  The shells were well cracked making the sweet morsels of flesh easy to get to.  Finally, the cioppino was a masterpiece.  It was perfectly proportioned with clams, mussels, crab legs, and halibut; then topped with a garlic bread so good, it would have made a perfect meal by itself.  You won't be able to quit the sauce - you will want to ask for more bread to soak up every drop.  

We sat at the bar where you can make eye contact with your chefs, who were two lovely ladies passionately working to keep up with all the orders.  They were cheerful and clearly loved their work, occasionally, looking up to see that we were enjoying the fruit of their labor.  The service was great as we felt very well attended to.  In all, we love this place and can't wait to go back.
author: Johnny R.

description: Never open when I pass by. No RSVP.  Will change my review once I get to try the place.
author: Leilani I.

description:
Awesome oysters, shrimp cocktail and clam chowder.  This place is definitely on the expensive side (or maybe I just can't stop eating oysters).  My favorite places to eat on Castro Street when money isn't an object.  

I originally gave them only 4 stars because of price, but I have to change it and give them five because they are quality and quality is worth paying for.  Their menu is so logical and so perfect without any silly items on it (Gordon Ramsay would approve).  The interior of the restaurant is small but clean and neat.  I would say the interior is very simple but somehow very sophisticated at the same time.  No crap inside, which I like.  I like the front window too.  Whenever I walk by it ALWAYS appeals.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
the selection of oysters today were mostly all briny oysters...which were OK for me. i prefer creamy, smaller oysters.  they were fresh no doubt, but they didn't have the oysters I normally would die for.  

anchor oyster bar is VERY tiny.  so tiny in fact it will be guaranteed to be busy at any time of the day.  So do yourself a favor, before you walk in, write your name on the white board!!!  I don't know how we managed to walk by it without noticing....oh well, it happens.  i tried the sampler (half order) which included steamers, shrimp & oysters.  i did myself a huge favor by ordering the clam chowder.  SO DELICIOUS. this is the chowder I am used to.....rich, thick, creamy, filled with clams and potatoes with every bite size scoop... all they were missing was the bread bowl.  it was nearly perfect and traditional in every sense. 

i was not hungry walking in...hence the appetizer samplings.  all their entrees looked really good and looking forward to the next opportunity to stop by again.

great location ... go grab yourself some cookies at HOT MAMA afterwards for a sweet treat!
author: Brittany H.

description: Wonderful dinner. Had half a dozen of oysters,3 different kinds and all great. Afterwords we had the clam chouder and that was very hardy and nice however I only found  2 clams...! Then the crab cakes, that were good but our main was just excellent. Salmon with an almond crumble and veggies (on the specials)! We also had a bottle of Chardonnay from napa that was good but rather pricy.
author: Vicky S.

description: The wait at Anchor Oyster Bar can be upwards of 1 1/2 hours, and you do need to sta within earshot (sorry, no buzzers here), but they do pass shots of clam chowder out while you wait. Once inside the kitchen is bustling, the servers are efficient, and best of all, the seafood is fresh. It's a bare bones kind of presentation so don't expect anything fancy, but you will be delighted all the same.
author: Marie F.

description: This place is tiny and expect to wait unless you come right before closing time.  Since there were only two of us, we managed to get a seat at the bar fairly quickly.  We ordered the clam chowder, their tomato heirloom salad and the scalllops special.  The scallops were very bland and a steep price of $26.  The clam chowder was good but the $7 bowl was more of a cup.  The weirdest part was when one of the waiters asked us to move over one seat mid meal which we did but I am not sure why since no one ever came to sit down next to us considering it was closing time.  The other older gentlemen who was helping us was a sweetheart.
author: Monica G.

description: I love this little place. Fresh ingredients, great flavors and good service. The New Zealand sea bass was amazing, perfectly cooked.
author: Keith S.

description: Worst service ever, not worth the hype. You wait hours ,at least 2 hours wait on friday. First, it was 1 hour wait then another 40, then another 20 and still waiting. Really terrible experienced 1030 pm and still not served. The worst service i had on my life. After all, they offer the bar area, not even a table. Terrible terrible. Dont bother go there.
author: Inaki G.

description: I like Anchor a lot, but...Don't place bread and butter on my table and then not tell me that it will be added to my bill.  It's really a very dishonest way of up charging unsuspecting customers.  Why not just ask your customers if they want bread and let them know what the price will be?  Better yet how about no charge for bread or less bread if it's that big a stretch for your bottom line.  Other than that the food is pretty good.  The clam chowder is very overrated.  NO CLAMS.
author: Larry d.

description:
Went here since I saw the amazing reviews and was not impressed. Had a bowl of there $7 clam chowder and I was expecting to actually find a clam in there. 

Next had the half order of the anchor special and the oysters were okay, the clams had a grainy texture to them which I didn't care for. 

The only thing that saved it was the 2 jumbo prawns which were top notch. 

Service was good and friendly just a tad bit slow. Would not go back especially for the price.
author: Mike T.

description:
After waiting 30 minutes at the Ferry Building at 3pm and my parking meter running out, I decided to ditch the line for oysters there and come to Anchor Oyster bar instead.  I am so glad I did.  Got a 1/2 dozen oysters on the half shell, clam chowder, champagne, and garlic bread.  The garlic bread was late coming out of the oven and they burnt it, so they offered to comp it for free.  Then it was late again and they comped me a second glass of champagne.  Fantastic food, fantastic customer service.

The place is very small and I loved the vibe.  If you sit toward the back of the restaurant, you can watch them cook.  It's a small place so I imagine if you go during peak hours there's going to be a wait.  If you go around 2 or 3, you'll probably be able to be seated immediately.
author: Codarus C.

description:
Went early on a Wed evening, got a seat at the bar. Waitress was attentive but not invasive. Here's the breakdown:

Oysters: 2 Hog Island French Kiss and 2 Mass Quivits
Garlic Bread: Shared with neighbors since it was a hefty portion
Clam chowder: Delicious, creamy, lingering savoriness
Crab cakes: A bit too much filler, not enough crab, but I still enjoyed them

Overall, I a great meal with reasonable prices. I want to go again tomorrow!
author: Shannon B.

description:
Went there last night b/c I've been reading about this place on yelp for quite some time..

3 Stars...

For a Place w/ "oyster" in their name, I was expecting a FULL menu of Oysters, like the mother of them all Oysters...  negative..

I asked for a Menu, there was 3 kinds... only 3 Kinds of Oysters! 

Ordered the Full seafood platter, comes w/ one dozen oysters, 4 shrimps 
and a Clam Dish. about $30, worth it.. 

$9 for a Glass of White Wine!! woah there... 

another $24 for a Crab Cake Dish..

total bill before tip was $80.90... wowers... =O

The place was really cute and warm! Cute and Cozy Kitchen

I'm still on a mission to find my best oysters deal in SF..
Cheers..
author: Emily L.

description: Cioppino is amazing. Rich broth, incredible seafood. Service is so warm and friendly. Don't miss this gem.
author: Cat M.

description: One of the top seafood restaurants in SF if you really like seafood.  It gets busy however, especially on the weekends but if you go Monday thru Wednesday the line doesn't seem as long.  Also, their restaurant looks and smells clean.  Their cute little bathroom is clean too, which is important to me.
author: Claire D.

description:
When it comes to seafood in San Francisco, this is a must go place. It beats nearly every seafood place I have eaten at both in FL and CA. There is a moderate wait but definitely worth it! 

The appetizer was amazing--artichokes with seafood and Italian bread crumbs with a cream sauce on the side. The main course was amazing. The menu had some regular items, but also some items that are daily specials or that are specials not written anywhere.

The quality of the food and presentation are outstanding. The service was very prompt and the staff was amazing.. If you are looking for a gem in the heart of the Castro district, look no further. This is a place that you will not leave disappointed.

If you have a certain wine you like? Just bring it and they will pour it for you. You can hit Castro Village Wine Company or Swirl and get your favorite wines to bring with you that are near by.
author: Pierce B.

description: My favorite seafood restaurant in the city. The space is intimate but vibrant and the food is delicious. The staff are all very friendly and Taylor is a fantastic chef.
author: Jon R.

description: Get the Cioppini!!! Omg its to die for. We waited for two hours and I was about to leave to go to another place but it was SO with the wait.
author: Jimmy W.

description:
Somebody missed the boat on this one, and I mean missed the boat.

They call this place an oyster bar?  There were three oysters on the menu (late October 2010).  Whole foods carries a better selection.  I ordered the Anchor Special; of the 12 oysters shucked one had slipped off its shell and hung like a salvador dali clock.  The "chilled prawns" were no better and no worse than peeled and boiled frozen jumbo shrimp from the supermarket.  The clams were, I am still shocked to write, cooked with chicken broth.

I see a lot of good reviews of their clam chowder.  This too is cooked with chicken broth.  You think they made that broth with whole chickens?  I think not.  Who puts canned chicken broth in clam chowder?  Automatically disqualified.  I thought this was a seafood restaurant?

All was not lost.  They serve beer and wine, thankfully.  But not Anchor Steam, neither in draft nor in bottle.  Yes, I was disappointed, though the draft Trumer was a consolation.

Attention to detail or lack thereof reveals boatloads.  And after all was said and done, $67 before tip.  12 oysters, 4 prawns, 12 clams, a cup of soup, a glass of wine, 2 Trumers and some bread for 67 dollars.  Not a good value.

Disembark.  Disembark.

EDIT: Run, don't walk, which is what I did the morning after.
author: Careless W.

description:
Originally, the plan was to go to Ike's Place, but plans fell through because our ETA to SF was past closing time at Ike's.

This ended up being our back up plan after searching through yelp in the car. We got to Anchor at 8pm and promptly placed our names on the waiting list. Sat around. Sat around. Waited.

....Waited.

And then a server comes out and counts how many of us were outside. I was thinking this was a bad sign. Was he counting to figure out when to stop letting people sign up? Was he counting because he was overwhelmed by the number of people outside and the lack of seats inside? And then a minute later, he walked out with 8 bowls of clam chowder. Not just that! He sprinkled ground pepper into each bowl & accompanied each bowl with sufficient oyster crackers. First of all, I LOVED the clam chowder. It wasn't too thick like chowder usually is. And it was perfect for the cold, rainy weather outside. And second of all, how freakin' sweet of them to send us clam chowder.

Okay, so I might have exaggerated out waiting time. But we did wait about 40 minutes before we decided to walk to the local bar and have a quick drink. We stayed about 15 minutes at the bar and went back only to find our names were skipped. Talk about bad luck. The nice thing about Anchor is that they don't just erase your name if you're not there. We were still kept on the waiting list, and we were still able to get our table after a little more waiting.

Yes, the wait is long, but it's SO worth it! It's a small place with limited seating and they really don't try to rush you. It's just that kind of atmosphere where you can have a nice meal and not feel like they're trying to get rid of you quickly.

The garlic bread was indeed amazing. I ate like 6 pieces from the basket! It cost $5 for a fairly big basket of garlic bread, sufficient to share amongst 4 or 5 people.

The sea bass with aioli was really a delight. The sea bass was moist & seasoned lightly with pepper and salt (I'm not sure if anything else was on it). The aioli complimented the fish well, being light with a little bit of a tang. My friends got a dish with various shell fish. They loved the mussels. While I'm not a shell fish eater myself, I tried the butter, white wine, herbed broth that the shell fish came in and it was absolutely delicious. I kept dipping my bread in the sauce to get the flavor.

The food was well worth the wait. And the service is very friendly. I would love to come back sometime when I'm in the area!
author: Emily T.

description:
How funny that my latest find has been here for decades.  Anchor Oyster Bar thoroughly reminds me of my life, long ago, as an artist working in costal New England restaurants to help pay the rent.  This place is an authentic seaside raw bar!  So authentic that it feels a little out of place in the Castro.  Then again, it was here before the nabe was even called the Castro.

For me, it's all about the oysters.  Good selection, slightly expensive, but really served right.  Some crusty bread, a selection of wines and beers oriented to work with oysters, and a really nice setup that lets you decide how much horseradish to mix into your cocktail sauce.  Most of all, the oysters are fresh, fresh, fresh.  And the staff is really nice too.  So whether you're in the neighborhood and ready for something different, or an East Coaster looking for a fix, Anchor is here to hook you up.
author: Ted R.

description: This place is a classic.  I love everything about it - the food, the service, the atmosphere.  Sometimes you have to wait but usually it's not bad.  I tend to get whatever the fish special is and have never gone wrong.  The cioppino is a special treat when crab is in season [and, BTW, contrary to popular belief, cioppino originated in Croatia, not Italy].
author: Douglas E.

description: Amazing fresh and vibrant dishes that melt on the palate. The staff is friendly and the atmosphere is intimate.
author: Anthony P.

description:
Will remember this place forever for two reasons:

- it's where I finally confirmed that it's not true that I don't like oysters, I'm just very picky and I like only the East Coast ones...
- it's where I scarfed almost an entire load of bread soaking up the delicious broth from the clams we had....

No wonder it's been there 20 years: so cozy and delicious.
author: Dario B.

description:
Small restaurants like Anchor tend to have the vibe of being inviting yet exclusive simultaneously.  Once you get that coveted table, expectations are sky high.

The food here is pretty good.   But does it justify the intimacy and social cost of eating here?  Maybe.

Clam chowder is proper.  It tastes like a real Boston clam chowder, if a bit light on the clams.  Potatoes are al dente, a nice touch.

The fruits de mer platter with oysters, shrimp and clams is satisfying.  The oysters are all from the east coast, an oddity in San Francisco, but quite nice.  The clams taste heavily of raw garlic.  The chilled shrimp are slightly overcooked.

Bay scallops are breaded and baked, which leaves them cooked evenly and lightly, a nice touch.  There's a huge pile of mashed potatoes that taste mostly of salt, but lacking creaminess.  Steamed vegetables are a bit sloppy:  undercooked carrots, red peppers with the skin and bitter membrane left on.  Asparagus at varying levels of doneness from al dente to limp.  I love the house-made tartar sauce; it's like a lighter sauce gribiche.

Mexican halibut is an oddity.  Why?  Surely there are fresher, more local fish to try.  It's cooked with herbs such as fresh thyme, but the salt is sorely lacking and the cut leaves the edges bone dry with a juicy middle comprising about 50% of the total dish.

Anchor is a breath of fresh air in the Castro with really fresh seafood, and a homey exclusivity that defies the come-one, come-all mentality of the rest of the street,  But at its price point, it needs more precision to justify itself.  Nevertheless I appreciate what they are trying to accomplish.
author: J W.

description:
We came here on our last night in San Francisco just under a year ago... 

We still talk about our meal. 

We had the clam chowder -which was comped b/c we agreed to switch seats for a larger party... SWEET! i LOVE free stuff... and the clam chowder itself was pretty delicious :) creamy and clammy and not too thick or thin

The main that my friend had was some platter ... with a 1/2 dozen raw oysters and some other seafood fixings... I ordered a seafood pasta which was the special of the evening

which brings me to why we still talk about our meal...
The seafood pasta was DELICIOUS. scallops were juicy and seared and translucent, shrimps were not rubbery even though they were big and meaty, broccoli rabe for veg and a spicy tomato sauce...

No joke, my friend (who i graciously let finish my plate) had watery eyes when he finished my plate. we were both actually SAD it was finished (when we left we realized we should've asked for a plate to go)

service was great too. :)
author: Carm Y.

description:
Great atmosphere, excellent food and reasonable prices. A fun intimate vibe. Great choices of wine and champagne to pair with the interesting and flavourful specials...makes for a great evening before heading out for a night on the town.

It has become o staple at every visit to the city (at least once or twice a month).
A little fun waiting outside until your table is ready but definitely worth the wait; usually not a long one either. I have tried oysters at other restaurants (including some at fisherman's wharf)....Anchor is hands down better, not stuffy at all.
author: Craig R.

description:
Really love this place. I have the advantage of living about a block away - but I don't think this biases my review. 

Anchor Oyster is my favorite for comfort food. The Cesar is delicious and decadent , but beware ordering it as a starter for yourself because it's pretty huge. They cut up toasted garlic bread to make the croutons and toss it with a health slathering of dressing. We always split the salad and an entree and usually have food left over. Their prices are a little on the high-side, but the portions are big so sharing is satisfying and economical. 

The staff is friendly, they pour wine generously, and their bread and butter is yummy. The space is small but adds to the experience with a heavy marble bar, tiled floor, and aluminum furniture - it feels the part of an oyster bar while remaining cozy. 

The wait can be a bit long, but you can put your name on the list and walk around the Castro if there's time to kill. Best for two people, not a great place for parties of 4+.
author: Haley B.

description:
A good as it gets! However, if you aren't willing to wait and in a hurry, don't even bother. This is the type of place you come to when you want great food, great service and spending a great time with your friend, partner or family.

The food is incredibly delicious :D
author: Jim S.

description: Huge bowls of fresh fish and shellfish in amazing broths ! out of this world good. The steamed shellfish combo is the best I have ever had, and I have eaten a lot of shellfish, I mean a lot! The cioppino is also the best I have ever had and I have been eating cioppino in San Francisco for 40 years. The broth is not a after thought like most places, I mean you could have just the broth as a soup, and the buttered toasted sourdough slices go perfect, toasted, hmmm, who would think? There was a piece of white fish in there that was bigger than a dinner portion at a lot of S/F places. I'm a fan, I will always be back, thanks soooo much. Oh the staff are friendly as well as professional, a rare combo.
author: Peter C.

description:
Put your name on the board and WAIT!
Well worth it!

I  was just looking for seafood and this place poppped up on my mobile yelp app and we went.  It's a little place with a board by the front door where you put your name down and wait for a table.  The parties ahead of us had waited over an hour.

We waited only about 20 mintues and it was so worthwhile.  I love places like this, simple, but perfectly done.  Great music and lighting, simple decor and very quaint and intimate.  Even though it's tiny and busy, they don't rush you.

We had the crabcake appetizer, honestly the crabcakes were a bit on the bland side, but their homemade tartar sauce was great.  I had the sole for my entree and it was fabulous, as well as enormous, it came with whipped potatoes and steamed vegetables  My husband had oysters, I'm not a huge oyster fan, but he had nothing but positive reviews about the ones he ate.

I'd highly recommend this place and will come back!
author: Jennifer W.

description: I don't know why people say this place is good. We basically waited an hour to eat tasteless food. I only gave them two stars because I love baby oysters but their oysters were so over priced.
author: Sandy S.

description: I absolutely LOVED it! Our waiter was kind and so helpful, the food was better than what we expected (and we had high expectations), and we left feeling perfectly satisfied. There was a long wait to get in, but that was well worth it for the great service and quality food. I'd recommend this place to anyone!
author: John C.

description:
Two things I want on the day I die 1) lunch at the Anchor Oyster Bar.  Start with the clam chowder, then move onto the fresh crab in a garlicky stock. This is the best meal in SF.  Add some garlic bread and I'm in food heaven.  There is a reason you will wait to get in and pay a premium it's the quality.  2) make love one last time.
It's been a good life.
author: EC N.

description:
This place is amazing. If you like seafood, you must eat here. MUST.

I've eaten here a half dozen times over the past six years, and the food is always amazing. This slice of life is small, neighborhood-y, and completely non-corporate and unique. 

Their Cioppino is my favorite. They don't skimp on the crab, and the portions are quite healthy. Everything is fresh.

No reservations, typically a line. But, a wine bar is across the street. Once you put your name on the board, go get a glass of wine across the street while you wait. The wait is well worth it.
author: Jeremy K.

description:
1 hour 45 min wait to get a table of 2 on Saturday night, came for dinner, left happy.

Their steam clams and Dungeness crab were delicious and flavorful.  Often time with clams, if they aren't prepared well, you might get some bits of sand within the clams.  Fortunately, we didn't find any of the sands that might have distracted us from savoring the flavor of their claims.  We really liked their clams.

The Dungeness crab was ~$30.9x for the entire crab (comes with clam chowder).  They pre-cracked most of them, making it fairly easy to access the sweet and plump meat.  The garlicky broth complements the sweetness of the meat.

I forgot the name of the beer that we had, might be Big Daddy IPA.  I wanted something hoppy to go with the crab.  The server's recommendation was right on.

Their service was friendly and attentive.  None of their patrons were ever rushed.  However, since we waited for 1 hour and 45 min, we were famished, and polished off the bowl of clam chowder (came with the Dungeness crab), the huge bowl of clams, and even larger servings of the crab in no time.

During the 1 hour 45 min wait, the server/host came and gave people waiting outside some free shrimp appetizer of some sort.  It made the wait enjoyable. 

My only question is to the two male patrons that sat at the table next to the window for over 1 hour 45 minute chatting over coffee while others waited patiently for their table, "seriously? It is obvious you both like each other, get a room already, and let me have my table."

All joking aside, the food and service were excellent.  We look forward to our next visit.

TIPS:  When signing up your name on the board, make sure to write in your time of arrival.  Their sign up board can only accommodate a small list.  They use your time stamp to make sure that you are called within the right sequence.  I wish the operator will change the board to something else.  Also, a note to the host, please be aware of people that take short cuts.   One couple cut in line in front of about 12 people waiting outside after we waited for about 1 hour.   All 12 of us were stunned.
author: David H.

description: Been here 10+ times. You cant go wrong with any dish. Best cioppino i've ever had. Great service. wait across the street at swirl for your table.
author: Ezra K.

description:
This tiny, cute, amazing restaurant was BY FAR one of the best I've ate at. I found it courtesy of Yelp and made my way there early. And glad I did!  Got there around 5 and happened to stop at the clothing store right next door. Great style and great prices!  Loved it!  I mentioned I was going to Anchor for dinner and the lady also raved how great it was and that I was in luck because she saw the chef on his way in and he was the best.  Idk about the rest of the chefs there but this guy was good (and easy on the eyes as he stood in the kitchen window most the time). 

I was a party of one with a few ppl ahead of me. Mind you, there's only 6 tables and the bar in the whole place. There was some awesome sisters that were visiting as well. They offered for me to join the table as who really wants to wait or be solo at this great place. We didn't talk much ...until our food came out and we ordered the same thing. GARLIC. DUNGENESS. CRAB.  OMG. we all were besides ourself on how amazing this was. Hot damn amazing!  And them we couldn't stop talking!  

Great food. Great atmosphere. Great service and ppl. Great company. Great garlic. And that crab!  I shlda got the whole one but settled with half order. And the price?  On par with most SF restaurants with farrrrrrrrr better quality. I will make this a staple for every trip there and recommend it to the rest of team that travels there.  Sooooo goooood!!!

Treat yourself but get there early.
author: Heide S.

description: Dropped by to eat here today with a friend and  I noticed the reviews were at 666 so i must write a review..lol.  The Cioppino is awesome, very flavorful and filled with seafood.  Clams, shrimps and crab.  It comes in a huge bowl and some garlic bread.  We also tried the cod special of the day, but after eating the cioppino the cod tasted average.  The oysters were also really good and im not really an oyster kinda guy.  I also had a glass of red wine that went well with the meal.  I was recommended the fish taco special and i will need to try along with their clam chowder.  Great food and great company left me very satisfied.
author: Hugh L.

description:
Been here several times in the past 10 months..Still superb oysters, usually four different kinds..they still taste like the sea..fresh and briney..
Consistent food, great staff!
author: michael s.

description:
My friends and I decided to try this place because it was on SF's 7x7 list.

I really can't believe this place has so many positive reviews.  The servers and owners are quite snotty.  The place is tiny and it takes forever to be seated and get your food.  Warning: NO RESERVATIONS can be made ahead of time.  Apparently, only one person can take your order and ring up your bill.  The other waiters were useless and kept referring us to the busiest guy in the place, who really ignored us for the most part.  They also were very rude when we finally got tired of waiting for our check and asked for it.  

The four of us tried the clam chowder and garlic bread.  Honestly, it's the not the best damn clam chowder I have ever had.  You can go somewhere more unpretentious for your seafood.  I really just don't get it.

Honestly, I wouldn't come back to this place and I wouldn't recommend it to my friends.
author: B. N.

description: I was craving crab for DAYS and was determined to eat it as soon as possible. One of my girlfriends and I came here last night, Thursday at 8:45pm and were seated in 20 minutes. There was fresh bread and butter on the table already waiting for our very hungry stomachs. We ordered the cioppino, crabmeat salad, and 1/2 a liter of chardonnay. The portions were ginormous and we ate the entire 2 meals much to our stuffedness. I WAS IN CRAB AND SEAFOOD HEAVEN. Everything was extremely fresh and oh so delicious. I have been living in SF for almost 20 years and this was my first time eating here, but definitely not my last. Thank you, Anchor for satisfying my extreme crab craving!!! I can't stop thinking about the food and wish I was eating there again tonight! :D
author: M L.

description:
Amazing!

We yelped Anchor Oyster Bar, and jumped into a cab out to Castro to see what all the fuss was about. We were greeted by an one hour long wait, but all the people that were waiting seemed to be regulars and told us that it was worth the wait. I wasn't less convinced by all the people exiting the restaurant, reinforcing the statement that it really is worth the wait.

We simply put our name up on the wait list, and skipped across the street to Swirl and enjoyed a glass of red while we waited. When we finally got our table, we were taken care by Michael who has been working at AOB for 32 years. He was extremely friendly and accommodating, but not at all too intrusive as many ambitious waiters are today. The setting is your typical oysterbar (or at least what I perceive to be the typical oyster bar): raw, bare and lots of tiles and stainless steel. The lighting was very nice, and it was neither too dim nor too bright. Oh funny detail, when going to the bathroom you'll have to pass through the kitchen. I loved that, felt so casual and homey. 

About the food. Just fantastic. Some of the best seafood I have had in a very long time. I was there with a friend, so we decided just to share whatever we ordered. We had the shellfish platter to start off with, and for entree we had seabass and their version of bouillabaisse. It was all rather amazing!
author: Erik M.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this place!!! Wouldn't go anywhere else for an oyster bar place. Too bad I can't visit it often because I don't live in SF. Had I lived in SF I would so go here every week. 

Hate the Parking and waiting... But the food is all worth it.
author: Amy D.

description:
Where to go and what to eat during lent and all you can eat is seafood?  Anchor Oyster Bar!

My sister and I went here one Friday during Lent......probably as well as the other good catholics out there abstaining from meat.

We ordered fresh oysters, a cup of clam chowder and a combination shrimp and crab meat salad.

The chowder was deliciously smooth and creamy.

The oysters ultra fresh and good.

The salad was served with dressing on the side so it wasn't drowned with salad dressing.  very refreshing and light for the hot day we went.

Served with bread - ahhhh it was sooo good!

Don't need to wait for Lent....will need to go back soon!
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
Wow. I am still thinking about my meal from last week. A total knockout. Don't let the casual decor of this restaurant fool you. It is one of San Francisco's BEST. 

I had one of their specials: sole wrapped around crab meat. Blew my mind.
author: Villager E.

description:
A little gem in the middle of bustling castro.  Fresh, fresh seafood and just some really well cooked dishes.

Anchor Special - The oysters and shrimp were good, but the star for me was the clams.  My god...they cook the clams in this heavenly broth that's filled with tons of butter, fresh herbs, at least an entire bulb of garlic, and then probably some chili oil (the broth had a red hue to it).  I couldn't stop having the broth!  I guess I wasn't really having clams - more like drinking broth that happened to have clams in it.  After I polished off the clams, I had to use the house bread to soak up and finish off the rest of the broth...ok, enough about the broth.  :)

Clam Chowder - Solid.  It's got good flavor and it's not overwhelmingly creamy.

Cioppino - It's a really well made dish.  The seafood is fresh and the soup has a really strong tomato flavor with a good amount of kick.  By the way, the garlic bread that came with this dish was incredible.  So, so good and you can also order it as an appetizer.
author: Y K.

description:
Wow, the wait is long due to first come first serve rule.  There's a whiteboard to the right of the entrance so definitely write you name and party size down.  The key thing is to use common sense and try to arrive early before the dinner rush time.  Now, onto the juicy stuff (no pun intended).....food.  Here's what our double date ordered:

* Complimentary bread and butter
* 2 bowls clam chowder (1 for each couple)
* Full order of Anchor special (8 steamed clams, 4 chilled prawns, 12 oysters on half shell with 3 different types and 4 of each type)
* Cioppino

The clam chowder is your 4 star San Francisco clam chowder.  It's contains a fair amount of clams, not too creamy, and not too watery.  Has enough taste to deem it worthy of SF.  The anchor special was the highlight of our meal.  The different seafood were freshly made and there were several varieties of oysters to satiate our taste buds.  I don't remember all 3 but one was from the local Hog Oyster Farm.  I think the other was Maine and the last sounded Japanese.  Anyway, all 3 had their unique flavors.  I opted to squeeze lemon on mine but the other people ate it straight up or added cocktail sauce to it.  The last is the cioppino.  Holy moley is this thing huge.  With unlimited supply of bread, you literally can feed an entire family of 6 with it.  Loads and loads of mussels and other seafood in it.  I think we could have skipped the cioppino and ordered a smaller dish but since we traveled all the way to Castro we might as well finish it off with a bang.
author: Ronald L.

description:
A quaint, cozy gem hidden in the Castro.  The service was friendly and personable which was surprise, considering how busy it was.  

I had the artichoke-crab appetizer and Boston clam chowder, both of which were delicious and satisfying.  Something not on the menu which I ordered was the cioppino which was simply incredibly.   I'm typically not a fan of oysters, crab, and mussels but the broth of the stew was so flavorful and so well seasoned that I very much enjoyed all the seafood in the dish.  A warning about the cioppino: it's flavorful, delicious, and there's plenty of fresh tasting crab, shrimp, mussels, oysters and fish, but it's a large portion.  I shared it with a friend and we were only able to eat about half of it.  If you order it, make sure you're hungry and share it with a friend.  

If you're a fan of oysters and mussels, this is probably a great place to go.  

I'll definitely be going back again soon!
author: Franklin L.

description:
People are right. This place is unbelievably good. Definitely some of the best seafood I've ever had. 

If they have SCALLOPS on the menu that day. Get them. They're delicious and always perfectly cooked. Also, get the CLAM CHOWDER. This stuff is sooo good, the best even.  And of course, OYSTERS. They're fresh and they're delicious.

Now... I understand that all of this may add up. scallops, clam chowder, oysters... it's a pretty pricey meal so be prepared. It's worth every penny though. I know the wait is long... but sometimes you just gotta do what you gotta do.
 
Basically. I'm telling you... this is it, the motherload of seafood. Oh, and the service is impeccable. Really excellent.
author: Abbey S.

description:
