Came by here 'cause it came up first on yelp, but I was VERY happy with it.  
We ordered a bowl of clam chowder and split a half order of their special (oysters, clams, and prawns).  The meal came out to about $20 each after tip and tax, but it was filling enough, especially using the bread to eat all the soup and sauce with.
The clam chowder was delicious with the bread (and the unlimited supply of oyster crackers next to our table didn't hurt either) and the seafood was great as well.  
The service was also great.  We tried asking one of the workers about some of the courses (we had assumed he was a waiter) and he still did his best to answer our questions before referring us to one of the actual waiters.  Our waiter also was great with keeping our water glasses full and refilling our plate of bread throughout the meal.  He even pointed out to us where each of the different types of oysters were from when he brought us the seafood plate.
The seafood was a bit expensive for how little food there was, but hey, it's seafood.  I'd still buy it again.

A very good seafood restaurant with excellent service.
author: Keith C.

description:
Flavorful food merits returning but getting into this tiny place is painful, so we're unlikely to return.  
Crab cakes and cream-based Welsh turmeric seafood stew were wonderful.  Carbs were sub'ed with a generous serving of veggies.  Clam chowder broth was too thickened.
Noise level is high in this small space where dishes are constantly being washed inside the same room with the diners.
Service was amazingly pleasant, despite the frenetic pace they keep up.
author: Anne J.

description: The oysters were fresh and delicious! :) Great place for a nice dinner date. Can be a little loud - so hard for conversations but still a great atmosphere.
author: Andersen Y.

description:
Yes it's true! The Anchor Oyster Bar is the Best Seafood!
I am originally from Boston and the Chowder is spot on.
You can taste the LOVE in the Food...
...the Kindness of our Waiter...
...and the Great Energy from the Kitchen!

Thank You Again !...I will be back

p.s.
the welsh fisherman stew might be my favorite
author: Pete S.

description: I really wanted to like this place after reading such great Yelp reviews, but I just didn't. We went there today for lunch, starting with a cup of clam chowder. It seemed weak compared to lots of New England or Pacific Northwest chowders, sort of watered down in my opinion. Then had the Caesar salad with crab for the main dish, which was huge and lots of crab so I'm not complaining about the size, but everything just seemed tasteless, the lettuce bitter, very little dressing and bland. Just a very blah salad and for $25 I wanted to be wowed by it. For 3 of us for appetizers, mains and cokes/lemonade, the bill came to $91 + tip. That seemed really pricey for a lunch that wasn't very memorable. Staff was great but sadly, due to the quality of the food, I won't be going back.
author: Nichole B.

description:
Love the small town feel of this diminutive spot. Unfortunately, our meal wasn't all that memorable. 

Oysters were, of course stellar. If they weren't then I would have questioned things. The miyagi oysters were plump, sweet and tasted like the sea.  

After a good warm up with the oysters, I was ready for the rest of our seafood selections. Unfortunately, the oysters were the hight point. The clam chowder was too thin, the ono was on the verge of being overdone and the asparagus served as a side to the ono was mushy and overcooked.

I really wanted to love this place, but when you specialized in seafood, you should execute with perfection.
author: Lee H.

description: Great little place.  Came here for an early early dinner.  Waited about 30 minutes to get seated.  To start it off, oysters a mixture of different varieties - the best was the welsby?),  followed by crab cakes and stuffed petrale .  Stuffed petrale was done just right.  the fish was moist and tender. The stuffing  was great - filled with shrimp, the stuffing was an excellent pairing to the sole.  The crab cakes disappeared within minutes of arrival.  So good
author: Bill L.

description:
Some advice for going to Anchor based on experience:

Try not to go with more than 2 other people - the place is tiny and the wait can be incredibly long for a 4 top.

Sit at the bar if possible - once you get a table the service can be very noticeably slow.

Don't bring people who don't like seafood - pretty much every item on the menu had seafood, all but one had shellfish.

Order the oysters - they are knowledgeable about their selection and although they have fewer choices than other oyster bars, it's a well curated selection.
author: Kimble M.

description: Tiny spot with the very best cioppino anyplace. Unique in that it was loaded with garlic and red pepper. Serving oysters but by no means an oyster bar. Garlic bread was decent. Requires patience due to no official reservations but a white board sign in. The staff inserted a 4 top that thankfully no showed in front of us on the white board. Grrrr.
author: Joel N.

description:
Small place with a friendly staff and an awesome chef who works magic in a tiny kitchen.  The cioppino which is not on the menu was fabulous.  The garlic bread that came with the cioppino was the best I have had recently.  Crunchy and soft at the same time and perfect to dunk in the amazing sauce.  We wanted  more bread, it was that good but we were stuffed .  For two, the one order of cioppino exceeded our expectations in size and flavor.  We were full but could not stop eating the broth .
I am sure everything is good here, but I am returning for more cioppino.
author: Carol S.

description: This place is by far one of my favorite restaurants in the city! I went on Saturday night and the line was about 40 minutes. Even though it was cold outside, the wait wasn't bad at all, given that the host was super nice and even gave everyone a free cup of chowder for having to wait. Once we got seated, we were waited on immediately and all of the servers were very personable and attentive. We ordered the cioppino and the raw bar combo and both items were out of this world. It was the best cioppino I've ever had at a restaurant, and the seafood was super fresh. The oysters were delicious and everything was well presented. The atmosphere is really chill and welcoming. It's not pretentious like other high end seafood places are in the city. I would highly recommend this place, although if you have a party bigger than 2 or 3, expect a pretty long wait seeing as the restaurant is pretty small.
author: Regina L.

description:
Oh yes. For sure. Great fresh oysters, a very European atmosphere, super small and cozy. The clam chowder was great, the garlic bread was great too - everything was delicious and just right. We had the clams in the wine broth - and dipped it with garlic bread. Must get the special - includes the oysters, a combo plate with shrimp and the clams. 

Good stuff. I also loved our server, she was very accommodating and friendly.
author: Ha-ti N.

description: I am an oyster aficionado. i don't put anything at all on them, and god forbid they should be cooked. you eat oysters raw, or you don't eat them. i am still grieving the demise of Drake's Bay, but Anchor is pretty darn close to perfect.
author: Jack A.

description: Came here for lunch while vacationing in the beautiful S.F.  My husband and I shared west coast oysters of the day, 3 each, we both had the clam chowder, he had the crab burger and I had the steamed black mussels.  Everything was phenomenal and we washed it all down with a few glasses of wine.  The service was fantastic, the food was fresh and incredibly delicious.  The one "not so great" part of the meal was the astronomical check!  Over $100 for lunch for two.  As great as the meal was, I would say this is a place to splurge and would be an occasional treat for me.
author: Marina S.

description:
Anchor was a very quaint place in the very walkable Castro District, surrounded by little stores and businesses. The atmosphere was very comfortable, easy to converse or relax with a paper or e-book. The staff were very friendly and made us feel relaxed the entire stay....now onto the food.

Oyster Shooters: Brine-y, silky, and simply delicious. 
Garlic Bread: Words do not accurately capture how tasty this appetizer really is. There was a thick crater-like crust of baked cheese and garlic on top which was outstanding in its own right (see clams below).
Clam Chowder: The right balance of clams, broth, herbs/spices, and potato. 
Clams: Delicate and buttery, this dish was contained in a broth that was awesome. Dipping the bread, plain or garlic, is mandatory here.

I left Anchor feeling satisfied, content, and longing for another visit....
author: Gary S.

description:
YUMMMMMMMMMM!  Can you say crab-licious!  Clearly I love this place.  Don't love the no reservations though...it gets cold out there.  In a month I have eaten there 3 times.  With so many places to choose in SF how could that be?  Oysters expertly shucked, crab is ridiculous and the steamed artichoke amazing.  For the price this is a real find!  Service can be so-so and you wait a bit to have someone take your order.  The guy who seats you though...great.  I don't really agree with others on the clam chowder, its okay but not the best.  I personally prefer my chowder with more "stuff".

Buy a bottle of wine from across the street..the restaurant wine is hit or miss and they do not charge corkage.  Booth tables great and roomy but the other tables and the bar are really tight!!!!

Regardless......YUMMMMMMMMMMMM!
author: C S.

description:
The Anchor Oyster Bar is a friendly neighborhood place specializing in bivalves. I have been there for lunch three times and loved on each occasion.  A sure sign of a good neighborhood place is how many of the local folk are there.  Two of the three times it was packed with locals.  I hit them on a slow day when I was there earlier this month.

My only complaint, if you can call it that, is that it is pricey.  Go to the ATM or polish up the plastic before visiting.
author: Paul B.

description:
We showed up right at opening on a Friday morning and had no wait, but around 11:30 or so, people had to start writing their names on the chalkboard.

Delicious: The daily special of "Crab Burger" which was not what I expected. What I expected was a crab cake on a burger bun. What I received (and happily devoured) was hand-picked Dungeness crab on a burger bun with a house tartar sauce that should really rename itself to something better like "XYZ aioli". I don't like tartar sauce; I really enjoyed this sandwich.

Also Delicious (and why you come here!): The oysters. We had a half dozen to get a fair sampling of the 3 types on the daily menu. They were all fresh and delicious, and the local ones were very different than the East Coast oysters I'm accustomed to. Creamy, briny, and just about the cleanest taste you can imagine.

Delicious, but not nearly as much as everyone seems to think: The Clam Chowder. And this is more of a personal preference. I like a creamier, thicker clam chowder, and this one is a bit more soupy. That said, the flavors are delicious, and it's a great side to whatever else you're getting to eat. This is pretty much the only thing preventing me from giving 5 stars here.

It's places like this that have me asking why I live so far away from SF.
author: Gina E.

description:
This is a nice little restaurant in the Castro district. The wait wasn't terrible on a Friday night, as long as you're not dining with a part of 4 or more. The restaurant has a quaint setting in the sense that there's only one person assigned to each specific restaurant position. 

The dining menu was fairly simple; one page, double sided, with food on the front side and drinks on the backside. The highlight of the place is of course its fresh oysters. Surprisingly, the price for a single serving of oysters were not listed on the menu because the restaurant has a variety of oysters from all over the country. The only way to find out about them is to talk to your waiter. the waiter introduced to us to their current seasonal oysters which came from Massachusetts, Washington, and Northern California. From this, we opted to try two of each as a sampler. In addition to the oysters. we ordered one of the night's fish special, the mahi mahi, along with some house garlic bread.

Overall, the food was exceptional but the service was okay. I say this because it took the the waiter 15 or more minutes to come to our table an take our order and it wasn't as if the restaurant was all that busy.
author: Ben W.

description: This restaurant, around since I moved here in 1982, makes the BEST clam chowder.  Their seafood salad is so fresh and special garlic bread amazing.  It's not to be missed!! The staff knows how to treat its' customers and it is truly worth the wait.
author: marilyn a.

description:
Super small intimate spot with great oysters and wonderful specials.  I have nothi bad to say. 
Service is excellent 
Food quality is top notch
The bathroom is small but so is the restaurant. Defintely a great seafood choice on date night.
author: Joseph M.

description:
This small space is like the clean cut cousin of Swan Oyster Depot, and a similarly fantastic place for seafood. You can belly up to the bar, or take a gamble on waiting for one of the few tables they have. 

I started with the crab cocktail, only because I didn't feel like wrestling with a Dungeness husk that evening. The crab was pretty good, but I bet it is better straight from the shell. Lesson learned. I really liked the cocktail sauce, which was topped with a hefty dose of horseradish. 

Next up was the caesar salad, which was maybe the best one I have had in SF. I tasted the anchovies in in the dressing, which was delicious but not overwhelmingly fishy. The croutons were amazing: chunks of bread toasted to perfection to be crunchy on he outside, and moist inside...perfect dressing reservoirs! 

My wife and I split the pasta with clams as a main course. It was buttery garlicky goodness that did not skimp on the bivalves, and the pasta was cooked just right. Every dish came in sizable portions, and the small but well chosen beer selection was a good match for the food menu. 

It took us a little while to get served here, but once our order was taken the food came out quick.
author: Aaron S.

description:
Great night sitting at the bar eating dinner.  Oysters fresh and tasty.  Clams were amazing, bread kept on coming.  I could dip the bread in the clam broth all night long.  
Cioppino is off the menu, order it. You will not be disappointed.  Crab cakes good but not amazing. 
Great wait staff.
author: John S.

description:
Very cool place with a marine and bohemian atmosphere. Can fit both romantic dinner and friends parties. We just signed on the blackboard outside and then strolled a bit around the colorful Castro to come back there and find our place at the restaurant :)
Bartenders are nice and polite. The oyster and the shrimp cocktail are AMAZING!!
author: Emy G.

description: One of the best meals we've had in SF. First of all, be prepared to wait, a lot. we arrived at 6:30 PM and had to wait about an hour to be seated, they do bring out complimentary clam chowder to the people outside and you can pop across the street for a glass or two in the lovely wine store/bar. We ordered some fresh oysters as starters and the ciopinno and a baked sea bass with a panco and porcini crust off the specials list. Everything was delicious and super fresh, the ciopinno can easily feed 2 and comes with their fantastic garlic bread. This place is well worth the wait.
author: Sefi K.

description: We enjoyed another dinner here on Valentine's day and we shared crab- it was amazing and we ate every last bite! The service was also great and I enjoyed it so much that I went back again the next evening with a friend. When I visited the next night I ordered the sole which was served with fingerling potatoes and fresh vegetables- the entrees here are huge and  I usually share so despite how great it was I wasn't able to finish it. We also shared the prawn cocktail which was very good- I love the carrots and olives that are served with the salad. I would recommend this place to anyone who loves great seafood!
author: Natalie M.

description:
I LOVE THIS RESTAURANT!!  I'm a clean freak.  I hate dirty restaurants.
This place is immaculate!  It is a TINY place.  A bar....and a couple of tables.  Not the place to bring a big group.....but....perfect for a nice dinner alone at the bar....or with a date.  I love mussels.....and they prepare them perfectly here.  I like the big green lip mussels.  They arrive in a big bowl, with at least a pound of he little treats steaming in a bath of white wine, garlic, fresh herbs.....and fresh sourdough bread to sop it all up.  The perfect foggy weather dinner!
author: Bryan M.

description: Went for dinner tonite spent $185 dollars plus tip . We had a party of 3 and had a lot of food left over , put in a Togo box, we all thought one of us grabbed the box, we only got one block away , returned to get the food, was told 'sorry we threw it away' , WTF ?????  If I could give you zero stars I would select that. Your service sucked. What will you do to make this up anchor oyster???????????. Im thinking of calling the credit card company to dispute the charge. You threw away food we had paid for . Wouldnt it make sense that we would be back in 5 min to pick it up?
author: michael r.

description:
It may have been pricey but I was completely taken in when I strolled into Anchor Oyster Bar a few months ago, dropping by on a whim whilst wandering the Castro.
It was so delicious! They took the classics and made it to memorable perfection. In an instant I stamped this as definitely Jessica approved and can't wait to go back for more. The clam pasta, the garlic bread, the chowder??? All of it was perfection, I really couldn't have asked for more. But, man, talk about delivering on excellent service, on great atmosphere... that aroma? So tantalizing.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Rating only the cioppino which is all we had.  Of all the restaurants that serve it, this was the only one that gave us the requested dry sourdough toast!  Excellent food, friendly available staff.  We will return!
Since I wrote the review above we have been back several times & tried many dishes
never being dissapointed.  The freshest & always perfectly prepared, fish in town!!!!
author: Iryce K.

description:
Very friendly service. Space is very tight.

Ordered the Anchor Special (?) which came with 12 oysters and a steamed mussels in delicious broth. Miyagi's were the best they had, although I wish they had Kumamotos!

Fish dishes were great, pasta was super heavy and massive, but pretty good.

Think it's a bit overpriced.
author: Marty G.

description: Last night was, I think, my 7th visit. Last night was the deal-breaker. Small, but great menu. We waited over an hour and a half last night-Saturday-for a table. By the time we got in, we were too cold and weary to find the enjoyment for which we hoped. So, the food is great. Because they don't take reservations, they provide a white-board out front for diners to write their names. As the waiter calls the names on the board, if they aren't there, he passed on to the next name. Even after a name was called several times, the names remain on the board and the name keeps getting called when space inside becomes available. People were showing up an hour or more later after their names had been called repeatedly, and they still got table. Sort of like being punished for waiting. I really like the place, but there are others as good without the insane waiting.
author: Patrick M.

description: I ate here yesterday after strolling around Castro St. and It was fabulous! We came at just the correct time to be shuffled right in an receive a cozy seat in the corner. I decided on the crab cakes dinner with the clam chowder option, both of which were phenomenally flavored. I also ordered a glass of the house white wine that tasted surprisingly decadent and bubbly. One of my judgements of service at a restaurant is how often my drink runs low and I have to ask for a refill. Fortunately, at this restaurant, there was a lovely, charismatic young man named Michael who made several rounds with a full pitcher of ice water and questions if we were doing okay and needed anything. He took very good care of us and made quite an impression on our party. I would definitely eat here again without a doubt, service and food are unparalleled. I'm literally craving some at this very moment!
author: K. K.

description:
After a perfect day of hiking up / down atop "Twin Peaks", which delivered the most amazing view of the city, I wandered up the street - stomach demanding food soon when I stumbled upon Anchor Oyster Bar - a small, locally owned seafood restaurant.   Remembering a local friend had recommended AOB several times for some of the best seafood in the city, my stomach went into full revolt as in STOP NOW idiot.  My friend had warned me about the usual waits but since it was about 14:00, there was no line and a open spot at the bar so I thought - destiny of both time and place!  

I walked in and was seated at the end of the bar where I had unobstructed view of many dishes being expertly assembled with great care in the kitchen not more than 5 feet away - talk about torture.  After about 10 minutes of watching various mouthwatering seafood being whisked out the main portal and reviewing the simple menu and specials, I decided upon a board special of a lite and cool dish of Seafood Gazpacho with Prawns, Bay Shrimp, Dungeness Crab, Avocado and Sour Cream (held).  While I waited anxiously, I devoured the excellent sourdough bread and many glasses of ice cold water.  The waiter expertly maintained my glass at full though at times I'm sure he thought I was performing some sort of torture test of his attentiveness with me downing all that water after that hike.   Once the Gazpacho arrived, I was even more impressed with the meal and the taste - oh my it was just want I needed after that hike.  The dungeness crab was a wonderful addition to what I am sure is an already spectacular dish!  

Overall, if you do not mind a wait during peak times, as they can only seat about 25 seats (I counted), AOB is a nice place to get some really good and assuredly fresh seafood prepared by a master.  Cheers.
author: G M.

description:
I've lived in SF for about 6 months now, and i've been to Anchor about 12 times.  Lol.. I can't say enough about this place.  The oysters are always fantastic and there hasn't been anything on the menu that i've tried that has disapointed.  I'm always going to recommend the Anchor special.  I start EVERY meal with it and never once have I not.  Nothing beats the fresh oysters, the juicy prawns, and those CLAMS! YUM!! I could just drink that broth!  I know it sounds like a small detail, but I also LOVE the side vegetables that come with most of their entrees.  It's usually a carrot and green bean mix and they're always cooked perfectly! (with just the right amount of crunch).  Other recommendations would be their clam chowder, garlic bread, and a custom ordered pasta.  The sauce they toss that pasta in is AMAZING.  

The only negatives that I have are:  First of all, I have had two specials that were just ok.. don't get me wrong, they weren't bad or disappointing at all, but they just didn't thrill me.  And secondly, the service is pretty slow.  Not that the service isn't good, but it's a small place with a small staff and they have a tendency to take their time.  

With that said, show up early and waaay before you're hungry.  Cus the wait list is usually pretty long.  You write your name on a white board, outside and you wait, outside.  So if you're going for dinner, don't forget your jacket!  =)
author: Joanne K.

description: The best oyster bar in town. Worth the wait. The oyster shooters are divine. Great wine pairing selection and tasty artichokes. Clam chowder is extraordinary! Make it a fin date at the bar!!
author: Rez F.

description: We went for the first time before theater.  No reservations, but the 40 minute wait on a Saturday at 5:30 pm was WORTH it!  The chowder and the mussels were outstanding.   The wine selection was small, but the sauvignon blanc was excellent. The service was friendly and competent.  They serve samples while you wait.  This is a tiny (seats about 23 people total), neighborhood place -- unpretentious, just great food and good service.
author: Leslie P.

description: Was here on a Saturday evening.Great food.We waited about an hour and 20 minutes.Why?Good question-just why were a party of 5 seated before a party of 4?We arrived before the party of 5...come on guys-ya need a better system.The only reason to go here is for the food-if service is what you are looking for-pass on it.
author: Grae S.

description: I came here with a few friends after class. I had the Alaskan Halibut and a ginger cider. It was an delicious and healthy meal. Would love to return.
author: Paul M.

description: This place is very cozy. Even though we had to wait about 30 min, it was well worth it. The food was amazing. I ordered a mix of oysters and a crab salad. Both were very good. The service was excellent as well. While we were waiting one of the wait staff offered us free clam chowder soup. It was a great experience and recommend it to anyone. And great location in Castro Street as well!
author: Disanto D.

description:
My bf loved the small oysters.  He would go there every week if his pocket would allow him.
I'm not a huge oyster fan, but I wanted to give it a try..... it wasn't good for me..... I guess it's an acquired taste.
author: K F.

description: OMG. The best food. My dying wish would be a bowl of Chiopinno from Anchor Oyster Bar. They don't always have it but if they do, GET IT.
author: Juli G.

description:
Anchor Oyster Bar has firmly anchored itself within my heart. Everything about this small Castro seafood establishment wowed me. My boyfriend and I wrote our party info on the outside dry erase board, gazing up and down the vibrant street while waiting a short while for a space at the bar. Fragrances of fresh, high-quality seafood wafted around the room, rounded out by the warm lighting and hot male chef and waiter. I appreciated the hook beneath the granite bar top--a place to safely secure my shopping bag and purse. 

I asked for a Hogue Late Harvest Riesling, since I noticed they carried the Cab. Because the Riesling wasn't available, our waiter disappeared in an effort to find something similarly light and crisp: the Bonheur Convivial. 

The bar overlooks the dish washing area, above which the daily specials are hyped on a dry erase board. Along the mirrored back wall, menu staples are written in white. Plus, an arched opening reveals the kitchen. 

Since I couldn't decide between the Crab Caesar and the Pasta with Hog Island Clams special, the waiter suggested I order half of each. The crab Caesar salad, brimming with fresh generous crab meat, contained bright green roughage; soft, melting, house-made croutons; tart cheese; and cracked pepper. Although I was relatively full after attacking my mind-blowing salad, I shoveled a hearty amount of my pasta as well. The penne pasta, tossed with clams still in the shell, contained spinach and garlic, gaining a subtle, pleasant flavor from lemon and white wine. 

My boyfriend, who usually doesn't eat much, finished his Half Moon Bay Cod, poached in a lemon-thyme broth. Fresh thyme sprigs, roasted potatoes and string beans added depth to the light, flaking fish. 

In addition to the wonderful meal and comfortable atmosphere, I appreciated the classy service. I had been trekking through the city all day, dressed casually and sweating like a tourist. The waiter treated me like an important patron--his attitude toward all customers, I'm sure. 

Anchor Oyster Bar is one of the reasons why I can't wait to return to San Francisco.
author: Bobbin W.

description:
I am not fond of oysters, but I found myself finishing off 1/2 dozen with no problem. We got a mix of the oysters to try them all, and we enjoyed every single one. 

If you have not tried an oyster before, or if you are a connaiseur--go to Anchor Oyster Bar and you will not be sorry!

Non food related: the bathroom requires you to go through the kitchen. Its worth the walk through to see all the great food being prepared.
author: Marit S.

description: Tried this place yesterday for the first time with a friend. I am very picky with oysters, but yesterday I ate a whole bunch. Their oysters are soooo good and fresh!!! Also tried the garlic bread, and the crab burger. This is definitely a place I will come back to.  Just a tip to folks who will come to this place: it's a really small restaurant (hard for big groups), they don't take reservations, street parking only, and they do not seat not until party is complete. But it's all worth it!!!
author: Romina L.

description: worth joining yelp to praise this place.  first rate, and well-priced too. I'll be back. simple.
author: Dr. H.

description: Only stopped in for some wine and oysters on the half shell. Service, food, and drink were all excellent, and I don't know if it was the oysters or the wine, but this place brought out the animal in me.
author: BarbWire X.

description:
This place is so good, my only complaint is that sometimes you have to wait for a table.

If you're seeking variety, I can definitely recommend the Special: oysters, shrimp and steamed clam combo. It does not come with garlic bread, so get that too, to sop up that clam broth.

They have excellent specials, but I keep returning to the combo. Be careful, and refrain from eating the crispy oyster crackers before dinner, because they are addictive and accessible.
author: A I.

description:
I just discovered this hidden gem a few weeks ago. A friend was visiting from Hawaii and she was craving oysters and really good seafood. I was avoiding the Fisherman's Wharf tourist trap. Anchor Oyster Bar was just a few blocks away so we decided to check it out. We ordered and shared:
 - Half order of the Anchor Special (comes with six oysters, steamed clams and four chilled prawns).
 - Open face crab sandwich with a small salad

According to my friend, the oysters were AMAZING! We both loved the steamed clams and the yummy sauce they were swimming in. We kept dipping our bread in the sauce. It was goood! The shrimp was just right with a little bit of sweetness.

The open face crab sandwich was amazing as well. We were glad we shared it since it was pretty heavy with gooey cheese and mayo. We called it the crab dip sandwich as we were eating it.

While eating the owner and our server kept talking to us and making sure we were taken care of. They were fascinated that my friend is from Hawaii. A fellow diner sitting behind us was listening and joined our conversation as well. 

I'm glad to have discovered Anchor Oyster Bar. Delicious food, excellent service and  great company from other diners and the servers. I am coming back again with out of town guests and friends who doesn't know about this place.

*diner tip: come during the lunch hour. there is no wait for a table. our server also recommended coming between 6 - 7 p.m. just before the dinner rush to avoid the long wait.
author: Jocelyn P.

description:
We waited for 1 hour and 45 mins for table for 4. Right when a table was ready a couple walk right in front of us and the waiter sit them at the table for 4 ppl that was so limited !! When I asked the waiter why the couple got the table he shrugged and said that they were waiting a long time..He did not even look at the waiting board. My friend actually saw the couple when they put their name on the board, and they were behind us.. Not sure what's going on, but this totally ruined the experience for me. 
The food was good, but not worth the waiting time and the attitude.
author: N A.

description: OMG I cannot tell you how good their seafood is!   1st timer visiting from LA w/ the wife we decided to try it out because of all the great reviews on Yelp.  We ordered the famous Cioppino and Anchor special half order. The raw oysters were so fresh and the steamed clams in a garlicky Italian style broth almost made me faint cuz they were heaven!  Crabs were so flavorful and delicious.  Service was top notch, very attentive and the waiter kept bringing us yummy bread.  Now if we ever come back to San Francisco this place will def be the 1st stop!!
author: Tommy L.

description:
Clam Chowder, Oyster Shots and Crab Burger... 

Suberb food, great location and very helpful wait staff.
author: Robert L.

description:
I don't really remember what I ordered for the entree, but all I can remember were the oysters. It was superb! A must go to spot for fresh oysters! the clam chowder was really good too!!!!


BTW: this place is REAL SMALL!
author: Tam T.

description:
There is no better Sea Food in SF...and it's right here in the CASTRO.  I have been going for about 25 years and it is always the best, freshest seafood....served fresh and fast by a helpful friendly staff...

Down side...not great wines, that are priced a bit high...and there is always a wait...but it is worth it....
author: Patrick G.

description: This place is very good had the combination seafood cocktail and cioppino. The cioppino broth was very bland and I had to add a lot of hot sauce in it, but the seafood was very fresh. I wouldn't go again but it was nice and the experience was great.
author: N A.

description:
A story:

I was apartment hunting and had been all over the city. My last showing was in the Castro.

All the double entendre offerings at the cutesy eateries on Castro weren't doing it for me, so I said fuck it, and had oysters at Anchor Oyster Bar. The line to eat there is always endless, and it was just me, and it was a cold and rainy Thursday, so I went for it.

I sat at the bar and got cheap wine and expensive seafood. (Not really, it's fresh seafood. That shit costs.) The service was comfortable and unassuming and nice. I fell in love with oysters a while back, but rarely indulge due to they can really ratchet up the dinner tab. Tonight I had six, two Sweetwaters from the local waters here, two gems from Cape Cod, and my favorites, the twin beauties from British Columbia. Just lemon, and swallow. So perfect. I never knew. 

I also had clams and soup some, but they oysters were the main event.

One of the servers behind the bar caught my ear as he chatted up a regular, and I settled up my bill. It was distinctly Southern; it was unmistakable. Even underneath all his otherwise effeminate voice, I could hear it in his "well, welcome back" to the gentleman beside me.

"Where are you from?," I asked him as I handed over my card. It's a standard opening line in these parts. He grinned as he said, "Texas."

Not quite Southern, but oh so close when you are this far away.

I told him I was from Tennessee, and that his drawl is unmistakable. And nice to hear. You rarely hear the Southern accent that unbridled here, and his was certainly thick.

"Have fun during your stay," he told me warmly as he returned my card with a pen and requisite receipts. I nodded, and headed for the door. I tucked the rental application papers further down in my purse as misty rain greeted me at the exit.

I crossed at the crosswalk, and saw the lights of the 24 approaching the stop down the street. I hustled, oysters jostling, and easily made it.
author: Brittney G.

description: Not quite as great as the reviews make it seem. The oysters were good but I've had better for cheaper. The clam chowder was subpar.
author: Tony P.

description: Service sucks.  Owner treats you like garbage because his restuarant is "successful" and sees you as expendable. In his mind, he does not have to treat customers nicely or with respect because someother customer will fill the void and he will earn the business ANYWAY.  Not an establisment I'd like to support.
author: Haliegh S.

description: One of my favorite Seafood places in San Francisco.  I have never been disappointed.  I hate to plug it, because it is already difficult to get a table at times.  I'll go there alone and eat at the bar.
author: S E.

description:
For TRUE seafood lovers, as from the NorthEast Coast USA, etc. you might want to skip this place unless your REALLY want seafood badly.  We tried this place OPTIMISTICALLY, and were in a good mood and happy to wait, but were disappointed.

The positives:  The Castro is a nice area, the restaurant has sort-of a nice genuine seafoodey atmosphere, the staff cared about the fact you are waiting outside in the cold, and the clam chowder was tasty (we got some while outside free since we had to wait a long time).  

The negatives:  For starters: the wait was too long on a Tuesday though regulars waiting said it was worse than usual.  

The shrimps were large buy WAY WAY WAY overcooked, as if they had been prepared the day before rubbery.   

The oysters were fresh enough but were pretty microscopic and poorly shucked.  A few of them were still attached to the shell - which I guess is OK - but every last one of them had serious chunks.  They could do better if you are paying a lot for each oyster.  At least, consuming "shell" is something that may be good for you in small doses and may explain Okinawan longevity.  I'd rather do dark chocolate.

The Caesar salad was just OK, but I'd say not up to Bay Area standards.  Buy hey- I am not impressed with oversalted, overdressed salads...    If Caesar salad is going to be one of the 3 things on your menu, it should be outstanding.

Also, beware:  steamed clams means they are steamed in a bunch of ingredients, not just steamed on their own like the East Coast.  EVEN the oyster crackers were stale.

So, in short, maybe we had a bad experience... but if you go stick to the clam chowder and the salmon of the day - what we probably should have gotten.
author: Lujinski M.

description:
I came here and had an 1 and half hour wait on a Saturday. That kind of wait is normal in NY but SF... well this was worth the wait. I had the cioppino and it was the best I've ever had!! So good that I told everyone they had to try it and I couldn't stop thinking about it. Its a complicated dish that requires the right temperature for each seafood item and all the places I've been to, it was just forgettable. I was hesitant to try the dish but its so good that each piece of seafood was succulent. The broth was also amazing and I loved the chunks of tomatoes. It was great to dip the garlic bread into it.  It was a huge dish for 2 people so I would recommend half order of this for 2 people unless you're starving. 

Other highlights were also the garlic bread and the oyster shooter. Unfortunately the clam chowder is a miss for me. Its a small place so having a big party will be a longer wait.
author: lia m.

description: SO GOOOOOD. We walked in on a weekday (Monday) around lunch time and the place was full of, well, very older people. Not usually the demographic of crowd I identify with but my goodness was the food fantastic (and the service was great too). Bread while we waited, amazing clam chowder (so good I bought another cup to-go), and the cioppino... oh man. It wasn't on the menu, so we asked if they had it and they did... it was a $45 bowl of insanity. The broth was perfection, with tons of flaky fish in the soup base. Mussels, clams, crab, shrimp, fish... perfectly seasoned, just delicious.
author: Lauren O.

description: Fresh back from 2 weeks in SE New England...lobster, steamers, cherrystones, Bomster scallops, striped bass etc. Stopped at Anchor- chose scallops in panko with homeade tartar sauce and side salad. The exquisite presentation--including a yummy pickled carrot for color -the Washington State scallops were perfectly cooked: crispy panko coating contained barely-cooked buttery scallops. These measure up to CT  Bomsters and Cape Cod scallops--well done Anchor!
author: Jack G.

description: Best cioppino. Wine. Bread. I'm drunk.
author: Halle L.

description:
EAT HERE AT YOUR OWN RISK!!! UNSANITARY FOOD PREPARATION TECHNIQUES.

this is one restaurant where i almost walked out when i saw how the food was being prepared.  but i decided to stay, primarily so i could continue to observe the atrocity of it all and report back to fellow yelpers.

1. the same rag is used to: hold the oysters while shucking, wipe down the food preparation area, take pans out of the oven, and clean off your plate to make it presentable before it is served to you. 
2. cook had two friends visiting him on the night i patronized this place.  one was his girlfriend, the other a male friend.  both were drinking wine and eating food in the kitchen.  where did the food come from? let me elaborate a little further. cook prepares customer's food in oven or stove. when ready, dishes some on friends' plates and then dishes the rest on the customer's plate.
3. cook takes baked scallops out of the oven, gives a couple to his friends, gives the rest to the customer's plate. realizes he gave too many to his friends and goes back to their plate, removes some and puts on customer's plate.  Wipes around the edge of the customer's plate with rag mentioned in #1 to clean it off & make it presentable.  Dish served to customer.
5. cook went into the bathroom with his girlfriend. 5 minutes later, comes out & wipes mouth on the back of his hand and resumes preparing food for customers.
6. cook's girlfriend, who is probably tipsy at this point, comes to food preparation area with food in one hand, glass of wine in other. Talks & laughs with mouth full over food that is being prepared.
7. cook's girlfriend eats & talks over a pan sitting on top the oven.  When she leans over, the pan is less than 5 inches away from her mouth.  Pan is used later on in the night to prepare food for a customer.
8. not inappropriate for food preparation rather a demonstration of how unprofessional the wait staff is. I was with my parents, it was around 8pm, rainy & cold and the only space available was 3 seats at the bar.  I ordered a beer, my parents did not order drinks.  After taking our order, the waitress at the bar says to a coworker in a voice loud enough so we can hear her say "I don't know why you would take up space at the bar if you're not ordering drinks." Mind you, we just ordered raw oysters, clam chowder, two appetizers, and three entrees.  The name of the establishment is "Anchor Oyster Bar."  Not "Anchor Bar."

I had a difficult time swallowing the 6 oysters I ordered (oh normally yummy kunamotos).  The rest of the food was hard to enjoy after watching how other patrons' food was being prepared.  I'm sure stuff like this happens in other kitchens.  But those kitchens don't happen to have a large window into their kitchen.  The owner / host did try to move me and my parents to another table once he noticed we were watching the food preparation.  He also went to talk to the cook, who was then EXTRA careful when preparing the remainder of our food.

I am going to lodge a complaint with the SF Department of Public Health.

On another note, I waited two weeks to write this review so emotions from the unprofessional waitress comment would not influence my review.  I have only documented only what I observed.  SF DPH does keep a public record of their inspections.  Anchor Oyster Bar has had multiple violations over the past couple of years with regards to food storage / preparation and cleanliness.

zero stars if i could.
author: Catherine A.

description: This place is amazing.  I've been in the restaurant business in Chicago my whole life  I can tell you this is great, not good. Oysters, garlic bread, cezar salad, on and on. very fair prices also. I would recommend this place to anyone. They do a bang up job. Small quaint place and Castro street is wonderful to walk around after dinner.
author: Greg W.

description:
This place is small and it gets packed so i suggest getting their early and only going in small groups. If it's two of you, than just sit at the bar. 

It happens to be dungeness crab season right now and we ate here and got the full crab and a bowl of their cioppino (mixed seafood stew with a red tomato sauce). 

It was the best shellfish meal I've had in....oh...I don't know...my entire life! 

And they give you handy dandy tools for cracking the shell and shellfish scissors for getting into the smaller parts. 

The flavors were amazing, and the environment is cute and clean. 

If you need to use the restroom, be prepared to walk through the small kitchen and shake hands with the chef because it's cozy back there. But it's a nice bathroom regardless. 

Ask for a bib, because you'll need it. 

Unless you're watching your cholesterol (Which let's face it, isn't going to stop me from going back) you need to try this place out. 

The service was a little slow in the beginning, but there's only a few guys catering to everyone and the food was so good in the end that i had to give it 5 stars regardless. 

The menu is simple and to the point. If you don't like seafood, then head over to the Sausage factory at the end of the block!

Oh, and if you have to wait awhile for your table and it's cold outside, they sometimes come out and bring you a little cup of clam chowder....how awesome is that!
author: Philip H.

description:
YUM!!! Seriously, this place was so good. Friend and I were thinking of where to go for dinner last night and so of course I searched on yelp for some helpful tips and fellow yelpers...thank you!!! The reviews for this place were good so had to give it a try, we were not disappointed at all!! I am a oyster fan, but usually, I can maybe eat 4 or 5 before i'm over it...not here! The oysters didnt have the unpleasent after taste that some oysters leave in your mouth...not grimy at all. Hint of sweetness on top of the oysters freshness....I am so glad we decided to come here...great food all around. 

I know I will go back home to LA and be craving these here and there!
author: cassina Q.

description: This place is awesome! The full order of the Anchor Special came with a dozen oysters from different locations, an order of the steamed clams in white wine, rosemary, garlic, (butter?) and clam broth, and 4 chilled prawns. We came here for Father's day and we purposely arrived early since its first come first served. The staff was warm, attentive and accommodating. Will definitely come back here again.
author: Jojo G.

description:
The Anchor Oyster Bar is my favorite seafood restaurant in town.  They always have a selection of fantastic oysters (to be eaten raw!), as well as a hearty selection of simple and tasty fish specials (usually grilled or as a pasta or stew) that will make your mouth water.  Price-wise it's very reasonable and the perfect place for a date.

My only criticism is that you've got to wait for a while to get in.  I'd recommend coming a little early or late and avoid the 7pm rush.
author: Robin S.

description:
moderately hung over on a sunday? Well go somewhere else, can't help you. I want the window seat at Anchor!! You can't have it.

Sitting here with the friendly staff, yummy crab, and wine just made my day.
author: Nikki M.

description:
If you're from New England, you won't be wowed.

I've just heard SO many people talk about this place and almost orgasm about it. I just don't get it.

I'm really not trying to be a snob, and I'm not of the mindset that "Oh, I'm from New England so of course I'm a real sea food connoisseur." But the reality is that if you are, you'll probably think the food is just okay. It's by NO MEANS bad. It's totally decent fare. But I wouldn't say it's "great." 

The chowder was bland and too thin and watery of a consistency, for my taste.

The crab cakes also were pretty bland and there was nothing special about them. 

All other items were okay. Not bad. Not great.

Oh, and our waiter, an older gentleman, couldn't care less about good service. He was really unfriendly and cold.
author: Cee D.

description: A decadent treat but SO EXPENSIVE. Sheesh. $2.50 per oyster. Don't go at peak times or you'll have a long sad wait, though they will bring you some soup to stay warm. Instead go early or at lunch - no wait! Get the lunch special - Crab Burger with soup for $15. OR the melted open faced seafood sandwich - SOOO rich, yum! I pretty much only get these things. I have had the seafood salads and they are also great and more reasonable than some of the other dishes, which top $20 and $25. Stick with beer. I think their wine is overpriced. REALLY great staff, cute space, an ICON. Support them!
author: Aaron W.

description: Small but fantastic place.  Should have $$$ instead of $$ but well worth it.  The staff is warm and friendly and the food is outstanding!
author: Diane R.

description:
This is a great, down to earth earnest seafood restaurant. The seafood is FRESH. If you want a plate of fresh oysters, you can't go wrong here.We tried a couple of dishes and they were good too. I use to live on the North Shore of Massachusetts and the Oyster Bar reminds me of some clams shacks there. 

They don't take reservations, it's first come first serve, but it is worth the wait.
author: Mark F.

description:
Writing review while still stuffed full of possibly an entire Washington crab, that had been happily shredded over the most amazing crisp Caesar salad, filled with oily soft croutons, drenched in what I assume was house made dressing, topped with coarselly cracked black pepper.

Ya pretty much in heaven.
How did I spend so much of my life not having come here?

I sat at the grey marble counter and enjoyed the gradual hum of the small place as it filled up. Like Swan's of the Castro. I can see why they've been shucking crabs since '77. Which all begs the question, why don't more of these old school style fish joints exist?
author: Susie W.

description:
Really have done the world dining over the years and have to say it is rare to find a place so busy, with such a positive attitude.  These folks were over the top.  They invited my wife to sit alone at a table for over 20 minutes while I tried to find a parking spot on a Saturday night (a task in itself).  They were all so positive with gangs of folks waiting, not sure I would have held it together like they did.  The staff has always made or broken an occasion, and there is no question this was one of the most positive experiences in years.

Very small, maybe eight tables and an oyster bar of probably fifteen feet. Clean and a great personality for its size.

My wife stated it was the best cioppino she has experienced.  I ordered a special with scallops and a side of lightly breaded fish, don't recall the type.  Scallops were perfect, did not care for the fish although cooked well, but that was because I generally do not enjoy a light white fish. I have no idea why I ordered it, my bad.

Wine was reasonably priced. Staff is amazing.  Beats anything on the Wharf by miles . . .
author: Ron W.

description: I've been there twice to hang out with my friends, each experience was amazing. Not only by the food but also by the services I got there, I was amused. They were very kind to give us extra claims because we split in three. however, the wait was a little bit long, average waiting time was around 30 mins.
author: Ellen R.

description:
We were expecting a good and fancy place. We found a little restaurant with only 5-6 tables and crowded... but it overpassed our expectations. Worth the 60 minutes wait and very good quality price relation.

The pasta was delicious!
author: Erick L.

description:
I had date night with my honey here the other night. It. Was. The. Bomb. There were people outside waiting but turned out they were one large party so we were seated right away. Score! We had never been here before and this place was small, yet so very charming.

We ordered wine, crab cake appetizer plate, clam chowder, and the Anchor special which included clams, a dozen oysters of 3 varieties, and 4 large shrimp cocktails. It was seafood heaven! I think my tastebuds are still dancing from that night! 

They first brought out the oysters which were fresh fresh fresh along with the shrimp cocktail. Next they brought out the clams that were in the most amazing broth. The clams were on the small side and weren't really the star of the dish; it was the broth that brought this dish to life. They even brought out extra bread just so we could dip it in the leftover broth. 

Soon after, they brought out the crab cakes. 

Oh sweet mother of Mary, the crab cakes.

They were a tad on the pricy side, but O....M....G.... they were well worth it. I could not have savored that crab cake any slower than I did, taking tiny delectable bite after another. I honestly could have ordered the crab cake entree after that! My mouth is just watering just writing about it! HEAVEN!!! And an absolute MUST if you come here, you will not be disappointed.

Along side the crab cakes, we also had the clam chowder. Amazing flavor, texture, and creaminess. And a touch of Tabasco made me fall in love with it just that much more. 

Our bill came to about $70 for the two of us, which was a little high, but the quality of food and the customer service definitely made up for it. 

Excellent food and great ambiance made our date night perfect! We'll definitely be back.
author: Dexter C.

description:
I've searched high and low for a decent place to eat in the Castro and nada...until now.

The food is amazing. I had a pasta dish with calamari and clams. Everything was cooked *perfectly*. The sauce was a white wine based sauce and it was light and spicy and perfect. No heavy creams and cheeses on this stuff.

I also ordered some oysters on the side and they were beautifully presented and very very tasty.

The only reason I give it 4/5 stars is because there is always a wait and the prices are high, even for SF. I know that they can't do a thing about the wait, and since they always have a line outside there's no reason for them to make it a bit more affordable. I just wish it was more affordable because I would eat there all the time!
author: Will N.

description:
This review is for dinner on a Saturday evening.

GOOD:
- The SEA BASS WITH POTATOES AU GRATIN (daily special) was good. They did a good job getting the potatoes right with the crispy outside and cheesy inside and the potatoes sliced nice and thin.
- They had 4 different types of oysters on the menu (and one off menu). It isn't that easy finding places that offer more than 1 or 2 types of raw oysters in SF.

JUST OKAY:
- The HALIBUT CHEEKS (daily special) were not that exciting. The fish was a little on the dry side (overdone) and the overall dish was not very memorable.

BAD:
- The CLAM CHOWDER was disappointing. It tasted like they made it with fat free milk instead of heavy cream. Order it if you like your clam chowder thin and watery. 
- This place is on the pricey side for SF. The daily specials (entrees) were about $26 each and raw oysters are $2.50 each, regardless of how many you order. This place basically has Manhattan prices.
- The service was very friendly but also slow and inattentive. This place is relatively small and seats about 25 people at a time but there was only one server covering the entire place on a Saturday evening.

CONCLUSION:
I had high hopes for Anchor Oyster Bar but the food was not great, and most of it was very average and overpriced. 

If you are a seafood lover and know how to cook seafood, you will be disappointed with this place. If you are the type of person who likes seafood and eats it occasionally, and has no idea how to cook seafood, you will like this place.
author: Alex P.

description:
One of the best meals I've had in the city. 

The restaurant is small and cozy and we sat at the counter.  My boyfriend and I sampled each of the three oysters they were serving that night.  We preferred the local over the BC and the other.  Salty and yummy. 

Next, the highlight - Cioppino.  Not the menu, however, I knew to order it from Yelp (thank you, yelpers).  OH EM GEE.  Drop what you are doing and go straight there and order this dish.  The portion is HUGE and can easily be shared between two people.  This is a hearty, flavorful dish filled to the brim with crab, fish, shrimp and more.  The garlic bread they served with this dish was ridiculous.  We ate all the fish and took the sauce home, which I then froze and tossed with pasta the next week.  It still held up.  This was by far and away the best Cioppino I've ever had (don't tell my Italian grandmother). 

Delicious!
author: Kasie V.

description: I wrote my name on the board and the wait was not as long as I thought it would be.  We were seated at the counter within 30 minutes.  It is a small place, smaller than Swan's but the food is worth it.  We ordered a dozen oysters and it was to die for.  Then we had the cioppino.  The broth was slightly spicy but just right.  We are on a mission to compare other cioppino's in the City.  So far, this is on the top of the list.
author: Judy T.

description:
Cute little restaurant that seats no more than 25.  We had a seat at the bar. Service was superb as well as the food. I really enjoyed my dining experience here.  Luckily we got there early because a line started to form while we were eating.

Garlic Bread and Clam Chowder:
I love garlic bread, but I am not usually too fond of clam chowder. For some reason, I really enjoyed this clam chowder though. Maybe it was a very cold day and it helped warm my stomach, but I found that it went very very well with the garlic bread. I dipped my bread into the soup and it was a perfect starter for our meal.

Baked Corvina Seabass: garnished with toasted almonds and served with a tomato-basil butter with mashed potatoes and vegetable

I loved that it was garnished with toasted almonds because it definitely adds a richness to the flavor of the fish. I love fish, mashed potatoes and asparagus, so this dish did not go too wrong besides the fact that the fish didn't taste too fresh.

Combination Seafood Salad:
This wasn't my entree, but it was sooooo good. Very refreshing. I loved the heirloom tomatoes, the dressing and the seafood. There were crab, shrimp, prawns and I don't even remember what else. The seafood itself was full of flavor and it left my mouth watering for more, bite after bite. It was delicious.
author: Sarah F.

description: This is my favorite seafood place in San Francisco.  The location, and quality of food is great.  I've been going here for years and used to live a block away from it.  Be prepared to put yourself on a chalk board wait list to get in, but it's worth the wait.
author: Jon S.

description: I was craving oysters, so of course I insisted on Anchor Oyster Bar. They have a waiting list you write your own name on, and we sat there for an hour and a half in the cold on a Friday night. They were nice enough to bring up little appetizers (chowder, shrimp cocktail, etc) which made the wait a little sweeter! I wish there was more seating, but I love this place all the same.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Great place. Both Swans and Hog Island have pretty early closing times so this place is perfect for dinner.

Had a dozen oysters and the mussel combo. Perfect. Wait times are long but worth it. Eat some oysters get drunk in the castro after
author: jason l.

description:
BIG HINT ~ if it's your first time and it's a busy night! There is a whiteboard right outside the front door (under the specials) with the waiting list. No going in and asking for a table, not really a hostess at this place. The servers seem to do all the seating which is fine for such a small place. 

Had the special cioppino with fresh crab legs, mussels, shrimp, clams, ad big hunks of fish. It was amazing. I felt like I was in Lisbon again eating away along the waterside in summer. (Yeah I know cioppino is Italian, but the Portuguese make some tasty seafood stews too).  The garlic bread was the good kind of greasy garlicky that made me want to eat more and more and not put it aside for the dog.

I noticed people who didn't finish everything got to take home doggie bags.  The portion was a little on the large side but I wasn't complaining! The complimentary sourdough bread reminded us we were in the city. 

The place is small but seems larger then it appears because of all the stainless steel and glass on the walls.  Open shelves seemed nice and clean. I bet the fresh shucked oysters are terrific! 

The menu was just enough variety that we debated between a few dishes, but didn't agonize and take forever because of too many choices. 

GO - you won't be disappointed!
author: Tina P.

description:
swan oyster depot is a MILLION TIMES BETTER.
ended up here because swan was wayyy too crowded after anthony bordain had to go and ruin it for everyone! (stop reviewing hole-in-the-wall's, i beg you, bordain!)

the seafood here is just okay. probably could have been the saving grace if it had been anything better than meh. but really it was the service that earned the 1-star. the guy i dealt with from the beginning of our wait through the close of our meal was just incredibly rude. the best part was, halfway through our long wait, when he seated people before us who had gotten there after us. when i asked him what was up with that, he admitted that it was his mistake, but didn't apologize, and proceeded to explain that he "couldn't take the seats back" from them (I didn't ask him to...), so we "just had to be patient." WTF! rude! and in front of my visiting family, ugh....


bottom line: i will only excuse poor service if the food is awesome enough to go back for.... and the food was definitely nothing great. had better mussels at the beach chalet the night before. oysters were good (they'd better be if it's an oyster depot...) but you can get a WAY better overall experience at swan if you brave the line.
author: Molly E.

description:
They have this show on the Food Network that features different food festivals held across the country, and I'm a complete sucker for it!  I've seen the episodes with the apple festival in WA (I'm from Seattle and I've never been to it), the garlic festival in Gilroy, CA (that's 1.5 hours from where I live now and I've never been), and many others.  I guess I like the show because it gives me something to want to go to even if I never make it.

From the show, I've become fascinated with the seafood festivals in New England.  Lobster, crab, chowder, you name it.  I'm always nagging my bf that we should take a vacation to these random towns just so I can attend one of them!  

Alas, I've never made it beyond NYC, but I'm content eating seafood at Anchor Oyster Bar in SF.  The seafood there is the best!  I haven't eaten there in about 4 years, and I finally made it back for lunch because, frankly, I was having a crappy-ass morning and I knew that Anchor would cheer met up.  And that it did!

There's a small standard menu at Anchor, but you really need to order from the specials menu above the counter.  The restaurant is tiny with only three stainless steel 4-top tables, two 2-tops, and a marble counter.  Therefore, don't expect to get seated right away during the dinner rush.  It's worth the wait though!

Today I had the crab burger with a cup of chowder.  The burger came with a large pile of fresh, juicy, chunky crab meat on a warm toasted sesame bun.  It also had mixed greens, tomato, and their house tartar sauce.  Simple, yet, oh so delicious!  The crab there is amazing, and although I did encounter a few inner shells, the extraordinary taste of the crab eased my annoyance.  The tartar isn't very strong and actually helps to enhance the crab flavor.  Don't get me wrong, I love fatty, thick tartar sauces as much as the next person, but you can walk away from eating this burger without feeling bloated and vomit-y sick.  Same goes for the chowder!

In the past, I've had their addictive salads topped with crab and shrimp, and I recommend those whole-heartedly.  Actually, everything I've ever had at Anchor was delicious.  That's because everything is so freakin' fresh!  Try their oysters, the varieties change depending on what's in season.

The service is always friendly and attentive.  One customer came in and sat one seat away from me at the counter.  He had his salad up in the window within 2 minutes without even ordering from the waiter.  If only I could afford being a regular at Anchor!  

(I guess that's why I only give Anchor 4/5 stars.  It's great, but it can get pricey!)
author: Vicente G.

description:
Came here with my Mom and sister on the first day of introducing them to my boyfriend. Super high pressure dinner, so needed a great place. AOB DELIVERED! Everyone loved it.

Clam Chowder was creamy, fresh but not too heavy. We order one bowl to try and the wait staff split it in four cups. Now that's service!

The steam clams were out of this world! I normally swear that West Coast manila clams are much better than East Coast ones. They somehow made these Massachusetts clams taste like heaven in a white wine, garlic, thyme, and red chili flake broth. This is despite numerous New England visits to my boyfriend's parents and sampling the clams there. The clams came with the AOB Special seafood platter (prawns and sampling of oysters). Great bargain!

Everyone loved the Cioppino. Every SF restaurant makes it slightly different. AOB's is super fresh (made to order, as I had views of the kitchen), with no fishy taste so you know the seafood was fresh, and lots of herbs. They didn't skimp on the seafood i can tell you that! Fantastic cheesy bread too.  They brought out so many utensils and bowls/plates that made it easy to eat.  My stain-prone boyfriend kept his French-cuffed white dress shirt spotless.  Amazing!  This was everyone's favorite dish.

The surprise of the night for me was wild King salmon with thyme(?) garlic sauce. I ordered it mostly for the side of veggies and rice to share.  And the basmati rice and carrots/broccoli/cauliflower were all done right.  With the right technique, simple things can taste amazing.  But the sauce, OMG! The wait staff automatically brought out extra sauce for me, obviously seeing how much I loved it. I want to bottle that sh*t up and sell it all over town I Love Lucy style. So delicious and addictive!!! And the salmon was perfectly cooked, tasting light, fluffy and fresh. None of that overpowering salmon taste that normally turns me off except with overpowering teriyaki sauce.

The wait staff apologized for our wait despite us getting the table within 30 minutes on a Saturday night (a fluke for sure as we see the lines here every night on the way home, that being the reason we haven't been here in many years). And really our wait was because the previous diners just sat there for a long time after finishing their dinner and made my poor mother wait in the cold. Thanks guys, though I am sure they were just rehashing their own fantastic dinner. Anyways it was worth it. My sister loved it despite constantly being taken out on corporate expense account dinners at far fancier places. She even texted her boss to try this restaurant during dinner. Yeah she's got a smart phone addiction. Looks like I have a new obsession too: AOB!

PS, I think my Mom really liked my boyfriend.  She especially liked that he served cioppino to everyone else before serving himself.  My evangelical mother liking my gay boyfriend.  Maybe there is a god after all!
author: Jason J.

description:
What a great restaurant located near the Castro Theatre. We went for the first time this past Friday night. It is small and intimate and doesn't take reservations but worth the wait.
The staff is very accommodating and constantly in motion to provide an incredible array of seafood.
There are handwritten menus above the bar that are spectacular. Fresh Sweetwater Oysters on the half shell. Mexican prawns served in a sauce you will not taste anywhere else. And the presentation of each is as good as it gets.
First of all the garlic bread they bring to the table may be the best you could ever hope to eat. Then the clam chowder is creamy and tasty. The Cioppino is so good you dream somehow you could actually make it at home. A large special order of crab legs was served with bibs to help you enjoy them all the more.
Our first time there but certainly not our last. Everyone was so friendly and went out of their way to make us feel a part of their family for a few short hours. Put this restaurant on your short list now!
author: Rich R.

description: Been back to this place several times over the last few months -- still deserves all 5 stars with enthusiasm, but make sure to try all their different kinds of oysters by getting the full special plate. I never knew that oyster of different species/from different climates could be so different -- it's fun to see what the differences are by getting the sampler.
author: David B.

description:
I'm really not a fan of oysters.  Never been, and didn't think I'd ever be.
And then I came to Anchor Oyster Bar. 
I couldn't believe how great their oysters were! I duly enjoyed my meal, mainly because almost all the oysters I tried were free of that fishy ocean taste of unfresh oysters. The ones served here were awesome.
I'm still not a fan of oysters, but I'm a fan of Anchor Oyster Bar.
author: Annie G.

description: What a wonderful restaurant. The service was beyond great. Nicest people we encountered in all of SF. As for the food, it didn't disappoint. I had their pasta special that night which was full of mussels, scallops and a lot of other stuff I can't remember. It was big enough to serve two but I finished it and still had some of everyone elses food. Well worth the price. What a great place. Just make sure and thank the chef if you enjoyed it. He makes everything off of four burners for the entire restaurant. That takes talent.
author: Tyler B.

description: The clam chowder was absolutely fantastic! The oysters were good but not the best I've had. The clams and bread were very good as well.
author: Johnny N.

description: If it was more affordable, it would easily be a five-star. Everything I have eaten there is fresh and delicious, the staff is friendly and the beer is cold. Only thing I have eaten and not loved was the chowder, which I thought needed some more seasoning. They had a crab and shrimp melt, served open face, that was delicious. The oysters are fresh and from a great variety of locations. They have a small selection of beers on tap, but they aren't macrobrews, and rotate with good frequency. The portions are large as well.
author: Michael J.

description:
Really Great food!
The wait might be long but I think it's really worth it!
They even served us clam chowder while we were waiting outside one time!:)
author: Yassi Z.

description: LOVELY! Amazing place-small, quaint, delicious food (BEST CRAB CAKES AND CHOWDER), friendly staff.
author: Tara B.

description: Love, Love, Love this place!!!!!!!!!!  Lived in / near the Castro all my life & finally ventured into this darling restaurant  - Delicious seafood, awesome clam chowder - just overall worth the price and quality is fantastic...... staff also friendly.
author: Valerie M.

description:
Came here on a Monday night. Place is small, but has very nice decor and clean.  We ordered the steam clams, their special raw oysters of the day, and grilled trout.  Everything was delicious/fresh and the portions were very satisfying! We also tried their Soju Bloody Mary that had a raw oyster in it.  Very enjoyable! 

Based on my experience, and being that I love seafood, I would come back again!
author: J G.

description: Clam Chowder was perfect!  Oysters were out of this world....West & East Coast options and the fresh crab topped the meal.  We arrived right as they were opening...so didn't have to wait for a table, but will wait for sure when we go back (if we have to) because the quality of the oysters served, well worth it.
author: Candice S.

description:
The place was so nice and clean on the inside, there is even benches to sit on if you are waiting for a table.  The place is small but well worth the wait.  The service was OUTSTANDING!!!  You are given bread to start out with and its warm and soft....the clam chowder was nice and warm and perfect with the bread.  We ordered the half order of the Anchor Special which was perfect for three people. Clams which were out of this world and the crab salad was huge and fantastic!!!  The best was the crab cakes...they were fresh out of the oven...YUM!!!

Can't wait to go back!!!
author: Hillary B.

description: Excellent seafood. Consistent quality. Gets busy for dinner, involves a wait. I often do take out.  Can be expensive, portions are large!
author: Jay W.

description:
This meal was probably one of the best meals I've had thus far. We did wait a while because they don't take reservations but I promise you it was worth the wait. I love the area as well right next door was the office of the famous Harvey Milk which is now the Human Rights Campaign office. The area is eclectic, swanky, funky and gay as can be which is why I love it so much. 

We started off with their garlic bread, it was the perfect amount of fresh garlic, parsley and of course parmesan cheese....WOW! Then for the appetizer had a half order of oysters there were three different kinds but of course I'm not gonna remember they were all too die for ate some with the vinegar mixture or cocktail sauce with a hint of fresh horseradish. Then for the main course, I had the special pasta dish, a Mediterranean pasta with mussels in a meyer lemon butter sauce. It was too die for, creamy, lemony but light and the perfect amount of mussels in a mostaccioli type pasta. 

I cannot wait to come back.
author: Sourma K.

description: oysters, and then scallops for dinner...my friend and I have never been so ill from food poison! Two days of HELL!
author: John H.

description: Came here for my sister's bachelorette party and they were so great!! Oysters, clams and chowder were all great as usual! We got garlic bread on the house and a free shirt for my sister!
author: Soo B.

description:
In my hard search for good yet cheap oysters I have stumbled across this  place. It looks cute from outside. It's small and very inviting, but once you come inside you know that this place is on the expensive side. 

I ordered the House special I think. It has 12 oysters on half shell, clams, and prawns. I guess for all of that $36 was a decent price. 
However, the oysters were not as good as I thought it would be, and the prawns (even though they are big) are hard. 

My friend ordered a creamy crab sandwich which is deliciousssss! thats why I give this place a 3 star. That sandwich alone is one star. 

Other than that, the service was okay. Nothing too special.
author: Miss C.

description: This is my favorite seafood place in town . Have been going there for years and never been disappointed ...Whether it is the Crab melt Sandwich or the Cioppino , Oysters, Clam Chowder or their everyday specials, I love it all.  All the friendly servers ( that have been there for decades) make the experience even better.
author: Sunny B.

description:
This was my first port of call after flying in from Chicago. My husband and I came in craving fresh local oysters, and this establishment did not disappoint!

We started off with a few west coast oysters of the day (I believe they were miyagi). Perfect start to the meal.

My husband had the crab burger (amazing value given the amount of crab meat) with a side of chowder and I ate the Welsh fish stew. 

Gigantic portions!  The size of the stew portion would usually last 2, maybe 3 meals for me, but it was so delicious I slurped it down in one. A dish worth being a glutton over. Clams, mussels, big meaty shrimp, big chunks of a mild white fish (sadly I forget what type), crab and fish stock, served with garlic bread.

Staff were patient with us while we chose from the flawless menu and the prices were very fair.

A great start to a wonderful trip!
author: Sarah M.

description: Everything was phenomenal! From the service to the cozy atmosphere, this place is a tue neighborhood gem. We had oysters to start and then crab cakes and the crab burger with sides of clam chowder. The food came out quick and it was prepared perfectly! The tartar sauce on the sandwich was memorable also.
author: Alex R.

description:
I went again last night and I have to say, that this place never disappoints me. We arrived early (about 4:30 PM) because this place can and will fill up quickly. I highly advise a game plan of some sorts and/or dine alone for a better chance at success. You can easily wait a good 45 minutes for a chance to eat. But once your in, it's definitely worth the wait. Why, last night Chef's Rose & Taylor had a wonderful Seafood Chowder on the menu that was simply amazing. First of all, it was huge! You could very easily share this with another person and walk away satisfied. It had all the fixings of their Cioppino, except it was in this creamy, white sauce that went straight to the soul. 
I highly recommend ordering oysters when you dine here. They tend to have a small selection of premium oysters. Which, to me is a good thing. Three or four of the highest quality oysters should be enough for any discerning gourmand or glutton. We did a sample of each variety and needless to say, every single one of them were as fantastic as they were different. Great Selection! 
Another reason that I love this little restaurant is that they let you bring your own wine, beer etc. NO CORKAGE FEE! That is really cool. And when you finish what you brought in, order wine from the menu. They have a decent selection of beers and wines to choose from. 
I really do love this place. The best quality seafood, in a convenient locale with a truly wonderful staff and talented chefs. Why go anywhere else?
author: Gabe T.

description: f yeah, great crab louie and garlic bread, tiny place, the waiter was excellent, kind and considerate to our 4 year old
author: Barry C.

description:
This tiny place in the Castro is not bad, but it just isn't as good as Swan Oyster Depot.  Everything was super fresh: we had the seafood salad and a dozen raw oysters.  While the salad was good, it wasn't nearly as overflowingly bountiful as Swan's, and the price is at least as much if not more.  

If their prices were more in line with Swan's, I might bump this place up to four stars.  But as it is, they serve pretty good, fresh seafood albeit at a pretty hefty price.  If you really order up, you can spend a small fortune here easily because the portions are definitely on the petite side for the money.
author: Dave N.

description:
We waited outside for about an hour on a cold SF sunday night, but it was well worth the trouble!

I got the dungeness crab special that night, which was whole steamed crab in a GREAT white wine, garlic sauce with herbs. the special included a cup of their clam chowder for only $27.99! that's a great deal for a whole crab and a cup of chowder that's $4 by itself.  The crab was steamed perfectly and the sauce really made the dish.
