The others who went  w/ me got the Anchor Special - 4 different types of oysters, shrimp, and steamed clams. I tried one of each from their meal and everything was fresh and tasty.

For how fresh and quality the seafood was, this place is worth the price and wait. 5 stars!
author: WeiLi T.

description: I was really hoping this place would be as amazing as I had heard, but sadly I was a bit disappointed. I had the clam chowder and an order of the garlic bread. While all the food was tasty, it just wasn't anything spectacular.
author: Chelsea M.

description:
Went here for a snack this week.  I've heard a lot about over the last 20 years of living in the castro and mission, but strangely never been there.  Normally I would not review a place like this after one visit but this was exceptional.

We ordered a bowl of clam chowder and some muscles.  The clam chowder was fine, but the muscles were clearly not fresh.  They just tasted off.  They were soft, stale and fishy.  We politely sent them back.  

The first server didn't seem surprised but was polite and apologetic.  The second servier went back and told the kitchen.  Unfortunately for them, there are no walls between the kitchen and the counter where we heard the "chef" say "yea, they aren't fresh.  I don't have any fresh ones". 

Everyone was apologetic but no one was surprised.  To think the that they knew how bad that food was (shell fish no less) and sent it out anyway.  Clearly, this was more the norm than the exception.  
 
Again, I rarely would give an institution like this a bad review when it could have been an off night but clearly they knew exactly what they were doing and have done it frequently.  We were just the first people to actually send it back.

The service was polite, friendly and apologetic but to knowingly serve something that was borderline rotten is terrible.  

Try Woodhouse a few blocks away.  Anchor has hopefully seen better day because if it's always been that bad, it should have closed down decades ago.
author: James G.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday last night, and it was as great as always. We ordered the cioppino, artichokes, lobster and shrimp entree, and the seafood bucket - everything was just perfect.  Generous portions, and not heavy. 

The place isn't big, so be prepared for a wait.  But it's so worth it, not to mention they sometimes bring out free chowder while you wait.
author: Jing Y.

description:
A bit on the small side in terms of seating, but overall a Great Place to visit and enjoy some Oysters!  The Garlic Bread is a MUST (Large Portion),  and same with Oyster Shooters (Larger then i expected, more like a mini V-8 with Tobasco + oyster treat).  

Came here on a Thursday arrived at 6:45.  Only a 5 minute wait, but i hear on weekends it can get bad (45-1hour).   The service was great and the setting was dim and somewhat homely.  They also have Bar seating which we would have taken if it wasn't for the short wait.   I didn't get a chance to try to house pasta, but will def do that next time.  

A must try if you are in the area.
author: Andrew J.

description:
They are so nice here.  Just what I need after a long day at work along with  good fresh seafood and, of course, a glass of wine.  I've eaten in and also taken out.  

I usually order the half crab Caesar; it's huge and comes with large softer croutons.  It's a meal in itself.  Tip:  If you do not like a lot of dressing, ask for half dressing since they're pretty generous with it.  I also get a cup of clam chowder which is rich but not too creamy that it fills you up.

Don't forget to check out the specials that are on the white board above the bar.
author: michelle s.

description:
I do not like when people put less than 3 stars to local business. Especially me being part of this gayborhood. As a gay guy i can tell you i can be picky at times, but for 25 dollars they gave me a tiny little cocktail. That claimed to be a combo but all i saw it was shrimp from Safeway can. That i could pay 3.50 for it.

Their service is hideous horrendous . The servers ( about noon) are not pleasant and not happy working there.  It is painful to know that the food is good (except for my cocktail), but come on guys you need to be warm towards clients, is not only tourist people that eat there. Also people who happens to live in the city and will never come back. Like ME. 

I gave 2 stars for the taste of the shrimp.
author: Luis D.

description: Freaking awesome! Everything is so fresh. The prawns were gigantic and the garlic bread was out of this world. I'g give it 5 stars if the seating was a little more comfortable. All and all, good eating and good customer service.
author: Chac S.

description:
Finally some real seafood. This place is adorable. It is small but cozy, friendly but busy. The good food: awesome bread, delicious large bowl of steam clams, super fresh combination appetizer, real crab cakes, excellent pasta dish with clams. The only disappointing thing was the clam chowder. Fisherman's Wharf has much better chowder. Here it was pretty liquidity and missing the chunks. It was disappointing that this was the first dish I had there, but after that it got good with the rest. Just odd to me that they cant make this better. Also one person in my group was expecting more of an oyster selection. Not a fan of oyster so no bother to me. 

Point to note: don't come with a big group. 3 of us came for dinner at 5pm. There were 2 groups of 4/5 in front of us but we were seated right away while they waited. Also note: Menu is small and all seafood. 

I will definitely come back again and want to try the mussels or fish next time.
author: erika e.

description: Amazing chowder. the best I ever had. beautiful oysters and I had delicious crab burger. The place is tiny and you have to write your name on a board and wait. lunch time is best.
author: Christophe B.

description:
Tiny little restaurant tucked on Castro away from the crowd. I came here on a Monday and guess got lucky because we didn't really need to wait. And parking right in front of the place, score!

I tried the clam chowder and mixed shellfish dish with mussels, clams, and shrimp. The food was great and the service was outstanding.
author: Tatyana K.

description: This is one of my all time favorite restaurants in the city. Love everything. I go there before the movies at the Castro, but need to come early as after 6PM it's hard to get a table.
author: Marla V.

description:
Seafood lovers paradise.  Castro st was full, but found empty pay spot off of 18th st near the Moby Dick bar!  Colorful, clean, and safe neighborhood.
     6pm Tues was no wait for a group of 4.  Near 7-8pm the bar area and all tables were full with a short line and the noise level slowly increased and was to the point of loud shouting to talk to each other; small lively place, no biggie.
     Tried the 3 different oysters (Hog Island Kumamoto, Washington, and East Coast).  I'm a purist, no sauce or lemon.
The East Coast variety was my fav the sweetest tasting.
     Half portion of the Anchor special is enough for one.  The dozen steamers in garlic sauce was sooo good with an order of the garlic bread to dip, cocktail shrimp was just okay to slightly below average.
     Artichoke appetizer with shrimp and crab was also great.  One of our guest rave about the Hog Island pasta special.  My lady ordered the trout special was so buttery sweet and large portion that I had to share.  The crabcakes were massive and filling.  Heirloom tomato salad was nice appetizer to share.
     No verbal pressure to leave, but did notice some stern glances from staff and people waiting while our group was chatting for a bit after the bill and the table was bussed, but left a decent tip so I guess they didn't mind.
    Mike was friendly and great.  Water was always filled and attentive to our needs without being pushy.
    I would go back again to try more things.
author: David K.

description: The wait was long but the manager brought us a cup of amazing clam chowder while we waited. Food was worth the wait but the menu was not as extensive as I had hoped. Great service and atmosphere!
author: Alana T.

description:
this place was pretty good. a little pricey, but very fresh. 

it just sucks cuz the wait. and the place is sO small.
author: Lisa N.

description:
Really cool. 

We had the little table in the window. It was great. The place is tiny, so get there early....once we got there, the food was so good, that we didn't feel any pressure to hurry up even though there were lots of people waiting....

The oysters were great, the cioppino was nice and spicy, with lots of sea food.

All that, and throw in some wine? We were stoked. 

Also, if your s.o. likes seafood as much as my gf does....this is a pretty romantic place. 

We will be back...
author: Michael T.

description: I've always wanted to eat here, but was put off by the wait outside. If you arrive by 6:30pm you can usually get a seat right away. I enjoyed everything about the wait staff, food, presentation, choices, food freshness and atmosphere. I highly recommend the Italian Seafood Stew, just expect to be absolutely stuffed when it's time to pay the check!!
author: Megan T.

description:
3.75 stars so I'm rounding up because the staff was very nice.

First learned of this place from watching Check Please! and I have bookmarked it.  From the show, I thought the place was bigger. Anyway, when we walked by while looking for a place to eat - I remembered and knew we had to go inside.  More importantly, it was near empty!  We had our choice of seats at the counter or table - how can we turn that down?  

The place is quite small - about 8 stools at the counter and probably 6 tables of 4? That will explain the long waits.  Actually, we got in at the right time (about 3ish-4pm) because the crowds grew and there was a wait by the time we left.  

We weren't super hungry and we still want to save our stomach to snack at other places.  So we ordered a cup of chowder ($4.95) and one of the day's special - fish stew ($18.95).  

The cup of chowder was tasty and not very thick.  The bags of oyster crackers they have were great, not salty like others.  You can eat them alone - we did!  The fish stew was very generous with 2 prawns, clams, mussels and many pieces of cod.  The sauce was a mixture of tomato sauce w/ chicken broth - tasty but a little on the salty side.  It came with 2 large thick pieces of garlic bread - it was so good that I stuffed myself with it even though I was full.  

They still wash their dishes, pots, pans...etc. the old fashioned way - by hands!  If you sit at the counter, you'll see the busy man cleaning away.  

If in the area, we will definitely visit this joint again.
author: Gloria H.

description: So this was stop #3 on our oyster tour of San Francisco, it was Hog Island first, then Swan Oyster Depot and finally Anchor Oyster Bar. Well, after sampling the oysters at each of these establishments I must say that Anchor is worthy of competing with the big boys. The oysters were fresh, delectable, and  priced accordingly. I very much enjoyed their unique seafood salad, these guys went out on a limb and steered clear of the traditional iceberg and mayo situation and presented me with a mixed petite greens salad with bits of carrot and celery and topped it off with their own creamy garlic salad dressing, which was am-ahhhh-zing! Thanks for the good times Anchor, the #4 oyster destination is SF awaits ...
author: Colleen J.

description: We moved to San Fran In about mid october and were so busy unpacking and getting our house together, the first night we were finally able to go out for a nice dinner was on October 31st. And Halloween is generally not a night we would be going out. But the meal was so incredible, that we have been back, at least half a dozen times since then. Every single thing on the menu is delicious. The green lip oysters are absolutely amazing. And the oyster shooter is fresh every single time. This is the way oysters are meant to be.
author: Dr Judith N.

description:
Fairly decent seafood, but it was not nearly as awesome as some of the reviewers here make it out to be.  We split a bowl of clam chowder and the Anchor Special (dozen oysters on the half shell, steamed clams, and shrimp cocktail).  

Clam chowder was tasty, though not the best that I've had and a little on the thinner side.  Got 4 different kinds of oysters.  2 I remember liking very much.  The other 2 kinds were nothing special.  Clams and shrimp were good, but not great.  

Considering that this place is a bit more expensive than other seafood places I frequent (total came to a bit over $40 for the above), I'm not sure I have much reason to come back.  Maybe if I'm in the area again, but I wouldn't go out of my way.
author: Leslie L.

description:
Holy seafood Batman, this place is good.  

There were oysters, and lemon, and white flaky fish, and garlic, and mussels, and butter, and scallops, and....  Everything tasted amazingly fresh and every dish was amazingly rich.  The cioppino came topped with fresh crab and garlic bread.  I was as happy as .... the 30 clams I ate. 

The service was warm and friendly, even when the restaurant was full.  I actually started to get mad at one of the waiters who came to check on us, because I didn't want to stop stuffing my face with shrimp long enough to answer "how are you doing?" - then I realized this is the type of service I crave at lesser restaurants.  

The downside is that the place is tiny and it looked like the wait was long.  We came on a weekday around 6 and didn't have to wait for a table - but by 6:30 there was a line.  However, the waiters repeatedly went outside with samples of clam chowder for those braving the fog.  

I'd give it  6 stars if I could.
author: Amelia B.

description: Found this place on Yelp. It's friggin' delicious. We were lucky to get a seat at the bar since larger parties were waiting outside in the rain and were just two! We had the clams + shrimp + oyster appetizer and shared the crab covered ravioli. SO yummy. It's a fun place but I think it's a bit pricier than you would expect to spend with a "$$" amount on Yelp. Closer to "$$$" but it's definitely worth it.
author: Dalia M.

description:
Wow is the word to describe this gem in the city! 

If you like really good seafood cooked to perfection this is the place. I have eaten allot of seafood in my life time and found some good and bad but not one that gets my WOW rating! 

The place is in the Castro one of SF best place to have a drink, lunch or just to hang out and window shop. I found this restaurant by mistake many years ago when my best gal in my life needed some good food to finish our day in the city. 

At first when you walk in you notice its small, not a hug place like you would find down by pier 39. A few tables, a bar and two by the window. They have a wide selection of menu items from crab, to fresh oysters. Also a number of chef specials to choose from. The food is always the best and is served by the nicest staff they are grateful to serve you. 

We always order the clam chowder is the bomb! creamy, clammy and cooked just right. I also had the steamed clams and mussels which I found to be tender, juicy with a hint of the ocean. When in SF we always make time to stop in the Anchor for a beer and lunch. One of the best restaurants I have found in the city. 

I say check them out!
author: Tim H.

description: There seafood are tasty and fresh. Only thing is the place is small and kinda pricey but would come back if I was around town.
author: Philip W.

description:
This continues to be the absolute best seafood restaurant in the city. Tops on my list!
The seafood is always fresh...straight from the boat. 
The service is stellar.
Most of the staff have been there for 20+ years...very telling about how the restaurant is managed.
The owner, Roseann, is delightful and clearly dedicated to ensuring hospitality is paramount.  Where else would you find the owner serving tastes of their homemade clam chowder to guests waiting for a table?
Don't let the bogus review recently posted sway your decision to visit this gem.
This is not a spot to go when you are in a hurry. Small, intimate, and inviting...you won't want to leave.
author: Tom L.

description: I was just walking in Castro district with my friends. We found this place accidentally. All the dishes we ordered were very fresh and delicious! Especially I enjoyed oysters! Best ones I've ever tried! So fresh, so tasty! The only minus - we needed to wait about 20 mins, this place is really popular! But it was warm and sunny day and we enjoyed fresh air while waited! I'm sure you'll like this place, if you are keen on seafood!
author: Ganna B.

description: Love this place! Yes, it's tiny (barely seats 20) and the wait can be long. But, it's so worth it! The service is just lovely and you can basically see you food being cooked (or shucked) from most seats in the restaurant. We usually start off with a bowl of the clam chowder. It's thinner and more refined than other places. Everything is so fresh and tasty. On this trip, I also got a sample if all 4 oysters they were offering for the evening. The were all fantastic, but the sweetwaters were exceptional. Husband had the wild salmon special (loved it) and I had the cioppino. Best.Cioppino.Ever. Seriously. They should bottle the sauce. I'd buy it. It also came with the best garlic bread. We usually order a side of garlic bread anyway, but didn't this time. I'm still regretting it. :( Great service and great food. Every time. Love it!
author: Eme L.

description: this has to be the best seafood place in the city right??? its def my faveorite place to eat rodents of the sea! im not a huge fan of seafood, but this place is different than the rest. its in the heart of castro so the ppl watching is quality, but the wait is usually at least 2 hours...so don't go hungry and expect to eat quickly. great spot to take a date imo.
author: Morty S.

description: Oysters were great, but the Italian seafood stew and green lipped mussels were absolutely incredible!  Just knocked Swans out of my favorite spot for seafood in San Fran.
author: Mitch H.

description:
i went here for the first time yesterday and wow, what a STEAL!

for two, we ordered their daily pasta special (which was clams w/ white wine sauce & linguini), half order of an oyster/clam/shrimp combo, a crab burger, 2 cups of clam chowder, and half a liter of wine for $88. it kiiind of sounds like a lot, but i was extremely impressed with the portions of seafood they gave us. 

first of all, the "half" order combo came with basically a full size order of clams in a delicious light broth. i'm not sure if they did that because they were approaching closing hour or if it's usually that size, but i was amazed nonetheless. second of all, my crab burger had the most crab i've ever seen. it wasn't mixed with anything else, just pure crab with some tomatoes, lettuce, and homemade tartar sauce spread on a lightly toasted sesame bun. seriously, each bite was heaven. i even did a little dance while i was eating and the waiter brought the CD to my table thinking that i liked the music. hahaha! no sir, it is the oh-so-perfect crab burger that is making me dance. ;) the clam chowder is definitely one of the best i've ever had due to the consistency and flavor. the pasta was pretty good (judging from my 2 bites of it) and it came with a lot of clams. the waiter also continuously offered us bread which was a nice touch. andddd yeah, i was basically in love with the whole meal. 

the only con was the looongggg wait. you'd think that on a sunday night with 5 parties of 2 ahead of you it wouldn't take that long but i was very wrong. we waited for about an hour, but with impeccable service and great food you'll forgive them instantly for the wait. also, the place is pretty small so it's understandable. just don't go there hungry.

anchor oyster bar, i will be raving about you for awhile :)
author: Jessica C.

description: Really great fresh prawns, although the garlic sauce was a bit too salty for my taste.  Fantastic service.  Overall, great experience.
author: Fred M.

description:
This is a gem of a place on the quieter end of Castro. My wife and I stopped in for lunch last weekend and were shocked by the joy this meal brought us. 

I had a crab burger that was completely amazing. Beautiful taste! Perfect portion as well. My wife had a bowl of their clam chowder. She was simply shocked at how good it was. All of this for a very reasonable price. 

The house wine was great too. 

Seriously, this was a total gem. 

It's a very small place, I can see it filling up for dinner. Otherwise, if you're in Castro and looking for some fish this is the spot.
author: Adam M.

description: One of the top ten meals of my life. The steamer broth was so good we asked for straws. The service was friendly and warm. Be aware there are few tables so you likely will wait. It is worth it.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
I won't go into the detail already covered by the many reviewers about this place, but will definitely give this a thumbs up.  It is a very small place, serves good sized portions of very fresh and well prepared seafood.  There were 3 of us, we shared the Steamed Seafood Combination, a Crab Cake entree (that came with a salad and potatoes) and a liter of the house Chardonnay.  It was perfect.

I will definite come back when I visit the bay area.
author: Guy D.

description: Love this place! Always the freshest shellfish and the service is great! Very small inside but worth the wait.
author: Liz T.

description:
Hubby and I arrived at 11:25 am and waited outside until they opened, which is 11:30am. We are visitors and have never eaten cioppino but read the great reviews about it @this establishment. First of all, as a reference, the hubby does not usually like any soup or stew dish. We decided to order the large cioppino and when it came out, the smell was so good. We dug in, each with the garlic bread ( it comes with 2 large pieces). It was so good. The seafood was fresh and plentiful. The garlic bread was toasted just right. The man who served us ( think he was the owner) brought us more regular bread to scoop up any remaining juices. We ate it up and enjoyed every bite. The restaurant is small, about 6 tables and 5 bar stools, so get there early. We thought the service was good. Please be aware that this gentlemen not only took orders, but cleaned tables, and rung up our bills, so service might not be super fast. He was very friendly to us - we told him we were 1st timers. Would I come back here- yes, for sure. Just wanted to thank all my fellow Yelpers for a great recommendation. We will definitely be back next time we are in town.

Btw, they do have a restroom but u walk through the kitchen to get  there. It is small but very clean. The restaurant is very small but I think that is the norm for all these family owned places in San Francisco.
author: C C.

description:
We went at 3pm on New Years Day and there was no crowd and no line - Yay!  

Clam chowder is the best I've ever had in SF.  Very creamy and clammy, but not too heavy.  Tastes supper yummy with the endless supply of oyster crackers.

The special was a cheese open face sandwich with shrimp and crab in it.  It was a bit heavy and I think they could have done a better job of describing it on the menu.  It just said "seafood cheese sandwich" so we expecting something like a grilled cheese which it definitely was not!

I may be tempted to come back for the cioppino.
author: Josie M.

description: Best sea food and oyster bar in the Castro
author: Danny R.

description: I almost hate to write this review because these guys are so good and I don't want to draw a bigger crowd. I try to get there early so I don't have to wait for a seat. But, these ate the best oysters I've ever eaten. All of the food is of excellent quality and the staff is so friendly they are like family now. Sometimes they have clams on the half shell and they are a very special treat. Try the fish stew ( not on the menu). Their sourdough is just right for dipping into the bowl of stew. The restaurant is small but it's worth waiting for a table.
author: J B.

description:
i FINALLY got the chance to come here for lunch last week and i only work down the street! (literally... on castro and 18th!!) the place is small but since they do pick up orders... i decided to just pick up an open faced crab melt and a little cup of chowder. good call for the pick up order for me because when i got there... there was already a line. eeeppp!!!

i pick up my food and take a 2 minute walk down the street to each my lunch in my break room. they packed my sandwich perfectly.... and it was still fresh and pretty looking. most to go orders dont look like this! and my chowder with the complimentary bread... omg.. so delicious! i didnt even eat all of the bread they gave me because i had the sandwich as well... but man.. if i knew about their complimentary bread that came with the chowder, i dont think i wouldve gotten the sandwich! that's like.. 2 meals!!

the chowder.. yes. lives up to the hype for sure! the most delicious chowder i've ever had! esp with that bread! oh me oh my! and that sandwich... can't say its the BEST i've ever had. but it was DEFINITELY delicious as well!

i can't wait to go back and eat in the actually oyster bar... i'm definitely giving everything a try there! pricey.. but SOOO worth it!
author: amelia g.

description:
This is the best restaurant I have been to in San Francisco.  I have been there three times.  It has been consistent.  

I don't know or care if the sauces involve chicken stock.  All I know is that you will ask for more bread to soak it up.
author: Alex R.

description:
Yay, it's true what they say! There's only one place worth eating at on Castro Street, and it's Anchor Oyster Bar!

First, to start out, they gave out free clam chowder to those of us waiting outside, even though the wait wasn't that long. It wasn't the bgest clam chowder - I like mine a little thicker - but I'm not going to complain about free things.

The seafood sampler was delicious - great selection of oysters - so fresh, of course - as were the mussels in that amazing broth. As a previous reviewer noted, these are delicious crab cakes, the flavor really shows through.

And the bread is absolutely delicious! If they just let me dip their bread in mussel broth all night long, I'd be happy too.

Delicious garlic bread too.
author: Mark A.

description:
the food, the service, the decor, the atmosphere, the smell, the cozyness..


we loved it ALLLLL!!
must shout out to MIKE, our server. he was soooo sweet and friendly. 

here's what we ordered:
oyster shooters - DELICIOUS, im craving one as i type..
12 oysters on the halfshell - DELICIOUS
cioppino - i didn't have any, but it was almost all gone, and none of the girls were talking, too busy eating...so i'm assuming it was good.
cheesy garlic bread - holy mother of---SOOOO gooooood. super garlicky cheesy amazingness on thick cuts of french bread.
some pasta dish w/ mussels...again, this was almost all gone.
clam chowder - to DIE for. so hearty, perfect balance of saltyness and creamyness. Mike gave us an extra bowl, bc we had to wait a while for our table. so sweet, he didn't need to do that :)

he also threw in an extra 3 oysters for us, on the house.

i absolutely ADORED this restaurant. it's warm and welcoming. the staff was super friendly, the cook seemed like he really enjoyed his job, and you could totally taste it in the food. i'm already looking forward to my next visit when i'm in the bay!

Thank you Anchor Oyster Bar..we all left with happy and full stomachs.
there's a bit of a wait, if you go in a wknd for dinner---but the food and people more than makes up for it!
author: Tee L.

description:
This place has been my secret love since I moved to the Castro five months ago. In an entire neighborhood full of passable, uncreative food with steep prices and not a lot in the ambiance department, Anchor is a homey place with spectacular food and somewhat less steep prices. 

I CRAVE the clam chowder at least once per week, and since I'm self employed, I keep finding myself drawn to the place for a cream-based, high calorie lunch, with a side of carbs because you can't not get bread & butter to dip. I've strayed a bit, tried other things there, but the chowder, oh the chowder. 

In fact, it's a cold day, and I'm headed there now: to sit at the bar, read through my RSS feed, and to max out my calories. Who needs abs, anyhow?
author: jason l.

description:
As the wife was craving seafood, we decided to give the Anchor Oyster Bar a try after trolling Yelp for recommendations.

In general, we were quite pleased.  No, it's not cheap, but the food quality was quite high, and given the fresh shellfish, the prices were reasonable. 

Food highlights- 
   The New Zealand Green-lipped mussels were excellent.  They were not overdone and came in a wonderful seafood broth that had a hint of tomato and a mild kick to it.  The broth was so good that I decided to take the leftover broth home and use it as a base to make cioppino.
   The bay shrimp-stuffed artichoke served as a large appetizer for multiple people, and was wonderfully cooked.
   We had a special bottle of Chateau de Sancerre that really complimented the seafood well.

Food Cons- 
   My wife's mahi-mahi was a tad overcooked, although the green salsa verde that it came with was intensely flavorful and we both ate it with the roast potatoes and bread.

Other notes- 
   The chowder was tasty, although it did not really stand out.
   They do not take reservations, and there will be a wait, even at 9pm on a Wednesday night.  There is a comfortable bench outside, and our party was not bothered just hanging out and people-watching on a gorgeous night.  On a 40-degree rainy February evening, that might not be such an enjoyable experience, however.
   The atmosphere was bustling and the small size of the place definitely contributed to its charm.  The wait staff were attentive, yet at no time did we feel rushed through our meal, even when we stayed 45 minutes after the close of the night.
author: Patrick Z.

description: Went here during a cold windy night with momma tran and boy was it a magical experience. The wait was pretty longgg but totally worth it. We ordered the steam clams and the portions were outstanding! We were expecting a few shells and bunch of garlic cloves and parsley but it was just a bunch fresh big clams! Perfect with the garlic bread. The second thing we had was the cioppino, a lot of fresh seafood and mildly spicy. Small space and very intimate.. The prices are high but the freshness and portions trumps that. Just go and enjoy! Why are you still waiting? Haul ass!
author: Dennis T.

description: One of the best seafood restaurants I've ever been to. They don't take reservations so be prepared to wait about 30 min or more depending on the night, but it is well worth the wait. The Cioppino was out of this world, and the homemade rigatoni with steamed mussels was unbelievable! The chef is VERY talented. It's definitely not cheap, but the portions are huge! The service was great and the staff is so friendly.
author: Janina T.

description:
On several occasions, I've come across a well-reviewed restaurant on Yelp, only to find myself walking away disappointed due to the high expectations that fellow Yelpers had set for me.  Thankfully, my experience at Anchor Oyster Bar was not one of those moments.

On our first visit we were seated at the bar and had the clam chowder, the half Anchor Special, and the crab cake appetizer.  The chowder was nice and thick - creamy and buttery, oysters super fresh and cold, clam broth buttery as well, and chilled prawns huge and meaty.  The crab cakes aren't really worth mentioning, but I'm not a huge fan of crab cakes in the first place.

On our second visit we had a party of six and were seated at the bar again.  The server was apologetic about the hour wait and gave us a few orders of garlic bread on the house.  We split two full Anchor Specials among us for appetizers and each of us got an entree as well.  I went with one of the specials, a wild coho salmon which was served in a creamed vegetable stock with baby carrots and fingerling potatoes.  It ended up being more of a pot pie filling than a simple sauce, which was unexpected, but rather welcoming.  Another special was breaded scallops served on top of a bed of mashed potatoes - the scallops were really fresh.

If you go with the steamed clams or mussels, butter up some bread, break it up, and throw it in the broth to soak up while you eat the shellfish.  The Caesar salad looked really good, so the next time I go for lunch, I'll give that a shot.  I'm glad they don't serve dessert as it gave us an excuse to take a 10 minute stroll down to Bi-Rite for some ice cream :)

Service was spectacular both times - our water glasses were always full and the servers were really attentive without being overbearing.

It's nice having an oyster bar nearby instead of having to make the trek over to Swan or Hog Island.
author: Allen L.

description:
This cute little restaurant is amazing.
I love the garlic prawns, they are delicious. Also, they are one of the rare places in the city that serve Laurent Perrier champagne (which is my favorite).
The service is good and the food is great. I won't give 5 stars because there is usually a line to get in and we have to sit outside in the cold. Also their bread is not the best I've had.
But definitely a great place to go during the week and having champagne with prawns. Delicious!
author: Paula L.

description:
Wow!!! Finally an oyster bar I can sit at without my knees jammed up against the counter! (sorry Swan's) 

Unlike Swan's, Anchor's clam chowder is the real deal with nice chunks of clam and hearty pieces of potato. Nothing like water and milk mixed together with the nonexistent staples of a "Real" Clam Chowder!!! (sorry once again Swan's)

The daily specials are always fresh. I had the seared ahi tuna with saffron rice and covina beans topped with a chimichurri type salsa. UNBELIEVABLE!  Angela had a crab Caesar salad with probably a half pound of crab on it. It was amazing. 

The oysters are always fresh as well and regardless of what type of oyster you order they are all $2.50. They have great beers on tap and a great wine selection. The only drawback is the service is a little slow and if the place is packed you may wait awhile for a table but if you like seafood this is the place to be.
author: Jason C.

description: Great fresh oysters. However, its a small space so there may be a wait during prime time. This has a local charm feel to it and is a must for those seafood lovers.
author: Frank L.

description:
I don't like to give out five star ratings, but really... I can't find any reason to dock them a star.  The food here is damn good, and the service is very friendly.  The only down sides that I can see is that parking is very difficult in the castro.

I had one of their daily specials, a plate of breaded seared scallops and prawns prepared very similarly along with mashed potatoes and sauteed vegetables.  Everything was prepared just perfectly -- especially the scallops and prawns which were cooked just right.

I would absolutely recommend checking this place out.  Just be prepared to spend a long time searching for a place to park.
author: Robert P.

description: Arguably the best seafood restaurant in SF.  It is a small place with only 7 tables and about 10 counter seats so the wait can be long but the food is always great.  Plus there is no corkage charge so you can pick up a nice wine across the street at Swirl.  The chowder is always a hit. I love the Crab Burger, fresh dungeons crab, a tad on homemade tarter on a toasted bun. If you do not see it on the menu just ask for it.  Yum.  The cioppino is also a huge hit.
author: Julia B.

description:
A sliver of a place just beyond the most people dense part of the Castro.  I snag a seat at the end of the bar from where I can watch the chef at work.  The kitchen is remarkably small.  The oven and stove might come with a barbie doll set: teeny.  But what comes out of the kitchen isn't kid stuff.  My server was spot on and helpful, suggesting that if I was going to get the cioppino, then half an order of the caesar salad would be adequate.  He knew whereof he spoke.

The half caesar salad was generous and perfectly prepared.  Fresh romaine, slightly warmed croutons, and an anchovy dressing.  A refreshing way to begin. 

Cioppino was a bountiful serving of mussels, clams, sea bass, and crab in a spicy tomato broth accompanied by garlic bread.  The remarkable thing about the dish is that despite the assertive sauce each component of the plate was sea breeze fresh and retained its taste and character.  

Great place.  Great service.  Great food.  Great price.  Great value.
author: David D.

description: My favorite restaurant in the Castro. Outstanding, simple preparation of the freshest seafood. Have the steamers and garlic bread with a glass of California wine. Or the salmon or the swordfish or . . . you get the idea.
author: Frank S.

description: I really can't add much to what others have said.  Really long wait, but soooo worth it.  Go here.  Eat many many oysters.  Live a happy life--or at least have a happy mouth and tummy for the evening.
author: Ruth B.

description:
Great service. Great food. Even good classic jazz music. My new favorite!

I'd often walked by this place after hours and wondered about it, but I was finally convinced to go here by Check Please Bay Area!

I got here early evening on a weekday by myself so I was seated at the bar right away which is a beautiful slab (or two?) of cool marble. The menu is small and didn't have any one thing that sounded perfect so it took a long time to decide because everything sounded delicious. Then it hit me - a little bit of everything..

I ordered the recommended half a dozen mixed West Coast oysters (after being told that while listed on the outside menu, they did not have Kumamotos this evening), a cup of clam chowder, and the crab cake app as my entree. The oysters arrived artfully arranged on a bed of ice with cocktail sauce and fresh horseradish. Even the garnish of seaweed was beautiful. The horseradish raised the cocktail sauce to new heights. I prefer it to the vinegar stuff served at other oyster places. The oysters were sweet and delicate. The clam chowder was good and wasn't that thick gloppy stuff. Oyster crackers were readily available. The crab cakes were chock full of crab - not too much bread crumbs. All that and a glass of white wine was the perfect amount. The server was friendly and professional all evening.

A definite mix of patrons - families, seafood lovers, singles, couples. My only complaint was that in this tiny place, my entertainment was watching a dishwasher while seated at the counter.
author: Myla A.

description:
Pros: Yummy! Really good service, Michael was our waiter - he will really take care of you. If you are going with a group of more than 2 get the anchor special. The pasta with bodega bay clams in creamy marinara sauce is a must! Oysters are perfect especially the Kusshis from British Columbia.
Cons: The place is small, there are no reservations so most likely there is a wait. The service is a little slow so don't go here if you are in a hurry. The dungeness garlic crab needs some butter and lemon on the side.

Overall an excellent seafood restaurant!
author: Charlene I.

description: Fantastic fresh seafood! Go for the daily specials they won't let you down. Very tiny so typically crowded but always worth the wait.
author: Elizabeth J.

description:
Memories of Anchor Oyster Bar From One Visit:
1.) Delicious Food!
2.) Extremely Nice Customers and Staff!
3.) Many laughs about starting a bowling team.
4.) Great Prices in terms of Quality and Quantity.
5.) Guy next to me getting kicked out for being drunk and not waiting after telling me about his cocaine use.....

I loved Anchor and Hope. The garlic bread is the best I have ever had, sorry mom, and the oysters were among the best in the city, in terms of selection and freshness. I also enjoyed the shrimp that I tried, the potatoes, and the $13.00 small bottle of champagne, everywhere else it is at least $16.00.....

This place is super small and well known. There can be a wait, so I suggest either having a soup while you wait or going to Swirls across the street for a glass of wine and avoiding the cold and wind. It is worth the wait. I have never waited this long for seats in my life, but would I do it again, you bet!

In my opinion, this is by far the best restaurant on Castro Street!
author: Christopher W.

description:
Not many things in this world would compel me to drive across town in the rain to get to it, but Anchor Oyster Bar's Crab Sandwich is one of them.

OMFG - I think I seriously would drown a bag of kittens for a plate of these. Ok, maybe not drown, how about bathe? 

The crab is SO good, served hot with melted cheese and veggies on a bun....geez, I'm literally salivating all over my keyboard just writing this. Anyway - also comes with a fantastic bowl of clam chowder which is usually kinda gross most places, but here is fantastic. 

Eating the food here, you kind of get the feeling you are having something special - something not many people know about. Anchor has been both a revered staple of San Francisco and also a hidden gem for aver 40 years. If you haven't been, here's some tips:

-Get the freaking crab! (though everything is amazing)

-Prepare to wait if you come at prime-time dinner. They have VERY limited seating. Yes, I have seen them give some VIP treatment from time to time with the waitlist - usually doesn't delay you more than a few minutes and your taste buds will thank you for waiting!
author: Nick R.

description: Fresh, basic, highly executed, attuned service. Excellent location for those visiting the Castro and want a bite to eat. Parking is the only problem.
author: Ayala K.

description:
Came here a couple of weeks ago for lunch on a weekday and loved it.  I had the clam chowder (fantastic), garlic bread (so much!), and a special of the day: open faced crab sandwich.  All were fantastic and the service was great.

Can't wait to come back.  Definitely the best restaurant on Castro Street.
author: Courtney N.

description: Talk about one of the best meals I have ever had! I have told friends about this place whenever they come to San Francisco. Every time I am back in the Bay Area, I make a point to visit this particular restaurant. The coziness of the place, and the quality of the food, as well as the friendly staff and cook bring me in.
author: James O.

description: Definitely seemed like they could've cared less about our business since they had so many other customers anyway. Waited 2 hrs to sit down, 25 minutes to order after we did.
author: Andy L.

description: the castro... notorious...for lousy food... it has been a long hard road since stonewall, cant we get a decent meal on the Castro?  well we always have been able to...since 1978 ANchor has been shucking oysters, cool lovely oysters with a nice simple wine list and lots of tasty other treats! I have been eating here for years, and after a small break in the action I returned yesterday.. this is simply better than hog island better value nice people it is easier to get into than Swann... what's not to love here? if you like seafood then come eat it ...this is San francisco at our best! yesterdays  lunch? the full special for 40$ 12 oysters of various pedigree, a generous prawn cocktail and a big bowl steamed clams in wine with lots of garlic and oregano...heaven...washed down with a bone dry Riesling...might have to repeat again today...
author: Ricote F.

description: I come here at least twice a year.  An excellent little piece of the Castro. Fresh and lovely oysters, excellent staff.  Small but worth waiting outside for once in a while.
author: betty b.

description:
My favorite seafood place in San Francisco!  Super simple menu, and the most amazing seafood.  Service is friendly and impeccable!  Its not inexpensive, but its worth every penny.  The oysters are always delicious (try the kumomotos!) 

My tip is to just order something from the chef.  He is great at making things up.  So if you don't see something you like on the menu, just ask.  They are more than accommodating.  Believe me tho, you will probably see something already on the menu to make you drool.  

Very small and sometimes a wait, so expect that as a possibility and allow some extra time.
author: Lindsay C.

description:
Food AND entertainment!!!

If you don't mind waiting up to an hour (we waited for 30 minutes but got lucky, 6 other couples put their name down after us) and oogling naked men as you wait, you must try this place!! Here's a breakdown of everything i loved here:

The food: 5 stars!! The oysters were perfect, big selection, buttery, and FRESH. i would have liked a vinaigrette with them but the tomato/horseradish sauce was nice too. Our Cesar salad was the best we've ever had-seriously. We ordered mussels that were good but we are going back for the gazpacho...crossing our fingers that it will still be a special in the next week or two. It looked absolutely divine!

The Service: 5 stars!! Our server was efficient with a smile! He brought us more bread as we had to dip something into our mussels sauce. There were also some people trying to cheat and move their names up ahead of others and the other (there are 2) waiter was on it! Re-wrote everyones name in the right order and went back into the bustling restaurant to bring out food to patrons. I was fairly impressed as it's often hard for me to speak on the phone and tie my shoes at the same time.

The only drawback was the wait and the fact that there are no reservations accepted  for this place. Slightly inconvenient if you're starving, but the nice part is that it's in a neighborhood full of good food so if you can't wait, you can walk to the next yummy location!

Definitely recommended for smaller groups! will definitely go back!
author: nina B.

description:
After 2 visits, I'm officially hooked.  I love the seafood salad and the fresh-shucked oysters.  I've heard the pasta with shrimp and spicy sauce is amazing, but haven't been able to order anything but the salad...  It's just that good.

This is a tiny place that doesn't take reservations.  If you are worried about that, take turns shopping at Given next door while you wait.
author: Dina B.

description:
Who says gay men don't like fish?  Who says gay men don't like to go down on fresh briny oysters with red sauce?  This is the only restaurant that can convert bitchy gay men into clam-sucking seafarers.   

This is best seafood restaurant in the Castro.  Unpretentious...  Food lovingly crafted.  The meals are a bit square (always a starch and vegetable stacked mountain high with a huge piece of fish).  No cosmopolitans here, just really good, honest food.  

Locals who know this place always get the combination seafood salad.  Mounds of fresh crab meat and shrimp in home-made salad dressing (definitely get the creamy garlic dressing) with perfectly blanched carrot pieces.  

Skip "Catch" (mediocre seafood; people go there for the strong cocktails) on Market and skip "Woodhouse".  This is the best seafood in San Francisco.
author: Tom K.

description: I fell in love with this place today. The food was amazing. My boyfriend and I have the crab cakes as well as clam chowder. Both we're excellent but the clam chowder was OUTSTANDING. I will be back all the time for that chowder. The crab cakes and tarter sauce tasted very home made and I look forward to ordering it again and again. The Kitchen staff is amazingly kind. You walk through the kitchen when you are on your way to the bathroom. The ladies cooking give you big smiles and ask how everything is. Some of the most friendly customer service I've yet to experience in San Francisco. The tables are huge- I went during a non-busy time (2:00pm) and we felt there was lots of room once seated. By server assistant/busser was also the sweetest guy. He was very aware of what we needed at any time. When he brought our cokes he made sure to only fill half way and bring the can with the other half, no watery coke for me! In summary, I can't wait to return.
author: Tea F.

description: I'm from Massachusetts and I've never felt more at home in San Francisco. The clam chowder was spot on!
author: Sarah C.

description:
This cozy place is great, everything was amazing-- food, service, presentation and overall experience

She got the sesame crusted salmon entree.
I got a small green salad, 8 assorted oysters and the mahi mahi special
It came with some amazingly tasty mashed potatoes, asparagus that was not too soft and not too hard, and pretty carrot looking things

The small salad was also unique, with large chunks of stuff that was cooked down to make it softer and more pleasurable on the palate and stomach :)
The mahi mas thick, meaty but not too dry

Hers came with some rice thing and the rabbe? type of broccoli that was also the perfect consistency

The flavors on everything were optimally balanced, not too little, not too much
Bread, butter and water were immediately replaced when used

They Hoegaarden on tap and a nice array of wines as well as take Discover cards ( a rarity )

Who says you can't go on nice dates just because you are married?
author: G K.

description:
This tiny slice of heaven is AMAZING!  We made sure to get a table as soon as they opened (11:30 on Wednesday).  We sat at the very back table with our 8 year old in tow.  He did just fine, but it is not an easy place for smaller kids simply because of the size of the place.  Now to the important part.  THE FOOD!  I have been here twice and I have to start with two of each of the fresh oysters.  One would just be torture.  The fresh bread is always great to dunk into the chowder (a perfect 10) and the garlic bread is crazy good.  We like to save ours for the last part of our steamed clams (eyes roll back in your head clams).  The open face seafood sandwich was a repeat order for me.  Loved it and will have it again.  If you get a salad with your meal, be sure to ask for the garlic dressing.  OMG GARLIC DRESSING, I just renamed it.
The open kitchen has a sweet smiling chef clearly cooking from scratch  if you venture back into the kitchen (take a trip to the most clean ladies room you have ever seen) you will see the most fresh beautiful prepping going on.
The service is very friendly and casual.  Never an empty water glass or crumb left on the table.
This is clearly a local favorite as many of the people who came for lunch were welcomed by name (I want them to call me by my name).

A perfect San Francisco restaurant!  No wonder they have been around forever.

Oh and the simple yet beautiful decor was so pleasing....

AOB, I think I love you!
author: Jennifer R.

description:
I'm not a big fan of oysters, but I went there with my seafood lover friends. even though I am not the biggest fan of seafood, I still liked the place.

REALY fresh oyster, wonderful wonderful service, friendly and cozy place, the chain outside for waiting people is just so thoughtful and nice....just loved it, who knows, maybe even I become an oyster fan :)
If you are a seafood lover, you should definitely check this place out I think.
author: Gnaz A.

description:
Fresh oysters...hell, fresh everything. I've been going to Anchor Oyster Bar ever since I moved to SF ('97). 

When the "R" months roll around I jones for a platter of mixed east and west coast oysters. 

The specials they have are varied and interesting...very seasonal. 

The wait staff is very friendly. I believe that at least one guy there has been waiting there for at least 20 years.

This place is a  classic example of how to do it right...take one thing and do it well.

Fresh seafood is their thing.

NOTE: You can buy seafood to go there at AQ prices.
author: Jason M.

description:
Who says there's no good food in the Castro?  Oh right, that's me.  At least before I went to Anchor Oyster Bar...

The lovely Tom K. took me to Anchor Oyster Bar before we went to the Sound of Music singalong at the Castro Theater.  I didn't tell him that I don't like mollusks/bivalves/whatever you want to call them - I didn't want to break his heart because he seemed excited to go to Anchor Oyster Bar!  And I figured they would have other things besides oyster...and they definitely did!

We met at Anchor Oyster Bar at 11:30 a.m. on Saturday.  Rut-ro - it doesn't open until noon!  Good thing we were there right when it opened because the place was packed just a few minutes after 12.  This definitely seems like the kind of place where I'd want to kick back and have a longish lunch with some friends over wine...but we had to get a move-on to make it to the singalong.

Tom K. advised me to order off the daily specials menu - can't say it was the right choice because I haven't ordered off the standard menu, but I really enjoyed my entree.  I got the "crab burger" with a side of clam chowder soup (salad what?).  The waiter nicely explained all of the daily specials in detail, so I knew what to expect with the crab burger...which is that it's actually more like lump crab meat mixed together in a tartar sauce on a bun - not a crab cake on a bun (which he made sure to mention since I'm sure many people expect that).  The crab burger was so good - a nice, light (just the right amount of tartar sauce - not like a McDonald's Filet o' Fish) lunch.  The clam chowder was also tasty.  Other things on the menu of daily specials included a fish stew (which another friend devoured) and a stuffed sole (which Tom K seemed to enjoy also).  Daily specials ranged from ~$14 to ~$18 (most included a choice of soup or salad).  The standard menu is a bit spartan, but definitely enough for anybody who enjoys seafood - I'll have to go back for the crabcakes.  

The kitchen is tiny, and they do a great job making fabulous food in a tiny space.  The seating area is also tiny so I think there can be a bit of a wait...but definitely worth it.
author: Wendy L.

description:
If you're in the mood for anything fish, go here.

I head here an average of twice a week and almost always order some sort of combination of the following: Oysters on the half shell x6, Clam Chowder, Crab Cake appetizer, Caesar Salad, Cioppino (not on the menu but they usually can accommodate if you ask about it).

The food rocks. Sometimes you might even luck out with the house wine being a Marlborough sauv blanc. The caesar dressing, oysters, and the chowder are really some of the best I've ever had anywhere.

The only downside is that the place is pretty tiny... meaning you might not always get a seat and have to wait outside (in the cold) unless you want to go across the street for a few drinks at Nirvana to wait.

Oh, and if you need to go to the bathroom, you actually need to walk through the kitchen to get there... which is so awesome on so many levels that they really aren't trying to be like everyone else and are fine with being old school.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Sweet Lord above, why do oysters have to be so. fucking. expensive here?

I remember being in New Orleans during Mardi Gras, drunk off my ass, having just flashed my girls to a bunch a drunk frat boys and sporting ginormous beads, tottering into an oyster bar and paying a QUARTER (that's 25 CENTS) for an oyster. They grab them out of a vat of ice, shuck'em, and serve them with a wedge of lemon. All in under 30 seconds. Best oysters I've ever had and that is not the afterglow of a drunken haze. Oh no, I sat myself 
down and ate a dozen, and went back every day for more. 

So, the last time I was in geography class, I learned that New Orleans sits next to a nice sized body of water. Last I saw when I looked out my window, I saw a great big huge body of water out there too-absolutely fucking RIPE with oysters. 

Last time I looked, October has an R in it. R months mean lots of oysters, right?

So, why the hell are they so expensive here? Especially at Anchor? I had a 1/2 dozen today and a diet coke (served in a can, which I hate cuz it means no refills), and it set me back $17.  And it took almost 20 minutes to get them, with only one other table occupied. And who charges for bread? I know it's only 95 cents, but it's the principal of the thing. And I thought they were going to take the oyster crackers away from me, but shit I was hungry!  They don't even have a happy hour special.

BOO!!!!!!!
author: Tova S.

description:
After soliciting Yelpster advice on the best places to eat Kumamotos, we stopped in to Anchor this weekend.  The place is really small, but in a charming way.   Many people mentioned a wait, so we dropped by at an off hour between lunch and dinner and had our pick of bar or table seating.  The Kumos were excellent and we also had some Miyagis that were great.   

****Update 3/4/08
The food is incredible!  The best petrale sole preparation I've ever had.  They serve a handful of specials every night (I don't think there's a regular menu) and everything is excellent.  The wine list is not good, which is really unfortunate because the food is so great, and I'm not being a wine snob.   On the plus side, they don't charge a corkage fee and will happily chill it so you can bring something with you or look at the menu while you wait for your table then walk acoss the street to Swirl and grab a Viognier, Chenin Blanc, Champagne, Muscadet, etc to compliment your oysters or fish.  If you don't mind the extra step, I think it's great to be able to pair with exactly what you want.  It makes all the difference in the world!
author: P J.

description: Oh my gosh, our new favorite restaurant in our favorite city.  Totally worth the wait. Staff is super nice, food was off the charts fresh. My husband and I both had fresh dungeness crab (in season) steamed with butter.  It was excellent but I found myself ogling every dish that went by.  Everything here is a winner!
author: Lisa L.

description:
Worth the wait (which you're guaranteed to have). Very small place, but the food is amazing! Many choices of oysters - all amazing. The Cioppino is huge and amazing! Clam Chowder - some of the best I've ever had! I'd skip the crab sandwhich. It's good, but lots of things on the menu are better! 

It's on Castro street - a very interesting place to visit if you've never been before!!
author: Jamie T.

description: This place is among my top three restaurants in the city! The service is great, the place is super warm and cozy and the food is amazing! We have tried the clam chowder, garlic bread, cioppino, fish entrees and mussels. Everything is so YUMMY!
author: leah p.

description: I have been going to the Anchor Oyster Bar for decades, literally.  I am not sure why it has taken so long to write this review, unless on some level I don't want everyone else to know about it.  I mean, there are only 5 tables and the bar.  You've always had to wait a while to get in, but now it takes a long time because so many people have discovered it.  I used to live only blocks away; now I live across town but I still make my way down there at least once a month.  Best clam chowder this side of Boston!
author: Jeff S.

description:
My buddy and I just went there because we were looking for a place to grab a quick bite before catching our flight back to the office. After reading some of the reviews, I got worried that we may not find a spot to sit for an hour or so. I didn't need to worry. I guess 11:30am on a Monday isn't their busiest hour. Having said that, I can definitely see why it's a mad house in the evenings.

The clam chowder is THE BEST I've ever tasted. You know how some are too thick, some are too creamy, some are too watery, too this and too that. This one is simply perfect. I didn't even put anything in it because I was too afraid to ruin such a perfect chowder. The chowder was so good that the sourdough bread (which is part of the chowder order) didn't get any attention for the first half of the bowl. When I noticed the bread, i tried dipping it in the chowder. I couldn't believe perfect could get better.

Now here's the crazy thing. The clam chowder wasn't the tastiest thing I ate here. It was ...........drum roll.............. the deep fried oysters. I was so looking forward to the highly rated clam chowder that I actually just about forgot that the restaurant was called Anchor "OYSTER" bar. We tried the deep fried oysters and just about teared up at how delicious it was. Their homemade tartar sauce..........licking my chops now.......was so delicious. I would take a $49 flight to SFO just to have a nice meal there with my wife next time.
author: Kenny A.

description: This is the best seafood restaurant I have ever eaten at.  I say this with great responsibility. I have eaten seafood all over the country, as well as internationally.  I discovered this spot accidentally.  I have dined here upwards of a dozen times and it has exceeded expectations every single time and manages to be consistently blow my mind every time I take a seat here.  The small space yields an intimate atmosphere where you can watch each dish prepared through an open window.  You won't find fresher ingredients anywhere.  As someone who is a chef themselves, I go out of my way to visit anchor oyster because they manage to do the elusive:  serve simple dishes so fucking tasty that it is impossible to recreate.  I know food, and I know how to cook and I cannot replicate the dishes they serve.  You will wait.  You will stand in a line.  Go when they first open at 3 for easy service.  Order the special.  If not that, order the cioppino.  It is not on the menu, but the serve it on request.  It's about $30, but is the best god-damned seafood dish you will ever eat.  It's so good, it's unholy
author: christine h.

description: Very quiant...very good food.  Absolutely would recommend this place.  Be aware that they do not take reservations.
author: Clifton S.

description:
Soooo...I went here with my mom. Based on funness, it would be a solid 18 stars. But, after the 1 hour (they don't take reservations) wait, the garlic bread (3 stars), clam chowder (solid 5 stars), oysters (4.5 stars), halibut (2 stars), crab (3 stars...could have been 4.5 if they offered butter)...
I just ended up thinking that it wasn't exactly worth all the hype.
author: Kristen Y.

description: Can't get better then this :) evrything about this place is delicious n the interior design is awesome
author: Linda A.

description: Market fresh fish in the Castro! A true SF gem, shucking since Hector was a pup! The raw bar is excellent, the salads over the top, the entrees wonderful. If you want fish in the Castro, stay off of Market Street and come up the Castro to this sea star.
author: William M.

description:
I have a weird obsession with oysters where if I go too long without eating them, I begin inserting them into my daily conversation. Example below.

"How's your day going?" 

"Good, could use an oyster, but I'm on track to get you that document by end of day."

So when that happens, it's time for me to get oysters and stop being a weirdo. 

Living around the corner from Swan Oyster Depot and seeing the horrendous daily line full of tourists, my boyfriend and I decided to check out Anchor in the Castro. 

Sing it with me: OB-SESSED!

The oysters are phenomenal! We sampled all of the daily specials, though I have a special place in my heart for kumamotos - which were huge! (They are small oysters, but Anchor had ones that were bigger than usual.) They offer a variety of seafood options from clam chowder to seafood salad to seafood platters. They have a variety of beers and wines to complement each dish, though let's be honest, nothing beats oysters and champagne. 

The server was super helpful and offered oyster combos not on the menu. The space is small, but if you lurk outside before they open on Sundays at 4pm (like my bf and I did) then you will get first dibs on seats at the bar.

Sing it with me: HEA-VEN!
author: Defne A.

description:
Last night I'm waiting for my friend to show up because this is in her top five places to eat when she is in town and these two guy muffies, you know those preppie types with too much tan and starched khakis and I SWEAR TO GOD- a pink sweater tied over their shoulder, these two guy muffies looking like they just parked the yacht at Kennebunk are staring at ME, like I'm a white rhino escaped the zoo. In my own hood! Then I notice that I am the only female in the place. It is gay-maleorama. And tourist season. CRAP!

Now I love my gays, but visitors please note- women live in the Castro. No, we aren't contagious. Yes, it is not polite to stare. 

Food and service was fine, good place to get oysters if feeling too lazy to go to Zuni.
author: Krismet C.

description:
We came here on a Saturday afternoon for lunch and had a great time!
The tables were all taken so we sat at the bar.  This restaurant was a little too warm for me.  We ordered some beers to cool us off and they went down well.
The food took a little while to come so we enjoyed some more beer in the meantime.  The service was attentive.
We ordered the half order of the anchor special and it was some of the best oysters that I've had to date.  They were so fresh... tasted like they were just caught!  The clams were very tasty too.  My husband really enjoyed his crab cake sandwich and clam chowder.  We're looking forward to returning soon and tasting other items on the menu especially the fish stew which numerous tables were having that afternoon.
author: Lizete S.

description: This place rocks! My only complaint about this place is the size. Its a little cramp, so if the place ges busy (when isnt it busy), cluster-phobia can creeps in... With that being said, the food here is zee best. I am not even sure where to begin? everything we ordered were amazing!
author: Mike C.

description:
This place was definitely worth the wait! We got there at 7:49p and were seated about an 1 hour and 45 min later. I noticed a lot of people wrote their name down and then went walking around for an hour and made it back in time for their turn. This place has only 6 tables and about 6 seats at the bar. Another thing I noticed was that the people who came between 9-9:30pm were seated faster because the crowd was less and by that time most people finished their meal. While we were waiting outside one of the servers brought everyone some clam chowder. That was so nice and yum! Also, because we waited about two hours to be seated the chef came out and brought us delicious garlic bread on the house and told us thank you. All the employees here were very friendly.

Now my thoughts on the food- my husband and I had eyes bigger than our stomaches but we couldn't resist. We came all the way from San Diego and this was our first time. We ordered fried oysters, crab cakes, anchor special and 1/2 dungennes crab. I was seriously in a food coma after eating all this food. Fried oysters was the special for the night so if it's there when u go I highly recommend it. The tartar sauce went perfectly with it. Crab cakes were OK but it isn't a must have. I would pass on these next time. They were small and I tasted more of the fried batter than the crab. The anchor special was yummylicious! It came with three types of oysters, clams, muscles and shrimp. Everything was so flavorful and fresh. The oysters and shrimp were served cold and the clams and muscles came in this delicious sauce. The sauce was flavored with garlic, tomatoes, and a whole bunch of wonderful secret seasonings. The dungennes crab is not always in season but if it's there when you go you just have to try it. We ordered it hot and it was sooo good! The crab was cooked in garlic, butter, pepper and other seasonings that just made it sooo tasty. The crab was soft and almost melted in your mouth. There were nice chunky pieces too. 

Next time, I want to order the Cioppino. It's not on the menu so you just have to ask for it. I didn't find out about it until the end when I saw other locals ordering it. Apparently it's a very popular dish and it looked really delicious too!

We chatted with one of the employees and he said that the owner does the cooking on Friday and Saturday nights. It's great to go to restaurants where the owners do the cooking and are managing their restaurant. You know you are going to a good place when the owner does the cooking. It definitely showed in the dishes we ate.
author: akemi a.

description:
So I'd walked by this place a million times through my Castro crawls, but the pungent smell of fish as I walked by always struck me as a bad sign. (No Name Sushi, are you listening? Was I listening? More on that later.) Another friend had warned me about it as well, but last Sunday I was an overly amiable dumbass and went along with my other friends who said they'd been before. 

The food--I have to admit--was actually tasty. The chowder was creamy and my sole was nicely breaded. Prices weren't too steep for what we got. The place is tiny and they have one server, so be prepared to wait for, well, anything. So why only one star?

Well that's the part I was getting to: Several hours later, I woke up at 4 am, doubled over with stomach flu. Lasted another 24 agonizing hours. Shoulda listened to my nose in the first place.
author: Aaron L.

description:
This is my first time at Anchor Oyster Bar, and I now have it marked as a place I would definitely go back to. The place was intimate. The wait staff was very attentive.  

Good suggestion on the salad dressings to go with the crab salad--their creamy garlic dressing.  

I also had my first crab cakes in my life (I'm 42). I expected crab cakes to be very dense, but wow, they weren't--there's a airy factor to them.  I got to experience these three amazing hockey puck-sized yummies with tiny tip-of-your-finger-sized potatoes and a large-sized side salad. I was skeptical about those weird little potato things at first, but found out quickly that they were also very very good.

The place is pricey, but well worth it--$23 or so for three excellent quality and tasty crab cakes, potatoes, and a side salad.  My friend treated me, but I can't wait to treat her next time.  Just an excellent meal--I look forward to many more at this place.
author: Priscilla L.

description:
I didn't want to write an excellent review of my favorite seafood restaurant, because it's already too hard to get in.  But with so many people already saying how great it is, I don't think this review will be the tipping point.

In short, it's the place to go when you just want to get the best seafood you'll ever have prepared perfectly without over-doing it.  And the price?  You may look at the menu and think it's pricy, but it's not.  Why?  Because what you get is a generous portion of great seafood - best value in town, and I'd defy anyone to get seafood this good even raw by the pound for the same price.

Oh, and I thought I didn't like raw oysters until I had theirs.  The rest is history.
author: Stephen G.

description:
First off, this place scores points with me for simply being the quaint 30 year established neighborhood spot that it is, I just love that. The small room with its marble topped bar and exposed kitchen makes for a cozy space which the servers navigated admirably.

Okay, the clams were small, prices on the high side and beer taps not working, but the oysters were fresh and yummy and the smooth clam chowder was the perfect antidote for a cold winter day.  My lunch mate enjoyed the enormous crab burger but I can't vouch for it, I was too busy soaking up the wonderful broth the clams came in with copious amounts of sourdough to bother trying his sandwich.

It would be nice if there were some accent sauce options for the oysters on the half shell akin to what Eos offers (and a happy hour discount wouldn't be bad either) but all in all I was quite a happy clamper.
author: GIR ..

description: Write your name on the board, take a seat, then countdown to a magical experience you are about to embark on......Cioppino! Ciopinno! Cioppino!  It will have you screaming more, moar, moore....The bread will be tempting at first, but save your belly and order an extra side of the Garlic Bread...You will thank yourself later, as you sop up the juices from the delicious......?????......Cioppino, silly!  As a rule of thumb, dip into the white sauces first, then dip into the red sauce, then try not to dip back into the white sauce, for you will surely be disappointed..  For all you crackheads, be warned: this stuff will have you craving and coming back for moar!!!!  (No corkage fee too)...EFF INN Amazing!
author: Johnny P.

description:
I've walked by this place for many years without trying it. What a mistake! Since I did try it a few months ago, I've been back many times. The seafood is fresh and they have different dinner specials every night. I love their salads which are quite generous. 

And you have to have the chowder...I don't really want to know how many calories are in it -- and I only have a cup anyway. LOL. 

There is a limited but serviceable wine list.
author: Jeffrey H.

description: The regular menu is focused (small) in this cozy (small) eatery near the edge of the commercial part of the Castro. No reservations means you might have to wait, but there are few places around the block worth checking out in the meantime (for wine, check out Swirl across the street). Even though the regular menu is small, it's definitely reliable (clam chowder, oysters, steamed shellfish or in cocktail form, various salads w/ or w/o seafood, delicious crab cakes), and there's a possibly even better set of specials each night. The sides and accompaniments to the dishes tend to be simple to the point of un-exciting, but the seafood always, always shines. Definitely one of the top seafood joints around.
author: Alex C.

description:
This place never fails to disappoint.  Because it's small, you should expect a wait at popular times even then they served us a lovely shrimp cocktaiil

The server, Mike, is helpful and the service was attentive.  I had the special seafood gazpacho which was amazing! The crab and shrimp meat was so fresh and delicious -- the shrimp was meticulously cleaned and dry (i hate wet shrimp) which made it so special.   I also ordered the scallops which were nice, but too heavy for me -- i would get the tuna (my friend ordered) next time

i can't wait to come back - it was about 5 years before my last visit and remember why I love the place so much.
author: Marty E.

description:
5 Star Food, less-than-dateworthy ambiance. And, I ate my own bodyweight in seafood.

Mixed app oysters: must order. 

Shrimp: so good you don't need cocktail sauce. 

Clams with garlic butter, lemon & parsley: yum.

Italian Seafood Stew: swimming with seafood (not alive.) 

Seared Tuna w/Myer Lemon & Caper Vinegrette, Wax Beans, & Roast Potatoes: you could eat shoelaces in the vinegrette it's so good. I don't even like potatoes, and the potatoes were awesome.

Even the horseradish was good.

Just don't sit by the door.
author: Dina G.

description:
My long distance girlfriend has yet to be wowed by any of my favorite restaurants in SF.  In fact, when I took her to Avatars to tell her I love her, she vomited directly after I put it out there.  Don't worry though; she came back from the bathroom 10 minutes later with a flushed face and returned the sentiment.  

However, while its good that such a selective person chose me, it still bothers me that she didn't share my high regards for san tung, marnee thai, koo, tulan, etc.  

We stumbled upon the Anchor Oyster Bar only because we were craving oysters.  But it ended up being quite an enjoyable time all the way through.  

Cozy atmosphere, knowledgeable and friendly staff, crab-rich crab cakes (rare), great wine selection, and most importantly, an outstanding variety of oysters.  

Not only did I really like it, my love loved it, which makes me like it even more.  

On a side note, if anybody knows a place to take a critical eater, I'm all ears.  Thanks
author: Andrew F.

description: OMG! All the great reviews underestimated the excellent experience we had there!  The food, the service, the experience were ALL outstanding!!  Definitely going back...again and again and again...
author: chris r.

description:
Wow! How did I live in the neighborhood for 15 years before trying this place?!? Perhaps because there is often a line out front. Well that should have been an indication of the quality of the food. 

We have been here three times and each time was a treat! The freshest seafood I have had in a long time. Beautifully prepared and in a down to earth setting. I'm so bummed that I didn't try it sooner. Now that we don't live in SF anymore, we make a point of trying to go every time we go back to visit now.
author: Andrew S.

description: I have eaten at every seafood restaurant in SF. This teensy place is amazing. First they serve food between the evil hours of 2:00 and 5:00. Second they serve inspired food. We had the oysters of the day Kisshu, French Kiss and Wellfleet. Completely loved the French Kiss, creamy and just rich enough. The crab cocktail is a full cup of fresh crab. The ceasar salad has freshly made dressing and fresh soft but toasted croutons. The portion could easily be shared by two. We also tried their regular clam chowder and their special crab and corn chowder. The chowders were smooth and creamy and not broken. The crab corn chowder was sweet and rich and decadent with smoked paprika accenting the rich taste. Really good bread from panorama and soft butter. We were there at three ish apparently after five thirty when the dinner menu starts they get slammed. The place only seats about 20 people. Little noisy because the washing station is in the dining room and when they use the blender you can't talk. Bath is NOT ADA accessible.
author: Carol m.

description: Clam chowder was delicious. The atmosphere is nice and everything was very fresh and good. Yes, the oysters are amazing.
author: Fred O.

description: My boyfriend and I randomly came upon this place and it was such a fun lunch experience. It's expensive but the food is really good and you get a ton of it. The atmosphere is old school but nice and they play music from the 40s and 50s. Their famous garlic bread is really good but we so already stuffed when we ordered it, so I wouldn't recommend ordering it later on. Everything is so filling. It's a fun place especially for a date so I recommend going!
author: Rose1987 S.

description:
YUM!!!

Between two people we shared a bowl of the best clam chowder in the city (hands down!) and I got a ciopinno and my friend got the ahi tuna. Seriously we were silent for 30 minutes just straight stuffing our faces. 

The service was awesome, the waiter was friendly and when I asked if the ahi tuna was served raw (when I meant rare) we both started laughing really loud. This is a GREAT place for a date! I think it's hard to fit a group in here though, cause the space is not huge, but I prefer that :)
