Also the ciopinno was the size of my head, which is huge, so I couldn't finish it, and the waiter suggested we pack it up and serve it over pasta the next day. GREAT IDEA!!!

A+!!!!
author: ting b.

description: Holy jumpin johosafats! The best cioppino I have ever had. Who cares about the wait time. What if you only live once?
author: christopher c.

description: I had to try this place since it is soo close to my house and I love seafood. I got the pan fried oyster special which was cooked perfectly to my taste, along with a cup of chowder. Definitely not the best or thickest chowder I have had, so down one star cuz of that. The steam clams were pretty decent as well. Not that big of an oyster fan, but I am originally from Washington/Vancouver area. When all the oysters are from my old hood, it is hard to see what is special about it.
author: Minh V.

description: I've been here twice now, both times I would rate both the food and the service 5 star. First visit SO and I both got the cioppino. It ain't cheap, but it's to die for!!!  Second time we both chose a lunch special: I got the crab/shrimp melt and SO got the crab burger. Both amazing and just perfect. We shared the steamed green lip mussels to share as our starter. They were heavenly. I just can't say enough good things about this place!!  The only downsides, if I had to list any, would be that it's tiny inside and it's pricey. For what you get the price is justified.  Will definitely be back!!
author: Julie A.

description:
I read the reviews and checked this place out with my wife during our visit over Labor Day Weekend and I guess to me the place did not live up to the hype.

The food was tasty - the service was good ... but that's it.

Nothing special in my book.

I had the half Anchor Special and my wife had a prawn & pasta dish that wasn't on the menu. We both enjoyed our meals and the food was good but this place isn't anywhere near 5 stars.

We waited about 30 - 40 minutes for a table for two on a Sunday.
author: Mark S.

description:
Sure, it's small inside, but the food is pretty amazing.  

James and I both had the chowder (great flavor and thickness, just the thing to watch oyster crackers drown in) and salmon special.  The salmon special was a farm raised Scottish salmon with mashed potatoes and vegetables.  The potatoes were great, the vegetables were acceptable, and the salmon was great -- flaky and tender to the point of nearly melting.  

The waiter claimed the salmon farm was so humane PETA approved; I can only assume that humane farms make delicious salmon.  Note that we were both skeptical of PETA approving a salmon farm but with fish this good we were willing to suspend our disbelief for the 90 minute meal (hear that Michael Bay? it's not acting skills that Pearl Harbor was lacking, it's really delicious salmon).
author: Nathan Y.

description: I am not sure how I've missed this spot in my many travels to SF, but I am glad I found it.  I ate here several times on a recent trip to SF.  Anchor Oyster Bar delivers with fresh food and fantastic flavors.  I would suggest eating here during lunch or during the week as the place is small and thus a line forms for a table.  The staff was friendly... the place is lovely.... its really a wonderful spot in middle of the Castro.  Everything I have had here is really good.... I do not think you can go wrong with any item on the menu.  If you like seafood, you must eat here... I hope you will enjoy eating here as much as I did.
author: David C.

description:
The seafood is amazing here and the team is so friendly and nice.  Everything on the menu is delicious - my father who can be cantankerous and picky loves it too!

This is one of my favorite neighborhood spots!
author: Cheryl E.

description: This place is incredible.  Simple, deliciously prepared food.  No pretension, just fresh seafood in a cozy environment.  Best place in the Castro for sure.
author: Stephanie S.

description: I dont understand the why the long lines for this place. We sat at the counter and the taste of our dishes was overwhelmed by the dirty dishwater smell wafting directly in our faces. The dishwashing sinks being directly in front of us also wrecked our experience as the constant noise of the dishes and sink hose was really distracting. Mediocre seafood at high prices.
author: LT B.

description:
This is a no nonsense belly up to the bar and eat some good ass oyster's kind of joint!

What can I say...first off the decor is quaint and charming...the anchor motif is classic.  The service is excellent especially if you are sitting at the bar.  There choice in beer is small but solid. 

The real reason to come here and continue returning time and time again is the oyster selection. They always seem to have a fresh batch of oysters from all over the place.  Even though I have not sampled the other seafood specials, they all look and smell delicious! 

The garlic bread is decadent and dangerous all wrapped in one.
I highly recommend this as well as the Cesar salad; it looks like they make there own dressing and croutons.  

The croutons might I say, are dynamite! 
(My guess is that they are made from the same outrageous ingredients that the garlic bread is constructed of)

Back to the seafood.... if this place is packed full of people it only means that you should put your name on the waiting list and hang tough...This place rocks on a late Sunday afternoon if you are looking to down some tasty oysters and brew and or a liter of the house wine...thumbs up all the way! Cheers!
author: Scott P.

description: This place is much smaller than the typical restaurant. Felt like I was in a diner. The place only seats about 15-20 people and with the staff running around you barely have room to move! Because of this i felt i was yelling to talk to my lady sitting shoulder ro shoulder beside me! The oysters were good & fresh, the seabass my girl had was delish,the clam chowder was a little watery, the pasta with crab was tasty not anything to brag about. Oh yeah they don't have a bar(select wines & a few beer choices). Staff was courteous but this is not my idea of a quiet & romantic place for a date! With a couple of beers though it made for a good time.
author: Howard T.

description: This place was great.  Atmosphere is fab in the middle of the thriving Castro district.  Garlic bread is unbelievable!! Oysters, clam chowder, and  cioppino all outstanding.  Would definitely go back.
author: Colleen S.

description:
I celebrated my 30th birthday with a visit to Anchor Oyster Bar and it was literally one of the best meals I've ever had. I shared a half order of the Anchor Special (the steamed clam sauce was incredible), garlic bread (absolutely divine if you like garlic), and a blue nose NZ sea bass special with umbrian farro, spinach, and steamed vegetables (my favorite). The flavors were simple yet left me saying "wow" and "oh" after every bite (no seriously I did, you could confirm with my date). We ate at the bar and enjoyed the ambiance and intimate setting. For the quantity and more importantly, quality of our food, I felt like I was getting a bargain. The bill was ~$65 including wine.

I strongly recommend this restaurant!
author: Shelley J.

description: If you love oysters go to Anchor Oyster Bar. Going with 6 people to an already small restaurant proved challenging. Service was very friendly even giving me hot clam chowder as I waited in the cold as the others sat at an empty table inside waiting for our real table. When a small table was ready, they seated us, although cramped. The clams were excellent. The server explained each and every detail of each type of clam they had for us.
author: Spencer Y.

description: Went again last week and it was the best meal ever! We started with clam chowder, then had Caesar salary with crab (the best Caesar salad and crab ever - tons of crab), then shared crab cakes (1 each with tartar sauce and lemon - delicious), then had Cioppino to share. The Cioppino was outstanding - the shell fish fresh, the soup delicious. Such a great meal - definitely a MUST for the Castro. Bon appetit!
author: Lee J.

description: Forgot how good this place is...  I first tried Anchor Oyster Bar 12 years ago soon after moving to San Francisco -- took my mom there for some sea food.  It was delicious.  Twelve years later, my mom back in town, we decided to check it out again:  awesome.  The crab meat, shrimp and prawn "mixed cocktails" were super fresh.  The special pasta calamari was also quite good -- not too heavy, excellent flavor, great al dente pasta.  My mom had the Alaskan cod with potatoes and mixed vegetables and found the cod to be "fresh and well seasoned." They don't take reservations, so don't be surprised to wait 15-30 mins. for a seat.  You won't regret it. This is a gem of a restaurant that I hope never goes away.
author: Rudolph R.

description: I don't know why I went back here. Horrible service. Waiter completely forgets our order. Second time this happened.
author: Ddc C.

description:
Great hole-in-the-wall restaurant in the Castro with exceptional seafood dishes! (although, I did see this place featured on TV as a must-try restaurant, heh).  

We love oysters, so anything with "oyster bar" in its name is totally game!  So, we came here for dinner to give it a try -- we were very very happy that we did!

We were there around 5PM and they weren't serving dinner yet until 5:30PM, so we decided to just hang out and wait it out.  They were, however, still serving their lunch specials/menu, and on it was a crab and shrimp sandwich -- we though, why not?!   
It was by far, THE best crab and shrimp sandwich I've ever had!  

As if that wasn't enough, they finally put up their dinner menu and we ordered two fish plates (apparently, even their servers don't know what they're going to serve for dinner until someone actually gets a list and writes it up on the board).  It was delicious!!  Their seafood is so fresh and so tasty!  And, service was also great!

We would definitely come here again!
author: Crys L.

description: Really like the place. Did not have reservations so we waited for about 20 mins. Very small and tight. Sat at the bar, had a beer, an order of raw oyster sampler and  the clam chowder. The Raw Oyster sampler was really good, they had 6 different types so it was an experience. The cup of clam chowder is pretty small and a little water down.  I really wanted a t-shirt quotes on the back "30 Shucking Years" so I will be going back in the near future!!
author: Mason T.

description: Oyster Shooter to start!  My husband and I went to Anchor Oyster Bar on a Sunday, and couldn't have been more impressed!  I got a dozen oysters on the half shell that were mixed.  8 east coast/canada and four from the west coast.  I loved it!!!   The west coasts are of course my favorite....but that's personal preference.    My hubby got fettuccine(he loves his pasta) that had calamari(perfectly grilled) shrimp and clams.  It was on the specials board for the day.  It had herbs and tomatoes as well, and had a bit of broth at the bottom of the bowl.  Divine!!    we shared a cup of chowder, and it was delicious.   Good wine selection as well.
author: Jeffrey M.

description:
I have been here a few times before and just had dinner here again last night. I stopped in by myself and sat at the bar. For a Tuesday night, the place was fairly busy and unfortunately very slow service was a result. 

I had half a dozen oysters on the half shell to start. They were fresh and briny, but aren't most oysters in the Bay area. I also had the Asian style ahi tuna special. It was very good as well and cooked to a perfect rare. The tuna was also a very high quality.  One might initially feel that the prices are a bit high for the small 'oyster bar' atmosphere.  But once you compare the price to the quality of food, it is definitely in line.

Even though the food is fresh and flavorful, I really with they could speed up the service a bit.. But even with the slow service I experienced last night, I will most likely be back for more fresh seafood and the cute, cozy atmosphere.
author: Philip D.

description:
Oh hot dayamn, this is my jam...

5* for the food & service.  I go there for my oyster fix, and I got it with their seafood platter:  1 dozen oysters, 8 steamed clams (in delicious garlicy sauce... be sure to dip your bread in it!) & 4 ginormous prawns for...$35.   A half-platter goes for $20, in case you're not afflicted with a case of Miss Piggy like me.  

Don't expect a huge menu.  Go for the oysters.  

Get there early - the place is relatively tiny.  If you get there after 6:30p, be prepared to wait.  

Did I mention you should go for the oysters?
author: Doreen S.

description:
Maybe 4.5 stars because it's sooooo small and thus usually you have to wait for 20...er...40 minutes.  But this is, per yelp 5-star caption, as good as it gets.  I usually split the anchor oyster meal (a dozen oysters plus some other seafood) with my g/f.  The crab salad is a great value pick...especially to those who have picked crab.

Good service, too, when this place could be aloof or exclusive if it wanted to be.

Go, for crying out loud.
author: Rawley V.

description:
I am a fan, but I would choose other places in SF to get my fresh seafood fix.  I thought the menu was a little thin, and it was a bit expensive.  Overall the quality was good and tasty, and the service attentive.

We had oysters to start, then clam chowder, shrimp cocktail, and split a crab cake entree.  The crab cakes were by far the star, the best I have had.

Overall a great experience, just not a value for the price.
author: Ken p.

description:
My party of four waited a good hour for a table in this sliver of a spot that seated probably no more than 30 diners. It's tiny; not a place you'd want to carry on for long, if you care at all for courtesy. Its minimalist nautical interior theme prepares you for a simple yet satisfying menu. 

Fresh seafood cravings are often an easy fix in the city by the bay but Anchor delivers. Order the Anchor Special if you are with company. I would return simply for their ravioli with a zesty lemon-butter cream sauce, piled with a generous heap of succulent crab meat. Mmmm. Wash down with their house chardonnay.
author: Ramona P.

description: The seafood was great.  Got the raw oysters, clam chowder, Dungeness crab sandwich, and seafood stew.  All were great, but especially good was the seafood stew.  It was huge and very much like a chioppino.  It came with large garlic breads that was great to dip in the sauce.  Price was a bit stiff, and place was a little cramped, or else it would have been 5 stars.
author: Jim T.

description:
I love everything about this place. I was looking for good cioppino that wouldn't break the bank, and I gave this place a shot. Since it's not crab season yet, they serve "Italian fish stew" which basically means cioppino without crab. It was 26 bucks and more than enough to feed two people. Most people have covered the basics so here are my highlights:

- these were the most perfectly cooked mussels I've ever had. It's so easy to overcook them in a cioppino, and I don't think I realized what a truly fresh, tender mussel could taste like until I had the stew here. They've ruined mussels for me anywhere else, forever.
- the service was so friendly and helpful! Not a single person working at the place was anything but gracious and attentive.
- since you have to squeeze through the kitchen to get to the bathroom, I got to see the cook doing her thing. She was so sweet! Everybody who works here is so cheerful!
- wonderful music! It's a hot October day and they were playing old Ella Fitzgerald and it really helped cool off. The atmosphere was classy but unpretentious. Lots of sweet men from the neighborhood taking their mamas out for seafood.

I want to come back soon and bring my grandma. I loved my meal and will definitely come back!
author: Diana S.

description:
It was a cold and windy night when three friends and I were determined to eat at Anchor Oyster Bar. We waited outside for upward of 40 min. in biting wind for a table, and we were rewarded greatly. 

Awesome waiter move no. 1 - We all got small servings of the clam chowder (on the house!) served to us outside to help keep us warm. 

Awesome waiter move no. 2 - Once we were seated, he placed an order of their terrific (and warm) garlic bread on the table to help us warm up (again on the house!)

We agreed to share the Caesar salad and each ordered an entree from the daily specials (unfortunately my companions were not oyster fans - poor planning on my part.) The Caesar was excellent and the dressing was obviously made on site. We all noted a taste of horseradish which really livened up the salad. 

We shared entrees and they were all fantastic. I had the breaded scallops, with vegetables, potatoes and homemade tartar sauce. Cooked perfectly, the scallops were tasty and the home made tartar sauce pushed them over the top. 

Service was top notch. 

Food was amazing. 

Will I go here again? Absolutely.
author: Kemp M.

description:
Be warned that normal conversation is difficult when this place is full.  It gets loud and you may leave with a headache or ringing in the ears.  Like too many SF restaurants, they haven't done anything to try to keep the noise down - and they play music on top of all of it.  I can't imagine the long term effect on the hearing of the people who work here.

Having said that, this is an excellent restaurant.  It is amazing what they produce out of that tiny and immaculate kitchen.  

Get there early to avoid the line and be willing to sit at the counter.  There is only one waiter for the whole place.  On a recent visit we were seated for half an hour before the waiter took our order.  It didn't bother us, but not the place to go if you are on your way to a movie or otherwise have a deadline.  

They don't serve dessert (small place has to turn over tables quickly).
author: Bay G.

description:
Like rediculously good oysters? - Yes please!
Like a small, but quaint atmosphere? - yes please!
Like really nice servers? - yes please!

I've always walked by this place and never popped in until Friday night.  My hubbie and I planned on stopping in to have some oysters and drinks before heading on to Ararat for dinner.  It never happened because we were seduced by the CRAZY delicious seafood here.  We got an assortment of oysters and then we thought, well how about a seafood cocktail - this was HUGE and really good.  Then we thought, forget it, we're eating here, forget Ararat and we had the clam chowder and shared the Cioppino.  BTW, the cioppino is huge, so if just one of you is ordering it, they will make a half order, even though the menu doesn't say so.

Only four stars because the wait can be pretty long since it's so small.

Otherwise - Loved, loved, loved it.  Will definitely be back.
author: Kate B.

description:
A small inviting spot for an intimate dinner. A must is the cioppino, its got a fabulous spice, kinda spicy-kinda sweet I think they may use roasted tomotoes in their broth, and don't forget the oily and crispy sourdough for dipping- very YUM!

The monochromatic surroundings, of the stainless steel kind, help in focusing and heightening your tastebud experience. The servers are fairly attentive but I liked that they minded their business some because I was there with my sweetie and we enjoyed the subdued atmosphere and opportunity to conversate. 

Decent wines and some good mid-week price specials. Relaxing yet slightly decadent dinner rendevous!
author: Adrienne P.

description: Our high expectations for Anchor Oyster Bar were unfortunately only partially met. We came here on a Saturday afternoon following a matinee performance and added our name to the wait list. After about 30 minutes, we got seated at the end of the bar, which felt pretty cramped. To start, we shared clam chowder and garlic bread, both of which were quite good. We then ordered the shrimp salad and the garlic prawns with potatoes and vegetables. N enjoyed the prawns dinner, but the shrimp salad was a big disappointment: a basic, somewhat chopped salad (some of the large pieces of vegetables were awkward to cut further) with a pile of shrimp thrown on top. I feel bad saying this, but it looked and tasted like something I might have made at home using a bag of frozen shrimp. Not even close to being worth the $20 they charged. If we return at some point, I'll definitely be more careful about what I order.
author: Dan S.

description: Tried crab cakes and steamed clams. Crab cakes are delicate and fried crispy. Steamed clams are served in soup richly flavored with oil and garlic. Highly satisfied. Despite popularity, they do not take reservations. Be prepared for a long queue.
author: Kiyoshi F.

description:
When I moved to the Castro 6 years ago and spotted this place (actually, I had driven by before but never stopped) I had a momentary vision.  Could this be as good as Swan Oyster Depot.?

Alas, no.  Decent enough seafood, but not up to Swan's standars.  Maybe closer to The Elite Cafe on Fillmore.  

Anyway, we go in a pinch, but the fact that it is a 4 minute walk and we only go a few times a year, but trek across the city to Swan 10 times a year pretty much says it all.  Just average fish dishes.
author: hOWARD y.

description:
My favorite thing here? The old wait people, who've been here forever.  Entertaining to watch them in action

Clam chowder, very good, if I get dragged here again, I'll order it again, but I like Swan's on Polk better.

Crab cakes - awful, among the worst I've had, and I eat them where ever I see them on a menu.  So bad, I picked at one, gave the other to a homeless guy.

Oysters - a fine choice here

Daily pasta w/seafood - ho hum

Steamed clams - a bit over cooked.  The sauce had red pepper which made it too spicy, they should do a lot of garlic, butter & white wine instead.

The bread - they charge for it, and it's not fab

The Cesar salad - 2 stars

I think that a serious problem here is that there is a new chef.  I was watching him and he didn't seem that into it.  Maybe its the cramped kitchen?  If that's the case, they might offer less so they can do a few things perfectly.
author: Cinnamon Z.

description: This is by far the best place to take your date. They have the best oysters, seafood cocktails and fine dine dinner entrees. This restaurant is the only reason I'd go to the Castro.
author: Carlos G.

description: Their garlic prawns were the best seafood I've ever eaten. My partner had the Anchor Special (oysters, clams, and chilled prawns) and said it was perfect. The food was beautifully presented. The place is clean and neat. The decor is appropriate. The servers were friendly and knowledgeable. I can't think of anything that could make it any better. Even the coffee was great.
author: James S.

description:
3.0 STARS FLAT

I don't understand by this place is rated so high on yelp.  i find this place very mediocre.

I had the ANCHOR SPECIAL which is 1 dozen oysters, 4 chilled shrimp, and steamed clams.
The oysters are good...but not $2.50 EACH good.  I've had better oysters with cheaper price in the city before...so yeah, wasn't too impressed.  The shrimp..well, it's shrimp...not as fresh as i had hoped.  The clams were very mediocre...actually, they were kind of overcooked.  The steamed clam's soup was ok...not impressive.  

I also had the NEW ENGLAND CLAM CHOWDER.  Well, I lived in new england for a number of years, so yeah..it's not even close to being as good as boston's clam chowder.  But for the west coast, it's not bad at all.  Could be creamier/thicker and sweeter though.
So for the Anchor Special and 2 cups of clam chowder, the bill came out to be $56.00 including tip.  A little overpriced for what I was expecting...but at least I came out full.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
In the Yin and Yang of good seafood places to eat to in San Francisco, these people are on whatever side of the cosmos "clean" resides. The waiter actually went into the bathroom before me, verified its cleanliness, and then turned on the hot water to make sure it heated up for me. 

And then he left me alone. 

So he was terribly nice and his behavior could not be called kinky.
author: Bubbles L.

description:
Five stars earned based on customer service alone.

I came here as a party of three on a Saturday night at 8 PM. They don't take reservations and there were quite a few parties ahead of us. It was a beautiful night and we lingered outside patiently. Every 20 minutes or so, the wait staff would come outside with complimentary white wine. How wonderful to drink outside on Castro Street on a gorgeous, unseasonably warm night! 

My dinner pal pointed out Harvey Milk's former storefront and apartment, which were located next to the restaurant. This made my night and I snapped a few photos while we waited.

We were seated about 1.5 hours later, and our waitress brought us a complimentary order of crispy garlic bread as a thank you for waiting. We ordered a seafood sampler appetizer (the oysters were divine), crab cakes and chowder. Everything was delicious and I loved that the crab cakes were substantial and meaty. 

It was my understanding that this restaurant has been open for many years, and I can see why. Customer service can take you a long way in this industry.
author: Amanda D.

description: Two of my girlfriends and I were craving oysters in an intense way when we found this place.  Tiny place yet a crisp nautical feel.   We sat at the bar. We started with oyster shooters (duhhhh) and Hoegaarden since they were out of Anchor Steam on draft.  We each had a clam chowder which was one of the best I had.  Entree was their Anchor special which included a dozen oysters (four different types tonight, the Brewsters were yummy), chilled shrimp, and steamed mussels.  Will definitely return. Love love love.
author: Oana M.

description: today was my 4th time getting the cioppino (fish stew with dungeness crab) at anchor and it was still as good as the first 3 times.  got my order to-go (first 3 times were dine in) since i didn't feel like making dinner tonight.  kinda surprised i was able to order to-go as one restaurant wouldn't let me take the rest of my moules home citing that they didn't want to me to get food poisoning lest the shellfish made me sick.  however, the chef at anchor is meticulous with his to-go orders as his dine-ins. the seafood was cooked to perfection and packaged separately from the addicting tomato stew.  when i reheated the dish a few hours later, marrying the stew and seafood together in a pot over low heat, the cioppino still tasted as yummy as if we'd eaten it at the restaurant.  thank you chef!
author: Marie T.

description:
small location, friendly service and fresh seafood.

clam chowder is excellent, good flavor, good texture, clean with no gritty sand that some clam chowders sometimes have.  oysters in a half shell are almost creamy and very tasty. must get seafood special.  crab melt was a bit messy, but if it doesn't get all over the place, it doesn't... oh right, that's for hamburgers...
author: Wayne L.

description:
Oh my yumminess. 

What a fabulous little neighborhood joint...my mouth is still watering over the selection of fresh oysters, steamed clams and chowder. A little slice of Cape Cod in the Castro.
author: Suepattra M.

description:
Best thing in the castro by far.  Get there early on weekends, long waits are the only drawback, it's that popular.
The crab burger for lunch is a little secret myself and other castro locals appreciate.
author: Jeff S.

description: The food is quite good here but it sure is pricey!  My friend and I split an appetizer and had two entrees and with house wine it came out to almost $130!  You bet I was shocked.
author: Jay A.

description: 2nite my girlfriend & I shared the tiger prawn cocktail, the clam chowder, and the wild salmon w/a creme fresh dill sauce. The shrimp was a serving of only 5 which I thought was odd but they were cooked perfectly. The soup was @ 1st served warm but the chef (I'm almost certain she was) immediately noticed & reconciled that. They had another pot that was hot. It wasn't bad but could have had more noticeable clam chunks. And the salmon, oh the salmon! It was fantasic. Crunchy on the outside and perfectly cooked on the inside served w/fingerling potatoes, baby carrot spears, and cauliflower all served w/a light dill creme fresh sauce that made the dish. I would highly reccomend this place.
author: Erin L.

description: Food is Fab and Fresh. Small place. It has 5 tables and a bar that accomodates around 8 people. Service is quite poor (they are so busy that they cannot give you much attention). I would Definetely go back. Isn't the food what it's about?
author: Moses S.

description:
We waited 2 hours to sit, because some obnoxious guys just sat there for 1 hour after they finished eating. There are only 5 tables and 6 seats in the bar, and I was mad because people who came after us didn't have to wait as long. 

But the food was worth the wait. Dungeneese crab cooked with garlic was heavenly. Oven fried oyster were very good. Anchor special was very good. Oysters were very fresh. 

I will definitely go here again. Owner is there on Friday and Saturday's and she does cooking.
author: Zahir A.

description: I'm going to be fair and state my rating is based not on the food but the waiter and disorganized check-in process. We couldn't actually sit and dine due to the wait, that being said I will share my experience. Took a cab there nobody greets you; we had to ask other waiting customers how to get a table you'll have to put your name and time you arrived on a little chalkboard. Kicker here is that the chalkboard is not updated regularly and not in chronological order, you'll have to squeeze your name in wherever you find space in a lil corner over somebody else's name, and hope the waiter somehow finds you. You get the picture, waiter was really disorganized and frazzled not remembering who or where he left off on the chalkboard. Actually was argumentative with a  few customers when they inquired where they stood on the waiting list due to the chalkboard not being updated and accurate. Our check in was 8:20pm at 9:30pm they were only checking in customers from 6:30 and they close at 10pm so you could kinda guess we didn't make it in. I really want to come back and try the food by then I hope management gets the whole check in process more organized.
author: Bernard S.

description:
I found this place to be highly over rated and over priced. The food quality was abysmal for san francisco- a salad of ice berg lettuce with just a few greens, a greasy flavorless sandwich, and canned shrimp. Canned shrimp everywhere. For a city that prides itself on local high quality ingredients this fails the test. Shocked at how expensive the lunch bill for 2 sandwiches and 1 app - $55! 

On the positive side, the service was of quality. 

May I recommend you save your money and go around the corner to woodhouse.
author: Michael D.

description:
We had a lovely Sunday evening dinner here. The food was really fresh and the Cioppino was AMAZING! - Definitely a good choice! The menu is small- no fried options (all the better in my opinion)- but they do it very well. A lovely selection of fresh oysters. The Special consisted of raw oysters, steamed prawns and a side of steamer clams in the most amazing broth- you'll want extra bread- garlic bread maybe? Why not!!

The service was exceptional- prompt, friendly and gracious. The atmosphere is very quaint- simple, stainless steel nautical-in a straightforward manner. I loved the coziness of the place. If you are lucky enough to find yourself in the Castro and the Anchor has an open table stop on in! You will not be disappointed.
author: Gretchen S.

description: Great food! service was attentive and efficient.  We had the Anchor special which came withe 3 different kind of osyters, 2 each, 2 jumbo prawns, and one big bowl of steam clams and that was just a half order.  The sauce of the steam clam was so good and we had 3 loaf of breads and still got plaenty left when we done. We also had the ono special which is great too! Such a small place and we went there on wednesday right at 5:30pm to aviod the wait.  Will definately go again when they are not crazy busy.
author: Greddyv7 3.

description: I went here as an alternative to the usual clam chowder tourist trap stands near Fisherman's Wharf, and it didn't disappoint. It's a short walk from where I was staying and not far from Castro Station. The place is pretty small, but was not crowded when I went (around 2 to 3 PM on a Tuesday). For about $6.50, you get a decent sized bowl of clam chowder, plenty of oyster crackers (on the table), and bread and butter, if you opt for it. Service was fast and the food was tasty, definitely worth a visit!
author: Liane C.

description:
Outstanding, excellently prepared food.  Very tender vegetables, terrific swordfish, terrific scallions, great roasted artichokes, when they have them in stock.

Wine menu is very small and not of very good quality. See if you can bring your own.

A small restaurant, so it can be crowded. Often couples are asked to dine at the counter.  Our dinners didn't come to the table at the same time, which was kind of a bummer, but they comped a clam chowder to compensate.  The chowder is really, really good, by the way.

Overall:  Outstanding quality food at apx. $25 per plate.  Very popular. What it lacks in space is compensated for by the very high quality, healthy food. 

Best to walk by and see if they have seats available and be prepared to try again another day or wait your turn for a table.
author: Don m.

description: We were just walking around the Castro and found this place by coincidence.  We were lucky enough to get there just before the dinner rush.  Service here was outstanding.  Presentation just made me smile, because you don't see that much anymore.  They placed the seafood on top of crushed ice with seaweed swirled around overhead.  Very pretty.
author: Michelle M.

description: it was an delightful little late night snack run. The service here was super sweet and the waiter for our table was pretty knowledgeable about oysters, which is what I went there for. Decided to order the combination plate with steamed clams, shrimp cocktails and a dozen of oysters (3 of each kind, the wellfleet, miyagi, pacific, and the eastern). And it was De-li-cious! Miyagi is still my fav!  But definitely try this place out if you are in the city, the oysters are pretty fresh, didnt get to order anything else because my company kept on nagging about how I already had dinner and it's not right to eat so much and blah, blah, blah. But everything else looks pretty delicious as well.  And btw, did I mention the service is really good too!
author: Young N.

description: Ciopinno: that was my mission.  I did my research before heading to San Francisco and had a couple places in mind. (YELP!)  The Saturday of the Dyke March I went down to the Castro before things got started, to walk around and take in the other capital of gayhood. And because God likes gay people and, particularly, black-latina lesbians who are hunting for ciopinno, this place, which was already on my list, was a front seat to the gay bachanal on Castro street.  It's kind of a seafood diner: metal tables, counter service with rotating stools.  We signed up on the waitlist outside the door and then sat for a bit on the bench in front the place.  The restaurant is too small to wait inside. (Which was okay by me because it gave me a chance to take some pics of Harvey Milk's camera shop which is next door) But once inside, service was completely on point.  The ciopinno which I sought, is not on the menu. You must ask them to make it for you, which they will. Our table was right by the open kitchen so I could see the chef preparing the food. And then it came, loaded with mussels and clams and crab, a lemony tomatoey herbey base which was fantastic with the garlic bread that was served with the dish.  Certainly big enough for two.  Both my friend and I wanted to pay with credit cards.  The manager was kind enough to allocate the correct amounts to our separate credit cards. Nice. I will definitely be back.
author: Gail D.

description:
Anchor Oyster Bar wasn't bad but not very good neither.

My date and I arrived at 7:30 on a Thursday evening and there was a little waiting line outside the door. Don't forget to sign up on the white board. I learned that from the waiting patrons, a very nice crowd. 

Then we were seated and I ordered a glass of sauvignon blanc. To my surprise, the waiter brought me a taste sample. I don't remember when was the last time I'd get a tasting sample without ordering a full bottle. Nice!

Here comes the food...

- Clam chowder: watery and lack of any sweetness of clams
- Oysters: 4 kinds, 2 were excellent, 1 good, and the last was just ordinary
- Steam clams: nice touching taste of rosemary when having the clam itself, but over powering and salty when dipping with bread. My own fault?
- Jumbo prawn: love that cocktail sauce with hot mustard

All in all, I think the service was great but the food was just on par. Oh, about that glass of wine that I had. I have no idea on what kind of sauvignon blanc they're severing. I was pretty buzzed just after one glass of it.
author: Rio T.

description: Came here with the family on a Saturday at about 12:30 and was seated in 5 mins. We had our best meal in SF.  Started with chowder and the seafood plate of oysters, prawns & clams. Then had the pasta special and it was enough for the 4 of us, kids ages 10 & 13. House wine was nice and the price was right. Service was excellent - an example.  My daughter went to the bathroom and while she was gone, the chowder was served.  The waiter noticed she wasn't there and he promptly covered her bowl with another plate to keep the chowder hot.  Will be thinking of this place when reminiscing about our vacation in SF.
author: Sang C.

description:
ok so I first learned about this place on check please bay area. This was before I discovered about yelp. I can't express how much love I have for this place. 

what can I say that probably hasn't already been said?

-The bread is amazing
-waiting service is super friendly
- if you ask for their recommendation they will point you in the right direction 
-oyster shooters are AWE-SOME
-leaves you wanting more

this seating situation is a little bit tricky because the place is like super duper small, and when it looks full all you have to do is write your name on their little handy dandy white board and how many people you have in your party.
So if your not a fan of waiting for long periods of time for a table this isn't the spot for you.

If you are dining alone or with perhaps 2 or 3 people I HIGHLY suggest sitting at the bar. SIT AT THE BAR!!! I can't stress that enough. 
Sitting at the bar gives you a chance to talk to the waiter for more then just a quick second and they are more close to you so they won't really have to travel miles to get to you so your food is straight from the kitchen to your table =]

Also when sitting at the bar you can easily strike up some conversation and their staff loves to talk...trust me I talked to all of them..or most of them at least haha 

also their daily specials are very awesome the freshest fish I have ever tasted and their bread is amazingly good too =] also their clam chowder is thin and light which is nice change it was just overall goodness..

I don't know what else to say about this place I came, I ate, and I fell in love =]
author: Kimberly M.

description: I want to give this place 4 stars for the food, and extra star for the chef, service, atmosphere and dinners eating there!! I got there around 5:15pm and there were about 10 people in front of me waiting for table. Put name down and waited till 5:50, not bad for a popular place. I was seated on the oyster bar, and lucky to next to two super cute guys who are obviously so in love with each other. They strongly recommend the pan roasted crab with garlic, so added the crab to Anchor Special (6 oysters+cocktail prawns+steamed mussels). And the food was so so good that I wanna thank them for forcing me to order this. After they left, another couple sit down next to me, and the woman ordered scallops that look so divine. She spooned her scallops into my plate and urge me to try. Heavenly delicious!! People eating at this place are just so passion about their food. One guy recommended Bi-Rite homemade ice-cream on 18th street. As I was leaving, other dinners nodded and smiled at me. What a great, cheerful little place for awesome seafood :-)
author: Michele S.

description:
One of the most magical places in SF! If you want awesome seafood 
try this place. It will never disappoint. I've been going her for at least
8 years now. Their oysters are the freshest. The crab caesar salad is to die for. Their lemonade is the best I've ever tasted. Last, but not least,
their service is beyond compare. I love this place dearly...33 shucking years and going strong.
author: R B.

description:
How many times have I walked past this place, looked in, and noticed how happy and cheerful all of the people look? Several. It took me damn near forever to finally make it in there for dinner though (Thanks Bill! Had a great time!!!)

Ate right at the counter, which was kinda cool. Get to see everything in action, all action-filled and happening. I kinda like when I get to see that.

I'm not a huge fan of oysters, so I was freaking out thinking "Shit...shit...I'm going to have to suck it up and eat oysters." How dumb am I, right? They had a great selection of all sorts of food - fish, chicken, pastas, salads. Everything just sounded so good. Which made me feel bad when every time we were asked if we were ready to order, I scrunched up my face and said, "I....just....can't....decide....need more time....please...." :|

Finally did go with one of their fish dish specials, which was just beyond delicious. I usually eat my food in less than three seconds, but I was slow and savored each and every bite. So damn good.

And what's more, my friend that I went with is a regular there and knows the owner, and she brought us out a tray of their garlic bread. 

That was the moment when I drooled and instantly became a fan of this place. You give me garlic bread, and I'm going to be your friend. Like your favorite friend. I'll send you holiday cards in the mail and stuff. Yeah...you're getting one Madam Oyster Bar. Definitely. :)

If you're in the neighborhood and have not checked this place out...well, just for shame on you. Do it. And if you, like myself, have walked past several times and thought "I wonder..." then just stop wondering and go in. You won't be disappointed. Promise promise promise. :)
author: Nicolas H.

description: As has been mentioned countless times already, the food is amazing.  But amazing food is standard in this town.  What blew me away was the service and overall ambiance that the staff created for us. Being neighbors, they tried in every way possibly to make us feel at home our first time at Anchor Oyster Bar.  We came in early on a Tuesday evening and Instead of our waiter enjoying the calm before the storm, he took the opportunity to expose us to all corners of the menu.  He kept bringing out food that we hadn't ordered insisting that we must try they're signature items.  To pique our interest further, our waiter even showed us the specials for the evening as they came out of the kitchen.  "See, see, doesn't this look beautiful?"  Hands down, Anchor Oyster Bar created the best seafood experience I've had in San Francisco.
author: Krissy A.

description: Awesome! Had a cup of the amazing clam chowder and the crab cake appetizers.
author: Ben S.

description:
5 stars for awesome seafood. Crab Louie, Seafood Louie salads & Cioppino are all the best of their respective classes in this seafood lover's opinion. Don't skip the dressing. they're made in house and are awesome. Still haven't met one I haven't liked. This place has a small but good selection of East & West Coast oysters, and everything's consistently delish & fresh. Focus of all the dishes is on the seafood, so if you're looking for complicated tangled flavors/fancy fusion, this probably isn't the place for you.

Minus one star: The space is really teeny and they don't take rezzies. So bundle up if it's cold, nighttime and you head here. You could be waiting a while outside. Staff makes no effort to get diners who are dawdling out the door.
author: Lisa M.

description: I have been dreaming about Dungeness Crab sauteed in garlic and lemon for weeks, and it's all this place's fault.  Had an unforgettable meal here with my mom - crab, prawns, and a great bottle of cold white wine.  Sat in the window and loved watching as people stopped to take their picture in front of Castro Camera right next door.
author: Rebecca A.

description:
Hands down my favorite crab in town. I can eat an entire one and not feel guilty about it afterward, though I may not be able to move. Decent beer and wine selection and wonderful service rounds out a great time.
Went again on Monday and it was very crowded, but worth the wait. I had the Petrale in a blood orange sauce, delish! The seafood stew was amazing and apparently if you like oysters there are a plethora of options and they're all good. They had run out of the sardine special that was served with pickled fennel and the server said, "oh yes we're out of it and it WAS delicious" too bad for my guests.
author: Colleen B.

description:
Time/Date: Thursday  7:50 pm. No Reservations; place was full but we were seated immediately

Type/Quality: Local Sea Food Prepared well with oysters and shell fish as their specialty

Price/Quanity: ~$60 w/ tip gets you a full oyster/seafood sampler plate,  a cup of soup, and an entree. Its a good portions for two people who aren't too hungry. All the raw food is fresh and the prepared food is tastey. 

Service/Accesibility: The service is friendly and the food comes at a normal pace. Its the castro so parking isn't horrible but walking from market is more efficient.

Structure/Ambience: My cousin describes it as " Its like a giant bathroom". This equates to a small restaurant. Its cozy  and clean, with am atmosphere of a place by the beach in Mexico or on a pier in Santa Cruz.
author: Justin L.

description: This place is amazing. One of the best dining experiences I have ever had. The service was great and the food was out of this world. It is a small place (about 5-6 tables that seat ~4 and a bar that has 8 seats) which means that there will be a bit of a wait, but it's definitely worth it. Put your name down and walk around the Castro! I went with my significant other and we got the clam chowder, 6 oysters, and the California Sea Bass.  The clam chowder was thick, delicious, and flavorful. It came with some bread which rounded off that dish.  The oysters were fresh and tasty. The Cape Cod Flying Points were my favorite out of the three (Hog Island and Long Island Blue Points being the other 2). California Sea Bass baked with a lemon -- rosemary pesto, mashed potatoes & vegetables was amazing. The mashed potatoes were some of the best I have ever had. The portions are pretty big so you better have a big appetite!
author: Kevin H.

description:
Small and quaint, I live in the neighborhood and eat here regularly. This is some of the best seafood in SF. The menu changes daily depending on what's fresh! Great meals at a fair price...don't let the wait scare you off, it's well worth it. I have never taken anyone to this restaurant who did not want to go back.

This review is the subjective opinion
author: Mark P.

description: This is one of the BEST seafood places I have been to. Excellent service and fresh fresh seafood! They do not take reservations so plan on arriving early and waiting. We came on a cold weekend night and the wait was quite awhile. We were not planning on leaving because we have been talking about this dinner all week. One of the waiters was so sweet to bring us a cup of hot clam chowder while we were waiting outside!! How sweet! Highly recommended....food was excellent!!! Feels very family!
author: Melanie S.

description:
This is my favourite place in SF for oysters.... mmmm so good and at reasonable prices.  Not too fond of larger oysters so as to why I love it here since they always have the smaller, buttery, sweet selection of oysters.

Clam chowder is fantastic.  Cioppino is very good.  mmmm... I miss it already.

Key is everything here is absolutely *FRESH*, every time.
author: Win W.

description:
Top notch oyster bar. Can't believe it's been here over 30 years and I'm just now discovering it! Best clam chowder I've had in the city, yet (still not topping what I've had elsewhere, but we're getting closer!). The bread was perfect for dipping in the creamy soup. Good oysters (duh), and, best of all, PERFECT PERFECT PERFECT steamed clams! Love the sprigs of rosemary; a wonderful and aromatic compliment to the buttery white wine garlic broth. 

I must also commend the service. So friendly and helpful when I was in a bit of a crisis. It was also fun dishing with the waiter about the Harvey Milk filming, as it's next door to his old camera shop giving them a front row seat for filming. They've undergone a transformation, same as the rest of Castro. I hope I recognize Anchor once it's back to it's old (or should I say new?) look!
author: Veronica L.

description: This place is great.  Excellent seafood, creative but not weird, reasonable prices, cozy ambience.  It's very small, so sometimes there's a wait, especially on weekend nights.  Crab cakes are  good, and the specials are often very good.  I had one special - salmon on a bed of lentils with a creme fraiche sauce - that didn't sound that great, but was absolutely amazing.   Wine choices are only okay.
author: Julie H.

description:
i've loved this place for a while and last night more than reaffirmed my love.  having been there before i know it is a small place and that if you want in on a saturday night you will have to wait outside for a while.  that was fine with me.  i was prepared for it.  but last night was a particularly cold night in sf, so waiting outside for 20 or 30 minutes was not the most pleasant experience, or at least it wasn't until anchor outdid themselves.  as we waited in the cold, the chef came out with piping hot cups of clam chowder, which he gave us for free, and thanked us for waiting in the cold.  this is service above and beyond.   with delicious hot clam chowder warming my belly i actually enjoyed the cold weather.  we got a table not long after finishing our chowder and the rest of the meal was as exceptional as i have come to expect.  

sometimes small gestures make a huge difference.  thanks for the chowder.  it made my night.
author: Patrick M.

description:
Husband and I love this place.
     ORDERED:
     -appetizer: ordered 6 raw oysters
     -appetizer: mixed seafood appetizer
     -starter: 2 bowls of clam chowder
     -Main course: honey ordered the Rosemary Smoked Salmon Special
     -To be honest I can't remember my entrée because it has been a while   since we went so I will have to skip that. 
      --FINDINGS:
Oysters: were great but had the same issues that a lot of other places have; too many wayward shell pieces. Is that the norm? To me it's like a bartender leaving lemon seeds in your martini or your margarita....it just SHOULDN'T be done! Take the time to pick out most of them and you'll have happy customers. MAYBE ORDER AGAIN.
Clam Chowder: I heard all the hype and decided to try a cup. I would have to say that I was going to say it was okay but my honey and I saw the waiter pour a container of regular cream into it when it was running low and we decided then and there that it was not great at all. Like many would agree, I'm sure, more goes into clam chowder than just more cream. WILL NOT ORDER AGAIN.
My honey's salmon was cooked to perfection with sprigs of rosemary that actually burst in your mouth. The dish also came topped with pancetta slivers, rice and sauteed vegetables. The food, in its entirety, was mouth-watering perfection. What does that mean you ask? Try a whiff of rosemary  bursting on your taste buds only to be thinly coated with the taste of juicy, sweet, meaty salmon as it wars (lovingly) with the taste of pancetta. Next take a little salmon and couple it with a scoop of fresh tasty seasonal vegetables and a fluffy flavorful Basmati rice ending. 
     -JUDGEMENT:
Would definitely come back again. My honey will be ordering the salmon again (if available), not too sure about oysters as 20 shells is a little too many, clam chowder is out for us. In the end the restaurant is great and deserves another chance. All hail the salmon!!!! See you there : )
author: Tabitha R.

description: Really small on seating but big on taste and service. No reservations and on a Friday or Saturday you can expect a long wait for a table but it is worth it if you have the time. The ever-changing menu is always sure to please the taste buds and the staff are really friendly. We once waited outside for about an hour and one of the servers brought us out some garlic bread and drinks while we waited, on the house. For a restaurant that is listed as not recommended for kids they do a stellar job - crayons, coloring books, toys and kid sized portions at a good price.
author: Andre L.

description: I love the simple, delicious preparation of the dishes here.  Always fresh and healthy options.  If you are in the Castro and there isn't a line, jump at the chance to sit at the counter.
author: Geene R.

description:
Sorry, sorry, sorry, I am the reviewer #70 here, I feel like I broke the #69.
Passed by this place many times, tried it, it was good.
author: John L.

description:
My heavens this place is clean!  From the very white tiles to the tiny little bathroom in the back of the kitchen...it's impeccable.  Oh, and the food is great, too...very fresh seafood is always a plus.
The oysters were excellent, shrimp perfection and the clams absolutely heaven (especially, the broth which I sopped up with bread...down to the last drop).
The prices are very high, but sometimes you must remember that you get what you pay for...and for us, it was just a little afternoon pick-me-up as we traipsed through Castro like good little tourists.
author: Dana H.

description:
Anchor's wait staff's service problems prevent me from giving this charming neighborhood hole in the wall more stars.  I'll start with the bad, because the good nearly outweighs it.  The service is slow and often inattentive.  Usually, there is one waiter for the entire joint, which is OK because there are only 5 tables and a 7- or 8-seat oyster bar.  The waiters are particularly bad at keeping an eye on you to see if you're ready for your check, which is incredibly frustrating.

Overall, the food is good.  Not much variety in the menu, but Anchor's philosophy seems to be if it ain't broke, don't fix it.  During oyster season (November through February), their oysters are superb and they routinely rotate through about 4 different types from day to day.  The Boston Clam Chowder is always good, as is their open-face crab and cheese sandwich.  While salads are generally bland, adding fish of some sort to the mix improves them.  And their crab cakes, which can vary wildly in quality (density, moisture, and toasted-ness) are usually a safe bet and well worth it when they  are made well.  Don't bother with the prawn or miniature shrimp cocktails -- incredibly overpriced and the mini prawns taste like they came out of a can.

If you can stand slow, inattentive service, it's a fine place to have lunch.
author: Andrew L.

description: It's well worth the wait (grab a drink in Schuck across the road while you are waiting). It's not just oysters. Lots of of fresh fish specials served in  good size portions with nice vegetables and potatoes. Four people pigging out plus drinks is ~ $45 each.
author: Gary G.

description: Great cioppino, pasta, and herb bread.  I wish the restaurant is bigger, so I don't have to wait for a long time!  Will be back!
author: Elena L.

description: A beautiful little seafood restaurant in the Castro. This place is very easy to love. They have a good variety of oysters and such, and the garlic bread (really good, has cheese on it) amazingly is as good as the seafood! The anchor special is a pretty good deal and you get a large variety of stuff, including clams in a butter garlic sauce that was simply so delicious. The place itself is very charming and cozy (wait can be long), and the service is very warm and friendly. The oysters were fresh and delicious, as was the shrimp and the garlic breads. The ciopinno is something else... It might be the best ciopinno in the city! We've also tried the steamed shellfish plate, and it's amazing. The main/big dishes seem pricey, but the portions are huge and we always have enough to take home, so it's actually very reasonably priced. How this place isn't more famous is beyond me. It's one of our all time favorite restaurants in the city.
author: Dave Y.

description: Still great oysters and steamed clams with great service!  Awesome crab jack sandwich with so much gooey cheese drowning the open-faced sandwich....yummy I just drooled a little bit.
author: Elaine K.

description:
Well worth the wait for some fresh delish oysters. 
They had 4 types of oysters to choose from and we had the platter with all 4 types. They were definitely oceany fresh. Yum! 
Watch out for the oyster shooters......spicy beyond belief! After that I felt a little sick. Good thing dinner came fast.
For my "main" course, I had the penne with Salmon which was just ok. A little lacking in flavor. To make up for the lack of flavor, I cracked the heck out of their awesome pepper mill. That was the best pepper mill I have ever used. Big huge chunks of pepper, awesome! If I would of had a bigger purse, I would of had to put it in my bag! ;)
Service at this place is a little lacking. The dude there was a little abrasive, he seemed stressed as well. Then the girl that also waited on us forgot about the second glass of wine we ordered. When I reminded her, 10 minutes later she was cool about it and said it was on the house. Nice!
Cute nautical feel here. I'll be back to slurp some more oysters down in the future.
author: Kelley D.

description:
OK, one more rave review of AOB.  The food is delicious.  The staff is fantastic.  The place is immaculate.  The fellow customers are super nice.

No downsides, just some other observations:

Not cheap, but the servings are generous, so noneed to over-order.
Small, so be prepared to wait.
But, wait, it's worth it.
author: Gary H.

description: Dinner at the Anchor Oyster Bar was one of the best sea food meals that I've ever had.  Ordered the seafood combination and my wife had the steamed mussels.  Both dishes were hearty and plentiful.  Wonderful value for the dollar. The staff was really attentive even though the place was completely full, both the tables and bar section.  They were very knowledgeable of the standard fare on the menu and the specials of the day.   Note, this place is really cozy which is another way to say really "small".  So get there early otherwise you'll be waiting for awhile.
author: John L.

description:
I first started eating at the Anchor Oyster Bar when it opened in 1977 and have consistently enjoyed my dining experiences there. I most recently had dinner there with my current partner (over 34 years some things do change) just last week. We had to wait, but are accustomed and fine with that. To us it's worth the wait and often meet interesting and friendly people. 

Now I can't say every restaurant is always perfect, but when, over many years you get consistantly fresh seafood--which is, in my view the most challenging of foods to buy and keep fresh--our expectations were again met. And to us Anchor merits five stars because of its reliability, very exceptional in any restaurant that's been around a long time. To sustain consistantly fresh food and friendly servers for more than three decades is no minor accomplishment.

I suspect there have been some unfortunate incidents at Anchor, but I believe--based on my experiences, the vast majority of YELP reviews and feedback from friends I've sent there, they are extremely rare. 

I never hesitate to eat at Anchor, and in fact, make of point of dining there as often as possible, as good service and great seafood is great to find.

KM & FY
June 4, 2011
author: kenneth M.

description:
So my first San Francisco review!

Anchor Oyster Bar is a small restaurant , approximately 30 covers, that specializes in both crustacia and fish.  The cooking style is Californian / Italian.  

I went for luch today and was handed a laminated menu and informed of the the specials that were marked on a pen board above the bar.  The standard menu consists of various salads and steamed shell fish and crab.  The specials board had scallops, bass and a fish casserole. I opted for the casserole.

The casserole consisted of calms, green lip and regular mussels, shrip, cod, and topped with garlic bread.  Oh, and it was served with a tomato broth, which I assume was the steaming liquid.

The fish was very good and fresh, and the portion was enough for me, but I'm not a big eater.  My only complaints were there was not enough garlic on the garlic bread, and the service was a bit slow.

I would recommend this place and I shall go back if I'm in the neighbourhood.

My lunch, which included a soft drink was $19.
author: Angus D.

description:
Lately I've been in this restaurant rut.  I can't quite figure out where I want to go (and me being me, this is pretty much a nightly problem) and I get frustrated and cranky.  I feel like the surge of exciting new openings has once again come to a big ole PAUSE in SF.  Everything strikes me as overwraught, too difficult (parking, waits, pushy people) or too expensive.  In frustration, i turned to standby Tia Margarita and sadly, they were closed for some "plumbing emergency" (um, yeah, thanks, don't try to fit me in).

So...I found myself at Anchor for the 2nd time in a week.  Now I *really* feel qualifiied to write a review - I'm almost a professional critic with this restraint I have shown!

Well, I might have to rescind that cuz I did get a lot of the same stuff.  Or, different menu items but really just compositions of stuff in different orders....eg: on round 2, i'll take the caesar salad sans crab but can i have a crab cocktail please (as opposed to the casesar with crab, you know).

Highlights:

WARM CROUTONS.  so simple.  soooo good.  excellent caesar dressing.  they are not familiar with the term "lightly dressed".  not super surprising.

A lotta crab and good (even if this is out of season and hell, maybe it's canned - it did make me buy a can today to test it out), even for a very reasonable price.

Good horseradish plopped in the cocktail sauce; you can ignore the blob or mix it in.

Sinful garlic bread.  Enough has been written about this but in short, i concur.  The bread tastes SO much better as a crouton or as the garlic stuff vs. cold 'n raw.  

Clam chowder with oyster crackers in an abalone shell.  Keeping it real

Crab cakes - mostly crab - what a surprise!  they don't seem to run out

And last but NOT least, the ONLY regulation "3 sink" clean up kitchen I've seen in a SF restaurant!  Yeah!  You can feel good about eating here, even if you DO have to interrupt the cook in order to get to the bathroom.
author: Laurie A.

description:
Have dined here several times both lunch and dinner.  Their oysters are great and they have four different kinds which is a plus for those who only like one or two kinds of oysters.

I highly recommend their Anchor Special - oysters (you choose), prawns, and sauteed clams.  I love the broth of the clams and will treat it like soup with bread, love that garlic!
author: Tiberius A.

description:
went here on a cold night and waited 55 minutes even though we were third in line. the restaurant is small. one waiter, one bus boy, one cook, one prep guy and one guy to was the dishes. pretty efficient.

we ordered garlic bread. yum. oyster special. double yum. clam chowder. yum. cioppino. ehhh yum. very different then what im used to because i compare all cioppinos to sotta mares which is bar none the best. you definitely taste the rosemary only because theres two whole sprigs of it. overall three stars.
author: Ryan C.

description: Everything was GREAT....everything fresh...and tasty and cooked perfectly....place is small b prepared to wait, but well worth it...service is a little slow which would normally bother me...but they were very nice...and helpful...so it felt more not that they were slow but giving everyone equal attention...i wont come to san fran and not stop here...
author: Eric S.

description:
Being of Portuguese decent, I pride myself on fantastic seafood cuisine.  I took my parents here for the first time earlier this year (living around the corner after four-years, I finally had a reason to take someone there)...and we all fell in love with this place immediately.  It was a busy night, so we kept getting served free garlic bread you'll never want to turn down...its probably the most amazing carbohydrate one's palette will ever come across.  I had the opportunity to dip my garlic bread in the broth from my mothers mixed-shellfish plate, and it was to DIE.  My kale/yam stuffed ravioli topped with crab was seriously the best thing on a menu found in the Castro.  You can tell it was freshly made that day and the sauce was as equally as divine as the broth from my mother's Cippiono-style dish.  I seriously could have drank it like it water, its just THAT good. This truly is a gem that surprisingly finds itself situated in the Castro, where most food establishments are less than mediocre.  But once you put any food in your mouth, it's no wonder they've been around for decades.  Their specials vary daily, so I truly enjoy a place who can mix up their fare on the daily (you know they pride themselves on their food), and you'll always be stuck on which one you should order.  Don't worry, either choice will leave you thinking you made the best decision.
The most amazing part about this restaurant is that it also doubles as a fish market!  Yes, you can buy their daily fresh catches and take them home to prepare yourself a meal.  Isn't that grand or what!?  If you find yourself wandering in the Castro one night, thinking seafood is the way you want to go come here to enjoy.  But try to come early as the wait can get a bit long for dinner (the place is tiny, yet the nautical atmosphere is what keeps you in here).  Its definitely worthwhile!  The service is efficient, one waiter, yet backed up with individuals cleaning and bringing you items.  That truly makes a place shine in my eyes.
author: Boho H.

description: Only a 4* review as they have a very small space.  Come here at an off hour or expect to wait for a table.  The fish can't be fresher and it tastes great, I know I live across the street.  I wish less people knew about it.  Nothing is cutting edge, but everything is delicious.
author: Mickey D.

description:
my cousin and i went one night for dinner. No reservation or anything. we sat at the bar and had dinner. tiny place, but that's the kind of places i love. Took a little to place our order, we got our drinks very quickly. We got the dinner combo that included 12 oysters, 4 shrimp, and muscles. simply amazing. oysters were sooo fresh! the shrimp were amazing. and the muscles? i just want to bath in that sauce. I wasn't that much of a fan of the chowder, but i did live in boston for a bit so i'm very picky. 

Next time i visit SF, Anchor oyster bar will be on my radar for sure.
author: Darius S.

description: This is an amazing place with such consistently fresh and tasty food. There is a lot to be said for keeping it simple and don't mess with a good thing.  We have friend that visit us from around the world and they always want to come back here to have the crab Cesar salad..hummm humm good. Friendly staff. Small restaurant expect to wait.
author: Garden Lover S.

description: As a rule, I wouldn't recommend any restaurant on Castro St. for eating, but this is a definite exception.  I went here with a group of friends for dinner and was pleasantly surprised by the freshness, intimate ambiance, and amazing food.  I had the pan-seared scallops, which where cooked to perfection (not tough on the outside, but cooked and tender on the inside). I shared a clam chowder, which hit the spot on a cold night; usually i would complain about clam chowder being too runny/thick or salty, but this was perfect.  I'm definitely coming back here again
author: Ben T.

description: went again memorial day weekend, food's consistent except for the steamed clams broth wasnt as intoxicating as last time, but "still soak with bread" excellent.  like in n out, there's a secret menu such as cioppino, you just have to ask.
author: Jacky K C.

description:
Every time I eat here there is no wait. I usually go at 3:45pm on a weekday. Been coming here for twelve years, maybe longer.
This is the only place I eat oysters at - and they are always spanking fresh and always seasonal. Served on ice with seaweed and lemon like a real seafood house.
Clam chowder was stellar and tested HOMEMADE; tried the pan fried oyster appetizers which were tender and sweet like young coconut with a light crispy breading. AWESOME with the house wine.
We each also ordered the caesar salad and a plate of garlic bread. For some reason the garlic seemed to be missing from the garlic bread. When I mentioned it I was brought a brand new plate of garlic drenched bread. Wow!
My only criticism is that I'd love to see more of an intense anchovy flavor restored to the caesar salad. Consistency in the thick garlic flavors would be great. Dont be afraid of the garlic! 
A romantic atmosphere and authentically genuinely darling staff. This is a real Italian seafood house. I'm going back soon for the fabulous crab salad. Just waiting for the crabs to beef up.
author: Nan L.

description:
Friendly service, nice local feel and great seafood. 

Ask for any specials off the menu, sometimes they have surprises.

Thumbs up, thanks for the great service Oyster Bar!
author: Carl Y.

description: SO YUMMY!!! The artichoke was fab, the shrimp and oysters were delightful and the crab salad with a vinigerette dressing TO DIE FOR!!!! This is a little place is a must when in the city! Oh and the service was amazing! I can't wait to visit again =)
author: Chelsea H.

description: Anchor Oyster Bar is one of the best hidden secrets in SF.  it's a tiny seafood restaurant, very cozy and friendly.  The decor is very beach house chic and very clean.  the sea food is really fresh and super tasty.  The service is also really great!  We had sea bass and sole, both are super amazing!
author: Joey C.

description:
So, I have been to this place a TON of times and every time the service and food quality have been completely consistent.  Here's the deal...it is a small place - and I do mean small...however, that is part of it's charm. Plan on waiting...there is not a place to wait inside...so plan on waiting outside...and there are no street heaters, so it can get cold.  If that is a problem for you, then try it on a warm night...but the wait, the cold - it is all worth it.

The food is amazing and the waitstaff are completely friendly.  What to try?  First, check out the specials board hanging above the bar.  That will be what is fresh, in season and unique.  If you want to order off the traditional menu, try the shrimp or crab salad or the steamed combo.  One thing that is a must try is the cioppino.  It is not on the menu...any of the...but it is over the top!  If crab is not in season...ask for the fisherman's stew...is the cioppino without the crab, but just as amazing!  Both come with this out of this world garlic bread (and ask for a bib...you will need it).

The prices aren't cheap, but with the quality of the food and the huge portions the value more than makes up for it.  The last time we ate there we took the left over broth from my cioppino and used it the next night as a pasta sauce (based on the rec of our waiter...awesome call btw).
author: Steve L.

description: Consistently great service. Given that you can't make reservations, the wait is usually manageable. The food is excellent. Among my two favorite seafood restaurants in SF.
author: Chris C.

description: By far the worst restaurant service/food I've ever been to and I'm an easy person when it comes to food. Waited 45 minutes to get a table. Our waiter came asked us are we ready we said yes and he said ok let me take your order and then said hold on and we waited for another 30 minutes as he served another table when we were there first. This place deserves no stars. Food took about and hour or so to come out and everything was cold. Clam chowder PLAIN oyster dirty full of dirt and shell, garlic bread 2/10. Clams HORRIFIC. No flavor nothing tasted like a catch from the ocean and straight to our plate. Would not recommend this place. If I was going to die of hunger and this was the only place to save me I rather die than have to eat here again. This place seems to be racist. I'm asian and everyone else was white. We seemed to get the worst service. All waiters gave us attitude, didn't seem any interest for our presence. Like I said again WOULD NOT RECOMMEND.
author: Kevin T.

description: I went here for my birthday and it was great! The staff was super accommodating and friendly, and the seafood here was fresh and delicious! I can't remember everything my party had, but everyone was really happy with the food! They didn't mind when one of my friends showed up late with a cake for me. They even held it in the back (so we could have room on our crowded table) and brought out serving utensils and plates! All and all, a great experience. Minus one star for the brutal wait and small space. It's SF though, I wouldn't expect it any other way.
author: Hope D.

description: Been eating at the Anchor for a decade.  If I'm anywhere near the city I make it to the Anchor.  Outstanding seafood, tasty fresh oysters.  Can get really busy in the evening.  Great place for late lunch or early dinner.
author: Allen S.

description: I read about this place in a few guide books and it was highly recommended.  We spent a day in the Castro and were looking for some seafood to have for lunch.  I looked at the menu on my iphone and it was expensive.  We decided to go down there anyway and look inside.  They had a lesser priced lunch menu so we decided to try it.  We had to sit at the bar top area because it was packed.  This is a really small restaurant.  My friend had a seafood stew and I had the crab burger.  We had such a great meal and everyone that worked there was so nice and professional.  We walked out of there not really caring what we spent because we were so glad we had the experience that we did.  Big thumbs up to this place for great food and awesome service.
author: Christine S.

description: Thsi place is soooo good!!!! Probably will have to wait for a seat, but worth it!
author: Officer L.

description: In a city of great seafood restaurants, this is one of my favorites.  The fresh oysters are out of this world, and the daily fish selections never hit a wrong note.  For those who like to cook on their own, they also sell fresh fish.   I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Bruce B.

description: Took a 17.00 cab ride to get here from my hotel downtown - and would do it again. And again. Probably the best crab cakes I have ever had in my life - very little breading/stuffing with mostly crab!  Also, the oysters were fantastic - Kumomotos (?), Hog's Island, and another from B.C were on the menu that night.  My coworker had scallops that were cooked to perfection. Even the side salad I ordered was delicious. The restaurant is pretty small - 8 tables and a bar. In my opinion, it added to the restaurant's charm. Simple menu, but check the specials.  If you love seafood, you will not be disappointed.
author: Jess S.

description:
I've been eating here since the place opened (yeah i'm old) and still love it.  In crab season, their cioppino is superb, and the rest of the year they serve it without the crab as "Italian Fish Stew".

I love crabcakes and have had them in many restaurants both in the US and in Europe.  I have never had a better one.  In fact, all the crabcake fans i've brought here have said the same thing.

Some reviewers have praised the clam chowder, but as much as i love this place i have to be honest and say that it's rather ordinary.  (The best i've had on the west coast is at the Woodhouse, but neither their cioppino nor their crabcakes are as good as the Anchor's.)

I find the service both friendly and good, and the atmosphere is wonderfully unpretentious, considering the high quality of the food.
author: Matte G.

description: the best cioppino, the bowl was brimming with mussels, crab, prawns and the broth was delicious.  Worth the wait and service was professional, our tall sexy server was spot on and giving him the extra star for this review!
author: ham a.

description: if i was forced to choose only one restaurant to eat at for the rest of my life I honestly think this may be the place I would choose.  Oysters are by far my favorite food and this place delivers.  I love hog island for their product, but i'm not a big fan of the price and how it is a huge tourist trap, I would much rather just go to the farm.  Any time I am in the city I make every effort possible to come here and throw down at least a couple of dozen jewels from the sea.  Last time my girlfriend and I came here we were feeling extra adventurous and decided to share the cioppino and it was to die for (and I do not throw that term around loosely, I hate it, but in this case, I would actually die for this meal.)  The only problem is they are always pretty slammed, which really isnt a problem, of course they are slammed, they are delicious. (I've shared this rant before, but i'll do it again because some of the people who have also reviewed anchor have actually lowered their review due to the wait time.  GOD FORBID THEY ARE POPULAR AND CAN NOT CATER TO JUST YOU.  They are a business, they are good at what they do, they need customer to turn a profit).  So yeah, if you enjoy oysters or seafood in general head to the castro and put your name on the white board.  I promise you will not be disappoint.
author: Phil K.

description:
The wait sucks and the service ain't good, but HOLY CRAP do you forget about all that once you have the garlic crab.

I've eaten here a bunch of times and have never been disappointed. As long as you're not hungry when you arrive and can deal with having nothing for the next 30-60 minutes, you will completely understand why we all come back.
author: Ted F.

description:
Its hard to find a really good old-school seafood place. This would be it.

No frills seafood joint, fresh fresh fish and pretty standard (high) seafood prices.
