But damn, their crab and shrimp melt sandwich was actually divine.  I also hear that this place is where Gary Danko has lunch.  That has to say something.  

After living in the Castro 2 years, I'm finally glad I discovered this place.  Yum.  It will help me with my goal of eating as much seafood as I can before 2040, when all of the fish will apparently be gone from the oceans.  

Sigh.  Eat up while you can!
author: Megan M.

description:
This place has more fresh seafood than you would ever think from walking by.  It gets fresh catch of the day from the markets/docks and it shows.  I loved the clam chowder too.  A more upscale menu than Woodhouse Fish Company .(the other good fresh seafood place in the Castro area)  

I happen to be there on Father's Day and the server gave me a Oyster Bar T-shirt as a gift.  That was really nice of them.
author: John A.

description: I ordered the anchor special, it comes with 12 oysters, clams, and shrimp for $35 bucks that's a deal.  The place is very small so it has limited seating.  The service is great and I really enjoyed the meal.  I will definitely will be coming back.  I love oysters and these oysters are extremely fresh.  The clams were steams with butter and spices very delicious especially when dipped with french bread.  The shrimp was very large they were more like prawns.  Get deal for the price!
author: jenny l.

description: Oysters are a must and I heard the heirloom tomato salad was delis
author: Jein S.

description: Worth waiting for! the clam chowder was delicious - perfect consistency I had linguine and clams very tasty and fresh good service and friendy efficient staff Looking forward to going again and trying more things
author: lyn m.

description: I fell in love with there garlic steam clams, the broth in the clams were so good I almost wanted to drink the whole bowl. There's abit of a wait so come early, but I think it worth it
author: Angela T.

description: Homey and comfy good clam chowder their decor is
author: Jacqueline L.

description:
I think this place is way under rated. Probably because the Castro isn't known for cuisine. I love the super friendly staff, the excellent, rich warm chowder, the fantastic salad (with blue cheese), the Dungeness Crab burger. 

I always leave warm, happy and well fed.
author: Paige B.

description:
double wow.

I ate here on Saturday and all I keep dreaming about are them clams and that broth! OMG! So bitchin! 
We had the Anchor special - 12 oysters, 8 clams (SO GREAT), and 6 giant prawns, we had the great garlic bread, the crab, shrimp and prawn salad and the clam chowder. ( I wouldn't get the clam chowder, it was a really small bowl, for like 7 or 8 bucks and it was pretty bland)

So I saw this place on Check Please! that morning and had to go, initially we got pretty shitty service for some unexplainable reason, we also got a water refill with almost hot water... like the water fogged the glass up it was so warm, however as soon as I smiled and mentioned that we came because of the show, our waiter switched his tune and was super duper nice! Weird but great! And the reason why they aren't getting 5 stars from me.
I must be honest, the food was so great in my opinion, that I think I would have come back for more torture. Those clams!!!!!!
author: Zenaida H.

description:
worth the hype. especially liked the waitstaff

cod - cooked perfectly in a very tasty lemony broth
seafood stew - cooked nicely but probably wouldn't get again because the tomato broth is so familiar tasting
garlic bread - different and delicious

will definitely go back again to try more of the menu
author: Sanjiv P.

description: My husband and I went to this place and we had yelped it also as we were visiting SF.....had a very memorable night....loved the quaintness of the place and the staff and the fact that you can see your food being made by the one chef in the kitchen who was dazzling :)...food was fresh....definately try something with their lentils in it...enjoyed ourselves and then stumbled on the fact that Harvey Milks camera shop was just next door!
author: Leila B.

description: The cheese toast with crab and shrimp is freakin so good.  It looks heavy but was actually pretty light.  I thought it was going to stick to my fat bones but it made me feel like a normal fatty.  The oyster shooters were really good here. I don't like tomato juice but this was by far one of the better tasting oyster shooters I have eaten.  The only reason why I drop it one star is for the clam chowder.  It was flavorless and too thin for my taste.  I was surprised since everything else here was awesome.  I will be back with my back fat.
author: Fatty A.

description: We have been going to Anchor for the last five years and every time we've been here it has been wonderful.  The first time was a fluke...we were walking around the neighborhood in the afternoon and i looked inside and it's just the tiniest place, but it was cute, clean, and had a lot of charisma. This was the only time we didn't have to wait in line to get in, another fluke, which was good because we might have been impatient and never gone in.  So glad it wasn't busy that day. We have pretty much had to wait every time since, but, believe me, the food and the service are totally worth the wait.  Best fish and shellfish in town. We don't live in the San Francisco area, so whenever we are in town, we definitely make sure we stop in. We have recommended Anchor to friends and have brought visiting friends from as far away as Brasil: everyone loves it.  The only catch is they have got to love seafood...there is not the token burger or steak on the menu...it's all from the ocean, so be sure your dining companions are ready for some serious seafood.
author: Donna D.

description: Shrimp salad, crab cakes, clam chowder, and steamed mixed mussels. One meal here will satisfy your craving for seafood for a whole month! It wasn't until recently my friend pointed out that i haven't eaten a single oyster from here even though its called Anchor OYSTER bar! But can you blame me... just look at the menu. The oysters are the most boring thing on it... and that is a good thing! There might be a wait and the food does come out a little slow but its worth it. The service is always warm and friendly and you can't help feel you've been transported to New England inside this little place. I will order oysters next time i come for sure!
author: Charlie L.

description: Best seafood in San Francisco!  I went for the first time last week and loved it.  The wait was a little long but totally worth it!  Would definitely recommend to a friend
author: Joshua P.

description: Loved loved this place. We went here after Hope graduated from CCA to celebrate and did we celebrate. Worth every dime. Garlic bread wasn't better than mine but a vey close second. I think we tried just about everything. Clams, shrimp, mussels, crab, oysters, clam chowder, and garlic bread to soak up all that yummy broth. Go go go!
author: angela r.

description: Fresh seafood is best when prepared in a simple and straightforward manner (save the heavy seasoning for the frozen Costco fillets).  Anchor knows what's up and does exactly this - they offer up comforting dishes with no pretense.  The place is small and cozy (with great lighting) so you feel like you're eating in the comfort of your living room.  The $5 house wine is delicious, too.
author: Victoria G.

description: Absolutely the bomb! Best cioppino in SF! Only about 20 seats in the restaurant, but worth the wait. I've gone here 3x in a 2 week span. Great service, great oysters, great chef, ...I can't say enough.
author: Rouz E.

description: Yes the food is good but is it worth being treated like shit to get in? My friend and I waited 45 minutes to be passed over for friends of the waiter who were seated at the counter before we were - although we put on the sign that we would sit at the counter. And were not asked at all. Good food and it's a shame because I will never eat there again. F off Anchor.
author: Patrick E.

description: Very Yummy, The reason for the 4 stars was the prawns were kind of chewy...not the best. But the oysters, clams, and crabcakes were very good. It's a small place but worth waiting for a seat!
author: Jill T.

description:
What do you do on an afternoon in the Castro?  Stuff your face with seafood of course!  We walked by Anchor Oyster Bar around 4pm, peeked in and saw them setting up.  

The place is quite small but extremely cute with a very comfortable and cozy ambiance.  They were nice enough to seat us anyways.  Between the two of us, the husband and I ordered 6 oysters, enough for each of us to try all three of their daily oysters (kusshis, sweetwaters, beausoleils), crabcakes, a bowl of clam chowder, and a full cracked crab!  Service was awesome.  They people there are so incredibly nice and accommodating.  

I've had the oysters before except for the beausoleils so I knew they would be good.  The clam chowder was good but not the best I'd ever had since I did spend 6 years up in New England but the crab cakes were awesome!  They came with this homemade tarter sauce with fresh dill in there which I love.  I couldn't stop loading on the sauce even though it was covering the taste of the fresh crab in the crabcakes.  Now onto the cracked crab.  This was the whole reason the husband and I decided to have an mid-afternoon seafood extravaganza!  We wanted to taste local SF crab in the peak of crab season.  The options were $22 for half a cracked crab or $29 for a whole cracked crab.  Ummmm, really?!?!  Of course we're getting the whole crab!  It also comes with a cup of their clam chowder which the waiter was sweet enough to upgrade to a bowl for us.  Also, unfortunately, by the time we got there, the chef had already cleaned the crabs for all the gooey good ness under the shell which I personally love (crab butter) but I guess my cholesterol level will have to thank him for that.  The garlic butter that the crab came in was delish.  I had to put salt in it since I'm a salt fiend but it was great with the crab.  But there was a ton of crab!  Great value.  The only thing was that the crab didn't have that somewhat sweet taste that you get when you're really lucky.  Apparently the crab this season was not at it's peak but still pretty darn good.  We'll be back before the next year to see how next season is!

The one issue is that parking in the area is a bummer.  Also the wait can get kind of long as it got much more crowded by the time we left so just make sure to go early!
author: Susan L.

description: Tiny well-known restaurant with a very small menu - oysters, a few shellfish items, and 3 or 4 daily fish/pasta specials. Great vibe and decor. Sort of pricey, but very good quality seafood. Caesar salad w/ shrimp is decent but not amazing, spicy pasta/clam/calamari dish was totally bizarre but pretty tasty (spicy!).
author: E T.

description:
i was given a multiple choice where & what i want to eat for dinner tonight and none of the choices mentioned AOB, not until we saw a perfect parking spot across from this place and decided just to have some seafood here.

lucky indeed, there was no wait. we took the window seat, a perfect post to see the light rain pouring and people watch.

we ordered the most fascinating 6 pcs. of garlic bread in the planet. it was crunchy, toasty & soft in the inside and certainly bursting with flavor!!!

the huge bowl of green mussels, with a tease of soupy broth was amazingly edible, that you could dip your bread in it. the meat of this shellfish were all sensually plumped & deliciously, fleshy, warm to the palate. just perfectly cooked to be enjoyed with a squeeze of lemon.

the caesar salad with shrimp was also spectacular. they put the most rotund, pudgy shrimp ever landed in my salivating mouth. the romaine lettuce were gently tossed, for none of every single leaf was torn or bruised. a could hear the subtle crunch of these greens while chewing. 

the dressing was justly mixed and they definitely used splendid croutons, made from fresh french bread.

sea salt, hot sauce, pepper & oyster crackers (for your clam chowder, which they creatively used an abalone shell as a container) were all arranged conveniently on each tables.

the place is quite small, having 5 tables only and a tiny bar with simple decor.
impressively "shucking" since 1977, this place surely proves that they are doing an excellent job!
author: Nelle A.

description: A true neighborhood gem. When we finally had dinner here a couple of months ago, we kicked ourselves for the hundreds of times we've walked past this place and never stepped inside. WONDERFUL seafood... the specials board has enough options to supplement the regular menu nicely and the prices are very reasonable. It's teeny tiny and cozy as hell. Cannot wait to go back and try more of their delectable food.
author: margot b.

description: Very cute restaurant!  Next to the place where they filmed  the movie "milk"  I love this restuarant.  Very cute, small , casual date place.  The Kumotos oysters are amazing!  The clam chowder is probably the best chowder I've ever had.  The crab meat salad is delightful and light.  The service is wonderful and staff was super friendly.  I love this place!
author: Ying F.

description: Food here was great. Only reason it's not 5 stars is because the service was really slow. I'll give you that it was super busy on a Saturday night but like, one of my side orders never showed up and the waiter never came back by for me to tell until it was time for the to go boxes.
author: Lloyd B.

description:
I have been here 3 times over the past 2 months. I'm going to keep this as simple as the food and surroundings of this restaurant. 

Pros: 
- Service has been all over the place from outstanding to nearly perfect. OK. It has been perfect each time I've gone. The entire staff is attentive and smooth.  
- The crab cakes are light and do nothing to mask the flavor - the light breading, lemon wedge and dill dressing on the side enhance the sweet but firm pieces of crab meat. Do not threaten the crab cakes with physical violence like I did on Sunday. 
- The bread is not for everyone - don't order it unless you're a fan of all things having to do with garlic, butter and (just a touch of) melted cheese. 
- The clam chowder is delicate while but holding together - many clam chowders tend to break up as you eat them. Not here. The last bite was as good as he first. The clams melted in my mouth.
- Caesar salad - not a meek salad. Strong hints of citrus and crisp romaine are balanced with fresh home made croutons.
- Crab/ Shrimp cocktails - Both were simple and outstanding - although the crab meat has been a notch above the shrimp.
- Black and green mussels - if you have ordered anything else above besides the bread, don't even try it. These dishes managed to have a huge taste of butter, wine and garlic going perfectly hand in hand with the tender and flavorful mussels. It seemed like the bowl was filled with more mussels than seemed appropriate. These dishes paired with the garlic bread will keep True Bleeders and Twilighters away. Ordered together, the bread and mussels inspired awe and self loathing when I realized that it was difficult to finish and more difficult to send back the unfinished portion. 
- Oh yeah - the oysters. We have had oysters there for desert. Simply perfect.

Cons:
- The Anchor Stem has malfunctioned every time we've gone - I had to find something that wasn't completely perfect.
- There are too many people who like this place. Wait- is that even a con? Maybe everyone can come here during the week and leave it to us for the weekends? Any takers?

I recommend you stay away. On the weekends. Or if you see my GF and I walking in, would you at least hurry up and get on out as quickly as possible? We are there for a beautiful meal, thanks.
author: Jason S.

description: yep! i do my darnest 2try 2stay away from this beautiful layback yummi-licious of plaze... but can i stay away 222 long...? Nahhh, not possible! EVERYTHING's wonderful and dance in ya mouth-licious :p Ooooo... over here sum' ... ( i so have RAISED my hands !!)
author: LindaLu N.

description: Had the best dinner at Anchor last night!  It's a tiny little gem, and was well worth the wait for a table to become available. The oysters were so fresh and delish; our crab appetizer on lettuce leaves was to die for, then breadcrumb-encrusted fish with mashed potatoes and  cauliflower -- we were in heaven. Not to mention the freshest, most delicious bean and greens salad I've ever had.  Amazing service and a couple bottles of sancerre later, and you had a very happy table of 4 diners!  Thank you Anchor -- we will be back again and again.
author: Sarah B.

description: A little bit of New England in the heart of the Castro, this tiny, no-frills, storefront cafe - with just a handful of stainless steel tables and a small counter - has survived for well over two decades despite its minimal capacity. What they clearly don't make in volume they must earn on each individual serving, since prices are astronomically high. Those who crave raw shellfish will find at least three varieties of freshly shucked oysters daily. Most dishes are simple and straightforward but decidedly average.  A far better deal is Swan's on Polk.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
This was a wonderful surprise, the food is excellent, fresh. We ordered the large order of oysters/prawns, shrimp cocktail, steamed green lipped mussels, awesome and the steamed clams were the best. Both steamed shellfish dishes had one of the best broths I have ever tasted. 

Service was excellent, and we will be back this is a special little restaurant.
author: Esther H.

description: Terrific seafood specials, delightful service, and a chef that rules!  How could you go wrong?  Hands down, my favorite place to eat in the gay-borhood (the Castro).  The oysters are always amazing, and as stated the nightly seafood specials are a taste sensation.  Taylor is the main chef at night and I'm always impressed. The service is always with a smile and the staff is more than knowledgeable with all the menu and nightly selections.  You can't go wrong, really.
author: Keith B.

description: Lately, I've  gone by here at least once a week and on a whim, I decided to go in.  Okay, first off, I know it's a bit expensive, but it's seafood, right?  Anyway, i walked in and sat at the bar closest to the kitchen and let me say that if you're prone to be claustrophobic, this may not be the place for you, because it's a small space that fills up quickly.  The waitstaff was cordial and attentive and as I stated before, my meal was pricey but very good.  I had their green salad with shrimp and their bowl of clam chowder.  The green salad was fresh with  very generous portions of shrimp, I had it with a balsamic vinaigrette and it made you feel as though you were indulging without the guilt.  The seafood chowder was delicious and hearty.  I'm definitely going back, when I make a bit more money.
author: Carlos C.

description: always great food, good service and an interesting crowd - a tight fit, but that's part of the charm. I had the tuna tonight, and it was great - but my friend had the scallops, and we both agreed - these were the best scallops either one of us has ever had.
author: judah m.

description: I can't say much that hasn't already been said. You get service with a smile at Anchor especially when they bring out small cups of chowder for those who have been out waiting in the cold. The staff is always so friendly and the food is delicious time after time. Such a fun date - highly rec'd going with someone you don't mind getting messy with!
author: Ciao A.

description: Oooo la la, it's like you were there all along and here I was worshiping the Hog Island Oyster Company, but you knew better, ohh yes you did.  You knew that if anything was going to seduce me it was the special fish bathed in persimmon sauce, AND the artichoke smothered in butter and herbs.  All of this with yummy steamed muscles and oyster shooters?  I mean, seriously, I jammed it all in my mouth and uttered a sigh of relief that this place is TWO BLOCKS FROM MY HOUSE.  It's like I've been saved.  The only thing Hog Island has on this place is it's view and it's bread.  This place is GOOD, please proceed directly but leave me a spot at the bar.
author: Claire C.

description: This place just captures the spirit of the bay.  Cozy and perfect.  Organic and seasonal.  Tasty and unpretentious.  You start the experience by waiting outside with others and your name on a chalkboard.  A server comes out and offers everyone chowder.  People are talking and happy.  Once inside you can see why people wait.  It is just cute and and happy and romantic and casual and...The menu is written on the chalk board, the oysters are of course an item that must be eatten but it was the seasonal heirloom tomatoe salad and halibut main course that won my heart.  This is a place for date night and to impress out of towners.  You are not rushed.  Again, just perfect.
author: Jessica M.

description: The perfect neighborhood place. We've been going to the Anchor for years. Some weeks I think we went every single day for lunch. That's how solid it is. They don't take reservations, and the place is tiny. Soups and salads always delightful and impeccably fresh. Service always spot-on. Specials inventive and yummy. If you are a fan of the oyster, the clam, the shrimp, the crab, the mussel and the fish, you're in for a treat. Casual and always enjoyable. Friendly employees who have worked here for years make your meal even better.
author: mary m.

description:
This place was recommended by a concierge on our trip to San Francisco. We wanted to find local and quaint place... We loved it. We tried the crab cakes with delicious aioli sauce. Fantastic!
Of course, we both ordered fish. Both perfectly done!
I highly recommend it and can't wait to go back.
author: michelle p.

description:
On my birthday and special occasions I eat at this restaurant. Its a very wonderful experience. Candle lit dinner and some seafood. If you are a seafood lover this place is as good as it gets.

The staff are very kind and helpful. The meals are all prepared to order and again this is truly a wonderful dining experience.

Very romantic place and I hope you get to experience a dinner here. One of the best places in San Francisco for a seafood meal or a romantic dinner.
author: andrew k.

description: This was truly the best seafood in San Fran. Its very small and only seats 28 people so get there at 4pm when they open. It you have to wait I promise it will be worth it.
author: Torie H.

description: What great little place- stainless steel table tops, a quieter part of the Castro, great crab caesar salad, tasty pasta, garlic bread, nice little wine list, and very friendly service.  A nice little neighborhood joint worth a trek.  Not sure about the wait- my friends were seated by the time I arrived.  Will come back.
author: T W.

description: I would like to add my voice to the chorus fans; this intimate eatery never disappoints. The mark of a great restaurant is do a few dishes and do them well; try the seafood pasta special, two thumbs up.
author: Jon O.

description:
I walked by Anchor Oyster Bar probably over 100 times and always want to try it.  I even got rave reviews from some friends on their seafood.  Finally I cleared my bank account on my day off, went into Anchor and ordered myself a fresh dungeness crab meat sandwich with a cup of clam chowder.  The chowder came and it was hot which is a good sign.  A couple spoonful confirmed that either the chef had a cold or he forgot his salt and pepper.  It was a creamy concoction of diced vegetable and chopped clams.  Then the long awaited "fresh" crab meat sandwich arrived.  The crab meat was moist but lack of the sweetness of fresh crab meat (like the one I had at Swan).  In between the buns, there was a piece of lettuce and a slice of tomato.  No cocktail sauce, tartar sauce or even salt and pepper.  Again, with my high blood pressure and high cholesterol, I probably should appreciate that the sandwich did NOT come with any condiment.  I am just curious how did the management know about it in advance.

Service was very friendly and welcoming, to say the least.
author: Foodie C.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants.  I like the whole vibe.  You put your name on the white-board out front and either sit on the bench and wait, or go bar hop for 10-20 minutes and come back to be seated.  It is a lot of fun and how many 'shucking' years have they been serving great food?  Many!  I recommend just about anything on the menu but if you are budget conscious, go for the seafood salads.  They are huge!  Well worth your 'clams'.  Only drawback is the wait sometimes, but if you don't mind eating at the bar, you can be in and seated relavtively quickly.  But again, that just adds to the vibe.  If you are looking for a east coasty type of seafood restaurant, this is the spot.
author: Arturo S.

description: Well put together.... Staff, look, food.  Small cozy neighborhood feel.  More expensive than I thought it should be for the amount of food or time you can allow yourself to stay (there are usually others waiting and I feel I should get in and get out).  Quality is up there though!
author: Dizzy L.

description: It's a good if a little over-priced place in the Castro, which is an automatic four-stars. Spare, clean, good raw bar, good shellfish entrees.
author: patrick g.

description:
Absolutely delightful! This is the best seafood / oyster restaurant that I have been to in a while. The food was unpretentious and cooked and prepared so right. The oysters were absolutely amazingly fresh. When we went, they had 4 types of raw oysters, 2 from east coast, 2 from west coast which I thought was a good mix. The garlic bread is amazing. Such fresh ingredients in everything they make. The food & restaurant are just absolutely honest and unpretentious. My favorite type of restaurant. The service was fantastic. So attentive and everything just came out at the right time. The restaurant is very small and the restroom is through the tiny kitchen, which I don't mind walking by so much since I could see the condition they cook in. It passes my test. I also noticed there are a lot of regulars there and everyone just seem to know each other. They don't take reservations and it gets very busy during dinner time. But it is so well worth the wait, I can't wait to go back.
Food is much better than Hog Island at the Ferry Building and less expensive too.
author: Lai T.

description: Being new to the neighborhood, I'm determined to try all my locals.  My girlfriend and I popped in here for a late lunch on a Saturday and grabbed a couple open spots at the bar.  Both the guys behind the bar were attentive and helpful with our questions and keeping our tea glasses filled.  We each had one of the specials (crab sandwich and a tuna melt with an oyster appetizer).  It was all incredibly fresh and delicious!  The portions were not excessive and so we were not overly full despite both an appetizer and a meal.  Next time I'll try the oyster shooters and we will definitely be back!  It's a bit pricey, but for the great, fresh seafood, it's worth it!
author: Lara L.

description:
Makes me feel like an east coaster again.  The real deal, with no dress up.  I went with a friend, had the clam chowder, dozen oysters, crab, and a we each had a drink.  Service was perfect. My friend spilled her wine (only one glass) and they poured another with no question.  It was a pleasure to be here and I will definitely go back.
My one star taken away is for the soup.  It wasn't creamy enough.  I was so excited about it that the disappointment was, well, worth taking away a star.
author: J E.

description: Went there after a show at the Castro theater so it was nice to find a place open at 10:30PM.  Great New England small restaurant atmosphere and outstanding oysters (we had 3 kinds) and clams.  They brought tons of bread to soak up the clam juice.  Very nice service as well.
author: Gary M.

description: You gotta wait.  And you should.  It's fantastic every time.  Whatever special they've concocted for a given night is a winner.  Ravioli - awesome.  Mustard crusted sea bass - awesome. Oysters - awesome.  Wait staff and the chef (pretty sure she's the owner) are there just about every night, and have been for 30 years.  You can count on the same experience every time, and it's great.
author: Brian D.

description: The crab cakes at Anchor Oyster Bar are divine!!  Clam chowder is fresh and thick and delicious. Good bread too.  Nice wine selection.  Every fish special that I've ever had here was perfect.  I love the atmosphere becasue it is cozy and super clean.  The waiters are also very friendly.
author: Valerie D.

description: F-A-B-U-L-O-U-S.  I've been meaning to write this review forever but never found time.  Went here months ago after an evening at the de Young  -  so it must have been a Friday.  We strolled through the Castro looking for somewhere to eat, we were famished.  The restaurants were all packed and we kept walking hoping to find a place without a wait.  Passed the Anchor and knew this was it for us even though we still had to wait.   It was about 30min. before we got in but there was a little bench outside which made it easy for us to stare at people inside while wondering how good the food is.  It was worth the wait.  This place is small, cozy, some might say tiny, I thought it was perfect.  The sort of place I'd go back to with friends.  Sat at the bar sandwiched between a retired professional soccer player from Brazil - I forget his name, started with a P., and a world class physicist from Chile.  Needless to say I was enthralled with The Latin Sensation.  We had clams, simply delicious, bravo.  These clams were so good, it made us silly.  Then we had a huge bowl of cioppino - just the right amount of spice and tang we wanted.  We ate this with bread, butter, and fell in love.  At the end of the meal I complemented how refreshing the tall glass of cold water was, but what I meant to say is Thank you, our dinner was simply wonderful.  Everything was great from the moment we saw the place, walked in, and ate our meal.  The staff, ambiance, and food made for an unforgettable experience, a perfect blend of charm, zest, and robust flavors.
author: Pinky T.

description: A little restaurant  bar in the gayest town I ever been to, don't let that deter you homophobs. The service here is excellent, the waiter knew his oysters and told us exactly where they were from and how they tasted/ texture and comparable oysters from other regions. We got the anchor special , 12 oysters ( we had 4 differnt types, 3 each) 4 chilled peeled shrimp and a bowl of clams in a buttery wine/lemon sauce with herbs, lotta garlic and a big sprig of rosemary. Also you are given bread and a small wine list to choose from. The bread was great dipped in the clam butter sauce, the shrimp was shrimp ( can't do much to mess that up, it was soft not tough) the oysters were excellent, though maybe like three or four tasted overly salted, I don't know if they're naturally salty or if they sprinkled rock salt on it before serving. The cocktail sauce was decent.
author: Susan F.

description:
3.5* Rounding down  
This place tries to charm you with their attentive service (though beware there is only 1 server and he gets easily distracted), unsuspectingly sophisticated daily specials, and propensity to pacify the crowds with complimentary chowder, wine, and occasionally t-shirts. Although you will not be disappointed by the freshness of the seafood and near perfect preparation, the wait is long and brutal to get inside this once clothing boutique now turned restaurant if you are not equipped to endure the chilly SF winds.
Expect to feel like a whale if you are not less than 180lbs in  this restaurant that only seats 30,  expect to overpay, and expect a constantly changing menu in this cramped seafood cove. While certainly enjoyable, the food is definitely not extraordinary nor unique to the point that it should preclude anyone from indulging in SF seafood in a more convenient and comfortable venue.
The Food: The Paella ($27) was barely on par with my previous paella experiences, lacking the distinctive saffron fragrance of the dish. While I acknowledge that there is no one recipe for this Spanish classic, Anchor oyster bar is a bit limited in their preparation including only 2 prawns, 5 clams, 10 mussels, 3 crawfish, and sausage- leaving out the peas, tomatoes, chicken and squid you often get at other Spanish restaurants. The halibut ($24) was significantly much more noteworthy. We found it to be tender, flaky, and seasoned with just the right amount of fresh herbs to subtly compliment he natural flavors of the perfectly cooked fish. 
There is nothing exceptional about their signature chowder which is on the runnier side and lackluster when it comes to flavor. The sourdough is a bit tough, but perfect for sopping up the sauces/broth if you're a carbotarian.
author: Vicky V.

description: Best little hole in the wall for great seafood! I had the crab sandwich and clam chowder at the counter. The crab was so fresh and the chowder was perfect. Better than I get in the east coast. Enjoy!
author: Loren P.

description: I've been here twice now.  The first time, the food (Anchor Special for a dozen oysters, 4 large shrimp, and some steamed clams; and clam chowder) was 5 star amazingness.  Everything was incredibly fresh, and the sauce for the clams was perfectly seasoned with a spicy zing to it.  This past time, the oysters and shrimp were still great.  However, the clam chowder was significantly runnier and contained fewer actual clams.  And the sauce for the steamed clams was far too salty - I can handle salty better than most, but this was gag-- gulpdownwater-- tryagaintoseeifitwasreallythatsalty-- gulpdownwine-- donotdipbreadinit salty.  But service was great, and the crab cakes were good ... so I'll review it mostly based on my first experience (minus a star for the most recent visit's mishap), and give them one more chance to prove me wrong.
author: Kristen H.

description: The clam chowder is yummy! Oysters are deeeeliccccssshhh! Although there was only one waiter available... They are incredibly friendly (:
author: Monica C.

description:
Super mediocre experience with tasteless oysters.  They're lucky the much stronger competition is so far away.  I live in Noe, but will happily trek over to Swan Oyster Depot, Hog Island, etc rather than stop here.

Over priced, oysters didn't taste right, cramped tables, extremely loud service staff doing dishes on a metal counter right behind the bar, ambivalent service staff, weak beer and wine menu.  Maybe I'm missing something but I just don't see what all the hype is about.  The problem is I won't have another chance to try it - there are too many other good restaurants.
author: Zack S.

description: Was there last week again. Food as fresh as ever, the tastiest seafood on the west coast. You need to check it out!
author: J M.

description: The food here is great, the products fresh.  The only issue i have is the whiteboard system to reserve your spot in the list.  One of the staff seems to play with it a bit depending on what i don't know.  All i know is we didn't get seated in the order that was presented to us.  Watch that list!  Would have gotten 5 stars if it wasn't for that, which kept us waiting for a half hour longer than we should have (we waited an hour and 20 minutes total when it should have been much less).
author: M K.

description: A treat everytime we go. The clam chowder is excellent, and very authentic. I love the diverse menu, but the super special of 12 oysters, shrimp and clams almost always woos me away from other dishes. It is an orgy of enjoyment!
author: Steven A.

description: The worst service and waitress attitude I've experienced in my 12 years in the Castro, bar none.  At the time she brought my entree she informed my dining companion that they were out of the special he had ordered (at 6:15???).  Was this really her first opportunity to let us know that?  And to just bring my entree anyway, when my companion's would not be available for another 10 or 15 minutes? What, is this place run by junior high school students?  The food is good but not great.  So let me recap: horrendous service, mediocre food, downtown prices.  Absolutely avoid this place.  The staff is unfriendly, incompetent, and has attitude to spare.
author: Roger S.

description: This is a very cute little restaurant. Small, with classic seafood bar good looks. I had the excellent fortune of walking by here on one of the first warm weekends of 2006, so my wife and I dropped in and ordered a $25!!! salad. It was worth it though. Loaded with fresh crab meat and shrimp, it was just perfect for two people on a warm day in the Castro. And the waiter, I think maybe owner? really made us feel welcome. Clean and classy; everything about this place is just very well balanced. It could become a regular for us. Highly recommended!
author: Johnny O.

description: Woah! Thats some damn good seafood! I was recommended this place by a few trusted san francisco foodies for a trip that I just took there. We were told to order their daily specials off the chalk board that change constantly. When we got there we discovered that they apparently have free corkage, so we went in a desperately quick search for a bottle of wine, but to no avail. Although neither me nor my partner like oysters  very much, but we decided to order a half order of the anchor special- 6 different types of oysters- from BC, oregon, and somewhere else, clams in a delicious garlicy broth, and 2 huge prawns. I may be missing some of it... Anywho, We decided to order off the chalk board. I got spinach and ricotta ravioli w/ dungeness crab meat, and my partner got some of the best scallops ive ever had. Perfectly cooked, seasoned, and served with delightful mashed potatoes and steamed veggies. This place is small, but if you can make it here, I recommend it! This is definitely on our list of places to return to in San Francisco!
author: Matt P.

description: I enjoyed my visit here, even if the food didn't blow me away. The clam chowder was very good, the oysters were ho-hum and the Dungeness crab was above average. The Sancerre and sparkling wine were simple, clean and complemented the food well. I recommend it if you're in the neighborhood and jonesing for straightforward seafood. Service was fast and friendly.
author: Jason B.

description:
this is a great place to come for a snack, or for a full on meal.  fresh and delicious seafood, accompanied with complimentary bread and butter.

try the oyster shooters!
author: Sheri N.

description: If you want to taste Dungeness crab in its most authentic and glorious state, this is the place! The food is simple, and expertly prepared without the kind of fussyness that so often obscures the taste of excellent quality fish and seafood. Everything on the menu is top-notch but I'm especially partial to the California Caesar special: a giant salad with tons of tomato, avocado and enormous chunks of sweet Dungeness. The service is first-rate and the ambiance is super friendly.
author: M T.

description: I love Anchor and enjoyed having it around the corner from my house for so many years. I went there last Saturday and they were obviously having an off night. Usually the service is great, not tonight. It was extremely slow, our waiter seemed irritable and our food showed up in a strange order, oysters came after dinner and the salad came last? Anyway, the oysters were fresh as usual, but they were almost inedible because of the amount of shell in them. The garlic bread was burnt and the bread and butter I ordered never showed up at all. I do have to say their seafood specials off the board are outstanding, and the clam chowder is great too. Don't miss the oyster shooters either. I don't know what happened on Saturday, maybe someone was on vacation.
author: Sarah S.

description:
A jewel in the middle of Castro. I absolutely love this intimate, homey, "friendly to all" restaurant. I just can't wait to come back!

Atmosphere: Feels like you're in one of those small restaurants on the coast of Brittany, next to the ocean. There is a bar/counter, which is great for singles as well as couples, 2 small tables and 3 larger tables for groups. You can choose whatever makes you more comfy but would just recommend avoiding peak hours during week-end because this place is very popular and doesn't need advertisements.

Food: Don't hesitate to express what you like / would like to try because the servers would have the perfect food and wine pairing recommendations for you (as long as you don't expect the wine to be super fine/sophisticated)...I tried the oysters (and was not even found of oysters to begin with), the mussels as well as different fishes. Each time, it savored my shellfish/fish until the last bite. Portions are generous so I always order a 1/2 portion of mussels or oysters to start with

Service: Fun, friendly, knowledgeable, prompt (without being too fast either), attentive to details and to you! It is so refreshing!

The experience and quality of the food is well worth the price but if you're looking for a more formal/spacious atmosphere, I would recommend some other places.
author: Caroline B.

description: My gf and I saw this place on the way to Harvey's and decided to try it on the way back. We sat at the bar and I already knew what I wanted...Oysters. So I ordered three shooters. The waitress suggested I try a shooter with soju, so I said what the heck I am daring and love alcohol. Oh man what a bad idea. I first of all must of ordered it wrong because I just wanted a plain oyster with lemon, but I figured why not continue on with the adventure. I ate the first oyster with a bloody Mary kind of liquid and it was good. Then I decided I was going to try the bloody Mary soju one. It went down horrible and there was some shell in it, which ruined it even more. I almost threw up, but I decided I would be polite and swallow it. The bill for the three oysters came out to $13. I guess people don't come here for the oysters, but really for the crab, even though it is called an oyster bar.I  don't know if I want to have anymore adventures here.
author: Stephanie L.

description: 3.5 stars. Oysters...delicious.....fresh, raw oysters. Ordered the anchor special with 3 different types of oysters, which I can't remember what each were. They each had a different flavor to it, I had no idea oysters had different flavors to them! The oysters were fresh, small and clean. I really don't like it if I eat an oyster and there is a bunch of sand in the shell, not the case here. I also liked the steamed clam, it came in this very tasty broth, awesome for dipping the bread in. The clam chowder wasn't sandy and tasted pretty good. We also ordered the baked red snapper which was baked with a dijon mustard with some broiled veggies. I would have liked the red snapper more if it didn't have the dijon mustard but that's just because I like my fresh fish with as little sauce on it. It was still very good. I would recommend this place to others and the price was a little on the more expensive side but it's expected. We spent about $30.00 a person without drinks.
author: Tiffany L.

description: At the end of a meal, you may ask yourself, "would I come here again?" I said yes. So I would presume it to be 5 stars. My wife and I went there about 6 months ago, which left us with the impression that S.F. is a culinary city with the best quality seafood, hand-picked by the chefs, rather than a bulk buying chain restaurant. I had the special Rosemary Wild Alaskan Salmon and Pancetta. Outstanding taste, texture, and flavor. I have had rosemary on a salmon dish before, but the initial experience left me with the impression that rosemary was just too strong. This time, the rosemary was roasted just so that it popped with the perfect essence, but not too overpowering. Salmon was just barely crusted and medium in the center with no fishy taste whatsoever. Pancetta was the perfect compliment to the texture and flavor of the salmon. The atmosphere is a little cramped with a feeling of being "right in the kitchen" while your food is being prepared. Lots of white tile. Also, I know how New-England clam chowder should be, because my grandfather made it in R.I. This place uses WAY too much cream and potatoes. If any of you working there reads this, you need more clam broth, the soup tastes too milky. However, the salmon was the dish. My wife had the mahi-mahi with mango salsa. That was light and fluffy. Very pleasing to the palette. A great place to go with your special someone, or with a couple of friends that want great food to go with that conversation.
author: Edward B.

description: Try their Ciopinno. Amazing though really expensive. I crave it in the winter.
author: Trinity M.

description: Wow do I love this place.  Let me count the ways.  I love the clam chowder - more than anything in Fisherman's Wharf.  I love the crabcakes.  The ceaser salad with shrimp.  The cioppino.  Holy goodness!  The oysters - the freshest in SF by FAR.  The wine and beer selection.  The ambiance - like a dream from a far off corner of Europe.  This is the real deal.  The wait can be VERY annoying (as you have to wait outside).  The servers are always overwhelmed, which isn't great, and you know way too much about your neighbors (since they are on top of you).  Parking sucks - welcome to the Castro.  But it is ALL worth it.  Can't get enough of this place.
author: Dann H.

description: go early (as in 5ish) or it gets packed fast.  excellent oysters and their steamed clams had this somewhat spicy sauce that made me not be able to stop eating bread.   decent beer choices (i think -i got drunk fast here for some reason :) )
author: X X.

description: Had a fantastic meal. The sea bass was excellent and of course the oysters. Highly recommended and the service was great.
author: David F.

description: Unadored, and very good. the food and interior both. A rarity in the castro to be sure.
author: Stellah D.

description: Probably the best Sea Bass I have ever had. And the Crab in garlic sauce will make you melt. Side dishes tend to be on the small side and prices are a bit high. Limited but cozy seating, often with long waits at peak hours. Super friendly service. A little gem  amidst the splashier places in the Hood and in the City.
author: Eric P.

description: I agree with Cynthia - very nicely done Crab Caesar salad, as well as a tasty Manhattan clam chowder (tomato not cream based). There was an open-faced crab sandwich that caught my attention - unfortunately the mayo factor made it a no-go for me - but you dig in anyway! Generous crab portions which was a pleasant surprise. Not cheap but generous portions make it worth sharing entrees.
author: Mariangela S.

description:
Cute place! We decided to try this place since we saw a review on some restaurant tv show.  Service was lacking as we and a couple other customers were neglected at the bar.  (We all kind of looked at eachother and shrugged since it was obvious we were ready to order, get the bill, needed water, etc.)  I guess there are only two waiters and everyone else just cleans up.  Too many bodies behind the counter, not enough service to the customers.

 We ordered all that was recommended: 

1. 2 Oyster shooters - very good! I've never had oyster shooters before and the spiciness was just right.  
2. i bowl of Clam Chowder - heavenly.  Fresh ingredients and just the right creaminess.  We should have ordered one bowl each.
3. 1 order of Crab cakes appetizers (2)- The BEST crab cakes I've ever eaten- EVER.  We should have ordered more!
4. 6 oysters on a half shell- good, but SMALL.  I suppose since the types of oysters available are typically small, they were good, but I prefer the meatier ones.  About $2.50ea is a little pricey for oysters that are the size of a quarter.
5. Garlic bread- average.  I could skip this next time.

We didn't order any alcohol and the bill came out to $50.  

Overall a good place - we will definitely come back for the clam chowder and crab cakes.
author: Anna C.

description: Nearly stunning quality and taste, but a very long wait - vastly improved by a generous sample of their clam chowder. I had a super-tasty halibut, and my friend Anthony had Cioppino (I took the leftover broth & made a delicious pasta the next day).
author: Patrick M.

description: Great chowder, fresh garlic bread, and varied oysters. It's tiny, so either get there early or plan to wait.  Put your name on the white board outside the door, and they'll call you when ready.  The offerings change daily, and they post them above the counter.  This is the heart of the Castro and is obviously gay friendly.
author: Dawn G.

description: It's cozy, cute and comforting for New Englanders sequestered on the West Coast.  The food is delicious, the fish is fresh, and the staff is on the ball.  The only glitch is it's a bit pricey.  Dinner for one = $35-40.
author: Paddy G.

description: While I agree with many reported service problems at this restaurant (they try to get by with one waiter--the SAME waiter--ALONE, every night), the food IS great, the best on The Castro (unfortunately, a low bar).  Try the Borscht Stew--it's not on the menu every night, but when it is, I always order it.
author: Ed T.

description: Even though this place is tiny, I've always had luck getting a spot right at the counter.  The service is very pleasant, and the food is excellent.  The only reason I gave this place 4 stars, instead of 5, is because of the cost.  It's a bit pricey for me to eat here frequently.  That being said, now that I've discovered this place in my neighborhood, I've been here 3 times in the last two weeks.  The Clam Chowder is "off the hook", especially along with their incredible home made garlic bread.  The raw oysters have always been great, even though they are those tiny Kumimoto ones.  They have daily specials which have always been great.  I also discovered they have a Cioppino that's not on the menu.  It looked amazing.  The guys sitting next to me, said it was the best they'd ever had.  Which brings me to another nice thing about this place;  everyone is so friendly.  If you sit at the counter, you'll most likely become friendly with your neighbors.  By the end of your meal you'll probably be sharing what everyone has ordered, so you can try a lot of tasty things on the menu.
author: Vance P.

description:
yummy! 

i went here for my first real oyster bar experience and it was unsurpassable. since all the seats in this quaint little spot were taken when we arrived, they offered us a drink while we waited. 

sitting at the bar was great. they were on top of it, refilling our bread and butter as needed, and the food came out promptly. i ordered the clam chowder (scrumptious especially when dipped into with the freshly-baked bread), crabcakes - also delicious, and a half-order of the special which featured fresh raw oysters, two gigantic prawns, and clams in a tasty garlic sauce (also bread-dipping worthy).

my friend ordered the mussels which were actually my favorite. all topped off with an anchor steam, best first oyster experience ever!

oh...they have the teeeeny-tiniest bathroom i've ever seen, but it was clean!
author: april s.

description: I was expecting fantastic.  I really wanted to love this place.  Maybe my expectations were too high.  But with the great reviews on Yelp and Check Please! Bay Area I expected much much better.  We sat at the bar and had to watch someone wash dishes the entire time.  It was kind of unappealing.  The service was slow.  The food was ok, It wasn't necessarily bad there were just a lot of little issues that eventually added up.  To name a few: our bread was really hard and the butter practically frozen, our crab cocktail had too many shells in it and my steamers had a bit more sand than I like to consume in one meal.  The good news is aside from the shells and sand the meal was fine and my beer was delicious.
author: Roberta J.

description:
OMG! 
This place is TERRIFIC! 
My Mom lives very close to the neighborhood and I visit her quite often , on my out to Marin I   drive past it  and  have been doing so for years . I always very curious about it. WHY THE HECK DID I WAIT?? The clam chowder is so yummy... even better than the ones I have had in Boston. The Oyster platter to die for. The servers are really friendly. I have told everyone I know about this little gem.
author: Francesca S.

description: I'm not sure what all the fuss is over this place.   While it is a charming spot, the food leaves much to be desired.  There is really nothing special about it except the price of everything.  Wow!!! I'm not sure how they get away charging that much for food and wine, given the quality.  And with "Oyster Bar" in the name, I would expect much better selection on oysters.   The salad was almost laughable - some lettuce, a couple olives, and a couple cherry tomatoes. I think it was $8 or $9 dollars and looked like it cost 50 cents to make.  The wine sucked and cost about $9 a glass.  I had fish with vegetables.  Again....boring!!!  I could have gone home and steamed some veggies myself.  Absolutely nothing memorable about this place.  I've tried it a couple times and this one was my last.
author: Joe T.

description: The seafood was fresh. The service ok, the ambiance lacking...it does not compare to Swan's in my eyes, but still good seafood.
author: Adrienne G.

description: I am so in love with this place!It can be a long wait but it's definitely worth it!The seafood cioppino is not on the menu but they can make it for you every night of the week.The garlic parmesan bread is just divine!The waiters are extremely warm and very friendly.This restaurant is one of the reasons why I cannot leave my awesome 'hood!
author: Paulina L.

description: If you think Cioppino is a dish best made in San Francisco, then this should be the place by which Cioppino is judged.  It's really, really good....and not on the menu, so ask for it.  It's a very very small place....so best suited for intimate dinners of 2 vs. large parties.  Daily menu selections change based on seasonal items or catch of the day, but always consistent and top quality.  Come early for good parking and quicker wait times. It's obviously in the gay-ber-hood....so that's a plus for me.  If you don't like dining while looking at dudes on dates.....then why the hell are you eating in the Castro?  Oh...and you can get a good hand job next door.  I'm just sayin....
author: Todd C.

description: It's hard for me to give five stars but this place deserves it. I love their oysters on the half shell and they're helpful when asking questions about them. Steamed clams are great and their crab salad is bomb! They have great service and cute dining room.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Oysters are one of those rare treats and boy was it worth having it here. The varieties of oysters were super fresh and their boston clam chowder was really tasty plus the interior of the place is super cute! Yes, it can get pricey but it was worth the splurge!
author: Paola W.

description: God bless oysters and god bless this place. I don't know about the wait because we sat at the bar. Now the oysters are lovely, there is a nice variety and the garlic bread - yum and Cesar salad yum. If you like oysters go here, get a liter of the house white a dozen oysters share the Cesar and some garlic bread and sit at the bar if you can. The decor is really quaint as well - nautical and clean. mmmmmmmm just thinking of the place makes me wanna get an oyster on the half right now! Our friend got a special off the menu and it looked GOOD - she ate the whole thing. Don't go in a large group keep it to 4 or less. We were 3 and it was perfect and the waiter behind the bar was really attentive.
author: melissa h.

description: Love it. Love the oysters, love the gigantic crab caesar salad, I even love the bread. Oh, and love the delicious little oyster crackers. Go early to avoid the wait.
author: Jen S.

description: this is my first time go to this bar, is a small little restaurant, personal i small restaurant, and the food is very good. i love the house wine, i try the daily special  is the pasta is large and with so many ingredient and for the price i paying for, i love it!
author: zoe z.

description: Great fresh seafood specials. Some of the best clam chowder in the city. Make sure you try an oyster shooter Ofter a wait list at prime dining hours. Just put your name on the chalkboard and they will call your name.
author: Deno M.

description: Absolutely love Anchor Oyster Bar. This little diamond in a rough is so wonderful.Their garden salad was very fresh that even the plain carrots were so good, the garlic prawns were flavorful, and one of the fish specials ( I can't recall which fish I had) was made with a stunning sauce which just complemented and tied the whole dish together. Our waiter had great customer service and was very knowledgeable when it came to the oysters.My suggestions is to arrive early since it is tiny and will get very crowded. Definitely way better to go here for a full meal along with fresh oysters over Hog Island Oyster Bar with their mediocre food menu.
author: christine t.

description: I am on the fence for giving between 4-5 stars.  This place is fantastic.  The service was great (we sat at the bar -- if anything we were rushed, I'm sure they like to turn over the seats here).  Fun oyster selection but not overwhelming, great cesar, awesome shellfish platter special.  Our white wine was a bit on the too warm side.  Fix that and it's perfection.  Why doesn't this stellar seafood restaurant get more press in this town?
author: e w.

description: Went to Anchor for the first time the other night. After 20 years of living in the city its one of the only restaurants in the Castro that I'd yet to eat at. It didn't disappoint. Great simple seafood dishes in a very cozy environment. It was fun watching the pedestrians walk by while eating at the window table. The service was great and make sure to try the garlic bread--its out of this world! The prices are a bit higher, but I think the quality of the food makes up for it.
author: kevin b.

description: What can I add when there are already almost 100 other reviews? This is one of my favorite get-aways for that one night I usually have free, when attending conferences in San Fran. The food is great, atmosphere great and staff friendly. Like their slogan says, they've been at it for "Thirty Shuckin' Years." If staying anywhere along Market Street in the downtown area, the Castro is an easy subway or surface trolley ride down Market Street. Anchor is about two blocks south of Market on Castro.
author: Tim H.

description:
Hands down the best seafood restaurant in the city!

Had my second year wedding anniversary dinner here, complete with champagne from Swirl across the street and a dozen oysters. 

The special board is where its at, and the dinner salad with shrimpies is big enough for two. You gotta walk through the kitchen to get to the bathroom, and every time, I can't resist snooping. The kitchen is super organized and best of all clean, clean, clean, not a spec of dust anywhere. The small dining area is tough, but its a lot of the charm. 

Its definitely a neighborhood place and now that honey and I are further away, I have to say its one of the places I miss the most. Cheers to 30 years of shucking!
author: Penny K.

description: If you want to get away from the hustle and bustle on 18th & Market Street or looking for a nice light seafood fare before or after a movie at the Castro theater, I'd recommend lunching at Anchor.  The crab Caesar salad is well crabbed and the dressing was just right - not too heavy  and not generic tasting.  The warm fresh bread croutons are well seasoned and flavor filled. You can also get a 1/2 order if you're not up for the full platter size. While there, I noticed that half the diners were indulging in the raw oysters.  So those must be pretty happening too.  Don't forget to check the daily board for specials like crab burgers, Manhattan clam chowder or a open face seafood sandwich!
author: Cynthia S.

description: In a neighborhood defined by mediocre cuisine, Anchor stand out!  I drop in for an oyster shooter whenever I'm in the Castro to buy cheap lube.
author: Major M.

description: So excellent.  It was delicious shellfish and good Sauvignon Blanc.  Would go there over any other restaurant near there for 10 blocks.  The Cioppinno was divine, too.  I did not have dessert and the place was too warm for comfort last night so I can't give it a perfect five.  Wait staff excellent.  The bread looked great but I can't eat wheat so it would be nice to have spelt or rice crackers offered as an alternative but that is future tripping.
author: River R.

description: The best seafood in the city!  I've been here countless times and it never ceases to wow me.  I came here this past weekend with a group of friends and ordered two dozen oysters on the half shell (half dozen each of the 4 offered that day).  We slurped those briny buggers down over some hearty laughs and good conversation.  Delicious!  I almost always order the cioppino when I come here and it always delivers!  It's very tomato-y which is what I love, and overflowing with mussels and clams and claws and fish!  The broth is very rich and savory savory and seasoned just right.  Take home whatever sauce is left over and have it over pasta the next day!  The seared scallops are one of my favorites, buttery and cooked just right, served with chunky mashed potatoes and steamed veggies.  The crab cakes are breaded and seared just enough and the big chunks of crab meat are lightly seasoned and very fresh.  There is always a long line outside which is a testament to how much people are willing to wait to eat here.  No doubt I'll be back many times over!
author: P.J. D.

description: Anchor is by and far the best seafood in the city and the best kept secret!  Although the restaurant is very small (4-5 tables & a bar) and you may occasionally have to wait for a seat, the great staff and food is well worth it!  Anchor is home to my favorite chef and is my favorite restaurant in the city.
author: Robert F.

description: Our favorite place in the city to eat out. Casual, great staff and food. We always order off the specials board, which changes daily. The fish is always the freshest. You can even buy fresh fish to cook at home. It's small, and we often eat at the counter. Sometimes there is a bit of a wait to get in, but it is well worth it.  A Castro landmark for over 30 years.
author: Paul S.

description: been going here for years.....always fabulous. Great tiny secert in the Castrro, we bring all out of towners here. This is the real deal if love seafood. The service is also top notch. No reservations so go early.
author: KEN B.

description:
It is hard to find good food in The Castro, but this is always a sure bet for good food, though you definitely pay for it. Expect to wait for seating at busy times.

Definitely the best seafood in the area (Catch is alright and the new place opposite Safeway should be avoided - at least until they 'get their groove'.
author: Wolf L.

description: One my favorite places in the city to enjoy amazing seafood, in a comfortable atmosphere.  I have yet to find fresher fish, oysters or crab in the city, and I love their clam chowder - pasta's are always changing and delicious.  Not cheap, but you can't get better quality food.  Fun, friendly and efficient servers add to the experience.  This place rocks!
author: Mike P.

description: Always worth the wait.  The food is so fresh and these are some of the best oysters I have had.  The place is very small, but it really adds to the charm!
author: Joshua B.

description:
I rate this place at around a 4, and my girlfriend rates this at around a 3. Since it is my review, I would say 3.5. The wait for this place was pretty short considering they have around a 25-30 person capacity, and there were 10 people waiting outside. The servers seated us quickly, but then abandoned us. They brought us the beginning bread and waters, and then we chatted for about 10 mins until we noticed that no one was coming to take our order. Two or three servers kept coming to our table to take or present things, so I never knew who to flag down for an order. Our crab cake appetizer was pretty good, but the wait between dishes was lonngggg. My shrimp and mussel dish was very good and hence the reason for my 4 stars, but my gf's fish was very heavy and the mashed potatoes were too buttery....She's not a heavy food kind of person. The whole meal contained enough starch and lipids that we decided to forgo the dessert(almost never happens). 

Pros: Awesome shrimp and mussel, good crab cakes, Fast Seating. 

Cons: Lonnnng server wait, pretty pricey, and mediocre fish with mashed potatoes. Over hyped.
author: Chris D.

description: AMAZING. Not much room in this tiny little restaurant but worth the wait.  With friends and tried all the dishes on the table - every single one a winner.  Simply divine.  Charming atmosphere . . . polite and efficient service.
author: kiyo r.

description: two stars seems to fall below the average here.  if it wasn't for the 30 minute wait that ended with two separate parties being seated prior to us (despite being told that we were the first ones there), i'd have given them more stars.  what got me the most was the fact that our names were on the board before these people, AND the server actually pointed to us and sat both parties anyway.  no apologies.  after telling myself that i need to let this go, i finally allowed myself to enjoy my boyfriend's company and the food.  the special was good.  i loved the miyagi oysters and i especially had a thing for the steamed clams.  sopping up that broth with the crusty bread was a good thing.  it would have been great had it not been for the preferential treatment.  the only reason why i would return is if my boyfriend really wanted to go.
author: sharon b.

description: I live near this restaurant but had not been there in a number of years.  Recently I have had occasion to go there twice and had a great time on both occasions.  The first time two friends and I had some oysters, beer and grilled fish.  The service is attentive but rather casual and the food was nicely prepared.  On the second visit -- during our recent heat wave - a friend and I had to wait outside while a table opened up.  A server brought us a couple of frosty Anchor Steams as we waited.  Once inside we made the wise decision to select the cold mixed fish salad -- an excellent mix of very fresh salmon, clams, muscles, lobster, calamari, crayfish and more.  The fish is fresh and creatively prepared.  I will be back soon!
author: J. O.

description: I love seafood and I appreciate friendly staff. the seafood here is very fresh and very delicious. I go for the oysters, obviously and what ever special they have to offer. It's small but I seem to fit with another guest. The manager is always present, which is a good sign and they have someone at the front HAND washing dishes which is a rare sight. I mean I am so anal and type A it's not even funny so when I see this I am confident that I am not eating or drinking......well you know. I appreciate that. I mention it for obvious reasons, but not only that, whomever is there doing the dish washing at the time looks like they are peaceful and serene in their own world. If that makes any sense. It's at their own pace and it gives me something to focus my eyes on while indulging in some damn good seafood. It's not a hustle an bustle sweat shop line. Everything flows here  and the staff work nicely together and even the customers are all good with one another. I like it a lot! PS: Don't cheat yourself and order at least 18 oysters per person,  if you don't you will be annoyed and feel cheated even though it's no one's fault but your own.
author: S. L.

description: if you are into oysters, old fashioned seafood stuffs like shrimp or crab louie sala d, etc. then its a must try place in SF, then afterward you can wander around the castro and be entertained by the GREAT SEX WITHOUT METH? advertisements on nearly every corner and bustop.
author: christopher a.

description:
oysters, wine, huge dishes and great company? i think..i'm in heaven..

always drove by this place but it always looks like a long wait. tonight was no different, we waited an HOUR..but it was well worth it. they serve you drinks outside on their cushioned couch, which helped me survive. once you were in, they take great care of you. 

we each got half a dozen oysters and shared the cioppino, trout and sea bass (which i wasnt too crazy about) + 1/2 liter of house wine.

came out to about 60/person (can you say freakin SPLURGE) but it was def. worth it!
author: joanna u.

description: Awesome oysters, clams and prawns!  I had the half order of the Anchor Special, which was awesome.  They gave me a variety of six different oysters from around the world, each with different texture and taste.  They flowed into my mouth like velvty, melted butter.  The prawns were amazing in the spicy cocktail sauce.  The clams in garlic base were out of this world.  I asked for more bread to soak up the goodness.  The bread was a meal in itself.  I combined that with a small salad, which was fresh and crispy.  The staff really were responsive to our every need and advised about what to select.  As we were finishing, the place started to get full with patrons and the ambiance of the restaurant got really too crowded and noisy.  Getting to the restroom is a bit tricky, especially when you have to dodge quick turning waiters, fast moving chefs and a bunches of patrons looking for a seat.  The bathroom was stupendously clean.  I'd definitely go back to try some of their specials, but I'd make sure to go early for dinner.  The place get uncomfortably crowded after about 7:30pm.
author: Neil F.

description: the crabcakes, the seafood salad, the oysters, the clam pasta...all good stuff. just don't let the wait staff forget about you.
author: selma s.

description: By far the best Caesar's Salad I have ever had.  I asked for a few extra anchovies, and the crunch of the wonderful croutons and super fresh 'just creamy enough' dressing and I was literally in heaven.  A generous portion at that.  This served with a 'real' bowl of New England clam chowder and all the fresh sourdough bread I needed......few things in life are better.....really.  Truly worth the wait if it is busy, just put your name on the list out front.  I have never been disappointed with a meal here.  Go.
author: chowder k.

description: Haven't visited for about 10 years so I was happy to see they still have great seafood.  The clam chowder is wonderful, and the array of oysters was very good.  A bit pricey, but worth it if you're fussy about your bivalves.  The only criticism with the place is they don't keep enough oysters on hand.  We arrived at 7pm, and they were already sold out of the big ones!! Drat.  Nice choice of a French Sancerre wine to accompany was very tasty, but a bit pricey too at $40.
author: Susan B.

description: one of the best sea food gems i have ever been too! no wonder they have made it 33 years. it is such a cute little find, and should stay small, that's makes them so fabulous!!! . even if you might have to wait the owners are often there cooking, greeting the customers. i had the pleasure meeting roseann and terry and they are genuine nice folks, they love what they do, and it shows... keep up the good work, and here's to another 33 more years.
author: chucky p.

description: Just went to this place for the second time - one of my favorite seafood places in SF.  The only reason I didn't give them 5 stars is that you have to be willing to wait a while (20-30 min cause the place is tiny), but it's totally worth waiting.  They also brought out some clam chowder for those of us waiting outside in the cold, so the wait wasn't that bad at all.  The seafood is super fresh and deliciously prepared - simple and bold flavors.  The restaurant is also very flexible if you have any dietary restrictions (i.e. if you're pregnant and can't eat certain seafood) - they made me a delicious pasta dish that was totally tailored just for me.  The hubby had some cioppino (tomato broth with lots of seafood) with crazy amounts of mussels, clams, fish, crab - it's definitely enough for 2 people, so I would recommend sharing as we took a lot of leftovers home (which were delicious on day 2).  The service is also great - super fast and very pleasant.  If you like a place with character & delicious seafood, this is definitely a place to checkout.
author: squirrel l.

description: By far the best restaurant in the Castro, and as far as I am concerned one of the best casual seafood places in the city! The service is outstanding and they went out of their way to accommodate my indecisiveness... offering to let me do 1/2 orders of the two entrees I was wavering between! The waiter said why not have it all! My thoughts exactly! The Chowder and Mussels are excellent. The special ravioli may be the best I have ever had!
author: C H.

description: OH YEA! This place is awesome and a half! The specials are always really great and well prepared. The staff here is very friendly and helpful. You just can't help but want to come back. Take my money and fill my tummy!
author: Jesse V.

description:
once

very good food and friendly service.

shrimp avacado salad - yammi
crab caesar salad - outstanding
oyster - depends on the season, might not always be the freshest.
author: Yi S.

description: good food all around! i think we had 2 rounds of all the oysters on the board. i'm a huge fan of eatting at the counter where ever i go, and there's the option for that here. friendly waiter and my good friends as company made for a great experience. and of course, you must pair your meal with a bottle of olivet lane chard or zandotti frascati. ;")
author: Alexia P.

description: for when you're craving oysters but don't want to wait for swan's - fast, attentive service - really clean, and delicious fresh seafood
author: Lisa M.

description: there is nothing showy about the food, and that is why it's so good.  this place only serves what seafood tastes like.
author: Chris D.

description: A great little local that's been there for 30 years.  It's now our date night spot.  Staff is friendly and the atmosphere is homey. We like the low-key bar seating, though that's obviously not for everyone. Food is fresh, straightforward and never disappoints.
author: KM D.

description: A friend took me to this place to eat oysters.  We got the Anchor Special with a dozen oysters (4 different kinds), steamed clams and chilled prawns.  The oysters were so fresh and delicious!  The texture, temperature, taste - ALL to my liking.  I know some places, their oysters are a little salty for some reason, but here, it was as if they had just picked them out of the ocean, shucked them and served them.  The steamed clams were also very good.  I think just steamed with a little pit of garlic and some other seasonings.  Not too overpowering - you could still taste the actual clam.  The chilled prawns weren't bad either.  We got crabcakes as well, which were also very good.  All in all, highly recommended.
author: Sam C.

description: I love this place.  I went there after having my hair cut at Notorious For Hair (a few doors down).  My stylist recommended it.  I went back there again today and I think I am addicted!  The seafood is really fresh, and even though the place is packed (sometimes you have to wait a few minutes for a table) and the food is not cheap, it is definitely worth every penny!
author: Kaydee M.

description: So yummy!  The Cioppino is awesome with just a hint of star anise.  The caesar salad with fresh crab is insane and the garlic bread is way too good.  Portions are huge so you can definitely share.  It's pretty tiny so get there early or be prepared to wait (totally worth it though).
author: Corina K.
